DOC.HEAD: Miami Edges Notre Dame in Final AP Football Poll
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CLARIFY that poll that began 21 years ago was postseason. A longer version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The University of Miami was voted national champion Tuesday in the second narrowest voting since The Associated Press began its postseason college football poll 21 years ago. Notre Dame coach Lou Holtz, whose team finished second, was one of those who had a better choice in mind. ``You can justify why Miami won it. What you can't justify is why we didn't,'' Holtz said a day after the Fighting Irish defeated previously unbeaten and top-ranked Colorado 21-6 in the Orange Bowl. ``We played the toughest schedule, we had the best record ... and we beat the No. 1 team quite decisively,'' Holtz said in an emotional statement likely to renew debate over a playoff system. Miami won its third national championship in the last six years by beating Alabama 33-25 in the Sugar Bowl on Monday night. The Hurricanes and Notre Dame each finished with one loss, but Miami beat the Irish 27-10 on Nov. 25. ``There is no doubt in my mind that we're the best team in the country,'' Miami coach Dennis Erickson said. ``It just happens that it came down to two teams with one loss, and we beat them.'' Miami (11-1) received 39 first-place votes and 1,474 points, with Notre Dame (12-1) getting 19 first-place votes and 1,452 points. The 22-point margin was the second closest since the AP began its postseason poll of sports writers and broadcasters in 1968. The other two first-place votes went to No. 3 Florida State, the only team to beat Miami this season. Colorado fell to No. 4. Miami also was chosen No. 1 in United Press International's coaches' poll, and by USA Today-CNN. Erickson said the close vote will increase calls for a playoff in college football. ``The debate is going to go on until there is one. I really believe down the road there will be a playoff system,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Dies Accidentally In Panama, Army Says
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. soldier in Panama died of an accidental gunshot wound on New Year's Day, the Army said Tuesday. The dead serviceman was identified as Specialist Douglas J. Duff of Company A, 1st Battalion, 9th Infantry Regiment, 7th Infantry Division, from Fort Ord, Calif. Maj. Joe Padilla, an Army spokesman, said he had no information on the circumstances of the accident. Duff, 20, of Elgin, Neb., entered the Army in August 1988, a few months after his high school graduation, said his mother, Shirrale Legate of Elgin. ``He loved it,'' she said.``He wanted to do something with his life before he was old enough to get into law enforcement.'' She said her son telephoned her Sunday morning from Panama and said he hoped to make it home as soon as he could. ``He sounded tired. His spirits were good,'' Mrs. Legate said. She said her son had planned to be home for the holidays, but his leave, scheduled to begin Dec. 21, was canceled when his unit was put on alert. Mrs. Legate said she had not been told the details of her son's death. Twenty-three U.S. servicemen, not including Duff, were killed in the Panama invasion.

DOC.HEAD: New Cabinet a Mix of Ceausescu Holdovers, Technocrats, Dissidents
With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Romania's interim Cabinet is a blend of technocrats, dissidents and holdovers from the leadership of Nicolae Ceausescu, some of whom ran afoul of the dictator who was ousted and executed. Some of the leading members: _ Prime Minister Petre Roman. Roman, 43, was a professor of engineering with no political experience. His father, Valter, was a member of the then-tiny Communist Party before World War II and signed up with the International Brigades in the Spanish Civil War. Petre Roman attended the prestigious Petru Groza Russian-language high school in Bucharest and was later permitted to study at the University of Toulouse in France. He is married to Mioara Georgescu, daughter of a former Romanian ambassador to Switzerland. _ Foreign Minister Sergiu Celac. Celac, a Bucharest intellectual, was Ceausescu's Russian interpreter in the mid-1980s but fell out of favor for his outspokenness. His sister, Mariana Celac, is married to a leading dissident, Mihai Botez. _ Minister of Defense Gen. Nicolae Militaru. He was a deputy defense minister in the early 1980s but was demoted for unclear reasons. _ Minister of Culture Andrei Plesu. Plesu, one of Romania's best-known dissidents, was an art critic. He was exiled from Bucharest to a village in Romanian Moldavia for signing a letter criticizing the state-run writers' union. _ Minister of the Interior Mihai Ghitac. An army general who was commander of the Bucharest garrison, Ghitac was a key figure in the revolution, siding with the demonstrators against Ceausescu's dreaded Securitate security forces. _ Deputy Minister of the Interior and head of the General Police Inspectorate Lt. Gen. Ion Jean Moldoveanu. _ Minister of the National Economy Lt. Gen. Anastase Victor Stanculescu. He had been a first deputy defense minister under Ceausescu. _ Minister of Agriculture and Food Industry Stefan Nicolae. Under Ceausescu, he was a deputy minister. _ Minister of Water and Forest Management Simion Hincu. _ Minister of Chemical and Petrochemical Industry Gheorghe Caranfil. He once held the same position but was most recently ambassador to East Germany under Ceausescu. _ Minister of Energy Adrian Georgescu. _ Deputy Prime Ministers Mihai Grganescu and Gelu Voican-Voiculescu. _ President of Romanian radio and television, Aurel Dragos Munteanu. Munteanu is a dissident writer who was fired as an editor at the Morning Star literary magazine for being critical of Ceausescu.

DOC.HEAD: About 50 Arrested in Violence at Hotel Party
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS in 4 grafs to UPDATE with N.C. disturbance and to DELETE INCORRECT reference to Atlanta hotel being on Peachtree Street; pickup 4th graf, ```You get ...'; ADDS xx grafs at end with details on N.C. disturbance; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A New Year's Eve party at a hotel turned violent as drunken revelers threw potted plants and fire extinguishers from upper floors into the lobby. At least 15 people were injured and about 50 arrested, police said. ``Noboby knows what started it. One minute it was fine and the next minute things were falling,'' said a police spokesman who would not give his name. In a Charlotte, N.C., hotel, meanwhile, hundreds of young people went on a New Year's rampage, tossing furniture and other debris from balconies and windows, authorities said. The melee destroyed so much of a hotel's fire-safety system that officials evacuated the building for the night, but no arrests or injuries were reported. In Atlanta, about 2,000 young people were partying in the 1,685-room hotel, police Sgt. R.J. Lynn said. ``You get the feeling these kids are spoiled, irresponsible,'' Lynn said. ``When you start tossing bottles off the 37th floor, you could kill somebody.'' Guests reported there were fights, they were hit with fire extinguisher blasts when they walked out of their rooms and they were trapped in elevators when people somehow managed to short-circuit them. ``They're tearing the place apart,'' Henry Hancock, a telephone operator at the Marriott, said early Monday. ``They're throwing chairs, shooting fire extinguishers, tearing up carpeting, throwing plants and chairs over the railing. This place looks like World War III.'' Hancock said the hotel offered a special New Year's Eve package deal and sold out its 1,685 rooms, but many of the younger revelers apparently brought friends into their rooms. Charges against those arrested in the melee at the 47-story hotel included reckless conduct, vandalism and assault. Most were between 17 and 21 years old. Paramedics said as many as 15 people were treated for injuries ranging from broken teeth to cuts on the head. One was knocked unconscious, apparently by a falling object. Brad Bosworth, a hotel manager, said eight people were hospitalized and one was treated for a seizure, which occurred in the hotel's bar and was unrelated to the violent partying in the atrium. Bosworth said hotel officials had barely begun to assess the damage Monday. The hotel's atrium was strewn with toilet paper, beer bottles and cans, overturned furniture and potted plants. On several levels of the atrium, garbage and pillows were tossed about. In Charlotte, N.C., the disturbance at a Howard Johnson hotel was ``almost a riot,'' Charlotte Fire Department battalion chief Arnold Mullis said Monday. ``There must have been somewhere around 1,500 teen-agers,'' he said. ``They were out every window and on the balconies. There were a couple of hundred of them in front of the building on the street. We had to move our vehicles back to avoid being hit by flying debris, beer bottles, beer cans.'' The youths threw hotel furniture from balconies and windows of the 11-story hotel, and some furniture landed in the swimming pool, authorities said. The teen-agers also unwound fire hoses, emptied all the fire extinguishers, pulled smoke detectors from walls and broke the fire alarm system, and fire officials decided to close the hotel until the fire protection system could be repaired. ``There is no way we could have possibly left those people in that hotel with no way to even report a fire,'' Mullis said. A hotel desk clerk who was on duty during the melee said he could not comment, and the hotel manager was not expected in the office until Tuesday. The duty captain at the Charlotte Police Department was out of his office early Tuesday morning, said a police official who answered the telephone there would not comment on the disturbance.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor Barry Eyes Fourth Term, Battles Image Problems
DOC.TEXT: Plagued by rumors of drug use and facing a possible challenge from Jesse Jackson, Washington Mayor Marion Barry is heading into an election season declaring he can still run the city and win a fourth term. ``I am going to manage the affairs of the city, and I'm not going to address these rumors and innuendoes,'' Barry declares. ``We've received a lot of support and when the time comes to start campaigning we will be there.'' Polls, however, chart declining support for the mayor, who was buffeted all year by personal and professional woes: _Longtime friend Charles Lewis pleaded guilty to cocaine conspiracy charges and later testified under oath that he supplied Barry with the drug. The mayor denies any drug involvement. _Barry gave reporters a brief look at his medical records after a television report that he had been hospitalized twice in 1983 for cocaine overdoses, rather than the hiatal hernia reported at the time. Several medical experts said the documents appeared incomplete. _Washington's homicide rate soared to new heights in 1989, with police blaming drugs for more than 60 percent of the slayings. Law enforcement costs are climbing and the city faces the prospect of a second consecutive multimillion-dollar deficit. Barry shrugs off his ties to Lewis. ``That doesn't bother me,'' he says. But the matter clearly has made his re-election campaign more challenging. Barry told top aides last week he has raised $250,000 for the September primary and November general election. He predicted he ultimately would raise $1 million, according to sources. But one of the chief challengers, District Council member John Ray, had raised nearly $250,000 by Sept. 1. And when Barry outlined his re-election plans, he told top advisors he expects financial contributions from them. It was the first time the mayor sought direct financial contributions from his staff, according to an aide who asked not to be named. The aide said Barry campaign strategists told him they ``will need every dime they can get and from every source possible.'' Jackson's recent move to Washington has fueled rumors that he will eventually enter the race for Barry's job. Jackson denies that he will run against Barry, who fought alongside him in the days of the civil rights movement. A number of polls have shown Barry slipping over the past 12 months, and a majority of those contacted in a recent survey by a television station said they thought the mayor should resign. Four other candidates are vying for the Democratic mayoral nomination, and since the city has no runoff procedure, the nominee could win with less than a majority of the electorate behind him. ``There's a very real chance he could be re-elected,'' said Max Berry, who ran Barry's 1986 campaign but has since soured on the mayor. ``His best bet is to have all these other people stay in the race. If he wins the primary, that could give him enough momentum for the general election.'' Normally, winning the Democratic primary is tantamount to being elected in Washington, where Republican voters are scarce. But former police chief Maurice Turner, spurred on by the Bush administration, is preparing to run as a Republican and holds out the prospect of appeal to black voters. Even if Jackson gets into the race or Turner mounts a serious campaign, however, no one expects Barry to crumble under the pressure. ``He is the consummate survivor,'' says Mark Plotkin, a political commentator and D.C. Statehood Party member. ``Nothing has happened to him yet, and he's like a soldier who asks, `War is hell? I haven't been wounded.'''

DOC.HEAD: Says Albania Will Not Go the Way of Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Albania's leader, Ramiz Alia, vowed in a New Year's message to his nation to stay its socialist course and resist the upheaval that has toppled Communist regimes throughout Eastern Europe this past year. Albania is Europe's last hard-line Communist state. ``The events that have occurred recently in Eastern Europe have inspired certain known anti-Albanian forces to resume the campaign of slanders against our country,'' Alia was quoted as saying by the official Ata news agency. ``But, as our people say, they cannot succeed in doing us harm,'' he was quoted as saying in Monday's address. The news agency was monitored in England by the British Broadcasting Corp. Alia appeared to be responding to a call by the pretender to the throne of Albania, Leka I, for his 3 million compatriots to rise up and overthrow the Communist government. Leka I, son of the self-styled King Zog I who ruled Albania from 1925 to 1939, urged an end to the ``tyrannical and atheist regime'' in a message Sunday from South Africa, where he lives. Alia said his country ``is a society of justice'' that ``experiences neither social conflicts nor national oppression.'' ``I am conscious that we have much to do in order to be transformed into a rich country,'' he said. ``But we are proud of being free and independent, as we are sure that our future will be better and more prosperous.'' Alia claimed that since 1939, when the invading Italian army ended King Zog's reign, every year in Albania had been more prosperous than the previous year: ``This year, priority will be attached to the improvement of the people's supply with food products and industrial and mass consumer goods as well.'' But, he added, this would require hard work and ``economic austerity measures are demanded everywhere.'' Albania, lying between Greece and Yugoslavia on the Adriatic Sea, is one of the most isolated countries in the world, with foreign visitors strictly limited and access to foreign broadcasts and books tightly controlled.

DOC.HEAD: Most Veterans Don't Take Advantage of Burial Benefit
DOC.TEXT: The Veterans' Affairs Department says too few people are taking advantage of its most lasting benefit _ free burial in a national cemetery _ while at the same time VA officials are planning for more space. One-third of the nation's 27 million living veterans don't know about the national cemeteries, a VA survey showed. ``They just sort of forget about things'' many years after military service, said Jo Ann K. Webb, national cemeteries director. She said the burial should be viewed as ``something they're giving back to you in perpetuity for your contribution.'' Nonetheless, the VA expects the number of burials to increase by the year 2010. But the private cemetery industry says it believes the VA is overestimating the number of future burials, and it suggests limiting eligibility for burial in national cemeteries. All veterans but those with dishonorable discharges may be buried in a national cemetery regardless of whether service was during war or peace. Also eligible are reserve, ROTC or National Guard members who died on active duty, surviving spouses who do not remarry, and unmarried minor children. The VA prepares the grave site, buries the dead, furnishes a headstone or marker and a flag for the casket, and provides perpetual care. ``They are truly shrines,'' Webb said. ``You get a real good feeling when you visit them.'' The VA does not, however, provide funeral arrangements, transportation or military honors. Grave sites cannot be reserved. Veterans who choose burial elsewhere may receive a headstone or grave marker from the VA. Veterans also may receive an American flag to cover their casket and a memorial certificate with the president's signature. The VA buries about 10 percent of all veterans, Webb said, and with the increasing age of the veterans' population, ``We are in a growth mode.'' The median age is 67.4 years for more than 9 million living U.S. veterans of World War II, while more than 100,000 surviving World War I veterans have a median age of more than 92 years. The number of VA burials has grown more than one-third since earlier in the 1980s and should exceed 60,000 in the year ending with September 1990. The VA estimates burials will grow to 80,000 in the year 2000 and peak a decade later. Close to 2 million people have been buried in veterans' cemeteries since Abraham Lincoln created the first 12 on or near Civil War battlefields. The number of cemeteries has grown to 113. The burial operation's budget has risen from $39 million in fiscal 1983 to $49 million this year, although actual funding is expected to be $1.6 million less due to federal budget cuts. A 1987 report by the VA said that in the next few decades, 36 national cemeteries will have to join 47 that limit internment to relatives of people already buried there. The same report identified 10 areas where the need for burial space would be greatest. Those are Chicago; the San Francisco area; Miami-Fort Lauderdale; Cleveland-Akron-Canton; Detroit; Pittsburgh; Dallas-Fort Worth; Seattle-Tacoma; Albany-Utica, N.Y.; and Oklahoma City-Lawton, Okla. But the American Cemetery Association estimates there is enough existing private space for new burials for the next century, executive vice president Stephen L. Morgan said. The veterans' population is starting to diminish, he said, and ``as you turn the corner the veterans' population goes down very quickly.'' Morgan said he would like to see VA limit eligibility, perhaps to combat-era veterans, and abide by the policy adopted in the 1970s of having one national cemetery for each of 10 federal regions. The American Legion says it opposes any such restrictions on grounds people would be unfairly excluded, and it has gone on record as supporting additional national cemeteries ``as needed.'' The Veterans of Foreign Wars also opposes restrictions, and supports having a national cemetery in each state.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Trip to Lithuania Raises Questions of Military Intervention
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's upcoming visit to restive Lithuania should provide new clues on the limits to use of military force by large powers _ an issue lingering from the U.S. invasion of Panama and the revolution in Romania. The question is how much a superpower _ in this case the Soviet Union _ will allow its perceived security interests to be jeopardized in the interests of allowing a small nation to determine its own fate. Or more specifically, whether Gorbachev will escalate from words to arms to persuade Lithuania, a Soviet republic, to remain in the Soviet Union. Using military force in Lithuania, or its sister Baltic republics of Latvia and Estonia, would jeopardize Soviet relations with Washington, and President Bush told Gorbachev so at the Malta summit on Dec. 2-3, U.S. officials say. Administration officials are not saying what steps they might take if Gorbachev intervened in the Baltic republics. But at Malta, Bush promised to open talks on a trade treaty as a step toward conferring commercial favors on Moscow, scheduled a summit meeting in late July with Gorbachev, and has said work could be completed soon on treaties to cut nuclear, conventional and chemical arms. All that could be in trouble if things go badly for Gorbachev in Lithuania. No date has been announced for the Soviet leader's Lithuanian trip, which is expected early this year. At the State Department, one official said, ``Our people will be looking very carefully at the Gorbachev mission to Lithuania to see how successful he is ... and what the prospects are for that republic.'' Questions concerning the use of military force, however, were clouded by the U.S. invasion of Panama. Gorbachev encouraged peaceful reforms among his Eastern European allies, Poland, East Germany, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, and he refrained from intervening when the tides of change became bloody in Romania. As the fighting heightened in Romania, the United States invaded Panama with the stated purpose of replacing strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega with a democratic government. ``The difference is that the Soviet Union supports democracy by staying out of countries and thus permitting democracy to proceed,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III told reporters on Dec. 20. ``In this one and very unique instance, the United States did it by going in to assist a democratically elected government against a dictator,'' Baker said. The United States has never recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia during World War II, and Bush told Gorbachev at Malta the United States would object to armed Soviet interference with peaceful democratic and independence movements in the Baltics. In Malta, Gorbachev told Bush ``he did not intend to use military force to resolve the situation in the Baltics,'' said an administration source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Gorbachev also repeated his renunciation of the doctrine that past Kremlin leaders had invoked to justify the use of force to crush reform movements in Eastern European nations. Last week, he underscored his unwillingness to intervene militarily in Eastern Europe as violent revolution swept Romania, climaxing in the execution of Nicolae Ceausescu, who had ruled there for 24 years. The Lithuanian Communist Party announced on Dec. 20 that it was breaking with the main Soviet party, becoming the first republic-level organization to do so since the Civil War of the 1920s. Lithuanian communists have endorsed calls by the popular front there to secede from the Soviet Union, a right which is guaranteed by the Soviet constitution but which Gorbachev says would endanger the Soviet Union as a whole. A Lithuanian secession would prompt Latvia and Estonia, and possibly other republics, to follow suit. ``Today, to realize the right to self-determination through secession means to blow up the union, to set the people against each other and to sow conflict and blood and death,'' Gorbachev said in a speech on Dec. 23. Gorbachev appears to be drawing the line between reforms in Eastern Europe and reforms in the Soviet Union. Bush and Baker have applauded Gorbachev's reform efforts, and say they want him to succeed. Baker, moreover, has told Soviet officials that ``the United States would recognize the need of the Soviet Union to use force to restore and maintain order.'' Clearly, however, that approval would not countenance armed intervention in what so far has been a peaceful movement in Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia.
Bryan Brumley, a former Associated Press correspondent in Moscow and Warsaw, writes on national security issues from Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Fishing is Serious Business for Vacationing President
DOC.TEXT: Fishing is serious business for President Bush, so it was no laughing matter on New Year's Day when wife Barbara reeled in a bass and called out across the choppy waters of Cloverhill Lake, ``George, what's the matter with you?'' Bush, whose fishless skein in Kennebunkport, Maine, made headlines during the dog days last summer, actually had reeled in a little 1-pound bass not long after he and Barbara set out in separate boats on Monday. But her taunt did not go unchallenged. ``That's a cute little one Barbara got, a nice little fellow. Ahhh, a sweet little fish. Nice going. That's wonderful, darling,'' said the president, laying it on thick in his best Cary Grant imitation. ``That's wonderful. I'm so proud of her.'' The first lady, taking the bait, fired back as Audrey Hepburn might, ``So jealous!'' Did George want a picture of this trophy, she asked. ``Nobody wants to take a picture of a little minnow,'' shot back her partner in this comedy played out on a frigid lake for the benefit of the White House press corps. ``Would you like to hold it?'' she fired back. The first lady got the last laugh. At day's end, the Bush party _ including national security adviser Brent Scowcroft in a third boat _ had tallied 50 fish, with Mrs. Bush landing the biggest: a nearly six-pound bass. Bush's best was five pounds. ``They had a friendly argument about it, but clearly she won out,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater.

During the last administration, former President Reagan and his wife Nancy spent every New Year's Eve ensconced in the privacy and luxury of a black-tie party at the palatial Rancho Mirage, Calif., estate of Walter Annenberg. The Bushes did New Year's Eve their way: alone and tucked away in bed at their suite at the Houstonian in their adopted hometown after a takeout Chinese dinner by candlelight. ``We stayed up 'til 9:30 _ that's Central Standard (time),'' said the president, who got up before dawn as usual on the first day of the new year and the last day of his Christmas vacation. Mrs. Bush said they ate by candlelight ``only because someone gave (the candles) to us.'' There was also chilled champagne in the presidential suite, but they never popped the cork. ``We were the earliest people in bed in America, I think,'' the first lady told reporters. ``I haven't seen midnight in (on New Year's Eve) for 40 years.''

Bush said when he arrived in Corpus Christi Wednesday for his annual post-Christmas hunting trip to South Texas that he had worked ``pretty hard all year long'' and intended to enjoy this vacation. He did, from the hunt for quail on his friend and financial adviser Will Farish's Lazy F Ranch to shaking virtually everyone's hand at a barbecue dinner for 800 in Beeville to 36 holes of winter golf at the Houston Country Club. He got in his last round in the chill of a Sunday afternoon with temperatures in the mid-40s and barely another soul on the course except him, Scowcroft and Houston oilman John Ashmun. They finished as darkness fell. Putting is Bush's nemesis and it was no different Sunday on the 18th hole when he pushed a long birdie putt three feet beyond the hole. Holding his elongated putter up to his chest, the president chided the photographers in his media gallery to be still. ``I can't do it with the flicking of the cameras. It makes me very nervous, very nervous indeed,'' he admonished them. Then, talking out loud to himself, he lined the putt up anew, saying, ``Last putt of the year. It's an omen for next year.'' A stroke, and the ball inched past the hole. Bush bellowed out a pained ``OWWWWW!'' ``It's an omen,'' a reporter reminded him. ``On putting,'' said the president.

Before touring two military hospitals in San Antonio to visit U.S. servicemen wounded in Panama, the Bushes attended a worship service on Sunday at a chapel on Kelly Air Force Base. Chaplain Bobby Thornton told the worshippers that he had written his sermon ``two weeks ago,'' well in advance of learning that he would be preaching to the president. Thornton said he told friends he had no intentions of changing the sermon just because Bush would be there. But, as it turned out, ``I did change the sermon,'' he said, addressing Bush directly. ``I didn't do it for you, Mr. President. I did it for all these colonels sitting here.'' He said that, for one thing, he cut its length in half. That may have suited the array of colonels, but one former general dozed through most of the sermon. National security adviser Scowcroft later sheepishly admitted he had trouble staying awake.

DOC.HEAD: Milk Prices May Hold Steady in 1990
DOC.TEXT: The nation's dairy cows are headed for better times in 1990, and so are consumers, says the Agriculture Department. Food analyst Ralph Parlett of the department's Economic Research Service says the retail prices of dairy products _ mostly milk, cheese, butter and non-fat dry milk _ may hold about steady or, if there is an increase, might average only 1 percent to 2 percent above last year. That would compare with a 5.7 percent increase, overall, in the price of dairy products in 1989, the sharpest jump in years. In 1988 and 1987, for example, annual increases were held to about 2.5 percent. Parlett says much of the 1989 increase can be blamed on milk production declines caused by the poor quality of forage available for cows, a carryover from the 1988 drought. Also, there was a surge in demand for cheese at a time when inventories were low, and export demand increased for non-fat dry milk. Economist James J. Miller, writing in the USDA agency's January issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, said the biggest change for dairy in 1990 ``is simply a return to more normal conditions'' from last year's situation. ``Although the price declines from late 1989 will be dramatic, 1990 prices still will be higher than projections made a year or two ago,'' he said. Miller said the fundamentals of the 1989 dairy market were not much different from what they were in 1988. ``But the particular sequence of industry decisions and events in 1989 turned what might have been only a moderately tight market into a chaotic one with record prices,'' he said. Miller said 1989 dairy prices would have been lower if: _Cheese makers had been more aggressive about rebuilding inventory stocks in early 1989. _Non-fat dry milk producers had been less aggressive about export commitments. _Users had been more concerned about supplies, or milk production had weakened earlier than it did. Miller said commercial use of non-fat dry milk in 1989 was very strong, mostly because of the big exports, some 350 million to 400 million pounds. After prices declined in the first quarter of last year, exporters obtained ``extremely large'' commitments for the remainder of 1989. ``These export commitments, along with low commercial stocks of American cheese, made the dairy industry unusually vulnerable to any slowing in milk production,'' Miller said. ``Commercial use of non-fat dry milk in 1990 will be smaller because of declining exports.'' Commercial use of cheese through September was up 5 percent from the same period in 1988, he said. Although retail cheese prices were not as high as in recent years, continued economic growth and an end to USDA direct donations boosted commercial use, Miller said. Cheese use later in 1989 probably did not increase much because of sharply rising prices. Sales of fluid milk in 1989 was up 1 percent to 2 percent from 1988, he said. However, sales of frozen products and cottage cheese declined. And commercial use of butter dropped sharply in the first half of 1989, although sales may have recovered in the second half. Miller said milk production in the early part of 1989 was up 2 percent from a year earlier, in spite of the pressures of high feed costs resulting from the 1988 drought. ``However, milk per cow collapsed during the spring, as supplies of dairy quality forage were exhausted and hay crops were delayed by cool weather,'' he said. ``Output per cow has been below a year earlier since July, evidence of substantial damage from feed problems.'' The dips in milk output per cow and continued high culling rates kept the lid on total milk production after midyear, although ``very high milk prices and slipping feed prices created ample incentive to expand output'' last fall, Miller said. Thus, total 1989 milk production may have been just slightly under the record of 145.5 billion pounds of 1988. ``Forage quality and the extent of the mid-1989 damage to cow productivity remain key uncertainties for early 1990 production,'' Miller said. But if ``current incentives'' can stimulate production, milk output in 1990 may increase 1 percent to 3 percent from last year. ``Feed grain and protein meal prices in 1990 will be lower,'' he said. ``During the first half of 1990, however, milk prices will fall faster than feed prices. The now-favorable milk-feed price ratio and returns over concentrate (feed) costs will be substantially eroded by spring.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Striving To Count the Homeless for 1990 Census
LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: When the federal government took its last census in 1980, it never counted Brian Upshur, who was then 21 years old, homeless and staying in a rescue mission. ``I knew about the census,'' said Upshur, now head of food service at the Los Angeles Mission. ``But the census was always something you didn't want to be involved in. The attitude was the government was trying to keep tabs on you.'' In the 1990 head count, the Census Bureau will try to do a better job finding, gaining the trust of and counting homeless people _ one of the biggest groups missed by the last census, along with blacks and recent immigrants. The government plans to take steps like sending officials to parks and alleys where homeless people sleep and hiring the homeless themselves as census takers. Los Angeles and other cities sued the government to implement many of the new procedures because of what all agree was an undercount in 1980. The Census Bureau's own estimates are that the government missed 4.6 percent of Los Angeles residents in the last census. An accurate count is important because census data determines, among other things, federal funding for city and private programs and the number of elected representatives in Congress and the state Legislature. But despite a massive effort by the Census Bureau and the city, the homeless _ among the people who could most benefit by the government dollars and political representation that comes from the census _ will do their best to avoid being counted. Just finding many people will be a chore in Los Angeles' seedy and dangerous Skid Row area and lesser-known neighborhoods frequented by the homeless. Gaining their trust long enough to fill out a census form or answer questions will be a battle. ``Ultimately, the best we can hope to get is a guesstimate,'' said Cedric Hinson, a counselor at the Los Angeles Mission. ``I don't think we can presume that these things are going to be accurate.'' The city plans to open its emergency shelters, usually open only in bad weather, on March 18 so the homeless will be available for counting. City officials also are working with homeless shelters, church groups and community activists to develop ways to get the word out about the census and to draw up a list of the likely spots census takers will find homeless people. The Census Bureau will use the city's list of places to find homeless people as a road map when census takers hit the streets of Los Angeles March 20 and 21. On the first night of homeless counting, the Census Bureau will send people _ some of them homeless _ to organized shelters such as rescue missions and churches. The second night will be a bigger challenge. Starting at 2 a.m., unarmed and unguarded teams of census workers will search parks, streets and sidewalks for homeless people. Census takers also will stand outside abandoned buildings, asking people who come out how many homeless people are inside. ``If a guy is asleep in a cardboard box, then we'll just get a count, his race, estimate his age and move on,'' said John Reeder, regional director of the Census Bureau. The bureau purposely is shunning police escorts so the homeless won't be frightened away, Reeder said. But even the government's best efforts don't guarantee a complete count. Upshur said that although homeless people are talking about the census this year, especially because the government has offered temporary jobs to them as census takers, interest is low. ``You're not going to get a high level of cooperation,'' Upshur said. ``It tends to be a bit scary for a lot of people.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Marshall cq as girl's name in 3rd item.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor, who had predicted an outpouring of love and enthusiasm for her appearance in the Tournament of Roses Parade, appeared startled when she was greeted with Bronx cheers. ``Go to jail, you floozy,'' some spectators on Monday screamed when she rode by on her Tennessee walking horse, Silver Fox. The 72-year-old Hungarian-born actress was convicted last year and sentenced to three days in jail, fined and ordered to perform community service for slapping a Beverly Hills policeman who stopped her Rolls-Royce. She is appealing the conviction. She expected a different reaction from parade-goers. ``They'll love me, you'll be surprised,'' Miss Gabor said Sunday. ``I got 10,000 cards from people who said I was right.'' Miss Gabor did concede that the publicity about the trial caused her to have ``third and fourth thoughts'' about riding in the parade. ``I was afraid someone might boo (and scare) my horse. He's untouchable. If anyone boos, I'd boo back,'' Miss Gabor said. But no one saw her boo back. Her face was flushed and she seemed taken aback by the spectators' reactions.

World Wrestling Federation champ Hulk Hogan, 307 pounds, squares off against comedian Richard Belzer, 150 pounds dripping wet, in a $5 million lawsuit scheduled to go to trial today. The opponents meet in Manhattan state Supreme Court, the state's trial-level court, in a rematch of their March 27, 1985, fracas on a cable television show with Belzer as host. Jury selection was to start today. Belzer was rendered unconscious in that get-together and took nine stitches in his head. He then sued the Hulkster, tag-team partner Mr. T, World Wrestling Federation impresario Vince McMahon, and McMahon's Titan Sports, Inc. ``We see the suit as a publicity ploy, pure and simple,'' said WWF attorney Ted Dinsmoor. ``He asked the Hulkster to demonstrate a wrestling move, and he was accidentally injured.'' The comedian is expected to testify. Norman Roy Grutman, Belzer's attorney, has challenged Hogan and Mr. T to do the same, although Dinsmoor said it is unlikely either will appear. ``I am flinging down the gauntlet. If they don't show up in the ring of the courtroom, they are cowards,'' Grutman said.

First Lady Barbara Bush voiced delight over the addition of a grandchild to the presidential family. ``Great news,'' she said Monday, revealing that her son Marvin and his wife, Margaret, had just adopted a 2-month-old boy, Charles Walker Bush. The couple also has an adopted daughter, Marshall, 3. The Bushes now have a dozen grandchildren, five boys and seven girls. ``There's something exciting, we heard about the baby the day our brother-in-law died. There's something nice about that, isn't there? Sort of magical,'' Mrs. Bush told reporters en route to Alabama from Houston. ``I cried from happiness and sadness all day.'' Alexander Ellis II, husband of Bush's sister Nancy Ellis, died Friday of a stroke at age 67. The Bushes will attend his funeral in a Boston suburb on Tuesday.

Stand-up comedian George Lopez, who plays up his ethnic roots in his act, is dismayed by the lack of comedy roles for Hispanics. The 28-year-old comic, who plays a ski patrolman in the upcoming movie, ``Ski Patrol,'' said in a recent interview that Hispanics ``are being totally left out'' of television sitcoms. ``When you look ethnic it's that much harder,'' he said. ``Everyone is thin and Caucasian and I don't look like that. ... I'd like to play a professional, an attorney, a guy who just works for a living, a `thirtysomething'-type character.'' He steers clear of ethnic stereotypes in movie and television roles. ``In sitcoms, there's no one Hispanic, and I don't think that's right. When the first sitcom comes down that doesn't have 12 people in the family and there's not a rooster in the living room, then I'm sure writers will go back to the typewriters and say, `Oh, that's how you're supposed to do it!'''

DOC.HEAD: Government Begins Tackling Law Changes to Win People's Trust
DOC.TEXT: The revolutionary government began tackling the most hated legacies of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu by abolishing the death penalty, disbanding the secret police and legalizing private property. Bucharest was quiet on Monday, with no reports of sniper fire or clashes between the army and die-hard Securitate secret police units. Hundreds of its agents were still believed armed and at large. Crowds dressed in black gathered on the capital's central Romana Square to light candles for relatives and friends who died in the two-weeks popular revolt that claimed thousands of lives as it brought down the Ceausescu regime. As the country celebrated its first non-Communist New Year's Day in more than four decades, interim President Ion Iliescu announced major governmental changes in a broadcast address to the country's 23 million people. Iliescu renewed promises of multiparty democracy _ with free elections in April _ and said he hoped 1990 will ``mark a genuine leap in Romania's and the Romanian people's lives.'' In the speech, carried by the Romanian news agency Agerpres, Iliescu said the abolition of the death penalty ``underscored the popular and humanist character of the revolution.'' Referring to Ceausescu and his wife Elena, who had been the country's No. 2 leader, Iliescu said, ``the two dictators were the last persons`that deserved this fate.'' Ceausescu's 24-year despotic reign ended Dec. 22, and on Christmas Day he and his wife were summarily tried and executed on charges of ``genocide'' and other grave crimes. The government kicked off legislative changes with a decree guaranteeing the right to repatriation of Romanian citizens living abroad and allowing former Romanians to regain citizenship on reentry to the country, Agerpres reported. Agerpres said exiles would have priority in buying housing with hard currency and could repatriate goods bought abroad without paying duties. Other changes announced by Iliescu included the re-establishment of private property, with farmers now permitted to buy, sell and lease land and trade their produce privately. Iliescu, a former Communist who fell from favor for openly speaking his mind, also said work would stop on Romania's many ``opulent and wasteful construction projects,'' undertaken by Ceausescu that cost billions of dollars despite widespread poverty at home. The interim president also disclosed agriculture production figures that showed last year's cereal production amounted to 16.9 tons, way below Ceausescu's 60-million-ton claim. To pay off the country's foreign debt, Ceausescu had in recent years exported Romania's best agricultural products while forcing rationing upon his people. The new government is now opening up food warehouses to the people and is increasing energy allotments to permit warmer homes. In a further apparent attempt to lay open Ceausescu's former personality cult to scrutiny, Tourism Minister Maj. Mihai Lupoi said Monday that he was considering opening the late dictator's villa and its labyrinth of secret tunnels to tourists. ``It will be a good lesson in history for people to see what happens when dictatorship comes to a country,'' Lupoi told a news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Three Sisters Have Four Babies in 12 Hours
DOC.TEXT: When Ron Thompson sat down for lunch on New Year's Eve, he was the grandfather of five. At breakfast Monday, he was a grandfather of nine. Three of Thompson's daughters _ Mary Tolson, Joan Thompson and Carol Thompson _ gave birth to four boys at Seton Medical Center late Sunday and early Monday. When Ms. Tolson went into labor Sunday, she asked her 19-year-old sister Joan, who was in the ninth month of her pregnancy, to drive her to the hospital. After about five hours, Ms. Tolson, 28, gave birth at 2:40 p.m. to Shane Taylor Tolson, who weighed 7 pounds 9 ounces. At Ms. Tolson's delivery, Dr. Chris Seeker said Joan told him, ``You will probably be seeing me, too.'' Sure enough, seven hours later Joan was hustled to Seton by sister Carol. Joan gave birth to Jeremy Andrew Thompson Armendariz at 12:01 a.m. He weighed 6 pounds 10 ounces. Carol, 24, then went into labor and gave birth to twin boys just before 3 a.m. The mothers and four boys spent New Year's Day in good condition. ``This beats partying,'' Joan said. ``At least I have a (sense of) relief and not a headache.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Prime Minister Grounded
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi must have wished he were back at the controls today _ at least in the cockpit of an Indian Airlines jet if not at the head of government. Gandhi, a pilot for India's chief domestic airline before entering politics, had to change his schedule for a trip to the southern Indian city of Cochin when Indian Airlines canceled a flight from New Delhi to Bombay, United News of India reported. As prime minister, Gandhi had his own airplane. But when his Congress Party failed to win a majority in November elections, Gandhi became the opposition leader in Parliament and now has to book seats on commercial flights. Indian Airlines is known for its chronic delays and cancellations, and the problem has been compounded by heavy fog blanketing the capital for the past week. United News said Gandhi, who had planned to arrive in Cochin this morning on a connecting flight from Bombay, hoped to reach the city on a direct flight from New Delhi late this afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Theft A Fact Of Life In El Paso
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper publishes weekly car theft reports, rental agencies warn customers there's a good chance their vehicles will be stolen, and dealers make pitches for anti-theft devices as they sell new cars. These are among the precautions being taken in El Paso, where car thefts have increased 94 percent during the past two years. ``It has gotten so bad that we go to the stores and my husband _ he used to walk around the shops with me _ now when we go shopping he stands by the window and watches the car,'' said Mary Vallez, who had a 7-month-old car stolen from her driveway before dawn one day in 1979. Organized auto thieves make nocturnal sweeps of the city with ``shopping lists'' of the cars they want _ most often American-made models such as Fords or Chevrolets for which parts are available across the border in Mexico. ``When we arrest a suspect, they have told us that for that night they have a list of the types of cars to steal. Two of these, one of these,'' said Police Chief John Scagno. To find out what models are most popular with thieves in a given week, and how many cars are stolen from a certain neighborhood, residents can check a graphic printed each week in the El Paso Times. Through the first 11 months of 1989, 4,861 cars, trucks and other vehicles were stolen in El Paso, said Lt. Arturo Flores of the police auto theft division. That's a 10 percent increase over last year, on top of an 84 percent leap in the number of car thefts from 1987 to 1988, Flores said. El Paso lost 986 vehicles per 100,000 population, compared with a national average for major urban areas of 713, Flores said. The per capita car theft rate is higher in nine other Texas cities _ Dallas had the worst rate with 2,393 vehicles stolen for every 100,000 residents in 1988, according to the Texas Association of Vehicle Theft Investigators. But theft victims in El Paso are less likely than residents of other areas to recover their stolen cars, primarily because they disappear over the border, police said. ``Our recovery rate is terrible. That's what makes our vehicle thefts unique,'' Scagno said. ``Ten minutes more or less after the car is stolen it's in another country. It's crossing the border before its owners even know it's stolen.'' El Paso police recover half of stolen vehicles, compared with about 90 percent nationally. About 60 percent to 70 percent of those recovered are found in Mexico, Flores said. Many are found as far away as Mexico City. Several suspected thieves are juveniles hired by organized rings across the border, Flores said. One 17-year-old suspect told police he was paid $500 to $700 per stolen vehicle. The increasing rate of thefts in El Paso has residents on edge. ``We're like a big town with small-town insights, so when you say 100 cars a week have been stolen, that's startling,'' said Len Schermer, owner of Accessory Choice, a car accessories business that sells anti-theft devices. He said his sales of security devices such as steering-wheel locks, flashing lights, alarm systems and automatic engine shut-offs are up 70 percent over last year and now make up 20 percent of his business. Residents and city officials are fighting the thefts on several fronts, but so far results have been mixed. At least 300 vehicles have been registered in a new program in which owners paste stickers on a car that allow police to stop it without cause and question the driver. The program is called B.A.T. for ``Beat Auto Theft.'' Police set up temporary checkpoints at the border to try and catch stolen vehicles going into Mexico. Although thefts went down during those periods, they shot back up when the checkpoints were dismantled because they caused traffic jams. And another police crackdown on auto thefts in June apparently made little impression on thieves. They stole a pickup truck belonging to a deputy police chief who was leading the crackdown.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Wedding bells competed with jackpot bells at a casino here New Year's Eve. Phil Simpson, 31, and Sue Mason, 34, exchanged vows in a pit area at the Red Lion Inn & Casino. It was the second marriage for both. Red Lion manager Hugh Worden said he suggested the idea for the unusual wedding site because Simpson is the casino's games manager. He said the bride was reluctant at first to get married while encircled by blackjack tables, but decided to go along with the idea since it's where her new husband spends most of his time. Worden suspended action at ``21'' tables for 15 minutes to accommodate the ceremony. The bride entered to a traditional wedding march and tossed a bouquet into the middle of the casino after the ceremony. Patrons at the north-central Nevada casino were surprised at first but joined in the spirit of it, Worden said. ``We thought we'd have some negative comments about stopping the games, but everybody was in favor of it,'' Worden said. ``People even stopped playing the slot machines voluntarily and almost everybody in the casino was watching it. ``I always wondered what it would take to get a person away from a slot machine and now I know.''

If Monsignor Arthur Tonne has his way, clergymen may soon be giving comedian Jay Leno a run for his money. ``A lot of priests can't tell jokes,'' Tonne says. ``A lot of Protestant ministers can't, either. In fact, they probably even have a higher percentage who can't. Too many clergymen tend to be so serious about things, they just can't do it.'' As the author of seven volumes of ``Jokes Priests Can Tell,'' Tonne, 85, has a talent for keeping his followers laughing. Tonne said he goes to great lengths to make sure his humor is respectful. He uses the occasional ethnic jokes, but only after they've been approved by representative members of the targeted group. He doesn't like sexual jokes, but admits that ``You do remember the darned things.''

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Coal Strike Accord Headed for Rank and File
LaserPhoto WX7, NY8
DOC.TEXT: Striking coal miners welcomed a tentative settlement of their bitter 9-month walkout at The Pittston Co., but promised to keep the picket lines up until they've had a chance to vote on the pact. ``Nobody's celebrating yet,'' said Leo Carden, a union strike captain in McAndrews, Ky., after leaders of the United Mine Workers and Pittston announced the agreement Monday in Washington, D.C. If ratified by the company's 1,700 workers, the agreement would end a sometimes-violent strike that spread far beyond one small company, at one point triggering wildcat sympathy strikes by 46,000 miners in 10 states. Details of the tentative accord between Pittston and the United Mine Workers were kept secret until the union could explain the deal to its members in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. They will vote on the pact in the next eight to 10 days, said union president Richard Trumka. Trumka and Pittston Chairman Paul Douglas praised the agreement that emerged from marathon holiday bargaining sessions under the guidance of a federal mediator. But some idled miners reserved judgment until they see the details, including provisions on the sensitive issues of health and retirement benefits. Several union leaders said miners would keep walking picket lines. ``I noticed they used the word `tentative' when they announced the agreement,'' said Howard Green, a UMW international board member from the union's District 17 based in Charleston. ``They will stay on the picket line unless notified otherwise.'' ``As far as (picketing) goes, we're taking it as just another day,'' said Roger Nelson, a strike coordinator in West Virginia. The principal issue in the strike that began April 5 was Pittston's attempt to end its contributions to the UMW's industry-wide retirement fund. Pittston's coal subsidiary, Pittston Coal Group Inc., said it couldn't afford to continue payments to the fund, which covers 130,000 pensioners who retired between 1947 and 1976. Pittston has just 560 retirees covered by the fund. The union, in the most recent stand made public, insisted on continued contributions to the fund, fearing that if Pittston quit paying, it would lead to wholesale departures by coal companies. At a Washington news conference with the mediator, former Labor Secretary W.J. Usery, Trumka predicted the pact would heal the strike's wounds: ``We can continue to try to scratch each other's eyes out or we can accept a relationship where we can grow together.'' Pittston's Douglas added, ``We think we've met the essential objections of all those concerned.'' The strike was marked by mammoth labor rallies, vandalism and rock-throwing confrontations between strikers and other company employees. The union faces fines totaling $63.5 million for violating court orders limiting picketing and other strike activities. After the settlement was announced, miners who been getting by on $200 a week from the union strike fund gathered at a union hall in Castlewood, Va., cried quietly and hugged each other. ``This started out as a strike and ended up as a labor movement,'' said Virginia miner Jack Bartee. At the Slab Fork Mine near Logan, W.Va., Monday night was like many others during the strike, despite the announcement from Washington. A handful of miners warmed themselves over homemade stove built from the rims of coal truck tires. Music blared from a portable radio as they played cards and drifted in and out of the picket shack. ``There are a lot of ifs and ands and buts in the contract,'' said Terry Collins, a miner from Chapmanville, W.Va. ``If it's not what we want, we're willing to stay out for another nine months.''

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Tradition May Fade Into History
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: It's an Old World market with a New World neighbor, and the regulars are worried about its survival. Maxwell Street _ where raggedy peddlers have hawked their gadgets for more than a century _ likely will take its final bow in the 1990s, city planners say, the victim of blight and an ambitious university looking to expand its campus. The market takes up several square blocks about two miles southwest of the city's expanding downtown. Most days, it includes some 100 stores as diverse as Homer's outdoor sock stand and Nate's Delicatessen. ``Good buys in here, dolly,'' one merchant said on a recent weekday as he beckoned customers in to sample his wares. Every Sunday morning, the number of merchants balloons as vendors set up shop on the sidewalk, out of pushcarts or on the backs of pickup trucks. Bargain hunters flock to the seedy out-of-the-way outdoor bazaar, which started in 1870. The market's legendary melting pot still boils. Jewish merchants work side by side with blacks, Koreans and Pakistanis. Mr. Lee's Restaurant (``Chop Suey Breakfast Delivery'') stands a short distance from Slotkowski Polish Pork Chops. But the street, always grimy, has gotten grimier in recent years. Now its gleaming neighbor, the University of Illinois at Chicago, says it is time the market moved on _ if only a small distance _ so the school can expand by right of eminent domain. ``To say that Maxwell Street is the icon that it was is flying in the face of reality,'' university spokesman Dennis Church said. ``It's nothing now. It's Sunday morning, hang your product on the fence or search for a tire on the pile. ... It's not the market of its rich past _ it's a sinkhole now.'' The university's student body has grown by several thousand to 25,000 in the past five years. School officials want to build a new library and other facilities on a 31-acre tract that encompasses the market, Church said. Much of the property, including some vacant land, already belongs to the city. Recently, the city's Commercial District Development Commission re-designated the area from commercial to institutional to let the university buy land from the city, said commission Chairman Fidel Lopez. The city's Planning Commission and City Council still must OK the proposal. Lopez and Church agree that the market in some form must be allowed to continue. Both also agree its future lies somewhere beyond its current boundaries, perhaps just across the street from where it is now. But merchants and residents interviewed recently said they like it as it is. Most don't want to be relocated. ``They say they're going to replace us here, replace us there. I don't want to be replaced,'' said delicatessen owner Nate Duncan. A merchants' organization has been formed to fight relocation and some grass-roots activists loosely associated with the Greens ecological movement have taken up residence to organize the market's motley population. ``The merchants are notoriously jealous of each other ... but now it's a matter of survival,'' said Mike Metz, owner of Kelly's Sporting Goods. For Helen McGregor, a 78-year-old homeless woman who has spent her life on the streets around the market, there may be nowhere else to go. McGregor spends her nights with other homeless people sitting on stools in a rundown Mexican restaurant, courtesy of its proprietor. ``The owner has been so kind, so helpful,'' she said. ``I wouldn't be here now if it weren't for him.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Charged in Noriega Drug Case Face Court Hearings
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two co-defendants of Panamanian Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in his U.S. drug-trafficking case faced court appearances today. Lt. Col Luis del Cid, 46, the man prosecutors call Noriega's ``right-hand man,'' was scheduled to appear at a pre-trial detention hearing before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. And Daniel Miranda, charged with flying a plane carrying drug money for Noriega, was set to appear before a U.S. magistrate for an initial hearing. U.S. agents seized Miranda in Panama and brought him to Miami early Monday. Noriega, Del Cid, Miranda and 12 others are accused in the February 1988 federal indictment in Miami of running drugs and using Panama as a safe haven for traffickers. U.S. troops hunting Noriega invaded Panama on Dec. 20. Noriega took refuge in the Vatican embassy on Christmas Eve and remained there today. Del Cid was arrested by U.S. agents in Panama on Christmas Day after surrendering to U.S. forces. The indictment said he acted as a liaison and money courier between drug traffickers and Noriega. Del Cid, a commander in the Panamanian Defense Forces, faces racketeering, drug smuggling and money-laundering charges which carry a maximum penalty of 70 years in prison and $550,000 in fines. ``We allege he personally imported shipments of cocaine and he personally transmitted large amounts of cash,'' U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said after Del Cid arrived in Miami. Officials declined to say how Miranda, who was escorted by Drug Enforcement Agency officials on a flight from Panama, was arrested. ``He didn't surrender, but we didn't bust down any doors to get him either,'' said Diane Cossin, a spokeswoman for Lehtinen. The 12-count indictment alleges that Miranda flew a plane in 1983 that was involved in ``a business enterprise involving cocaine.'' It said Miranda and Eduardo Pardo flew $800,000 from Fort Lauderdale to Panama in May 1983. Miranda faces up to five years in prison and $10,000 in fines, Cossin said. Noriega would face up to 145 years in prison and more than $1 million in fines if brought to Miami and convicted on all charges. Miranda is the fourth co-defendant awaiting trial on charges of assisting Noriega in drug trafficking. Two other defendants, Brian Alden Davidow and William Saldarriaga, also are awaiting trial in Miami. Davidow is an alleged cocaine distributor in Miami and Saldarriaga is an alleged Colombian cocaine trafficker.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Out of gifted and sovereign people, the regime made us little screws in a monstrously big, rattling and stinking machine. We have become morally sick.'' _Vaclav Havel, the long-banned playwright who became Czechoslovakia's first non-communist president in 41 years, attacking the toppled communist regime.

``There are a lot of ifs and ands and buts in the contract. If it's not what we want, we're willing to stay out for another nine months.'' _ Terry Collins, Chapmanville, W.Va., coal miner, on the tentative settlement of the bitter nine-month strike at The Pittston Co.

I cried from happiness and sadness all day.'' _ Barbara Bush revealing that her son Marvin and his wife, Margaret, adopted a 2-month-old boy on Friday, the same day that Alexander Ellis II, husband of President Bush's sister Nancy Ellis, died of a stroke.

DOC.TEXT: A storm system in the Pacific Northwest today threatened to spread heavy snow across parts of Nevada, Utah and Arizona, while milder temperatures were forecast for the nation's midsection. As the West Coast cold front pushes through the Midwest tonight and Wednesday, snow was expected across the Dakotas into Minnesota and Wisconsin. Some scattered light snow could occur in Nebraska and Iowa on Wednesday. Strong, gusty winds continued to usher cold air into the Northeast, with gale warnings in effect along the coasts of Maine and New Hampshire. Skies will be clear to partly cloudy across the central U.S. today. Highs were expected in the mid 30s and 40s, about 10 to 20 degrees above normal. A winter storm watch was posted today for the mountains of Utah and for elevations above 6,000 feet in northwestern Arizona. Today's forecast called for from three to six inches of new snow. The storm spawned rain over Northern California, southwestern Oregon and southern Texas Monday. The precipitation was the first for the San Francisco Bay Area since Thanksgiving weekend. Scattered snow pelted the Great Lakes region and the upper Ohio Valley today. A lake snow advisory and advisory for blowing snow were in effect for parts of western New York. Between 4 and 15 inches of snow fell Sunday night in Washington's Cascade range and it snowed all day Monday. A snow advisory was in effect for the Cascades and the Olympic Mountains, with freezing reported at 1,000 feet. Accumulations of as much as 8 inches were expected by today, the National Weather Service said. The 1980s ended in dramatic fashion in much of the Northeast, where last month was the coldest December on record for at least 28 cities. Record low mean temperatures _ calculated by averaging the daily high and low readings for the month _ broke marks set in December of 1876 in Nashville, Tenn., with a mean of 29.5 degrees; Boston, 21.7; Cleveland, 19.2, and Buffalo, N.Y., 17.4 degrees. Other record cold December mean temperatures ranged from 7.3 degrees in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., to 26.0 in Charleston, W.Va. The new record cold mean temperature of 15.1 degrees in Worcesterl Mass., eclipsed the 26-year-old record of 20.2 by more than five degrees. Sunny skies and seasonable temperatures prevailed across much of the nation New Years Day. Monday's high temperature of 85 set a record for Jan. 1st in Hollywood, Fla. Monday's high temperature in the nation was 86 at Miami, Fla. DOC.TEXT: Cornelieu Bogdan, a Romanian diplomat who served under that country's deposed communist regime and its new government, died Monday in Bucharest of an aneurysm at age 68. Bogdan joined the Communist Party around the time of World War II. He served as Romanian ambassador to the United States from 1969 through 1977. He returned to Bucharest and was out of government for a time but later was named to a post in the foreign ministry that gave him authority over Western Hemisphere relations. There was friction between Bogdan and the government of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and he again left the ministry and was placed under what amounted to house arrest. He was allowed to travel to Washington in 1988 on a Woodrow Wilson fellowship and he remained in the United States until a month ago.

Solomon Birnbaum, a Jewish scholar credited with establishing the authenticity and age of the Dead Sea Scrolls, died Thursday`at age 98. Birnbaum, a native Austrian who was an expert in ancient Jewish languages, wrote two books on Hebrew and Yiddish and dozens of articles and research papers in an academic career that spanned most of this century. The scrollsl discovered in caves near the Dead Sea beginning in 1947, include the oldest known manuscripts of the Bible. Birnbaum analyzed the grammar and script to date them from the third century B.C. to A.D. 68, the same period later established by carbon-dating techniques. Birnbaum continued his research, and moved to Canada in 1970.

William Scott, a British artist acclaimed for his still-life paintings and drawings of simple foods and kitchen utensils, died Thursday of Alzheimer's disease at age 76. Scott`represented his country successfully at art festivals throughout the 1950s and 1960s. In 1961, he won the international critics' prize at the Sao Paulo Biennale. In 1966, he was named a Commander of the British Empire. He was noted above all for his paintings of objects such as kitchen pots and pans, baskets and bottles, eggs and loaves of bread laid out on kitchen tables. Scott's work is included in permanent collections of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Goteborg Museum in Sweden, the National Gallery of Modern Art in Rome and the Tate Museum in London.

Gweneth Margaret Howarth Feynman, a freelance landscape artist, world traveler and widow of Nobel Prize-winning physicist Richard Feynman, died Sunday of cancer. She would have been 56 on Thursday. Mrs. Feynman was born in Ripponden, England, and came to the United States in 1959. Her husband, a physicist who taught at Cal Tech, died in February, 1988. He shared the Nobel Prize for physics in 1965. Her final illness began while she was on a trip to Egypt. In her travels, she had visited every continent, including Antarctica.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Says It Has Identified Explosive in Four Shrapnel Bombs
DOC.TEXT: An Emancipation Day celebration held on the heels of a series of racially motivated bombings went off without a hitch, but protesters outside the NAACP headquarters in Baltimore denounced the civil-rights group. ``There's a group of black Americans who are under the illusion that we have arrived, that we have achieved, and that there is no longer a need for our civil rights organizations,'' the Rev. R.L. White said Monday at the NAACP-sponsored event in an Atlanta church. ``Sometimes it takes a rude awakening. Some demented mind will plant a bomb somewhere just to let us know the fight isn't over yet.'' In Baltimore, a handful of people, some carrying placards denouncing the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, picketed the organization's national headquarters and shouted anti-NAACP slogans New Year's Day. A sign carried by one of the pickets said ``Bomb Benny,'' an apparent reference to NAACP director Benjamin L. Hooks. The offices were closed New Year's Day. ``We are taking it seriously when people go to this extent where they come out and physically demonstrate against you with their hate signs,'' said NAACP spokesman James D. Williams. Meanwhile, the FBI said it has`determined the kind of explosive used in shrapnel bombs that killed a federal judge and a civil-rights lawyer. ``I think we're making some progress,'' William Hinshaw, special agent in charge of the FBI's Atlanta office, said Monday. He declined to provide details of the explosive. Killed in last month's bombings were 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance and Robert Robinson of Savannah, a black lawyer who worked with the NAACP. Last week, a group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System claimed responsibility in a letter for the bombs, and threatened to assassinate two more NAACP officials. In Atlanta Monday, police used explosive-sniffing dogs to search the Hoosier United Methodist Church before the NAACP's annual celebration of the Emancipation Proclamation _ President Lincoln's 1863 decree freeing slaves in the Confederacy. Police stood guard outside the church during the 3{-hour service, which included a sermon, hymns and speeches, most of which made reference to the bombings. Otis W. Smith, president of the NAACP's Atlanta branch, said the civil rights organization never considered canceling the celebration. ``We will continue to gather together until someday, hopefully, there will be no need for the NAACP,'' he said. The Rev. Richard Wynn said some people who might normally attend Emancipation Day events called him to say they would stay home this year because of the threats. About 200 people attended the church program. ``In light`of what has happened, it was an appropriate turnoutl'' Wynn said. Wynn joked about the dogs coming in Monday morning, saying they even sniffed out his pulpit. ``But little did the dogs or the FBI know, I made certain last night everything was safe,'' Wynn said. ``There was an army watching all night long ... the angels were here.''

DOC.HEAD: Proud But Homeless, Veterans Struggle For Dignity, Homes and Jobs
DOC.TEXT: The Vietnam War ended 18 years ago but the wounds of isolation borne by now-homeless`ex-soldiers reopened easily as they watched a new movie about one of their own. ``Our wounds are still hurting us,'' said Ben Colon, 36, after watching ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' ``I believe that we gave the best years of our life. Veterans should never be homeless,'' said Colon, who was shot in Vietnam and now must walk with a cane. Colon and Earl Beddoe, 41, have been on a liquid diet since Dec. 17 as a protest for better conditions at the nation's first homeless shelter for veterans, a facility`run by the Salvation Army in Queens. They hugged each other after emerging late Sunday from the film about a wounded veteran's struggle to cope. ``It's touching. You remember how you felt towards Vietnam and the way you came back and the memories of the way you were before and how you can never be again,'' Colon said. Nearby was 43-year-old Howard Fogelman, who proudly wore his U.S. Ranger button on a cap as he spoke matter-of-factly about being shot`seven times during two tours`of duty in Vietnam. The vets praised the movie, saying they identified with its portrayal of the isolation felt by veterans returning from the war. But unlike real-life vet Ron Kovic (played by Tom Cruise), who leads anti-war demonstrators and finally feels at home by 1975, Colon and Beddoe and their colleagues are still waging their own war for dignity in America. They feel they are losing. At the Queens shelter, the veterans have curfews and other rules they say are better suited for children than former U.S. servicemen, some of whom have emotional wounds even though bullet wounds have mostly healed. Fogelman has a large dent in his face where a bullet entered, and no teeth as a result of the shooting. His last set of false teeth wore out two years ago and he says bureaucratic red tape has blocked him from replacing them. Without`teeth, he has remained jobless and homeless. ``It has a lot to do with your confidence,'' he said. ``You don't want to talk.'' Drugs prescribed during his recovery from the facial wound led to a drug habit at home, he said. He's now in a methadone program. And he suffers from post-traumatic stress, which for him means ``you could just be sitting and you see images coming on the bus or the train.'' He returned home to New York in 1967, he said, to ``a completely different country.'' ``It seemed they were protesting everything, especially`the war. It was pretty bad coming home. I'm not bitter now. In this country you've got to do for yourself,'' Fogelman said. Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said he felt angry after watching the movie and hearing Kovic say he felt he was home again. ``I don't think these guys feel they're back home yet. They still have not reconnected,'' he said. ``It's an outrage that there's not enough services and resources for the homeless veterans,'' Siegel said. ``That ending is 1976 and it's now 14 years later. We're beginning the '90s and you've got hundreds of thousands of people who are homeless and hundreds of homeless vets, perhaps thousands, and it's not only in New York City but in cities across the country.'' The veterans are asking for a say in the operation of the shelter, where 400 veterans stay. They say they are treated without compassion by the staff, and note that only two of 80 salaried employees are homeless veterans. They are asking for job training and homes. ``We're not going to disappear,'' said William Dickensl 33. He pointed to the hunger strikers, who look weaker each day. ``Those two guys over there are on a hunger strike and theygre out here just to see this movie, to know that somebody else cares,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Little Changed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most foreign currencies in early European trading today, the first trading day of the new year. Gold prices were little changed in London. Currency dealers said the market was quiet and looking ahead to the release of U.Sn November trade figures on Wednesday and December employment statistics on Fridayn Dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _1.6852 West German marks, down from 1.6923 _1.5455 Swiss francs, up from 1.5430 _5.7598 French francs, down from 5.7860 _1.9017 Dutch guildersl down from 1.9100 _1,262.50 Italian lire, down from 1,270.00 _1.1576 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1587 The dollar fell more than 1 cent against the British pound. It cost $1.6234 to buy one pound this morning, compared with $1.6115 late Friday. European markets were closed Monday for New Year. Markets were closed in Japan because of the continuing New Year holiday. In London, the dollar was quoted at 144.09 yen. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $403.50 a troy ounce, up from $401.00 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's five major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $401.63. Bullion dealers said trading was thin and directionless, with few market players ready to take new positions. One dealer predicted the precious metal would drift back down to the $400 level, but he said good buying interest at that level would prevent gold from going any lower. Markets were closed in Zurich for a public holiday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold edged up 28 cents to close at a bid $402.25. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.22 a troy ounce from Friday's $5.18.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Arrested in Violence at Hotel Party
DOC.TEXT: At least 15 people were hurt and about 50 arrested after a New Year's Eve party at a downtown hotel turned violent and drunken revelers threw potted plants, fire extinguishers and bottles from balconies. ``At midnight it was literally raining bottlesn I got hit in the back of the head with a bottle,'' said police Sgt. J.R. Collinsn A similar scene occurred in Charlotte, N.C., where a New Year's celebration at a hotel turned into a near-riot. Fire officials evacuated the Howard Johnson hotel after youthful vandals unwound fire hoses, emptied all the fire extinguishers, pulled smoke detectors from walls and broke the fire alarm system. ``There must have been somewhere around 1,500 teen-agers,'' said Fire Department battalion chief Arnold Mullis. ``They were out every window and on the balconies. There were a couple of hundred of them in front of the building on the street. We had to move our vehicles back to avoid being hit by flying debris, beer bottles, beer cans.'' In Atlanta, about 2,000 young people were celebrating in the 1,685-room Marriott`Marquis hotel when the bash turned violent, Police Sgt. R.J. Lynn said. ``Nobody knows what started it. One minute it was fine and the next minute things were falling,'' said a police spokesman who refused to give his name. Guests reported there were fights, they were hit with fire extinguisher blasts`when they walked out of their rooms and they were trapped in elevators when vandals managed to short-circuit them. ``By the time we were ready to go to the symphony, there was no earthly way you could get out,'' Claude Talley, 62, said Monday. ``We became captives, hostages.'' Henry Hancock, a telephone operator at the Marriott, said the hotel offered a special New Year's Eve package deal and sold outM its 1,685 rooms, and many of the younger revelers apparently brought friends into their rooms. Charges against`about 50 people arrested in the melee at the 47-story hotel included reckless conduct, vandalism and assault. Most of those arrested were from 17 to 21 years old, police said. Paramedics said as many as 15 people were treated for injuriesM ranging from broken teeth to cuts on the head. One was knocked unconscious, apparently by a falling object. Brad Bosworth, a hotel manager, said eight people were hospitalized. The hotel's atrium was strewn with toilet paper, beer bottles and cans, smashed glass tables, ripped-up furniture and potted plants. On several levels of the atrium, garbage and pillows were tossed aboutn Bosworth said hotel officials had barely begun to assess the damage Mondayn In Charlotte, hundreds of youths threw hotel furniture from balconies and windows of the 11-story hotel. Some furniture landed in the swimming pool, authorities said. No arrests were made because officers were unable to identify those who did the damage, said Capt. Earl Mathis of the Charlotte Police Department.
