Authorities said they were uncertain if the melee was the result of a single, organized New Year's Eve party gone out of control, or separate groups converged into a mob.

DOC.HEAD: Pravda Newspaper, Vremya TV News Debut New Images
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda and the government's nightly TV news began the new year with a new look. In what might be called a Madison Avenue image makeover, Pravda on Jan. 1 unveiled a new simplified masthead that removes emblems of three awards and replaces them with a sketch of the newspaper's founderl Vladimir I. Lenin. An editor's note said the change was the first to the daily's masthead since 1972 and emphasized that the removal of the award emblems did not mean editors were not proud of them. The word Pravda, which means truth in Russian, now appears larger and the bust of Lenin shows him looking to the left above the phrase, ``The newspaper was founded May 5, 1912 by V.I. Lenin.'' The slogan ``Workers of All Countries, Unite!'' remains atop the masthead but the heading ``Communist`Party of the Soviet Union'' has`been removed so the only identification of the publisher is a note, ``Organ of the Central Committee of the C.P.S.U.'' (Communist Party of the Soviet Union). Also Mondayl the newscast Vremya, which means time, debuted a new studio set. The previous set had anchors sitting at a long desk in front of a wall. The new set was a desk in front of a window of a control room, with television monitors and TV workers visible. In a message to readers published today, Pravda's recently-appointed editor-in-chief Ivan T. Frolov said his reporters will try to be ``closer`to the people'' and ``give up old stereotypes.'' Frolovl who in October replaced Viktor G. Afanasyev, a conservative who had been in the job since 1976, also promised the newspaper will open itself to ``discussion, expression of dissent, socialist pluralism of opinionsn'' The changes reflect the newspaper's new leadership and the overall spicing up of Soviet media under President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's glasnost, or openness, campaign. Many Soviets consider Pravda dull, and the paper has lost circulation steadily while other more investigative publications have grown. In January of last year Pravda had 9.7 million subscribers and by October 9.3 million. Traditionally, the newspaper is dominated by long government or party announcements and other official business such as texts of speeches.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Protest Briefly Interrupts Rose Parade
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Harmony was the theme, but the Tournament of Roses`parade entered its second century confronting the issues of the day as AIDS activists staged a sit-down protest at the start of the event. The majestic procession of 60 flower-studded floats, 22 bands and 275 equestrians`had just started Monday when 14 protesters ran in front of a float and unfurled a banner reading: ``Emergency. Stop the parade. 70,000 Dead of AIDS.'' The group sat in the roadway, halting the 101st edition of the annual parade for 20 seconds. Crowds booed the brief demonstration and network television cameras broadcasting the parade for an estimated audience of 350 million quickly cut away. The protesters`said they were members`of Stop AIDS Now, or Else and wanted to show their dismay with government policies`toward the deadly disease, said group spokesman Bruce Mirken. ``It's a way of reminding people that for`70,000 people the parade is overl'' Mirken said. An estimated 1 million people lined curbs and sidewalks to watch the parade on a sunny, balmy day. The flowery head of Elvis Presley on Mississippi's float and a jungle barbershop quartet of hippo, giraffe, ostrich and tiger were crowd pleasers. The boos that met the AIDS protesters echoed again when unrepentant cop-slapper Zsa Zsa Gabor and embattled Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, the parade's grand marshal, appeared later. The appearance of Miss Gabor angered many spectators, with some screaming: ``Go to jail, you floozy.'' Miss Gabor was convicted for slapping a Beverly Hills policeman who stopped her RollsmRoyce last summer. Occasional boos also greeted Glenn, one of five U.S. senators who received a total of $1.3 million from Charles H. Keating Jr. and met with regulators`on behalf of his Lincoln Savings and Loan, whose failure is expected to cost taxpayers more than $2 billion. In Philadelphia, the annual New Year's Day Mummers Parade wasM postponed until Jan. 6 because of gusting wind and a threat of snow.

DOC.HEAD: Warmest Year in Britain In At Least 330 Years|
DOC.TEXT: Britain last year basked in its warmest`weather since records were first kept 330 years`ago, the Meteorological Office said today. The mean temperature in central England rose to 51.2 degrees in 1989, breaking the previous record of 50.9 degrees set in 1949. Meteorological Office spokesman Barry Parker said last year was the sunniest since 1909 and the driest`since 1976. ``While the maximum temperatures were not as high as 1976, the summer many of us remember with glee, the weather was consistent all the way through the year,'' Parker said, adding that April was the only month considered very cold. The government's records, compiled since 1659, show the winter of 1989 was the 20th century's warmest, the spring ranked 10th warmest`and the summer and fall were the seventh warmest this centuryn The mean temperature indexl which takes a sampling of weather stations`in central England, is considered the most reliable national weather guide. Earlier this year, the London Weather`Center announced that 1989 was the sunniest this century. The center said the capitol sizzled in 839.5 hours`of sunshine in May, June and July.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0468 to fix overline
Thief Stole Car With Child Asleep Inside|
DOC.TEXT: A car thief drove away with more than he had bargained for, a 4-year-old girl asleep`in the front seat. The car was found abandoned about an hour after the incident Sunday, and was`still asleep, authorities said. A woman had driven to an Eagle Food Store in this city 40 miles west of Chicago and left her daughter asleep and the cargs engine running, said Sgt. Norm Landwehr. The woman, who was not identified by police, returned to find that her car`and child were missing, Landwehr said. Police in the neighboring town of Streamwood received an anonymous call about a half-hour later, saying the car and the child could be found in the parking lot of a townhouse development there. The child was`reunited with her mother, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Claim Capture of Third Town; More Alleged Coup Plotters Tried
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian rebels today claimed they captured a third town in central Ethiopia as they pushed southward toward the capital, Addis Ababa. In a clandestine radio broadcastl the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front said it captured the the town of Jihur after a ``fierce offensive'' launched Sunday. Jihur is`70 miles northeast of Addis Ababa and 25 miles west of one of the two highways that connect the capital with the port of Assab, home of Ethiopia's sole oil refineryn The front is`a combined force of the Tigre People's Liberation Front and the Ethiopia People's Democratic Movement, a much smaller group. They have been fighting since 1974 to oust the Marxist government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The rebel broadcast gave few details of the weekend fighting, only`saying a brigade and a company of government troops were ``taken apart.'' The broadcast, monitored in Kenya's capital, Nairobi, made no mention of rebel casualtiesn It`was impossible to immediately`verify rebel claims. However, Western diplomats in Addis Ababa say previous rebel claims appear to be true. Since the rebels intensified the fighting in mid-December, they have claimed seizing the garrison town of Debre Tabor in northwestern Gonder province and Mehal Meda and Rabel in Shoa, the province that includes the capital. Those battles, the insurgents claimed, cost the government more than 8,000 dead, wounded or captured. Mehal Meda, Rabel and Jihur are all within 100 miles of Addis Ababa. Early this`year, the front seized virtual control of their home province of Tigre and in August began a push southward. They also joined the democratic movement fighters, who had confined their rebellion to Gonder. Mengistugs government and the front have held two rounds`of preliminary peace talks, the last of which ended Dec. 19 in Rome with both sides agreeing to meet in March. However, Western diplomats in Addis Ababa say the talks ``don't appear to be going far now.'' Also today, twenty-one military and police officers`accused of involvement in a May coup`attempt against`Mengistu were arraigned before a military court. The officers, including eight colonels, six majors, three captains and four lieutenants, are the second batch of security officials to appear before the three-man military panel for their alleged involvement in the May 16 coupn Presiding Judge Maj. Gen. Kefelegn Yiba, a military adviser in the office of the president, adjourned the trial until Jan. 11 to allow the defendants`time to secure attorneys. Meanwhile, the trial of the first batch of 14 officers to appear before the tribunal resumes Thursday. Prosecutors say they will seek penalties ranging from 10 years' imprisonment to death.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Advises Taxpayers to Ignore Surtax Line
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Internal Revenue Service said today there is one line on the 1989 tax forms that can be ignored by millions of elderly Americans _ the one suggesting they`may owe a surtax to pay for catastrophic health coverage under Medicare. ``Ignore the line,'' IRS Commissioner`Fred Goldberg said when asked about`the form on NBC-TV's ``Today'' show. ``We have to print (the forms) in October,'' he said. `Congress did not make the decision (to repeal catastrophic coverage) until December. It's real simple: Just ignore the line.'' And what about taxpayers`who made extra payments`during 1989 in anticipation of owing the surtax? ``If they have paid too much, it will be part of their refund and we will get it back to them as soon as possible,'' said Goldberg. The surtax could have ranged up to $800 for about 5 percent of the 33 million people eligible for Medicare. Most, however, would have paid a far smaller amount and about 60 percent`of Medicare-eligible people do not have enough income to have been subject to the surtax at all. Tax returns`have already been mailed to 107 million Americans and are due back in the mail by midnight April 16. Goldberg said those who file early can expect`a refund, if one is due, in about four`to six weeksn Those who wait until April are looking at eight to 10 weeks before they get their refund.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Says a Peaceful Germany Can Be Reunited| ^With PM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: EAST`BERLIN (AP) _ Newly elected President`Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia today made his first trip abroad in two decades`to an ally that has also cast off Communist rule, and gave hesitant endorsement`to German reunification. He said a peaceful democracy```can be as large as it wantsn'' Havel's comments at a news conference concluding his first foreign visit as head of state reflected the concern of Germany's neighbors over emergence of a powerful and dominant`nation in Central Europe, while acknowledging that one Germany is likely in the continent's near future. ``It is more important that Germany`maintains a democratic consciousness ... than whether it has 60 million or 70 million people,'' Havel told a packed conference hall after his meetings with East German Communist`Premier Hans Modrow and interim President Manfred Gerlach. ``As long as it remains peaceful and democratic, it can be as large as it wants,'' Havel said. A reunited Germany would have about 76 million citizens and an even stronger economy than West Germany's, already the most powerful in Europe. Germany has been ``both the cause and the resolution'' of Europe's most significant problems, and again poses ``the most extraordinary importance to the future of Europe,'' Havel said. Gerlach, a Liberal Democrat who like Havel rose to power`after popular`reform movements ousted the Communists`from monopoly rule, has`urged closer relations and stronger`treaty ties`between ``two sovereign German states.'' Havel, who was`named president on Friday, also planned a meeting later today in Munich with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Richard von Weizsaecker. Both Havel and Gerlach praised the direction their bilateral relations`are taking, and Havel's acceptance of the kind of reunification sought by Kohl and other`conservative West Germans appeared not to trouble his`East German host. Havel's visit`to East Germany lasted only five hours, but he metM with the two politicians`wielding the most influence in shaping a new nation. East Germany's grass-roots movement for democracy ousted an aging and orthodox leadership in October, giving encouragement`to those yearning for similar`changes in Czechoslovakia. Havel espouses a sharper turn away`from communism than East Germanygs interim leaders, and his New Year's message was gloomy and critical in contrast with the attempts by Modrow`and others to soften the harsh realities`of price hikes`and currency`reforms likely to result this year. East Germany's official ADN news agency said the Czechoslovak president`also planned trips`soon to Hungary, Poland and Austria.

DOC.HEAD: Horses Enlisted to Combat Nude Sunbathing
DOC.TEXT: Police losing their war on nude sunbathing by foreign tourists in the beach resort of Goa went back to nature to escalate their fight _ they're going on horseback. Mounted police patrols will ``be trained in arresting the culprits on the beach,'' the United News of India reported today. It quoted a police official as saying the five horses were brought from New Delhi, 850 miles to the northeast, in an effort to halt ``nudism and drug peddling on Goa beaches frequented by hippies and anti-social elements.'' There was no explanation why police on horseback might succeed where their comrades on foot and in motor vehicles have failed in the former Portuguese enclave on India's western coast 170 miles south of Bombay.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Raid Italian Villa Picked To Become Guggenheim Museum
DOC.TEXT: Thieves raided an Italian villa designated to house a collection of the Guggenheim foundation, stealing four paintings and a piece of furniture valued at $115,000, police said today. The stolen paintings were not part of the 110-piece collection of minimal and conceptual art, mostly by U.S. artists, which will be donated to the American foundation by Giuseppe Panza di Biumo. The thieves probably raided the unguarded villa a few days ago, police said. The final agreement between the city authorities of Varese and Guggenheim officials to establish a museum of the foundation in this northern city was expected to be signed next week. The Guggenheim foundation, based in New York, also has a modern art museum in Venice in a palace along the Grand Canal.

DOC.HEAD: A Wide Range In Death Toll Estimates, With None Approaching Reliability
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th pvs, `At one...' to UPDATE with Red Cross saying initial figures too high; picks up 6th pvs, `One Western...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Estimates of the death toll in Romania's bloody revolution vary from hundreds to tens of thousands, and the provisional government has yet to announce a final official figure. As the first sketchy witness accounts began to trickle out of the western city of Timisoara where the uprising began in mid-December, the death toll was first estimated at hundreds, then thousands. Then the revolution spread to other areas in Transylvania and finally to the capital, Bucharest, toppling President Nicolae Ceausescu on Dec. 22. Fighting escalated in the streets that day, with security forces loyal to Ceausescu battling the army and young revolutionaries, and estimates of the dead rose. At one point last week, a report set the number at up to 80,000. But days later, French health officials were told about 700 had died. A Red Cross spokesman in Geneva today said initial estimates of the death toll were ``far too high.'' Juerg Bischof, a spokesman of the Geneva-based organization, said the Red Cross was unable to give a revised estimate of the death toll, but that visits to hospitals throughout Romania suggested the initial figures were too high. One Western diplomat said Monday that he had information that indicated about 7,000 people had died. ``Our best estimate is nowhere near what the government says,'' he said. Before the fighting ended, the revolutionary government blamed Ceausescu for more than 60,000 deaths but didn't make it clear if the figure covered the revolution or his 24 years of power. Initial reports from witnesses and citizens in Timisoara, where security forces opened fire on unarmed demonstrators Dec. 17, set the death toll in the hundreds, then appeared to concur in estimates of between 2,000 and 4,500. At one point, there were estimates that 12,000 people were killed in Timisoara, more than 7,000 of them reportedly executed by the security forces after being detained. But Western journalists, returning from Timisoara and other cities in the region where heavy fighting had been reported, said they doubted those figures and thought the total likely would turn out to be much lower. On Dec. 22, the day Ceausescu tried to escape the capital by helicopter from the roof of his palace, U.S. diplomats said they saw 13 people killed in Bucharest. But East European news agencies reporting out of Bucharest before Western reporters were able to enter the country said hundreds had died. The following day, Dr. Marian Palaschivescu said he alone had counted 54 bodies, and an Austrian pilot said he counted 30 bodies at the airport after fierce fighting on Dec. 24. Ninety bodies were counted that day at just one of many morgues in the city. The East German news agency ADN reported that the provisional government estimated that 5,000 were killed in only two days of fighting. On Christmas Day, Hungarian radio cited ``authoritative sources'' as saying 70,000 to 80,000 had died and 300,000 were injured. But Victor Ciobanu, the health minister under Ceausescu but now a backer of the provisional government, said that day that 500 had died in Bucharest over the previous four days of fighting. The day after Christmas, Romanians in Bucharest began preparing to bury their dead, and 200 freshly dug graves were counted in one cemetery. French health officials were told this week that 746 people had died in the revolution, but Western diplomats estimated from witness accounts and their own assessments that some 10,000 people had died.

DOC.HEAD: Precede WASHINGTON
Romanian Diplomat Bogdan Dead At Age 68
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with confirmation from government official; Picks up penultimate graf, `Bogdan was ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Romania's new deputy foreign minister has died of a stroke, a government member said today. He was 68. Cornelieu Bogdan died late Monday, said Sergiu Nicolaescu, a film director and member of the National Salvation Front leadership that has sought to run the country since the hated dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was deposed. Nicolaescu told journalists that Bogdan was ``a man of honor, and a very close friend.'' Earlier, a stepdaughter, Svetlana Hoge, who lives in Washington, had reported the death and said it was believed Bogdan had died of an aneurysm. She said Romanian officials notified relatives in Washington by telephone from Bucharest and that her stepfather had a history of heart trouble. Bogdan served as Romanian ambassador to the United States from 1969 through 1977. He returned to Bucharest and was out of government for a time but later was named to a post in the foreign ministry that gave him authority over Western Hemisphere relations, she said. Mrs. Hoge said, however, that there was friction between her father and the government of Ceausescu and that he again left the ministry and was placed under what amounted to house arrest. She said he was allowed to travel to Washington in 1988 on a Woodrow Wilson fellowship and that he remained in the United States until a month ago. Bogdan was born Nov. 5, 1921, into a Jewish family in Bucharest. Mrs. Hoge said he enrolled in the Polytechnical Institute in that city but was forced to halt his studies by the coming of fascism and World War II. She said he joined the Communist Party at about that time. Besides Mrs. Hoge, survivors include his widow, Emilia Bogdan, and two daughters, Olga Bogdan of Washington and Illeana Popa of Bucharest.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Car Bomb Kills Cabbie Driving His Daughter To School
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded today in east Belfast, killing a cabbie who was driving his daughter to school, police said. The outlawed Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility. The 16-year-old girl was wounded in the attack, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. Police did not immediately release the names of the father and daughter, the first victims of 1990 of Northern Ireland's 20-year old political and sectarian violence. They were heading to the daughter's school when the bomb exploded and the car crashed into a lamp post, said a police spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British custom. The IRA issued a statement to Belfast news media claiming responsibility and alleging the dead man was a longtime member of the Ulster Defense Association and the Ulster Freedom Fighters, outlawed Protestant paramilitary organizations. An Ulster Defense Association spokesman said the man was not a member of its organization. Police said the man had no connections with the security forces, a main target of the IRA. The Irish Republican Army is fighting to oust Britain from Northern Ireland and unite the mainly Protestant province with the Republic of Ireland, which is overwhelmingly Roman Catholic.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Affordability Index Improves Slightly in November
DOC.TEXT: An index measuring the ability of the typical American family to buy a home improved slightly in November due to steady declines in mortgage interest rates and a slight increase in family incomes. The National Association of Realtors said its index rose to 105.8 in November, meaning that a family with a median income of $33,482 had 105.8 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced existing home costing $93,000. The median means that half of the families earn more and half less, or that half of the homes sell for more and half for less. The index was the highest since last February, when it registered 106.7. It was 105.5 in October. The Realtors said the median price for existing homes increased $400 in November, but this was offset by a decline in mortgage rates from 10.16 percent in October to 10.12 percent in November and by an increase in family incomes from $33,365 to $33,482. The association uses a composite rate reflecting both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages. The changes increased the monthly principal and interest payment on a median home by $1 to $660 in November, which represents 23.6 percent of the median family's income. ``The drop in rates generally is having the most impact in areas where housing is affordable for moderate-income buyers,'' NAR President Norman D. Flynn said. First-time buyers continued to have difficulty producing sufficient income for starter homes, however. The most recent first-time home buyer affordability index, for the third quarter of 1989, showed that on a national basis, first-time buyers had only 71 percent of the income needed to buy a typical starter home.

DOC.HEAD: Party Chief in Azerbaijani Town Injured in Attack
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party chief in the Azerbaijani town of Dzhali-Abad was among 80 people injured in a clash between police and demonstrators demanding his ouster, an official said. Members of a grass-roots political group, the Azerbaijani People's Front, staged the demonstrations Friday and Saturday, said Savili A. Perets, deputy director of the southern republic's official news agency, Azerinform. They attacked the police and regional party headquarters in Dzhali-Abad, near the Iranian border and the Caspian Sea. The protesters struck the top official there, Kherula Aliev, whom they accused of inattention to social and economic problems, Perets said. They demanded Aliev step down, Peretz said. Perets, speaking in a telephone interview from the Azerbaijani capital of Baku, said he did not know what object had been used to hit Aliev, who was taken to Baku for treatment. One demonstrator was wounded by gunfire, and more than 20 others and 60 police were injured by other means, Perets said. People's Front activists had claimed Saturday that police in Dzhali-Abad fired on a crowd of 20,000 to 30,000 protesters and that a 19-year-old man was shot and killed by police. But Perets said no one was killed. Several protesters detained after the incident have been released, and a commission of the republic's Supreme Soviet legislature is investigating. The situation in the area has since stabilized, Perets said.

DOC.HEAD: Uganda Releases 336 Prisoners Of War
DOC.TEXT: The government has freed 336 prisoners of war, including 10 children, that were held without charge since they were arrested in rebel fighting in 1987. Thousands of prisoners have been held since President Yoweri Museveni seized power in 1986, and their detention has been widely criticized by human rights groups. With Monday's release, only about 600remain. It was not known how many of those are children. The detainees released Monday were arrested in the northern Gulu district in 1987 during army operations to wipe out the Holy Spirit Movement, prison officials said. The Holy Spirit insurgency, led by a self-proclaimed priestess who convinced her followers her magic would protect them from bullets, was crushed in late 1987. A senior prison official said the 336 detainees included 10 children between 11 and 13 years old, all of whom were transported by bus to Gulu, 165 miles north of Kampala. The official spoke on condition of anonymity. Museveni, who seized power following a five-year bush war, has promised to release all of the prisoners of war from jails. About 5,000 were held at one time.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts of President Vaclav Havel's New Year Address
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to insert beginning of speech; Picks up 2nd graf, `Our country ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the New Year's Day address delivered by President Vaclav Havel on the eve of his first visit abroad to East and West Germany:

For 40 years you have been hearing from the mouths of my predecessors the same thing in different variations: how our country is flourishing, how many more million tons of steel we have produced, how we are all happy and how we trust our government and what beautiful future is opening in front of us. I assume you have not proposed me to this office only to have me lie to you as well. Our country does not flourish. The great creative and spiritual potential of our nation is not used in a meaningful way. Entire industrial branches manufacture things that evoke no interest, while we lack things we need. A state which calls itself a workers' state humiliates and exploits the workers.... We have spoiled our land, rivers and forests ... and we have today the worst environment in Europe. Adults in our country die sooner than in the majority of European countries.... The worst thing is we live in a morally spoiled environment. We have become morally sick, because we have gotten used to saying one thing and thinking another. We have learned to believe in nothing, not to pay attention to one another, mind our own business only. Phenomena such as love, friendship, compassion, humbleness and forgiveness have lost their depth and dimension.... The old regime _ armed with its proud and intolerant ideology _ degraded man to the level of a work force and nature to the level of an instrument of production ... it turned the gifted and sovereign people running their country in an ingenious way into little screws of a monstrously big, rattling and stinking machine... We are all _ although understandably each one to a different degree _ responsible for the operation of the totalitarian machine, none of us is only a victim, we are all at the same time its co-creators.... We must accept this heritage as something that we have inflicted upon ourselves.... All around the world people wonder where did the subservient, humiliated, skeptical and seemingly disbelieving citizens of Czechoslovakia find all of a sudden the amazing strength to shake off the yoke of a totalitarian system in a couple of weeks in such a decent and peaceful way.... Without changes in the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary and German Democratic Republic (East Germany), things that happened here would hardly have happened, and if so they would not have such a beautifully peaceful nature.... The fact that we have had good international conditions (for our revolution), does not mean that soembody was directly helping us over these past weeks.... Our first president said: Jesus, not Caesar ... Today this idea is alive again. I dare say we even have an opportunity to spread it further and bring in a new element to European and world politics. If we want to, our country can permanently radiate love, longing for understanding, power of the spirit and the idea. This radiation can be exactly what we can offer as our specific contribution to world politics. We are a small country and yet we were the spiritual crossroads of Europe once. Why couldn't we be the same once again? Wouldn't that be another contribution with which we can repay to others the help we are going to need?.... I want to be a president who will speak less and work more. A president ... who will be permanently present among his fellow citizens, listening to them carefully.... I dream of a republic that is independent, free and democratic, a republic with economic prosperity and social justice, briefly, a republic which serves man and therefore has hope that man will serve it right back.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Compares U.S. In Panama To 1979 Capture Of American Embassy
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency today compared U.S. troops searching the residence of the Nicaraguan ambassador in Panama City to the 1979 seizure of the American embassy in Tehran. ``The same country which raised a hue and cry over the justifiable revolutionary move of 1979 in Iran is now ignoring all principles of international agreements and norms of conduct and simply explaining away its behavior as a mistake,'' IRNA said in an editorial. President Bush called the search of the ambassador's residence a ``screw-up'' and apologized for the incident, but questioned what the numerous weapons found by troops were doing in the home. Iranian students seized the American Embassy in Tehran in November 1979 following the Islamic Revolution and held 52 employees hostage for 444 days. U.S. forces invaded Panama on Dec. 20 to topple Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who is wanted on U.S. drug trafficking charges. Noriega has been in the Vatican Embassy in Panama City since seeking asylum on Dec. 24.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn, Warner Fly to Panam to Review Military Operations
DOC.TEXT: Sens. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and John Warner, R-Va., flew to Panama early today to review U.S. military operations. Nunn and Warner will meet with U.S. military officers, American diplomats, members of the new Panamanian government and officials of the Panama Canal Co., Nunn's office said. Warner is a former secretary of the Navy and the Armed Services Committee's senior Republican member. The delegation is the second from Capitol Hill to visit Panama since the United States invaded last month to topple the country's military ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The previous congressional visitors were Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee and chairman of the Veterans Affairs Committee, and Rep. John P. Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House defense appropriations subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: Velayati Explains Ceausescu Visit Before Parliament
DOC.TEXT: The visit of Romania's Nicolae Ceausescu, only days before the Communist dictator was overthrown, was needed to protest a defense contract, Iran's foreign minister said today. Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati was summoned to Parliament to explain why Ceausescu was invited to Iran last month, but refused to give details on the ``vital, defense-related'' contract with Romania. ``Only part of this contract had been implemented, but if we had delayed the trip and stopped Ceausescu from coming, there was the possibility that this contract would not be implemented,'' Velayati was quoted as saying by official Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia. ``This would be a fundamental disadvantage to the defense of the Islamic Republic.'' During Iran's eight-year war with Iraq, Romania was one of the Eastern European countries that supplied Iran with armaments, including light weapons. Velayati has been criticized in the official media and by radical leaders who oppose the government of President Hashemi Rafsanjani. He also told the Parliament that Romania's position as a non-permanent member of the U.N. Security Council was important for Iran, which is trying to persuade the world body to exert pressure on Iraq to withdraw troops from Iranian territory seized in war. Ceausescu was welcomed in Tehran and signed an agreement to buy 1 million barrels of oil and 1 billion cubic meters of gas a year from Iran. Velayati said that despite Ceausescu's fall, contracts signed by him were still considered valid by Romania's new government. Velayati rejected allegations that ``we had not given sufficient information to our authorities, especially to the president, about the situation in Romania.'' Ceausescu was deposed by a popular uprising Dec. 22 and he and his wife, Elena, were executed Dec. 25 after they were found guilty during a secret trial of genocide and other ``grave crimes.'' The uprising against Ceausescu began just before he left for Tehran Dec. 18. Iran's ambassador to Bucharest, Mohammad Jamshid Gowhari, was dismissed following Ceausescu's overthrow, reportedly for his failure to inform the Foreign Ministry of the extent of the opposition to Ceausescu. But Velayati said his dismissal was because ``after Ceausescu's trip he had said things in various places that did not befit the status of a diplomat.'' Velayati did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Reaches 10-Month High in November
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending jumped 1.5 percent in November, rebounding from a 0.1 percent decrease in October and reaching a 10-month high, the government said today. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $421.7 billion in November. It was the highest level of spending since last January's $423 billion rate. Total spending in October was revised downward from the 1 percent increase reported initially. The November surge was due to a 7 percent jump in government spending, which represents about 20 percent of construction spending, combined with a 0.6 percent gain in residential construction, which accounts for about 50 percent of the total. Non-residential spending was off 0.7 percent. Construction spending fell to a yearly low rate of $410.3 billion last July. It has been among the sectors of the economy hardest hit by higher interest rates earlier this year, brought about by the Federal Reserve efforts to restrain inflation by tightening credit. But as inflation moderated, the Fed began last June to let short-term rates drop and analysts have been saying the lower rates should result in increased construction. Fixed-rate mortgages declined from a peak of 11.22 percent last March to 9.74 percent at the end of November, according to a weekly survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Residential construction totaled a seasonally adjusted $194.4 billion on an annual rate in November. Single-family construction was up 1.5 percent to $114.2 billion. Apartment construction gained 4.7 percent to $22.5 billion. Non-residential construction fell 0.7 percent to $100.7 billion on an annual rate. On the other hand, the volatile government sector jumped 7 percent to $91.4 billion. The total construction figure was up 1.5 percent from the level of building a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Comic Belzer Settles with Hulkster, Mr. T
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES New York-dated 2nd item in PM-Names, a0422, with lawsuit settled.
DOC.TEXT: A long-awaited legal grappling match that was to pit comic Richard Belzer against wrestlers Hulk Hogan and Mr. T never made it into the ring _ the combatants settled out of court at the last moment. Norman Roy Grutman, Belzer's lawyer, revealed today that the $5 million case _ involving an encounter on a cable TV show that left the comedian unconscious _ was settled ``in the last hour of the last working day of the year. I have not signed any papers, but we have exchanged faxes.'' And what exactly was the settlement? ``It includes a covenant of confidentiality which indicates that when asked by the media, I am to say that `The case has been settled to the mutual satisfaction of all parties.''' The high-profile lawyer sounded a lot like a child who had lost a favorite Christmas toy. ``I'm not happy about it,'' he admitted. Indeed, a lot of wrestling fans, lovers of comedy, court buffs and devotees of the bizarre were looking forward to seeing Hogan, the 307-pound World Wrestling Federation champ, take on Belzer, 150 pounds dripping wet. Jury selection had been scheduled to begin today. The suit stems from the appearance of Hogan and Mr. T on ``Hot Properties,'' a cable program hosted by Belzer, in 1985. The two were promoting an upcoming ``Wrestlemania'' tag-team bout; the whole thing was videotaped and would have been shown at trial. Shortly into the segment, Belzer says, things got ugly: ``He gives a front-chin lock. You know, some people call it the sleeper hold,'' Belzer writes in his 1988 book, ``How to Be A Stand-Up Comic.'' ``His arms are as big as mine are gonna be if I pump iron for 800 years. ... So he gets me in a front chin lock and he starts squeezing _ I figured he's fooling around. And then he squeezes more, and it starts hurting _ and my brain goes, `Check, please! No oxygen, I'm outta here, babe. Thank you.''' Belzer had submitted a three-page laundry list of injuries allegedly inflicted by Hogan _ everything from nine stitches to the head to ``trauma to the skull and neck'' to ``severe humiliation.'' He sued the Hulkster, his tag-team partner Mr. T, World Wrestling Federation impresario Vince McMahon and McMahon's Titan Sports Inc. Grutman's court papers never mentioned Hogan by his ring name; the big, bad Hulkster is simply Terry Gene Bollea. He and Mr. T are described as ``tough, outrageous, physically aggressive, brash, unswerving, unsympathizing, uncompromising macho types.'' ``We see the suit as a publicity ploy, pure and simple,'' said WWF attorney Ted Dinsmoor, before the settlement. ``He asked the Hulkster to demonstrate a wrestling move, and he was accidentally injured.'' Said Dinsmoor: ``He wants to get his name in the news. People don't go to court over a couple of stitches and Tylenol for a headache. This guy's a joke.''

DOC.HEAD: First Uninjured Troops Return from Panama
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Fifty-six soldiers ...' to UPDATE with arrival at Fort Ord.
DOC.TEXT: The first U.S. troops to pull out of Panama pronounced the invasion a success today, said they were mostly well received by the Panamanian people and expressed relief at making it back alive. ``Now they have a democratic government _ it's what they want. They love Americans,'' said Army Sgt. John Grauer, 29, of Fresno, Calif. ``They love what we did.'' Fifty-six soldiers in camouflage and face paint left Kelly Air Force Base here early today, arriving at their home base of Fort Ord in Monterey, Calif. The troops from the 7th Infantry Division arrived at Kelly on Monday from Panama, the first organized unit withdrawn since the attack Dec. 20. Kelly spokeswoman Phoebe Brown said another plane with 46 soldiers aboard arrived here early today and was to leave for Fort Ord this evening. As the soldiers left for their home base, 2nd Lt. John Jaskwhich, 23, of Greenville, S.C., said the troops in his field artillery unit were in Panama two weeks but that most of the fighting had calmed down before they saw action. Jaskwhich, the senior man in the squad, said his prevailing thought was: ``Just get me out alive.'' ``I'm just glad to be back to celebrate a little Christmas,'' he said. Army Spec. Melissa Jackson, who works in supplies and caught a ride back to the United States with the artillery unit, expressed a similar feeling. ``It's scary,'' said the 22-year-old, who was in Panama three months. ``Any time anything like that happens and you're in the midst of it, you get scared. If anyone tells you that they weren't scared down there, they're lying.'' A total of 141 soldiers from Fort Ord were pulled out Monday, said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``Their military mission is finished. It's just a continued tailoring of the military force in Panama as the need for combat troops is diminished,'' said Pentagon spokesman Maj. David Super. ``The growing mission down there now is for nation-building and civil affairs.'' President Bush expressed hope that the remaining U.S. soldiers in Panama could leave ``as soon as possible,'' Fitzwater said. He offered no timetable. About 12,000 troops are permanently assigned to Panama. An additional 14,000 were sent in as part of the invasion to topple Gen. Manuel Noriega. Twenty-three U.S. servicemen were killed in the operation and 322 wounded. Among Panamanians, 297 soldiers and about 300 civilians were killed, said the U.S. military.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Killed in Fierce Fighting Between Shiite Militias
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias using tanks, rocket-propelled grenades and 106mm guns today battled in southern Lebanon, and police said five people were killed and 12 wounded. The fighting raged among the bluffs of Kfar Hatta village, southeast of Sidon, a police spokesman said. The spokesman, who cannot be named in line with standing regulations, said the hills were essential for the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, to ensure supplies to its southern bases from the eastern Bekaa valley. Kfar Hatta is just below the mountainous routes controlled by Israeli troops and allied South Lebanon Army militiamen from Israel's self-proclaimed buffer zone in southern Lebanon. The new casualties raised the overall toll to 64 killed and 228 wounded since the current round of fighting erupted Dec. 13, pitting the fundamentalist Hezbollah against the pro-Syrian secular Amal militia. Efforts by Iran and Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization to curb the fighting have failed to stop the fighting. An Amal communique claimed its fighters repulsed a pre-dawn Hezbollah attack. ``The infiltrators who came under cover of darkness were forced to flee in chaos, leaving behind several dead on the battlefield,'' said the communique, which was issued in Beirut. A Hezbollah communique blamed the escalation of hostilities on a relentless Amal bombardment of its beleaguered bases in Jbaa and Ein Bouswar south of Kfar Hatta. Both sides also traded charges of collaborating with Israel and the South Lebanon Army, their common enemy. Amal's top commander in southern Lebanon, Atef Aoun, has claimed Iran paid $250,000 to Israel and the South Lebanese Army to allow Hezbollah to move reinforcements from the Bekaa to the region through South Lebanese Army lines. He claimed he had evidence of such a payment, but did not make it public. Statements from Hezbollah have claimed that Amal was out to expel pro-Iranian fundamentalists from southern Lebanon to set the stage for concluding a deal of co-existence with Israel. Israel has maintained control over its self-proclaimed 328-square-mile security zone since 1985, using it as a buffer against cross-border guerrilla raids. Hezbollah is considered to be the umbrella organization for extremist groups holding 18 foreign hostages in Lebanon, including eight Americans. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Precede NEW YORK
U.S. Rep Garcia Says He'll Quit Congress
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Robert Garcia, D-N.Y., awaiting sentencing this month on his extortion conviction in the Wedtech scandal, announced today he is resigning his House seat effective Jan. 7. Garcia, a six-term congressman, said in a statement that he made the decision ``with deep sadness.'' ``The people of the Bronx have always been the most important part of my life, and representing them is the greatest honor I could ever know,'' Garcia said. ``But I have always said that if I could not serve their best interests I would leave office.'' Garcia said he did not foresee a resolution to his legal problems in time to allow him to fully carry out the duties of his office. Garcia, 56, and his wife, Jane Lee Garcia, 48, were convicted last October of extorting $178,500 in cash, loans and jewelry from Wedtech, a now-defunct defense contractor based in Garcia's South Bronx district. They could face up to 45 years in prison and $750,000 in fines. In addition, Garcia is under investigation by the House ethics committee, although that probe will become moot once he quits. Garcia said he was timing his resignation to allow New York Gov. Mario Cuomo to call for a special election to fill out the remaining year of his term. A handful of Democrats have already lined up to seek the post, but Bronx Democratic leaders have privately suggested state Assemblyman Jose Serrano is Garcia's likely successor. The district is overwhelmingly Democratic, and whoever gets the party's endorsement would be a clear frontrunner.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Says Romanian Securitate Official Killed In Embassy Confrontation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with government saying investigation under way; picks up 2nd pvs, `The newspaper...'
DOC.TEXT: The security chief at the Romanian Embassy was shot and killed by its staff after dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was ousted, a Greek newspaper reported today. Government spokesman Pavlos Pavlopoulos said the Public Order Ministry was investigating the allegation. He would not elaborate. The newspaper Eleftherotypia said the unidentified official, a member of the dreaded Securitate security police, was killed ``in a dramatic confrontation'' with the embassy staff, which sided with the revolution. Romania's envoy to Athens, Nicolai Ecobescu, described the story as ``fantasy'' to reporters within an hour after the newspaper circulated in the Greek capital. Ecobescu was one of the first ambassadors to publicly denounce Ceausescu after the dictator was ousted Dec. 22. Ceausescu was summarily tried and executed with his wife, Elena, three days later. Citing Eastern European and African diplomatic sources, the paper said the official was executed the day Ceausescu was toppled. His body was put in a box marked ``diplomatic package'' and shipped by embassy car to Bucharest a week later, the paper said. Greek police earlier said they were investigating but there was very little they could do if the story was true since the alleged slaying took place in the embassy, which enjoys diplomatic immunity.

DOC.HEAD: Houses and Jobs for Ethnic Turks Who Return to Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of ethnic Turks who fled to Turkey from Bulgaria last year will be given back their homes and jobs if they return to their Communist homeland, a Bulgarian consulate official said today. ``Their property is still there, it belongs to them,'' Consul Slavi Slavov told a news conference. ``Everyone who lives in Bulgaria will have equal rights.'' It was the first news conference at the consulate since 1985 when the Sofia government launched a forced assimilation campaign against the country's 1.5 million ethnic Turkish minority. Slavov also said the new Bulgarian government would declare an amnesty soon for those imprisoned for other than terrorist crimes. He did not elaborate. He said these issues will be taken up at an extraordinary party congress which will be held Jan. 30. Increasing curbs on their ethnic and religious rights, including forced change of their Moslem names, last year prompted 320,000 ethnic Turks to emigrate to Turkey after Bulgarian authorities gave them passports. More than 15,000 other ethnic Turks have arrived in this country since Turkey imposed a visa requirement on Aug. 22 to slow down the flow. Official figures show nearly 100,000 ethnic Turks returned to Bulgaria after a short stay because of lack of housing and jobs. The end of the assimilation campaign was announced Friday by the Communist Party's policy-setting Central Committee. National assembly Chairman Stanko Todorov told demonstrating ethnic Turks in Sofia Friday that in the future ``everybody in Bulgaria will be able to choose his name, religion and language freely.''

DOC.HEAD: Tubes of Cocaine Found Attached to Belly of Ship
DOC.TEXT: Cocaine worth $4.2 million was stashed in two waterproof tubes attached to the underside of a Colombian ship, said police, who seized the drug and arrested four men who showed up in diving gear. Police divers worked for more than 16 hours to detach the tubes from the cargo ship Sunday. As police watched, four Colombians in diving suits appeared at a boat ramp across the St. Johns River from the ship, apparently to retrieve the 265-pound cache, authorities said. The men were arrested on drug trafficking charges. ``When you have four guys show up at the Arlington boat ramp with diving gear, it's unlikely they're here to spear fish,'' said Capt. Herschell Connell, head of the organized crime section of the sheriff's office. The area is not known for sport diving, especially in winter. Connell said the ship makes a trip every other week between Jacksonville and Caragena, Columbia, and that police were tipped off about the drugs. Sailors aboard probably were unaware of the tubes, and none were charged, he said. ``This is not the first time we had information there was something on the bottom of a ship, but it was the first time we found something,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Excommunicated Parishioner Arrested in Fire at Historic Church
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `The church ...' and SUBS 12th graf, `The man's ...' with two grafs to RESTORE full name of denomination, CLARIFY it is not part of the larger Church of Christ denomination.
DOC.TEXT: An excommunicated parishioner set a historic church on fire and held police and firefighters at bay for up to an hour before coming outside to dance on the porch in face paint, authorities say. The man, who had telephoned police an hour earlier Monday saying he was baricaded inside the 87-year-old wood building with hand grenades and other weapons, had said he would surrender if he were allowed to dance. ``It was something to the effect of a native American Indian dance,'' a police officer said. ``He was jumping up and down.'' The 25-year-old man, who was not immediately identified, was arrested and was to be charged with burglary and arson today, police said. Police found no weapons inside. Police officers gathered a block from the church, while tourists, oblivious to the standoff, strolled past monuments and markers on the south side of the church, where parishioners believe that Christ will make his Second Coming. The standoff ended when a police officer hiding behind a stone marker captured the man as he danced briefly outside, his cheeks painted with brightly colored stripes, authorities said. Firefighters then moved in and battled the blaze for about 25 minutes, but flames had engulfed its second floor. ``The church was totaled,'' said Alvin Harris, pastor of the Church of Christ (Temple Lot). He said he believed it would cost $200,000 to $300,000 to rebuild the church. Harris said the man, who claimed to be part Indian, had recently danced around a century-old tree, and the tree had burned. The man was ``sort of a religious zealot. He's always acted kind of weird, but nobody ever took him seriously. We feel sorry for him,'' Harris said. C. LeRoy Wheaton Jr., a church elder, said members had to remove the man from the church during a prayer meeting last summer because he was wearing a sword and threatening people. ``He thought he was the one to straighten us all out,'' Wheaton said. Church officials said the man was excommunicated a few months earlier and had been warning them for months that God had ordered him to cleanse the church site. The man's name was removed from church records, said William Sheldon, secretary of the council of apostles, when it was discovered he had been baptized in another faith that, like the Church of Christ (Temple Lot), follows the Book of Mormon. The church that burned Monday has about 200 members in the Kansas City area, and worldwide the denomination claims about 2,300 members. The Church of Christ (Temple Lot) has no connection to the larger Church of Christ movement. The church was built in 1902 on property purchased in 1867 by followers of the Book of Mormon.

DOC.HEAD: Bushes Attend Funeral for Relative
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf, Ellis, 67, to CORRECT that Ellis was husband sted brother of Nancy Ellis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his wife Barbara, on a quick trip out of Washington, flew to this Boston suburb today to attend the funeral of Bush's brother-in-law, businessman Alexander Ellis. As the Bushes and a small entourage arrived at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, a handful of protesters stood quietly with a large banner saying, ``Will you attend the funeral in Panama?'' The trip here came as the first group of soldiers that Bush sent to Panama to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega returned to the United States. The 141 GIs were only a fraction of the some 14,000 troops dispatched from U.S. bases for the Dec. 20 invasion. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said more troops were expected to follow ``as soon as possible.'' Bush has encountered some criticism for the death of more than 200 civilians during the height of the invasion. Ellis, 67, was the husband of Bush's sister, Nancy Bush Ellis. He died Friday following a stroke and major intestinal surgery. The Bushes were accompanied as they entered the small traditional church by family members and White House aides, including chief of staff John Sununu and Fitzwater. Bush, entering through a side door, apparently did not see the protesters, who were standing with about three dozen onlookers behind police barricades across the street. Fitzwater announced the return of the 141 Army troops based in Fort Ord, Calif., on Monday as the president flew home after a six-day vacation, most of it in Texas. ``We want them all to come out as soon as possible, except for the 12,000 there permanently,'' Fitzwater said. The first 56 soldiers arrived at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio on Monday for a layover before returning to Fort Ord. Pentagon spokesman Maj. David Super said the troops were from the 7th Infantry Division. ``Their military mission is finished. It's just a continued tailoring of the military force in Panama as the need for combat troops is diminished,'' Super said. ``The growing mission down there now is for nation-building and civil affairs.'' Fitzwater said other units would return home over ``the next few days.'' ``We'll see groups like this coming out on a continuing basis,'' he said, adding that the troops would be withdrawn unit by unit ``because of varying duty assignments, varying mop-up needs that remain in Panama.'' The beginning of the troop withdrawal came 12 days after the pre-dawn U.S. invasion that toppled the government of dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. On Sunday, Bush visited two military hospitals in San Antonio, Texas, and met with U.S. servicemen wounded in the action. Noriega has been holed up in the Vatican embassy in Panama City since Christmas Eve. Fitzwater said Monday there was ``no change'' in the status of the stalemate between the United States and the Roman Catholic Church over his fate. Over the weekend, Bush said he wanted to bring troops home as soon as possible, but that he did not intend to act precipitously. Twenty-three U.S. servicemen and three civilians were killed in the invasion and more than 300 were wounded. About 14,000 U.S. troops were sent by Bush to augment the 12,000 already there. Mrs. Bush commented Monday on Ellis' death while announcing that the Bushes' youngest son, Marvin, and daughter-in-law Margaret, of Alexandria, Va., had adopted a 2-month-old boy, Charles Walker Bush. The couple also has an adopted daughter, Marshall, 3. The Bushes now have a dozen grandchildren, five boys and seven girls. ``There's something exciting, we heard about the baby the day our brother-in-law died. There's something nice about that, isn't there? Sort of magical,'' Mrs. Bush said. ``I cried from happiness and sadness all day.'' Of Ellis, Mrs. Bush said: ``He was a wonderful man, so wonderful that we wanted him not to live because he would have been a vegetable.'' When a reporter congratulated the president on his 12th grandchild, he said: ``Thank you. Funny how life goes on ... Nancy's husband and this.'' The Bushes spent about four hours bass fishing on a private lake near Montgomery, Ala., on Monday with Alabama sportsman Ray Scott before returning to Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Councilor Votes Against Himself
DOC.TEXT: Boston City Councilor Brian J. McLaughlin voted against himself swinging the election by a 7-6 vote to a conservative president of the non-partisan council. Liberals on the 13-member council sought McLaughlin's support right up to the last minute Monday, offered him the presidency and voted for him. But McLaughlin said he had promised Friday to support Christopher Iannella for a third consecutive one-year term. McLaughlin generally votes with liberals, but said he made the promise figuring the liberals could not guarantee more than five votes for him for president. ``I made a commitment, and I kept it, and I'm proud I did,'' he said. The president of the City Council appoints committee chairmen, a power that was the key issue.

DOC.HEAD: Skydiver Falls to Her Death
DOC.TEXT: A woman fell about 10,000 feet to her death after jumping from a plane just north of Houston Gulf Airport. The League City woman, whose name was withheld pending notification of relatives, died just after the fall at 5:20 p.m. Monday. Lindsay Carleton, owner of Skydive Spaceland, said the woman jumped with three other skydivers from a twin-engine turboprop airplane. Neither the jump parachute nor a reserve chute were opened, he said. ``I believe panic probably had something to do with it,'' Carleton said. ``It was a normal sky dive. When it came time to open, she didn't open either parachute and we don't know why.'' Skydive Spaceland provides about 10,000 jumps a year to students and experienced parachutists, Carleton said. The woman was among 150 people to pay $15 for a New Year's Day jump. She is believed to have been making jumps for about a year.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Bigotry Project Set For Georgia Schools
DOC.TEXT: From racial strife to vandalism at religious schools to the exclusionary traditions of private social clubs, close-to-home issues of bigotry are coming to Georgia's classrooms under a new education project. The voluntary program, to be formally unveiled Thursday, will provide teachers with materials and training to include anti-bigotry lessons in their curriculum. The program includes general themes of racial, religious and ethnic understanding and portions dealing with matters of specific interest to Georgia. The materials will be made available to school systems through the ``A World of Difference'' campaign sponsored by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith and several corporate backers. The program got started in Boston in 1985 and has expanded to about 25 cities, said project coordinator Ginger Carter. Fourteen public and private school systems in Georgia, including the Atlanta city schools, have signed on as participants. Lessons are based on recent events of prejudice that can be incorporated into existing social studies or history classes. The lessons examine incidents of discrimination by having students read articles about the examples, become familiar with the vocabulary common to discussions about bigotry and discuss the implications of prejudice and attempts to stop such practices. ``We ask the students to think about if a problem exists in their own school and how they can address them _ how would you react if something happened at your school and it was addressed at your race and religion?'' Mrs. Carter said. In Georgia, the project also is being sponsored by Georgia Power Co., WAGA-TV in Atlanta and the California-based Milken Family Foundation. ``The time for change is ripe,'' said Bill Dahlberg, president and chief executive officer of Georgia Power. ``Working through the schools and our children, this program will help spread the word that prejudice is not OK.''

DOC.HEAD: Drunken Youth Kills 7 in Greenland
DOC.TEXT: A drunken 18-year-old gunman opened fire at a New Year's party in southern Greenland, killing seven people, Greenlandic radio reported Tuesday. Police in Narsaq were alerted by one of the wounded victims that a shoot-out had occurred in a dormitory on Monday, and they discovered the bodies of three men and two women. Two other women who were seriously wounded died Tuesday at the Narsaq clinic, the radio said. The killer also wounded his 22-year-old brother. A heavy storm made it impossible to transfer the wounded women to a hospital in Denmark with better facilities, Greenland radio added. All the dead had been shot in the head with a semiautomatic rifle. The youngest victim was 18; the oldest 34. The suspect, who was not identified, told police he was drunk when he arrived at the dormitory where friends and relatives had celebrated the New Year. He said he opened fire after a quarrel, but gave no other motive. According to Greenland radio, the killer had a criminal record for theft and was on probation.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Bans Rallies Outside Parliament
DOC.TEXT: The government announced Tuesday it was banning demonstrations outside Parliament, the site of several anti-government opposition rallies last year. The decision, which takes effect Wednesday, apparently is meant to thwart a planned opposition demonstration outside Parliament when it opens its session Thursday. The prohibition will remain in effect as long as the Parliament is in session, the government said, with assembly by more than four people prohibited. Deputy Police Commissioner Mansur Ahmed did not say what the punishment was, although political detentions normally are for two to six weeks. Thursday's rally was planned by a seven-party coalition, led by the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, to demand that President Hussain Muhammad Ershad resign and hold new elections under a caretaker government. Opposition parties, alleging government corruption, have sponsored strikes and rallies. A former general, Ershad took power in a bloodless coup in 1982. He resigned from the army in 1985 and a year later was elected to a five-year presidential term in voting that political opponents and foreign observers said was tainted by widespread fraud. Ershad says he is willing to hold new elections without handing over power to a caretaker government, an offer the opposition has rejected.

DOC.HEAD: DC-10 Makes Emergency Landing After Smoke Reported in Cockpit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with passengers reporting chutes did not work properly. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An American Airlines DC-10 made an emergency landing at Baltimore-Washington Airport today after the pilot reported smoke in the cockpit, and nine people were hurt evacuating down the jet's chutes, officials said. Passengers said many of the injured were hurt in shoving that broke out at the jet's exits when the chutes failed to drop all the way to the ground. Flight 240, with 247 passengers and 10 crew members, was bound from the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport to LaGuardia Airport in New York City when the pilot reported smoke, airline spokeswoman Susan R. Kelly said. Passengers also reported smoke in the cabin, but Kelly said she could not confirm that. The plane landed here just after midnight. Passenger Thomas Glanville of New York City said light smoke was coming from the rear of the plane. He said he was waiting in line to leave the plane when passengers realized that the chutes were wrapped around the wings. ``Several people became panicky and didn't know what to do or where to go,'' he said. Kelly said the wind caused the chutes to stick straight out and prevented them from falling to the ground immediately. ``They were standing up straighter than normal,'' she said. ``They were deployed properly.'' Nine people were treated at North Arundel Hospital in Glen Burnie for sprains, aches and bruises, said Kevin Murnane, hospital spokesman. The passengers were injured ``from bumping into each other as they were going down the slide,'' Kelly said. The cause of the smoke was under investigation, Kelly said. But she said there was no fire. Kelly said passengers waited on the tarmac for 15 to 20 minutes until buses took them to the terminal. Some, who had begun their trip in Acapulco, Mexico, were dressed in clothing too light for temperatures that dipped into the 30s. ``This was not really a long time, considering the plane was not expected in there at all. They had to find some buses to get out there,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Hardware Arrives from U.S. for Exercises
DOC.TEXT: U.S. soldiers on Tuesday began removing about 1,000 pieces of military hardware sent by ship from the United States for use in upcoming exercises in West Germany. U.S. Gen. John Galvin, the top military commander in Europe for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, reiterated that the allies still needed to maintain a strong defense despite easing East-West tensions. ``What's happening in Eastern Europe is as of now still not entirely predictable,'' he said. ``As long as we have this kind of uncertainty ... it will be very difficult to say exactly what will we see a year from now or five years from now,'' Galvin said. ``In the meantime, I'm going to do my best to make sure we keep our powder dry.'' The trucks, trailers and other heavy equipment that were loaded in Savannah, Ga., arrived on the Navy cargo ship Altair on Monday night at the Belgian port of Antwerp, about 30 miles north of Brussels. Two more naval ships, the Pollux and the Antares, will arrive soon with more hardware. The shipment of the equipment is part of the ``Reforger'' _ Return of forces to Germany _ exercise. The maneuver, the 21st of its kind, tests the United States' ability to send troops and supplies to Europe in the event of war, and Europe's ability to receive the reinforcements. Nearly 15,000 military personnel will fly from the United States to link up with the equipment and take part in Centurion Shield, a field-training exercise. In all, 57,500 U.S. and European soldiers will participate. About 12,000 support personnel also will be involved. Reforger had been scheduled to take place in September but was postponed until now and scaled down in size. About 17,000 soldiers traveled from the United States to take part in the 1988 version, with about 125,000 U.S. and European soldiers in the field. War games have become increasingly unpopular with the European public because of their financial costs, noise and damage to farmland.

DOC.HEAD: First U.S. Troops Return Home; Tug-Of-War Over Noriega Wears On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with Nunn, Warner, Eagleburger visits; Noriega not to be charged today; Picks up 12th graf, `The move ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAN1
DOC.TEXT: As the first elements of the U.S. invasion force withdrew, Panama's new president urged the Vatican to surrender Manuel Antonio Noriega to the United States because his government is incapable of trying him. A church official said it was up to Noriega to decide when to leave the Vatican embassy, where he sought refuge Christmas Eve after being ousted by U.S. troops. Two artillery batteries from Fort Ord, Calif. _ a total of 141 soldiers _ were pulled out Monday, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. One planeload of troops arrived at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio late Monday. The rest of the 14,000 troops sent in for the Dec. 20 invasion that toppled Noriega will probably leave ``on a piecemeal basis,'' Fitzwater said. He did not specify when that might occur. ``The president is glad to see some of the troops coming home and hopes the rest can leave as soon as possible,'' Fitzwater said. The 12,000 troops permanently assigned to Panama would remain. Twenty-three U.S. servicemen were killed in the operation and 322 wounded. Among Panamanians, 297 soldiers and some 300 civilians were killed, according to the U.S. military. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger planned to fly to Panama late today for talks with President Guillermo Endara on U.S. aid to Panama and other issues, officials said. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, flew to Panama early today to review U.S. military operations. Nunn was accompanied by Sen. John Warner, R-Va. Meanwhile, 20 American diplomats expelled by Nicaragua in retaliation for a U.S. troop search of the residence of that country's ambassador to Panama left Managua on Monday night. Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista government on Friday gave the diplomats 72 hours to leave the country and ordered the U.S. Embassy support staff cut from 320 employees to 100. The United States apologized for the incident, saying the troops were unaware the home was a diplomatic residence when they entered it _ over the protests of Ambassador Antenor Ferrey _ to search for weapons. President Bush said it was a ``screw-up'' but questioned what the numerous weapons found by troops were doing in the home. In the latest round over Noriega's fate, Endara said the stalemate could end if the Vatican and the papal nuncio ``say once and for all that Noriega doesn't deserve to be sheltered in the house of God, that he is a common criminal of the worst kind and should abandon the sacred place.'' Noriega is charged with drug trafficking in the United States. Rogelio Cruz, Endara's attorney general, said Sunday murder charges would be filed against Noriega by today. But Cruz said he hadn't had time and ``I won't be filing charges today.'' The move appeared to lay the groundwork for the mission to release Noriega him to the Panamanian government. But Endara said Monday that Panama does not have a prison secure enough to hold Noriega. He acknowledged that once outside the embassy, the general would be captured by U.S. troops surrounding the mission. ``Only after the American authorities are done ... can we have the opportunity to extradite him to Panama and make him pay in Panama for the crimes and offenses he has committed here in Panama,'' Endara said after a New Year's Day Mass. ``But for the moment, we can't do it.'' Endara, elected last May in balloting nullified by Noriega, is still in the early stages of establishing a government. Archbishop Marcos McGrath said Noriega would have a fair trial and greater personal security if he went to the United States, but said, ``He will have to leave by his own decision. ``He will have to weigh his choices and come up with that which is the least disagreeable,'' McGrath said in an interview. Vatican officials have said they were urging Noriega to leave of his own accord. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro confirmed that Vatican envoy Monsignor Giacinto Berloco arrived at the embassy to ``give a hand'' to the negotiations. Navarro declined to give any details and said the Vatican would have no comment on the affair today. Navarro was asked to say whether a much-reported Endara letter, allegedly asking Vatican to turn over Noriega, had arrived. Navarro refused to answer the question. In other developments, the U.S. Southern Command said it arrested Rodolfo ``Papito'' Chiari, Noriega's interior and justice minister, on Saturday. The military communique gave no details. U.S. troops, the only real security force in the country since the invasion, have been arresting anyone the Panamanian government wants detained. Fifty members of Noriega's ``Machos del Monte'' battalion, which came to his defense during an Oct. 3 coup attempt, surrendered Sunday near Rio Hato, 80 miles southwest of Panama City, the Southern Command said. The process of transferring the Panama Canal to the Panamanian government advanced a step further Monday when Fernando Manfredo, a 62-year-old economist, became acting administrator of the waterway. He is the first Panamanian to hold the post since the canal began operation 75 years ago. The 1977 canal treaties cede control of the canal to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999. The agreements set a Jan. 1, 1990, date for a Panamanian to be named canal administrator.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Withdraws Dismissal, Weizman Quits Inner Cabinet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf, `Abu Sharif ...' with Shamir reaction.
DOC.TEXT: Defusing a political crisis that threatened the coalition government, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today canceled his decision to fire Science Minister Ezer Weizman for alleged contacts with the PLO. In a political compromise, Weizman had agreed to quit the decision-making inner Cabinet. The announcement came after Shamir summoned Weizman today. In Baghdad, Iraq, a Palestine Liberation Organization official said Shamir himself had sent a message to PLO leader Yasser Arafat a few months ago on a possible settlement of the Mideast crisis. ``I wonder why Shamir is making a lot of noise about Weizman's contacts with the PLO when he and other senior Israeli politicians made similar contacts,'' said Bassam Abu Sharif, Arafat's political adviser. Abu Sharif, who is known to have contacted Israeli officials on behalf of the PLO, declined to reveal the precise contents of the message or say who was the intermediary. In Israel, a spokesman for Shamir dismissed Abu Sharif's claim as ``utter nonsense.'' Shamir's earlier firing of Weizman sparked a major Cabinet crisis in Israel. The agreement between Weizman and Shamir ended two days of intense efforts to save the coalition of the conservative Likud bloc that Shamir heads and the center-left Labor Party of which Weizman is a senior member. The crisis was the worst to shake a Likud-Labor alliance in six years and concerned a major issue that has split the nation _ how to resolve Israel's festering conflict with Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. On Sunday, Shamir gave Weizman written notice that he was fired as of today because of contacts with the PLO in which Weizman allegedly divulged secret Israeli strategy that he learned in meetings of the 12-member inner Cabinet. Weizman told reporters after the five-minute meeting that Shamir had not confronted him with evidence of the PLO contacts. ``Firstly, the crisis is over. Secondly, all attempts to say I am guilty or not I don't accept because for me guilt is a matter of being brought to court or not,'' Weizman told reporters. Weizman, 65, a former defense minister who defected from Likud, said Shamir took back the dismissal letter. The arrangement was worked out before the meeting and finalized in Shamir's office ``with smiles and a handshake,'' Weizman said, adding he would go ahead with a planned trip to Moscow on Wednesday. Under the compromise, Weizman will remain science minister in the overall, 26-member Cabinet but will no longer sit in sessions of the inner Cabinet, where government strategy is decided. Eliakim Rubinstein, the Cabinet secretary and a top Shamir aide, said Shamir would consider restoring Weizman to the inner Cabinet in 18 months. ``The prime minister stressed to Mr. Weizman the seriousness with which he viewed all contacts with terrorist organizations, leading them the PLO,'' Rubinstein said. Labor had demanded that Weizman not be ousted without a chance to see and respond to evidence against him. Labor leaders were split, however, over how far to go in defending Weizman, who has openly advocated talks with the PLO despite government policy against any dealings with the organization. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who was reportedly shown the evidence, told Labpr Party colleagues Monday he was uncertain whether Shamir ``does not have a case against Weizman.'' Weizman said the compromise that ended the crisis was worked out by Rabin and Vice Premier Shimon Peres, Labor's chairman. ``I'm a party man and I had to listen to my colleagues. It was hard for me, but I had to accept this.'' Shamir's evidence against Weizman, including his alleged exchange of messages with Arafat, was gathered by the Shin Bet, indicating the secret service had been shadowing the Cabinet minister for some time, Israeli media reported. Shamir claimed Weizman's contacts with the PLO were undermining Israel's efforts to launch Middle East peace talks. Shamir's strategy is based on excluding the PLO from negotiations. According to Israel radio, the most serious accusation was that Weizman advised PLO leaders in a telephone call to Tunis that ``if they take the right steps they will even get Jerusalem,'' whch Israel has declared its capital. Weizman sharply criticized Shamir for leaking the accusations without showing him the evidence. ``I am already accused of selling Jerusalem without anyone showing me proof,'' he said on the radio before the two met. Weizman also alleged that other Labor Party leaders, including Peres and Rabin, were aware of his contacts with Palestinian leaders abroad via an Israeli Arab physician named Ahmed Tibi. ``Links with Tibi I had, the Shin Bet knew about it at least for a years and nobody has said anything until now,'' Weizman said. He added that on one occasion, Tibi phoned him from Tunis and at the same time Peres instructed Weizman on another line what kind of message to convey to Palestinian leaders there. ``He (Peres) told me `listen, tell those people to stop making a fuss, to accept the five points,''' a reference to a plan by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III to renew Middle East peace contacts, Weizman said. Weizman credited the conversations with bringing about indirect PLO agreement to Baker's ideas. ``I feel clean, that what I did benefited the peace process, that it brought acceptance by the PLO of the five points.''

DOC.HEAD: Workers Ready Space Shuttle for Monday Launch
DOC.TEXT: Workers switched Columbia's power back on Tuesday as they readied the space shuttle for launching Monday on the first of a record 10 missions planned in 1990. The spaceship had been dormant on launch pad 39A for more than two weeks as most of the Kennedy Space Center's 17,000 workers were off for the holidays.
