Liftoff had been scheduled for December but was put off because it was taking longer than expected to ready the launch pad, which has undergone a $50 million renovation since it was last used four years ago. Small crews remained on duty over Christmas and New Year's to monitor Columbia and to straighten out the pad problems. ``We're off to a good start in the new year; everything's looking good for a launch on Monday,'' said NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. Launch is scheduled for 8:06 a.m. EST Monday. During 10 days in space, Columbia's crew of five will deploy a Navy communications satellite and track down and retrieve a science satellite before it falls to Earth in March. The satellite has been orbiting for nearly six years. The launch delay increased NASA's 1990 shuttle launch schedule to 10, setting up its most ambitious year yet. The most shuttle launches in one year was nine. That was in 1985, the year before the Challenger explosion that put the program on hold for 32 months. Two missions were flown in 1988 after flights resumed. There were five in 1989 as NASA has been gradually building toward 12 a year in 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Couple Pleads Innocent in Five Slayings
DOC.TEXT: A farm couple pleaded innocent Tuesday to charges that they killed five transient farm workers to cover up a cattle-theft scheme in northwestern Missouri. Judge Kenneth Lewis of Livingston County Circuit Court denied bail for Ray Copeland, 75, and his wife, Faye, 68, who were indicted last week on five counts of first-degree murder. The state attorney general's office, which is assisting the county prosecutor, said the death penalty will be sought. Barbara Schenkenberg, public defender for Copeland, said she is considering seeking to have the location of the trial changed. The Copelands were arrested in October on charges that they conspired to steal cattle, but those charges were dropped after they were charged with murder. No bodies were found on their farm, but five were found on nearby farms where Copeland had worked. The victims had been shot in the head, investigators said. Prosecutors allege the couple used the men to write bad checks to buy cattle, then killed them to keep them from talking.

DOC.HEAD: R. Jess Brown, Civil Rights Lawyer, Dead at 77
DOC.TEXT: R. Jess Brown, a civil rights lawyer whose clients included James Meredith as well as a young black man who was lynched before he could be brought to trial on charges of raping a white woman, has died at 77. Brown, who died of cancer Sunday at Hinds General Hospital, took an early stand against segregationist Jim Crow laws and was credited in the 1950s with filing the first civil rights suit in Mississippi He was one of Meredith's lawyers in his successful bid to break the color barrier at University of Mississippi in 1962. Brown also represented Mack Charles Parker, who was accused of raping a white woman in 1959. Parker was lynched and thrown into the Pearl River after Brown raised the issue of jury discrimination prior to Parker's trial. A native of Muskogee, Okla., Brown attended Illinois State Unversity, Indiana University and the Texas Southern University law school. In the 1950s, Brown filed the first civil rights lawsuit in the state, on behalf of a minister in Jefferson Davis County challenging laws that made it impossible for blacks to vote. Brown in 1948 also sought equal salaries for black teachers in Jackson and worked with the NAACP Legal Defense Fund in fighting discrimination against blacks in transportation and other public accommodations in the 1960s. Survivors include his wife, Jether; a son and a daughter. Funeral services will be held Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: British Broadcasting Watchdog Fights Sex, Foul Language on Airwaves
DOC.TEXT: More than 25 years after launching her crusade to clean up television, Mary Whitehouse is still fighting to keep sex, violence and four-letter words off the air. Now, instead of being a lone voice, the 79-year-old woman has the backing of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Prince Charles and Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie. Her latest target is the British Broadcasting Corp.'s radio serialization of ``Lady Chatterley's Lover,'' which began Monday night on the popular program, ``A Book at Bedtime.'' The D.H. Lawrence novel is being read complete with sexually explicit passages and four-letter words. ``To give the status of `A Book at Bedtime' to `Lady Chatterley's Lover' and the language which was included in it seemed to us to be totally inappropriate and irresponsible,'' Mrs. Whitehouse said in an interview. ``And what I felt after listening to it last night reinforced what I said. It gave the four-letter word and other things a sort of status and respectibility. ... If they can do it ... then why shouldn't everyone else use the word all the time? It opens the door wider and wider.'' The BBC preceded its broadcast with a warning about the explicit content, but Mrs. Whitehouse said, ``I have no faith in these warnings. They attract the very people you feel they may be unhelpful to.'' Mrs. Whitehouse's reaction came as no surprise. She has been campaigning since 1964, when she founded her National Viewers and Listeners Association to fight violence on TV. It was the height of the permissive 1960s and Mrs. Whitehouse, then an art teacher, said she had begun to detect a great deal of sexual and moral confusion in the minds of her students over what they had seen on TV. Her main target was the publicly funded BBC. Nearly half a million people signed a petition in 1964 to close down the BBC, accusing it of broadcasting ``propaganda of disbelief, doubt and dirt.'' The BBC stayed on the air, but barred Mrs. Whitehouse from its programs for 15 years. Its director-general at the time, Sir Hugh Greene, said years later that her only contribution had been to raise the national level of intolerance. Mrs. Whitehouse wrote in her autobiography that Greene was ``above all responsible for the moral collapse of the '60s and '70s.'' Critics still accuse her of trying to be the nation's censor. ``Young people are not driven to excesses by explicit scenes of sex on the screen. She's a very sincere lady, but one of the most misguided,'' said Harry Turner, managing director of Television South West, an independent company. BBC controller Jonathan Powell said: ``Some of her views are quite sensible, for example, against the exploitation of violence in the name of entertainment. But her rejection of the portrayal of sexual relationships on TV is a more difficult matter.'' She has complained about the portrayal of homosexual relationships in the popular British soap opera ``EastEnders'' and sexually explicit scenes watched by a 10-year-old in ``The Singing Detective,'' a semiautobiographical series by British playwright Dennis Potter. Mrs. Whitehouse also objected to the following American films that were shown over Christmas and New Year's on British TV: _ ``Hollywood Shuffle'' about the difficulties of a black actor trying to make a living. ``The language was in our terms and American terms absolutely unbelievable. I couldn't repeat it and wouldn't repeat it,'' she said. _ ``The Verdict,'' starring Paul Newman, which she criticized for ``very bad language and violence.'' ``Legal Eagles,'' starring Debra Winger and Robert Redford. ``It's violent _ a man violently hits two women to the floor, one is knocked out,'' she said. _ ``Volunteers,'' which she said contained ``foul language, obscene language, blasphemy.'' Mrs. Whitehouse insists her only demand is that broadcasters fulfill their responsibility not to offend against good taste and decency or incite crime. ``It isn't that one's against sex, or showing on TV that men and women love each other, but it's the kind of close-up voyeurism that people are sick and tired of,'' she says. ``I don't want to open up someone else's bedroom doors and watch what's going on and I don't imagine the vast majority of other people do either. In any case, we all know what sex is about. We don't have to have it played out in front of our eyes.'' Mrs. Whitehouse may not be taken seriously by some, but her speeches draw capacity audiences. And as influential figures such as Mrs. Thatcher have spoken up against overly explicit TV, Mrs. Whitehouse has come closer to representing mainstream British values. In the United States, the battle over the content of TV shows has been waged by groups such as Christian Leaders for Responsible Television, a coalition of officials from 70 mainline and conservative Protestant denominations and more than 70 Roman Catholic bishops, as well as individuals such as Terry Rakolta, a Michigan woman who objected to sexual innuendo on programs such as Fox TV's comedy ``Married ... With Children.'' In 1988, in what was widely seen as a backlash against the permissive 1960s, the British government created the Broadcasting Standards Council, an agency to monitor ``sex and violence, taste and decency.'' Mrs. Whitehouse claims to have secured legislation to ban child pornography, control pornography in shop windows and on magazine covers, and classify videotape rentals. Last month her association finally succeeded in getting the government to introduce legislation to bring broadcasting under the obscenity laws. Mrs. Whitehouse's latest goal is to ensure that satellite TV, recently launched in Britain, does not beam in sexually explict programs from abroad.

DOC.HEAD: New Mayors Take Office in New York, Cleveland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, a0573, `Two mayors ...' with Masloff inaugurated in Pittsburgh.
DOC.TEXT: New mayors took office in New York and Cleveland, with David Dinkins, the first black chief executive of the nation's biggest city, downplaying racial and ethnic tensions stirred by his election and even the inaugural ceremony. Dinkins described his city as ``a gorgeous mosaic ... of race and religious faith, of national origin and sexual orientation _ of individuals whose families arrived yesterday and a generation ago, coming through Ellis Island, or Kennedy Airport, or on buses bound for the Port Authority (bus terminal).'' But the inaugural ceremony Monday demonstrated the divisions in the city the Democrat inherits: Jews objected to the presence of Archbishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa, and AIDS activists to the benediction by Cardinal John J. O'Connor, whom they accuse of hampering the fight against the disease. Also sworn in Monday were Michael White of Cleveland, Henry Spallone of Yonkers, N.Y., and John C. Daniels of New Haven, Conn. Sophie Masloff, the first woman elected mayor in Pittsburgh, took the oath of office today. Masloff, 72, the former council president, assumed office in 1988 after the death of Mayor Richard S. Caliguiri and won a full four-year term in November. Maynard H. Jackson was to be sworn in as mayor tonight in Atlanta. Dinkins succeeded Edward I. Koch, the outspoken three-term mayor he defeated in the Democratic primary in September. Dinkins went on to beat Republican Rudolph Giuliani, a former U.S. attorney, by a narrow margin. Dinkins, 62, just completed a term as Manhattan borough president. Dinkins said he wanted Nobel Peace Prize-winner Tutu and O'Connor at his inauguration because they are leaders and friends, even though, ``We're not in synch on all things.'' Many Jews object to Tutu's support for a Palestinian state, and AIDS activists oppose the Catholic church's condemnation of homosexuality and its opposition to some kinds of AIDS education. In Cleveland, former state Sen. Michael White pledged to fight crime, racism, homelessness, poor education and other city problems after taking the oath Monday to become Cleveland's 54th mayor. ``We see where ours has become a city where children go hungry, where sickness goes untreated and where whole families are left homeless. ... We watch our children grow through a school system that produces adults who in too many instances cannot read. ... And we see a city still haunted by the malignancy of racism,'' White said. White, 38, a Democrat, later paid tribute to his predecessor, Republican Mayor George Voinovich, and presented him with a key to the city. Voinovich became mayor in November 1979 and has announced plans to run for governor this year. In New Haven, former state Sen. John C. Daniels, the city's first black mayor, vowed during his inauguration speech to seek counsel from the ``maximum number'' of citizens. ``If there was ever a time when a small group of politicians and business leaders could sit in a room and determine what was best for the city, and where city resources should be spent, that time is certainly past,'' said Daniels, a 53-year-old Democrat who replaced Biaggio DiLieto as mayor. DiLieto, 67, who also is a Democrat, decided not to run for re-election after 10 years in office. Daniels is New Haven's 48th mayor. In Yonkers, Democrat-turned-Republican Henry Spallone stressed honesty and integrity in his inaugural speech. He offered conciliatory words on a federal housing desegregation plan that was key to his victory over one-term Mayor Nicholas Wasicsko, a Democrat. Spallone, 63, a former detective, was one of four City Council members who balked at implementing U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand's desegregation order. The four appealed a contempt citation to the U.S. Supreme Court, while Wasicsko supported the desegregation plan. ``We will abide by the decisions'' of the court, said Spallone, the city's 37th mayor. ``That is what law is about.''

DOC.HEAD: Body Taken from Crypt and Burned, Say Mystified Authorities
DOC.TEXT: A wooden coffin was dragged from a crypt and burned with the body still inside, police say. The door to the above-ground tomb was opened and the coffin, containing the body of a 65-year-old Jacksonville man, was pulled from the structure and set afire early Monday, police Detective Sgt. C.A. Shank. The body had been entombed at the city-owned H. Warren Smith Cemetery for only a few days. Shank said police didn't know if the burning was an act of vandalism, the work of some type of cult or an act aimed at the family of the dead man. ``We're keeping an open mind and looking at all possibilities,'' he said, adding that nothing found at the scene indicated any type of ritual. Several metal plates were torn from other crypts and some tombstones were toppled, he said. The body was taken to the Medical Examiner's office, Shank said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0562 to fix writethru sequence
Sinking Barge Rescued on the Monongahela
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with sinking barge rescued with no spill; PICKS UP 7th graf pvs, `The gasoline ...'
DOC.TEXT: A tugboat rescued a barge sinking in the Monongahela River with 400,000 gallons of fuel today, and crews drained the remaining gasoline from another barge that spilled up to 10,000 gallons. The sinking barge did not leak any of its gasoline and diesel cargo as it was pulled ashore today. It had rammed up against a lock and dam after breaking loose from its mooring Monday at Charleroi, 25 miles south of Pittsburgh. Tugboat operators today arrived to pump out river water that had seeped into the barge and freed it from the lock and dam about 40 minutes later. The two barges were among at least 50 to break loose Monday when rushing ice broke mooring ropes along a 40-mile stretch from Brownsville north to Pittsburgh. The Coast Guard and state agencies continued rounding up the barges. The leaking barge, owned by Gutman Oil Co. in Charleroi, hit the Monongahela Bridge and ruptured about 15 miles south of Pittsburgh, spilling gasoline Monday. The barge was pumped clean today of its remaining 360,000 gallons. Ms. Mallison said the spill did not affect area water supplies, and regional director of the Department of Environmental Resources, said the damage to the environment would be slight. The barge was tied up along the shore near New Eagle late in the afternoon Monday, but the swift current prevented a tug pushing two cleanup barges from reaching the site. The gasoline spill came nearly two years after a diesel fuel spill of between 750,000 and 1 million gallons in the Monongahela fouled the drinking water of Ohio River communities in three states. About 11,000 fish and 2,000 waterfowl were killed in the Jan. 2, 1988, spill, but researchers said the river's recovery was rapid and that the oil concentration at the bottom of the rivers is declining. ``The bottom line is the residual effects are not very significant at this time,'' said Edgar Berkey, president of the University of Pittsburgh's Center for Hazardous Materials Research. Several miles south of the leaking barge, about 25 coal barges broke loose Monday and piled up at the Maxwell Dam, where severe flooding resulting from a similar barge jam-up in 1985 damaged numerous homes. About 200 people temporarily evacuated their homes Monday near Maxwell, 30 miles south of Pittsburgh. A dozen barges also broke loose in Pittsburgh early Monday and floated into the Ohio River. Three became stuck underneath the historic Smithfield Street Bridge in Pittsburgh, and the span was temporarily closed to traffic.

DOC.HEAD: Realtors Report Improvement in Housing Affordability Index
DOC.TEXT: A typical American family's ability to buy a median-priced home improved in November, but many first-time homebuyers still were unable to afford starter-type houses, a trade group said Tuesday. The National Association of Realtors reported that its housing affordability index rose to 105.8 in November, meaning that a family with a median income of $33,482 had 105.8 percent of the income needed to buy a median-priced existing home costing $93,000. The index was the highest since February, when it registered 106.7. It was 105.5 in October. The median means that half the families earn more and half less, or that half of the homes sell for more and half for less. The increase in the November index was attributed to a declining mortgage interest rates and an increase in the median family income from $33,365 in October to $33,482 in November, the Realtors said. The association uses a composite rate reflecting both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages. By its calculation, rates fell from 10.16 percent in October to 10.12 percent the next month. ``These two factors offset a slight increase in the national median price, which rose from $92,600 to $93,000,'' it said. The changes increased the monthly principal and interest payment on a median home by $1, to $660 in November, which represents 23.6 percent of the median family's income. NAR President Norman D. Flynn said the drop in rates generally is having the most impact on middle-income buyers. ``We continue to see buyers taking advantage of favorable financing,'' Flynn said. ``The drop in rates generally is having the most impact in areas where housing is affordable for moderate-income buyers.'' But Realtors' chief economist John A. Tuccillo noted that many first-time buyers have insufficient income to make the transistion from renter to homeowner. The NAR's third-quarter index for first-time homebuyers showed that on a national basis, they had only 71 percent of the income needed to buy a typical starter home.

DOC.HEAD: New Year's Traffic Accidents Kill at Least 273
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATE with toll at 273 sted 272; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `A total ...'
DOC.TEXT: Traffic accidents nationwide claimed at least 273 lives over the long New Year's Day weekend. California recorded the most fatalities, 35, while seven states and the District of Columbia reported no fatal traffic accidents. A total of 317 people were killed in traffic accidents during the New Year's holiday last year, and the National Safety Council had estimated 250 to 350 would die this year. Alaska, Montana, New Hampshire, North Dakota, South Dakota, Vermont and Wyoming reported no fatalities. The counting period this year began at 6 p.m. local time Friday and ended at midnight local time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners Begin Leaving Cells Under Amnesty; Havels Blasts Communists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with thousands of West Germans cheering Havel, CORRECTS title of Czechoslovak justice official, writethru designation; picks up 16th pvs, `Out of...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PRA7
DOC.TEXT: About 20,000 inmates and detainees have begun leaving Czechoslovak prisons under the broadest amnesty in 40 years, officials said today. New President Vaclav Havel, himself imprisoned more than five years for his political beliefs, announced the amnesty on New Year's Day. Officials say it will set free about two-thirds of all prisoners and people awaiting trial _ except top Communists accused of abusing their power. According to Justice Ministry officials, there are 31,000 people in prisons and jails. The official CTK news agency quoted Justice Minister Dagmar Buresova as saying some 20,000 prisoners and detainees were being freed under the amnesty and other cases would be re-examined. The amnesty took effect immediately with the release of some prisoners and was to be completed by Jan. 21. It applies to all inmates except those imprisoned for murder, sex crimes or abuse of ``public authority.'' The highest-ranking former official to face that charge is ousted Prague Communist Party boss Miroslav Stepan, considered responsible for violent police handling of a peaceful student demonstration on Nov. 17. Havel's decree stipulates that people convicted of terrorism, murder, rape and sexual abuse also cannot be freed, but their sentences will be reduced by a year. Theoretically, that could result in the release of such criminals with a year or less remaining to their prison sentences. Sentences for other intentional acts will be reduced by at least two years, and for crimes out of negligence by at least three years. Havel also appointed a new prosecutor general. Czechoslovak television called it the broadest amnesty since the Communist takeover four decades ago. Before he stepped down Dec. 10, former Communist President Gustav Husak freed virtually all political prisoners, but opposition sources say at least six people are in jail on dubious espionage convictions. In his first speech as president, Havel fiercely attacked the toppled Communist regime, saying it ravaged the economy and environment. Havel reaffirmed his commitment to free elections and a free market, and urged the Dalai Lama and Pope John Paul II to visit. He called for full diplomatic ties with the Vatican and Israel. The once-banned playwright, elected by Parliament on Friday, flew to East Berlin today on his first trip abroad in two decades. He met with Communist Premier Hans Modrow and President Manfred Gerlach, who like Havel is a non-Communist who rose to power on a wave of reform sweeping Eastern Europe. Afterward, Havel gave hesitant endorsement to German reunification, saying a peaceful democracy ``can be as large as it wants.'' He then traveled to Munich, West Germany, later in the day to see Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Richard von Weizsaecker. Thousands of Bavarians cheered ``Vaclav! Vaclav!'' as he was driven through Munich. Kohl said Havel's rise to the presidency epitomized the changes that have led to a ``European Spring,'' a reference to the 1968 Prague Spring reform movement that was crushed by a Warsaw Pact invasion. On Monday, the vivid, straightforward language of Havel's speech contrasted with the bland style of his discredited predecessors. ``Out of gifted and sovereign people, the (Communist) regime made us little screws in a monstrously big, rattling and stinking machine. We have become morally sick,'' Havel said in the broadcast address. ``Our country does not flourish. ... we have the worst environment in Europe.'' Czechoslovakia was an economic power before World War II but slid into stagnation under 41 years of Communist rule. Pollution from the heavy industrial plants fostered by the Communists sickened the environment. ``We have to accept this legacy as something we have inflicted upon ourselves,'' he said. Havel urged the establishment of diplomatic ties with the Vatican and Israel. All Warsaw Pact nations except Romania cut ties with Israel after the 1967 Middle East War. Hungary, also in the grip of democratic change, was the first to renew full ties in September, and the Soviet Union and Poland renewed low-level ties in the last three years. Last month, Poland and Czechoslovakia said full ties with the Jewish state would be renewed in 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Militias Fight for South Lebanon Hills
DOC.TEXT: Rival Shiite Moslem militias fought for the hilly apple orchards of Kfar Hatta village Tuesday in their bloody war for supremacy in south Lebanon. Five people were reported killed and 18 wounded. Police said members of the two militias, Amal and Hezbollah, battled with tanks, rocket-propelled grenades and jeep-mounted 106mm recoilless rifles in the apple-growing region southeast of Sidon. They said Hezbollah, which is loyal to Iran, needed control of the hills to protect the flow of supplies from the Bekaa Valley to its bases in south Lebanon. Kfar Hatta lies just below mountain routes, controlled by Israeli troops and a predominantly Christian allied militia, that link Israel's ``security zone'' in south Lebanon to Jezzine, a Christian town east of Sidon. Tuesday's casualties raised the toll to 64 killed and 234 wounded since Dec. 13, when the latest fighting began between Hezbollah and Amal, a mainstream Shiite militia supported by Syria. Iranian spiritual leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei told visiting Lebanese Shiite clergymen in Tehran on Tuesday they should stop ``this fratricide,'' Tehran radio reported. ``We feel a great burden of responsibility for what is occurring among our Moslem children and these problems should be solved at the root,'' the radio quoted him as saying. A statement from Amal claimed its fighters repulsed a Hezbollah attack on the Kfar Hatta hills before dawn. ``The infiltrators, who came under cover of darkness, were forced to flee in chaos, leaving behind several dead on the battlefield,'' it said. Amal chief Nabih Berri appealed to Khamenei to stop Iranian arms deliveries to Hezbollah, his press office in Beirut reported. A Hezbollah statement blamed the fighting on Amal bombardment of its bases in Jbaa and Ein Bouswar south of Kfar Hatta. Each side accuses the other of collaborating with Israel and its surrogate militia, the South Lebanon Army. Atef Aoun, the Amal commander in south Lebanon, has claimed Iran paid $250,000 to Israel and the South Lebanon Army to let Hezbollah move reinforcements from the Bekaa to the apple region through militia lines near Jezzine. ``I have the evidence of the payment. I will make it public at the appropriate time,'' he said in a statement broadcast by several Beirut radio stations. Hezbollah statements have claimed Amal's aim was to expel pro-Iranian fundamentalists from all of south Lebanon and conclude a coexistence deal with Israel. Israel established the border zone in 1985, when it withdrew from a three-year occupation of Lebanon, as a buffer against guerrilla raids. The apple region faces the central sector of the zone, a strip 6 to 10 miles deep from Mediterranean coast 40 miles inland to the foothills of Mount Hermon. Police have cited the battle for control of the predominantly Shiite region as a major factor in a sharp decline of guerrilla attacks into the Israeli zone. Their records indicate a drop to 380 raids 1989 from 740 in 1987 and 780 in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Designer Patrick Kelly Dies in Paris
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with age, year of birth; Picks up 4th graf, `In 1972 ...'
DOC.TEXT: Patrick Kelly, the Mississippi-born designer whose witty fashions were worn by royalty and rock stars, has died in his adopted home of Paris, his company announced today. He was 35. Kelly, the only American ever to become a member of France's professional fashion organization, died Monday of bone marrow disease and a brain tumor at Paris' Hotel Dieu, said Martine Planterose, managing director of Patrick Kelly Boutique. Kelly was born in 1954 in Vicksburg, Miss., where his mother was a schoolteacher. In 1972, halfway through Jackson State University in Mississippi, he gave up studies for fashion. He prevailed on his aunt Bertha to teach him how to sew at a young age, and soon he was patching up clothes with whatever thread and even mismatched buttons were on hand. Craving big-city experience, he headed for Atlanta and got a job delivering used clothes. By chance, he met top model Pat Cleveland, who encouraged him to move to New York and then to Paris to pursue his career. In Paris, he first sold clothes in the street, specializing in tight dresses covered with buttons. His first collection, made on a portable sewing machine, was shown in Paris in 1985. At a 1987 interview, he wore clownlike bib overalls, neon orange basketball shoes and a red satin Chicago Bulls jacket. ``My clothes have a political-power message,'' he said then. ``I want 'em to make people happy.'' Bergdorf Goodman bought and displayed his 1985 collection, and Kelly went on to successes with a series of short, tight shift dresses decorated with bows, sequin designs and his trademark buttons. He became the only American ever to be a member of France's powerful Chambre Syndicale of Ready-to-Wear and Couture, the French professional fashion organization. In his spare time, he raced through the streets on a skateboard. His customers included the Princess of Wales, the actress Jane Seymour and the singers Madonna and Grace Jones. Survivors include his mother. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Ceausescus' Family-Planning Edicts Create Overburdened Orphanages
DOC.TEXT: Wailing infants compete for the attention of a single matron. Toddlers stand in their cribs, rocking from foot to foot, staring soundlessly ahead. They are some of Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu's youngest victims. The 800 orphaned or abandoned children live in Orphanage No. 1 _ Romania's largest _ an understaffed complex of seven aging buildings on the capital's north side. The oldest child is 3, the youngest a matter of days. The older children eat their lunch off tin plates, drink milk or juice from tin cups, and play in spartan rooms furnished with only a few plastic toys. None of these children know about Elena Ceausescu, her ideas on family planning or visions of increasing the population for Romania's ``Golden Era.'' The wife of the Communist dictator, who called herself ``the mother of the nation's children'' and who was executed with her husband on Dec. 25, personally supervised enforcement of Romania's family laws. The laws prohibited birth control, abortions and family planning information for women with fewer than five children. Mrs. Ceausescu envisioned Romania as a mighty state of 30 million people by the year 2000. ``The unhealthy and abandoned children living in this facility are the direct result of national policy,'' said Dr. Margareta Creteanu, the orphanage's chief medical officer. ``An ill woman could not have an abortion so many genetic illnesses were passed to the children,'' she said. She said about 40 of the children suffered from Down syndrome, genetic disorders or severe birth defects. ``Some parents don't want the children because they are ill. Some parents cannot take care of them,'' she said. ``Some of the other children were abandoned because their parents already have too many children, or because their mother was unwed and too young to care for her child.'' In 1987, Ceausescu ordered a freeze on adoptions by foreign citizens who had been paying thousands of dollars in fees and more under the table to get a child. Ms. Creteanu said there were 129 children at her orphanage whose paperwork had been completed, who were waiting only for a lifting of the freeze. Livia Mann, a Romanian emigre who lives in Portland, Ore., said she and her husband are childless and have been trying to win the freedom of their adopted 3-year-old daughter, Mihalache Georgiana, for 2{ years. The girl lives with Mrs. Mann's sister in Bucharest. The old government allowed them to take the child out of the orphanage, but not out of the country. ``We paid $1,400 in fees at first. But the government lawyer always told us there were more papers to sign. My husband had to come back to Romania twice every year to sign papers. Every time the lawyer wanted money, a color television or some other `present,''' she said. Mrs. Mann said the couple spent between $8,000 and $10,000 in their effort to get Mihalache Georgiana to the United States. ``Now the new government tells us too many things are going on and that this is not exactly an emergency,'' she said. ``I hope it will be very soon. But it will not be today or tommorrow. I hope it will be within four or five months.'' Without foreign adoption, most of the kids at Orphanage No. 1 face a childhood spent in state institutions. There is no shortage of children in the Romania the Ceausescus left behind. By the time they reach 4, the children at Orphanage No. 1 will have been sent to state residence schools, said Ms. Creteanu. At the orphanage, 180 people, including doctors, nurses and medical students, work around the clock to care for the children. The staff seems caring and efficient but overwhelmed by the numbers and the emotional needs of such young children. In the rooms of white cribs, some of the toddlers shout with glee at the sight of visitors. They hold out their arms, pleading to be picked up. Others stare blankly and rock slowly from side to side as they stand in their cribs. Dr. Horia Talfes, a volunteer at the orphanage in his spare time, laughs and plays briefly with a 3-year-old girl. He said the girl had been born premature and had required extensive medical care. ``What we need,'' he said, ``is specialized medicine for children and modern equipment. Ours is so antiquated. We have plenty of general medicines, but not enough of the kinds made specially for small children.'' Ms. Creteanu clung to the hope that Romania's revolution will make things better for its unwanted children. ``I think things will be better for the children and I think the number of children in the orphanages around the country will decrease,'' she said, noting the new government had already repealed the family laws. ``The new government has already said it will lift the restrictions on foreign adoption.''

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Secretary of State Leads Mission to Panama
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with State Dept., comment, other details
DOC.TEXT: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger was heading a high-level delegation that planned to fly to Panama late today for talks with President Guillermo Endara about U.S. aid and other issues, the State Department said. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said the purpose is to learn first-hand from the Panamanian leadership about their plans for economic recovery and to make recommendations to President Bush on ways in which the United States can help. Boucher left the impression that Eagleburger's mission, as presently planned, will not involve efforts to influence ongoing talks with the Vatican and Panamanian officials over the fate of ousted dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. The spokesman said contacts continue but he gave no details except to reaffirm that the administration wants Noriega sent to the United States to face drug-trafficking charges. Noriega has been staying at the Vatican embassy since he sought sanctuary there on Dec. 24, four days after American troops invaded Panama. Eagleburger is being accompanied by Deputy Treasury Secretary John Robson and a team of policy experts. They will confer on Wednesday with Endara, Panama's two vice presidents and other prominent Panamanians, including leaders of the country's business community. Among other subjects, they will discuss a dismantling of the sanctions imposed on Panama over the past two years as part of the U.S. campaign against Noriega. Of the estimated $370 million in Panamanian assets frozen in the United States, about $70 million has been returned to Panama since the invasion, Boucher said. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, flew to Panama early today to review U.S. military operations. Nunn was accompanied by Sen. John Warner, R-Va. On Thursday, House Majority leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., will lead a 30-member House delegation on a two-day trip to Panama City. An aide to Gephardt said the visit is not designed to evaluate or second guess the invasion but will be ``forward looking,'' aimed at what Congress will need to do to help rebuild Panama's economy.

DOC.HEAD: Black Students' 58 Percent Failure Rate Alarms Civic Leaders
DOC.TEXT: A dismal performance by blacks on high school exams has jolted communities into a search for remedies, with one newspaper calling for foreign aid to ensure that blacks are ready to govern after apartheid. ``Stop the rot,'' said a banner headline Tuesday in The Sowetan, the country's largest-selling daily aimed at black readers. Its editor, Aggrey Klaaste, wrote that foreign countries should consider a ``mini-Marshall Plan'' to ease a crisis that produced a 58 percent failure rate for black high school seniors. Other community leaders, while blaming the white-run government for the problem, said blacks must rely on themselves to make improvements. In Soweto, the largest black township, a parents' group announced that an emergency meeting on the school crisis would be held Sunday. Anti-apartheid activists and black civic leaders have complained for years about problems in segregated black schools, ranging from underfunding to overcrowding to classroom violence. But the sense of alarm intensified after the government announced last week that only 42 percent of black high school seniors had passed their standardized matriculation exams, the lowest pass rate since 1962. Of the 190,081 blacks who took the tests in November, 74,249 passed and 17,553 did well enough to qualify for automatic admission to universities. By contrast, more than 95 percent of white students passed the same set of tests, and more than 40 percent qualified for universities. The best performances among blacks were in rural areas generally insulated from the political unrest that has wracked urban townships since 1984. At high schools in Soweto, where 2.5 million blacks live, pass rates ranged from 14 percent to 29 percent. The Soweto Civic Association, headed by prominent anti-apartheid activists, issued a statement Monday blaming ``this tragedy'' on the government and the Department of Education and Training, which oversees black education. ``Thousands and thousands of children's lives have been maimed over the years by the policies of the government,'' the committee said. ``Their future as responsible parents and citizens of tomorrow have forever been destroyed.'' The central problem, said the committee, is that white officials ``refuse parents the right to take effective control of their children's education.'' The committee joined other anti-apartheid groups in suggesting that black pupils try to enroll at the nearest public school when the new academic year starts this month. This would mean black families who have moved into ``whites-only'' inner-city areas in defiance of residential segregation laws would present their children for admission at ``whites-only'' schools. Walter Sisulu, a senior leader of the African National Congress guerrilla movement freed in October after 26 years in prison, described the exam results as ``a blow to the community'' but reiterated his appeal for young blacks to pursue an education. ``We must persevere so that, at the end of the day, we have skilled people who are able to handle things when change comes,'' he said. Klaaste said the education crisis could affect the long-term prospects for blacks to gain voting rights and take partial or full control of the government. ``These expectations will be dashed, and even desperately-fought-for political solutions will come to naught if we do not stop the rot,'' Klaaste wrote. ``For its survival this country should be engaged in the biggest program in history to get blacks educated. And if the world is willing to help, money almost proportionate to a mini-Marshall plan should be poured into black education.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The court bout scheduled to begin Tuesday between comic Richard Belzer and wrestlers Hulk Hogan and Mr. T was called off before the combatants could make it into the ring. The $5 million lawsuit stemmed from a 1985 television encounter between the 150-pound Belzer and the 307-pound Hulkster which the comedian said left him unconscious. Jury selection was scheduled to start Tuesday in Manhattan, but Belzer's attorney said a settlement was reached ``in the last hour of the last working day of the year.'' Attorney Norman Roy Grutman said he was not free to disclose the terms. The action was against Hogan, wrestler-actor-personality Mr. T and World Wrestling Federation impresario Vince McMahon.

Oliver Stone, the director who won an Oscar for ``Platoon,'' and stayed with the Vietnam War in his new film ``Born on the Fourth of Jul,'' says it's time for him to move on. Making those two movies was ``cathartic to me,'' said Stone, a Vietnam combat veteran, ``and I felt a bit of an obligation to make them.'' Stone's next film will star Val Kilmer as the late rock icon Jim Morrison of the Doors, whom Stone described as the opposite of the hero of ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Vietnam vet Ron Kovic. ``The other side of the coin to Ron in the '60s was Jim Morrison,'' Stone said in an interview printed in Tuesday's New York Times. ``Morrison's father had been in the military, and Jim went exactly the other way. Ron was the good boy, and Jim Morrison was the bad boy. I can shed some light on that. There's a lot of the bad boy in me. ... I identify with Morrison. ``He was a shaman. He was a god for me, a Dionysian figure, a poet, a philosopher,'' Stone said. ``I'd like to bring his life out into the light.''

TV Guide magazine roasts Roseanne Barr, Geraldo Rivera and even itself, while retiring the venerable J. Fred Muggs moniker, in its annual tribute to television's silliest achievements. The awards were renamed ``Zap Awards'' after television remote-control devices, because the chimpanzee for whom the awards were previously named ``was getting long in the tooth,'' the magazine said in its Jan. 6 issue. Muggs was on the early ``Today'' shows when the late Dave Garroway was the host. Miss Barr and beau Tom Arnold won the ``Bottoms Up'' award for mooning fans at the Michigan-Iowa football game who asked to see tattoos on their derrieres. Rivera received the ``Bottomless Pit Award'' for his interview at a topless doughnut shop in Fort Collins, Colo. TV Guide's cover last year in which Oprah Winfrey's head was attached to Ann-Margret's body won one of three ``Phony Baloney Awards.'' The others went to Fox Broadcasting producer Larry Hovis for hiring actors in the ``Candid Camera''-type show, ``Totally Hidden Video,'' and to ABC's ``World News Tonight'' for simulating an alleged document switch between former U.S. diplomat Felix Bloch and a KGB agent. One of two ``Totally Outrageous Video Awards'' went to Cher for shooting her video, ``If I Could Turn Back Time'' aboard the USS Missouri clad in garter belt and body stocking. The second went to Zsa Zsa Gabor, whose celebrated cop-slapping trial was turned into a $9.95 home video. A ``Foot-in-Mouth Award'' went to CNN weather forecaster Flip Spiceland for his remark that ``women's logic is one of those contradictory terms, like military intelligence,'' which led his boss Ted Turner to bann ``free-standing commentaries'' on the network. The awards also poked fun at Donald Trump for lending his name to a bingo-type syndicated game show dubbed ``Trump Card,'' saying ``What do you get a man whose name is on everything?''

John Landis will direct the new HBO comedy series ``Dream On'' starring Brian Benben, according to the Hollywood Reporter. The show, expected to debut on the cable channel in mid-1990, features Benben in the role of Martin Tupper, a New York divorcee who views much of his life through the images of old TV movies and series. The series will focus on Tupper's relationship with his 10-year-old son, the Hollywood Reporter said Tuesday in disclosing the Landis-HBO deal. Landis directed ``National Lampoon's Animal House,'' ``Coming to America,'' ``Trading Places'' and the Michael Jackson ``Thriller'' video. He also directed the controversial segment from ``Twilight Zone: The Movie,'' in which actor Vic Morrow and two children were killed in a helicopter crash.

Charlton Heston and Vanessa Redgrave are at opposite ends of the political spectrum. But Heston still ranks Redgrave as the world's best actress. ``She does a wider stretch of parts and she takes more chances than any actress alive,'' Heston said on ``The Joan Rivers Show,'' taped Dec. 19 for Thursday broadcast. Heston said it's OK with him that Redgrave ``makes Jane Fonda look like Herbert Hoover.'' ``My political conservatism has gotten me some bad notices,'' he conceded, adding that he learned early in his career not to worry about critics. Heston named Ava Gardner, Jennifer Jones, Sophia Loren and Jean Simmons as the most glamorous actresses. Gardner and Jones ``are much better actresses than they think they are,'' said Heston, who has worked with both.

DOC.HEAD: Grandiose Palace Speaks of Ceausescu's Ambition
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The sprawling Palace of the Republic and the nearby Boulevard of the Victory of Socialism that dominate downtown Bucharest will serve as a lasting reminder of the ambition of their late dictator. The immense palace complex, still unfinished after six years of hard work, was conceived by Nicolae Ceausescu as an administrative center housing the country's parliament, government and the headquarters of the now-defunct Communist Party. The building was also to include a large presidential suite from which the Ceausescu family could exercise absolute control over the state. A balcony was designed so Ceausescu, during government-organized rallies, could address crowds gathered on a vast plateau in front of the palace. Officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said below the palace there is a bunker outfitted like a war room with sophisticated commands and a network of tunnels leading for miles up to a lake on Bucharest's north side. More than 15,000 workers toiled around-the-clock on the site, said Col. Constantin Luta, a senior construction engineer, who led journalists on a tour of the heavily guarded complex. ``The pressure was hard all the time to complete the works, but it was beyond human ability to finish on deadline,'' he said. Luta added that although no specific completion date had been set, Ceausescu wanted to move in by 1991. He said it was impossible to estimate the cost of the complex, which is 75 percent completed, because no financial records are available. Informed sources, however, said the Palace of the Republic and its surroundings have cost about $800 million since 1984, when work on the project started. Luta said it was also impossible to estimate how much marble and gold leaf was used to line the palace's walls and ceilings. Although the 258-foot-tall and 720-foot-wide building is generally complete on the outside, much remains to be done on the inside. The interior is littered with scaffolding, marble slabs and cement bags. The interior, clearly intended to awe visitors by its size and opulence, was to be finished in marble and wood paneling, with gold leaf inlay in the baroque plaster decorations on the ceilings. ``The amount of work was staggering and no matter how many workers were assigned to the project we were always told we were late,'' Luta said. Before the work began, housing had to be provided for about 50,000 people from old residential section of the capital that was razed to make way for the palace and the avenue that leads to it. Many of the bulldozed prewar buildings and several of the century-old 13 churches demolished in the process were of ``historical value,'' Luta said. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, took ``a great personal interest in the project'' and visited the site at least once a week. They interfered in its ``classical palace design'' so often that ``it no longer bears any resemblance'' to the original, Luta said. He added that ``their demands were extremely difficult to fulfill because they did not understand anything about architecture, and they caused enormous delays and headaches for the builders.'' The boulevard of the Victory of Socialism, a 3-mile-long avenue that opens on the palace square, is almost equally striking. The 450-foot-wide avenue is lined with dozens of high-rise apartment blocks decorated with arches, turrets, Greek columns, and marble-fronted balconies. Apartments there were reserved for high-ranking Communist and secret police. Many of the sand-colored buildings are finished but none is occupied in accordance with Ceausescu's master plan that tenants should move in all at once upon completion of the palace. Elaborate wrought iron street lamps, marble fountains and small plazas line the avenue. Behind it are the narrow, muddy streets of the old town, where stores are dark and shoppers crowd to buy meat, cheese, butter and other basic staples in short supply for years until Ceausecu was toppled Dec. 22. Officials said a special commission will be formed to decide what to do with the ``monstrosity,'' as residents call the palace. Luta said that because of the money spent on it, ``there is no question of tearing it down. ``To demolish it now would be a greater crime than those crimes of Ceausescu,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Victim Visits Music Star Michael Jackson
DOC.TEXT: AIDS victim Ryan White spent the New Year's holiday with pop singer Michael Jackson, resting and watching movies at Jackson's California ranch, White's mother said Tuesday. Jeanne White said her son had been at Jackson's ranch in Santa Barbara, Calif., since Thursday and was expected to return to Cicero later Tuesday. ``They've had a really good time,'' Mrs. White said in a telephone interview. She said the trip had taken her son's mind off of his most recent physical ailments. White, who turned 18 last month, has recently suffered staph infections, a low-platelet count, a hernia, a protein deficiency and fluid retention. A hemophiliac, White contracted acquired immune deficiency syndrome from a blood transfusion. Four years ago, he was barred from attending Western Middle School near Kokomo by officials who feared the AIDS could be transmitted to other students. A judge ruled that Ryan should be allowed to attend school because the disease can not be transmitted through casual contact. Since then, the Whites have moved to Cicero, where Ryan attends Hamilton Heights High School. White was hospitalized before Christmas to alleviate swelling in his abdomen caused by fluid retention. During the two-day hospital stay he lost four pounds of fluid, his mother said. ``It made him more comfortable.'' Mrs. White said his treatments include drinking a protein supplement five times a day.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Orders Special Elections for Texas District Judges
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today ordered that Texas' nine biggest counties hold special judicial elections in May under a set-up less likely to dilute Hispanics' voting power. The nine counties must elect their judges from districts rather than from each county as a whole, said U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton. Bunton's order is based in part on a settlement negotiated by Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox and the League of United Latin American Citizens, which successfully sued the state on grounds that countywide systems of electing state judges diluted minority voting strength. Bunton's plan will affect only 1990 elections and is designed to be replaced with a new, permanent set-up to be drafted by the Legislature. The judge, citing numerous delays by the governor and Legislature in dealing with the issue, said he was forced to go ahead and fashion an interim election plan ``that law, equity and justice require.'' Bunton today said the judges will be elected to four-year terms from districts based on existing political divisions such as legislative districts, justice of the peace precincts and county commissioner precincts. The elections will take place in Bexar, Dallas, Harris, Tarrant, Travis, Jefferson, Lubbock, Ector and Midland counties. Bunton ruled in November that the countywide method of electing judges violates the U.S. Voting Rights Act. At the time, non-Hispanic whites held 155 of the 172 district judgeships in the nine counties. The judge's interim plan will affect 115 state District Court seats in the nine counties. Gov. Bill Clements has said he wants to call a special legislative session in the spring to reform judicial elections. Clements, however, favors appointing judges, then voting only on whether to retain them. LULAC has objected to an appointment system, saying it would continue to shut out minorities. LULAC, three black former district judges from Dallas and a handful of other groups filed the lawsuit in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Again Says No To Talks with the PLO
An AP Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Israel's latest political crisis centered on the question of whether it was ready to talk with the PLO. The answer was no, even though behind-the-scenes contacts have become almost commonplace. The issue was Science Minister Ezer Weizman's alleged dealings with Yasser Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir shocked the nation Sunday by saying he was firing Weizman, a member of the center-left Labor Party. Shamir, who leads the right-wing Likud bloc, accused the former defense minister of going behind his back to meet with ``Israel's most dangerous enemies.'' Worse, he said, Weizman gave Arafat advice on how to block Israeli attempts to keep the PLO out of proposed peace negotiations. Weizman contended his contacts with Palestinians contributed to peace. He said the Shin Bet security service, which reports to Shamir, was aware of them. Shimon Peres, vice premier and leader of the Labor Party, threatened to leave the ``national unity'' coalition and bring down the year-old government. In the end, however, Labor shied away from forcing elections and a compromise was reached: Weizman will retain his portfolio, but be removed from the policy-making inner Cabinet for at least 18 months. Although he withdrew the decision to dismiss Weizman, Shamir appeared to strengthen his position by showing he had strong support, even in the Labor Party, for continuing the policy of not dealing with the PLO. Labor's failure to take up the challenge disappointed Israeli doves and prominent Palestinians working for Palestinian-Israeli talks and for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``This government is unable to take decisive steps for peace,'' said Faisal Husseini, a pro-PLO activist. ``Israel needs elections more than the Palestinians.'' Amnon Rubinstein, a liberal legislator and head of the Shinui Party, said the government should ``come out and tell the truth that there is no chance for peace without talking to the PLO.'' The Weizman affair illustrates the increasing difficulty of maintaining credibility for the official policy of refusing all dealings with the PLO, which Israel views as a terror organization. Weizman, who advocates direct talks with the PLO, accused Shamir and even his own Labor party leaders of hypocrisy. He said Shamir and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, a ranking Labor member, had sounded out peace proposals with Palestinians from the occupied lands who acted as direct conduits to the PLO. Weizman said the Shin Bet not only knew of his PLO contacts, but even offered advice on what to say. Peres listened in on one telephone call to an Arab contact in Tunis, where the PLO has its headquarters, and passed on a message urging PLO acceptance of U.S. plans for Israeli-Palestinian negotiations, Weizman said. He also argued that the government was indirectly negotiating with the PLO via the United States and Egypt. There is a long history of secret dealings with the PLO, including prisoner exchanges and the permission Rabin gave recently for a missing soldier's father to visit PLO headquarters seeking information. Recently, contacts have become more public. Liberal politicians, academics and journalists have joined with PLO members in large European forums also attended by others, thus skirting a 1986 law against unauthorized contact. Despite all this, Abie Nathan, Israel's leading peace activist, is serving a six-month jail term on conviction of having met with Arafat in Tunis. An editorial in the conservative daily Maariv suggested the contradictory policy may have to end. ``Is there a need to talk to the PLO?'' it asked. ``Not a few people think there is, and many say so openly. Not a few people think there will not be any way to avoid such talks, but prefer to be carried along by their forelocks rather than take the initiative.''
Nicolas B. Tatro has been Associated Press bureau chief in Israel since 1983 and also has reported from Egypt, Iran and Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Orr Will Run Again in Nebraska
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Kay Orr said today she will seek a second four-year term in 1990. Mrs. Orr marked her 51st birthday by announcing the decision, which she said was made after consulting her family. The move came despite newspaper polls that have shown high disapproval ratings for the governor. ``Because we love this state very much ... I indeed intend to run for governor,'' Mrs. Orr said. Friends and family sang happy birthday to the governor and presented her with a cake that said, ``4 More for Orr.'' Lee Atwater, GOP national chairman, has said the party has made Mrs. Orr's re-election a priority. Four Democrats have said they will enter the race, including Lincoln Mayor Bill Harris and Bill Hoppner, a former aide to Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb. Mrs. Orr defeated Democrat Helen Boosalis in 1986 in the nation's first gubernatorial race in which both major party nominees were women. She was Nebraska's first woman governor and the first GOP woman elected governor in the nation. The business community has hailed a major tax revision program she pushed through the Legislature as providing tax incentives that have bolstered the economy. Critics have said the tax breaks will haunt the state's fiscal future. A revision of the individual income tax system caused a political blowup when, despite Mrs. Orr's protestations to the contrary, it turned out to be a substantial tax increase. Mrs. Orr acknowledged a mistake was made and supported enactment of legislation intended to rectify the situation. A series of court decisions involving the state's controversial systems for taxing property, and a furor over locating a low-level nuclear waste site in Nebraska, confronted Mrs. Orr with more difficulty. She has taken a strong anti-abortion position and has acknowledged that abortion will be an issue in the 1990 campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Deep Woods `Candid Camera' Documents Wildlife
DOC.TEXT: Using a series of 40 hidden cameras, researchers have found a larger population of grizzly bears than previously believed inhabiting a section of national forest in northwestern Montana. The project was the first to use hidden cameras in a systematic fashion to document animals, and identified dozens of other species near the South Fork of the Flathead River, said Tim Manley, a research assistant for the South Fork Grizzly Study. ``We've gotten pictures of just about every kind of wildlife,'' said Manley, a biologist who invented the camera system. ``We've gotten deer, elk, moose, grizzlies, black bears, mountain lions, coyotes, wolverines, fishers, pine martens. We've gotten a couple of archery hunters who waved at us.'' South Fork researchers began experimenting with photography in 1988, and last summer used the 40 cameras. The camera method also spread in 1989 to grizzly research in Montana's Yaak region and Washington's Cascade Range. Another Montana biologist is using the cameras to study white-tail deer, and the U.S. Forest Service is interested in using them to document wolves. Such cameras also are being used to study an endangered nesting bird in Hawaii and black bears in Taiwan, Manley told the Spokesman-Review and Chronicle newspapers in Spokane last week. The 10-year state and federal project in Montana, in its second year, covers 320 square miles east of Kalispell and south of Glacier National Park. Its main goal is to find accurate methods of counting grizzlies in the dense and mountainous terrain of the northern Continental Divide, said Rick Mace of the Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife and Parks. A reliable count is important because grizzlies are a threatened species and land-use decisions depend on their populations. Early on, researchers identified 22 grizzlies by catching them in snare traps and fitting them with radio collars and ear streamers. But the cameras enabled researchers to identify seven other grizzlies in a way that eliminated the need for human contact. ``We identified individuals we had no idea were around,'' Mace said. Researchers said it's too early in study to make any conclusions about the grizzly population and the effect that would have on management of the area. Each of the 35mm automatic cameras are housed in steel boxes along with infrared motion sensors from burglar alarms and 12-volt batteries. The bears are attracted by hanging bait, usually road-kill deer, placed out of their reach. When they trip the motion sensor, the camera takes a shot. The time and date of the pictures shows up on each frame. Researchers found that 75 percent of the grizzly population in the area is female, and they have confirmed seven births in the past two years. However, of the 22 bears collared by researchers, six are known to have died.

DOC.HEAD: Small Quake Rattles Palm Springs
DOC.TEXT: A small quake rattled this desert community Tuesday, but officials say there were no reports of injury or damage. ``It came on with a good stiff initial shock and a few tremors right after that,'' said police Sgt. Steve Harrison. The 3.5-magnitude earthquake struck at 1:51 a.m. and was centered about 19 miles southwest of the resort, said Robert Finn, California Institute of Technology spokesman in Pasadena. The quake was felt in Perris, Hemet and other neighboring communities. Palm Springs is about 110 miles east of Los Angeles. ``We've had a couple of calls about it,'' Harrison said. ``One person said water sloshed out of their swimming pool.'' The quake was an aftershock of a Dec. 2 temblor that measured 4.3 on the Richter scale and shook the Coachella Valley and Palm Springs. A previous aftershock measuring 3.4 was recorded Dec. 21. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Police in Small Illinois Town Keep Busy Writing Thousands of Tickets
DOC.TEXT: Keep an eye on the speedometer when driving through this village _ or be prepared to reach for your wallet and join thousands of people ticketed in 1989. National City, with just 70 residents, has 12 officers to patrol the one-mile stretch of Illinois Route 3 that bisects the village. Last year, National City police wrote more than 5,000 traffic tickets and earned more than $122,000 for the village coffers _ one-quarter of the overall budget. The 35 mph limit is posted on at least eight signs on each side of the road, Assistant Police Chief Jim Farrell said Tuesday. ``You can hardly call it a speed trap, because the speed limit is well posted,'' he said. The Illinois Department of Transportation estimates 8,700 cars daily pass through National City, which is across the Mississippi River from St. Louis and home to the National Stockyards Co. livestock complex and related businesses. ``It's sort of like a racetrack out there at times,'' Farrell said. ``We try to keep the traffic speed down and keep somebody from getting killed.'' Police began closely monitoring the highway five or six years ago after residents complained about the number of accidents, Farrell said. County records show National City police wrote 5,091 traffic tickets from Jan. 1 through Dec. 28, 1989. Most drivers were ticketed for speeding, although some were cited for multiple violations. Those citations accounted for nearly 8.5 percent of the 60,000 moving-violation traffic tickets issued last year in St. Clair County, which has a population of 265,000, said Barney Metz, county court clerk. State Police Capt. Bobby Henry, area commander, said he was surprised by the high number of tickets issued in National City. ``That's not a negative comment,'' he said. ``For a small department, they're obviously out there working to get that many citations.'' Route 3 has a 30 mph limit as it enters National City from East St. Louis. The speed limit then goes up to 35 mph, and stays there as the road leaves National City. Police Chief Edward Daubach said tickets aren't issued unless drivers exceed the limit by at least 10 mph. Village Clerk Kathryn Kuecker said National City's annual budget is about $400,000 to $450,000, with most of the revenue coming from property and sales taxes. St. Clair County is one of the state's most impoverished. ``We really don't know how much would come in in a given year'' from traffic tickets, Kuecker said Tuesday. However, the minimum penalty for a moving violation in Illinois is $50, of which local authorities keep $24; that would mean National City received more than $122,000 from the tickets issued last year. The village, with five full-time and seven part-time officers, is patrolled at all times by two officers in one car who use a radar detector. Officers have heard their share of excuses from speeders, Farrell said. ``We had one guy tell us he was in a hurry to go home and take his medicine,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Maynard Jackson Goes to Work _ Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inauguration scheduled for 7 p.m. EST; lead planned.
DOC.TEXT: A familiar face returns to the mayor's office when Maynard Jackson, mayor from 1974-82, reports for term No. 3. Jackson's third term begins at his Tuesday night inauguration at the Atlanta Civic Center. Among those expected to attend were the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown, NAACP executive director Benjamin Hooks and Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga. Security was tightened in light of death threats associated with the recent string of mail bombings which federal officials said may have been carried out by a group with a grudge against the NAACP and the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Jackson, who was Atlanta's first black mayor, has promised changes for ``the greatest city in the world, bar none.'' The new mayor, who enjoyed strong campaign support from neighborhood activists, has said he will try to kill two controversial road projects: the Presidential Parkway, from downtown to the Druid Hills neighborhood; and the Georgia 400 extension, from Interstate 285 north of the city through the affluent Buckhead neighborhood to Interstate 85. Jackson faces the pressing problems of crime, drugs and housing the homeless _ problems also seen as critical by business leaders. His most immediate problem may be money. Finance officers, under the outgoing administration of Andrew Young, have called for a property tax increase; Jackson says he doesn't want one. Jackson, 51, served the maximum two consecutive terms allowed under the city charter and was succeeded by Young in 1982. Young, having served two terms, is running for governor this year. During his eight years out of office, Jackson practiced law, but remained a popular political figure. His chief challenger in the October mayor's race, Fulton County Commission Chairman Michael L. Lomax, dropped out of the race last summer after polls showed him far behind.

DOC.HEAD: Add Another 7 Inches on Matterhorn
DOC.TEXT: The Matterhorn is about 7 inches higher than the 14,776 feet, 2 inches reported on most maps, the Italian Geographic Military Institute announced Tuesday. The institute revised the Matterhorn's height to 14,776 feet, 9 inches, citing a recent survey that used U.S. satellites. The earlier measurement of the Matterhorn, or Monte Cervino, had been made in 1930 by an Italian-Swiss commission. The Matterhorn, one of the most difficult but most popular peaks in Europe for climbers, straddles the Italian-Swiss border. The Italian military authority in 1988 had said Mont Blanc, Europe's highest peak, was slightly shorter than previously believed.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Dissident Fang Lizhi to Be Allowed to Leave China
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials reached an agreement last month with China that will allow fugitive dissident Fang Lizhi to leave the U.S. Embassy in Beijing and go into exile this month, a magazine reported Tuesday. White House officials, however, dismissed the report and said there had been no new developments in the six-month impasse. ``He's still in the embassy,'' spokesman Roman Popadiuk said. The Chinese-language Pai Shing magazine reported that the United States and China reached an ``understanding'' on resolving the dispute over Fang when U.S. National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft visited Beijing in December. The magazine, a leading publication in Hong Kong reporting on Chinese affairs, did not reveal any source for the article. There was no immediate comment from the Chinese government. Fang, an astrophysicist who was China's most outspoken dissident in recent years, sought refuge in the embassy with his wife in June when authorities issued a warrant for their arrests as part of the crackdown on dissent. The United States' decision to shelter Fang has been a significant factor in strained relations between the two countries since the military suppression of the spring pro-democracy movement in China. Pai Shing said Fang would leave the embassy before Jan. 27, the start of the Chinese Lunar New Year, and would most likely travel to Australia, although Italy was also a possibility, Pai Shing reported. Senior leader Deng Xiaoping approved the plan after the Scowcroft visit, the magazine said. Chinese leaders recently have appeared to ease their stand on Fang, saying the two countries needed to find a way to end the impasse. Communist Party head Jiang Zemin said the deadlock could be resolved only if Fang showed a ``very good repentant attitude,'' but did not explain precisely what he meant.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Attends Brother-in-Law's Funeral
DOC.TEXT: President Bush made a quick trip to the Boston area Tuesday for the funeral of his brother-in-law, while protesters outside displayed a banner asking, ``Will you attend the funerals in Panama?'' As a handful of people demonstrated, Bush's motorcade arrived at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in the Boston suburb of Lincoln. He entered the church by a side door out of the line of sight of the sign carriers. Bush and his wife Barbara made the brief trip for the funeral of his sister Nancy's husband, businessman Alexander Ellis, who was a good friend of the president's. Ellis, 67, died Friday following hospitalization for a stroke and intestinal surgery. A decorated World War II veteran, he had been an insurance executive and was active in GOP party politics. He and Mrs. Ellis often spent time with the Bushes at the family vacation compound in Kennebunkport, Maine, during the summers. Like Bush, Ellis attended Yale University. In the Army, he received a Purple Heart for fighting in the Battle of the Bulge with the 82nd Airborne Division. The funeral service was led by Cardinal Bernard Law of Boston. Outside, Jonathan Franklin said the protesters thought it important to demonstrate at the funeral because Bush ``hasn't mentioned anything about civilians that died'' as a result of the Dec. 20 strike into Panama by U.S. forces. He and his brother, Christopher, both students, and their father, Cambridge attorney Tom Franklin, stood quietly with their banner, along with two other sign carriers. Estimates of the number of civilians who lost their lives during the fighting range up to some 300. ``Maybe in the future they can think of a way to get rid of a dictator so civilians won't get killed,'' Jonathan Franklin said.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Gives Cautious Approval to German Unity
LaserPhotos BER1,3,5
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia, who visited both Germanys on Tuesday, said their reunification appears inevitable and can be a benefit to Europe rather than a threat. ``It is more important that Germany maintains a democratic consciousness ... than whether it has 60 million or 70 million people,'' he said. ``As long as it remains peaceful and democratic, it can be as large as it wants.'' After short meetings with heads of state, government leaders and opposition groups, Havel pledged solidarity with the pro-democracy movement in East Germany. His cautious comments on reunification reflected European fears of once more having such a powerhouse in the heart of the continent, while acknowledging unity is a positive consequence of political reform. After five hours in East Germany, including a ceremonial crossing through the Berlin Wall near the Brandenburg Gate, Havel flew to Munich, West Germany, for talks with President Richard von Weizsaecker and Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Thousands of Bavarians cheered as Havel was driven through the city. They shouted ``Vaclav! Vaclav!'' and ``Freedom for East Europe! Bravo Vaclav!'' At a joint news conference with the dissident playwright who became Czechoslovakia's president, Weizsaecker said the visit to Munich proved ``we have come clean with our past.'' It was in Munich, on Sept. 30, 1938, that the pact was signed permitting Hitler to annex the Sudetenland of Czechoslovakia. Bitterness between Czechoslovaks and Germans deepened after the war, when Czechoslovakia took the area back and expelled ethnic Germans. Weizsaecker promised ``every support'' from West Germany for Czechoslovakia, particulary to clean up the environment. In an address to his nation on Monday, Havel described his nation's ecological condition as the worst in Europe. Kohl said Havel's rise to the presidency epitomized the changes of the ``European Spring,'' a reference to the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' reforms in Czechoslovakia that were crushed by a Soviet-led invasion. He said Havel would make an official visit to Bonn, the West German capital, in late February or early March. West Germany has led efforts to aid Eastern Europe in its transition from stagnant economies and centralized Communist governments, seeking to form a bridge between East and West that would allow German reunification. Kohl has made his goal of reunification clear. Weizsaecker, who has broad public support in both countries, has been mentioned as possible head of state for an interim confederation. During Kohl's visit to Dresden in December, the two German governments agreed to pursue closer official ties in what they call a ``treaty community.'' West German conservatives like Kohl view such relationship as a step toward reunification. Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany, on the other hand, has said it preserves the sovereignty and separateness of his socialist state. Modrow said Tuesday he took Havel's decision to visit both Germanys on his first official trip abroad as a sign that Czechoslovakia wanted to ``underscore the two-state nature of Germany.'' After his talks in East Berlin with Modrow and Manfred Gerlach, the Liberal Democrat who is East Germany's president, Havel acknowledged that reunification probably is a fact of European life. He said Germany's neighbors should try to make the process orderly, not to prevent it. ``The emotions on both sides must be reined in'' before formal steps toward reunification are taken, he told a news conference. ``It must be on the basis of negotiations, not wild.'' He made the comments, including those about a reunited Germany's size and democratic commitment, in response to questions. A single Germany would have about 76 million people and an even stronger economy than that of West Germany, already the most powerful in Europe. Havel said Germans must ease fear of a mighty, unified German state, but called reunification a likely and positive consequence of improving relations among European states. Germans present ``the most extraordinary importance for the future of Europe,'' Havel said, and have been both the cause and the cure of Europe's major ills throughout this century. The trip Tuesday was Havel's first venture outside his own country in two decades. Just four months ago, when the Communists still ruled, he was refused permission to visit West Germany to collect a peace prize at the Frankfurt international book fair. He had refused to leave on other occasions, for fear he would not be allowed to return.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Anthony Thornton doesn't mind if people think he's a little backward. He set the Guinness world record for walking backward a year ago and this year surpassed it. Thornton, 39, eclipsed his Guinness world record of walking backward for 89.77 miles in 23 hours and 48 minutes shortly before noon Monday. ``I was born to walk,'' Thornton said as he finished his backward walk back and forth across the Washington Avenue bridge at the University of Minnesota. This time, Thornton walked 95.7 miles in 23 hours and 45 minutes. He began walking at 12:30 p.m. Sunday and completed the walk at 12:15 p.m. Monday. Thornton said the night was uneventful for him. However, he said his wife, Judy, walking forward, tripped and hurt her arm. As he broke the record, Thornton said he was tired and his knees ached. Thornton, who delivers newspapers and does odd jobs for a living, said he started walking as a young man, hiking the 154 miles to visit his brother in Houston from his home in a small Louisiana town. He came to Minnesota in 1976, walking from Atlanta.

Emmanuel College got a twin bill in response to its offer of a free scholarship to the first baby girl born in Boston in 1990. The women's college doubled its offer when twin girls were the first girls born in the city. And far from chagrined at having to promise twice as much money, school officials say they were prepared for triplets. Karen Pizarro delivered Jessica and Jennifer Rios by Caesarean section at Brigham and Women's Hospital at 12 a.m. and 12:01 a.m. on New Year's Day. ``We think it's wonderful,'' said Margaret Spillane, senior director of administration at the Roman Catholic liberal arts college. The 1,100-student Emmanuel, located in the Fenway section of Boston, had guaranteed a four-year scholarship to the first female born in a Boston hospital to a Boston couple in 1990. The scholarship is contingent on the recipient meeting educational requirements. Pizarro, 21, said she and the twins' father, Pedro Rios, were familiar with Emmanuel, where his brother's wife is a student. However, neither was aware of the school's scholarship offer. ``We're just so happy,'' Pizarro said Monday. ``I am happy to have my daughters, about the scholarships, about just about everything.'' Pizarro lives in the city's Dorchester section with Rios and her two other children, 3-year-old Ibiana and 15-month-old Katherine.
