Spillane estimated the value of the two scholarships when the twins enter college in 2008 at more than $200,000. Students at Emmanuel paid $8,910 in tuition last year. The twin girls, premature and each weighing slightly more than 3 pounds, were placed in the hospital's neonatal intensive care unit, according to hospital spokeswoman Louise Homer, who said the babies were both doing fine.

DOC.HEAD: DC-10 Makes Emergency Landing Because of Smoke in Cockpit
DOC.TEXT: A DC-10 jetliner made an emergency landing Tuesday after the pilot reported smoke in the cockpit, and nine people suffered minor injuries which passengers said mostly resulted from shoving at emergency exits. The American Airlines jet with 247 passengers aboard and a crew of 10 landed at Baltimore-Washington International Airport shortly after midnight, said Linda Greene, a spokeswoman for the Maryland Aviation Administration, which operates the airport. Flight 240 was bound from Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport to New York's LaGuardia Airport when the pilot reported smoke in the cockpit, the airline said. The flight originated in Acapulco, Mexico. Greene said no flames were seen aboard the plane. Passengers reported seeing light smoke wafting through the rear of the cabin. Susan Kelly, a spokeswoman for the Fort Worth-based carrier, said she could not confirm those reports. Nine people were treated at North Arundel Hospital in Glen Burnie for sprains, aches and bruises, said Kevin Murnane, hospital spokesman. Passengers said many of the injuries were caused when passengers pushed and shoved at two emergency exit doors in the middle of the aircraft where chutes opened properly but were reportedly caught on the wings. Passenger Thomas Glanville, 31, of New York City, said he saw very light smoke coming from the rear of the aircraft. He said he was standing in line when it was learned that the chutes had wrapped around the wings. ``It was then that several people became panicky and didn't know what to do or where to go,'' Glanville said. According to Kelly, maintenance personnel at the airport said the plane's chutes worked properly and that people often suffer ankle and back sprains from the sharp drop down an emergency chute. She said the wind caused the chutes to stick straight out, and prevented them from dropping to the ground immediately. The cause of the smoke was under investigation. The plane was to be flown to Chicago for further checking, Kelly said. John Nouaisser, 34, of Paris, said he was seated near the rear of the plane when he smelled smoke and saw it wafting around the lights. He said a flight attendant told him food was burning in the galley and everything was under control. ``It smelled like burning wires, not burning food,'' said Nouaisser. Passengers spent the night at an airport hotel. They were flown Tuesday morning to New York on another American Airlines plane, Greene said.

DOC.HEAD: Levin Calls for U.S. Troop Reduction in Europe
DOC.TEXT: The threat to Western Europe posed by the Warsaw Pact is so diminished that U.S. troops stationed there should be reduced by as much as a third, Sen. Carl Levin said Tuesday. Levin said the first phase of negotiations with the Soviet Union aimed at cutting the 300,000 U.S. troops in Western Europe to 275,000 should be followed immediately with a second round of negotiations to reduce force levels to about 200,000. ``We should make clear we are going to stay there for the forseeable future, but that we want to do so at significantly reduced numbers,'' said Levin. ``The winds of freedom have blown down the Berlin Wall and they are also blowing apart the Warsaw Pact,'' he said. The Michigan Democrat, who is chairman of the Senate Armed forces subcommittee on conventional forces and alliance defense, commented after returning from a visit to Czechoslovakia, and East and West Berlin. He said he was told by East German Defense Minister Theodore Hoffman that his country's 1990 defense budget will be cut by about 20 percent, significantly deeper than the 10 percent reduction already announced. A significant reduction in U.S. force levels in Western Europe can now be made safely because the forces of the Warsaw Pact can no longer be relied on to join the Soviet Union in a cohesive attack on the West, Levin said. ``The Warsaw Pact threat is literally unraveling,'' he said, referring to the rapid rise of anti-communist, pro-democracy movements in Poland, Hungary, East Germany, Czecholovakia, Bulgaria and Romania. Levin said reductions in U.S. forces in Europe should be coupled with large cuts in the U.S. defense budget and the savings applied to waging the war on drugs, reducing the budget deficit, improving education, cleaning up the environment and aiding the newly emerging non-communist government in Eastern Europe to prosper. ``We can safely do it and we must do it,'' Levin said of the proposed defense spending cuts. ``We must shift resources in a significant way.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the chairman of the Armed Services Committee, also has called for restructuring and cutting back U.S. forces in Western Europe. Levin noted that the first phase of conventional arms reduction talks should be completed in June. ``We should not stop there,'' he said. ``The important point is that the new talks begin immediately so that the first phase is not seen as any kind of ending but as a beginning.''

DOC.HEAD: Romania Joins Security Council
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Romania joined the Security Council on Tuesday, and a senior Romanian diplomat said it was his goal to give his nation more credibility in the international forum. ``We respect our Warsaw Treaty obligations, but we will energetically pursue consensus solutions sought by the international community on major regional conflicts,'' said the senior diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We want to cooperate.'' ``Romania's position could possibly coincide with the position of the United States on some issues in the General Assembly,'' the diplomat said. ``We aim to give Romania more international credibility and it will have more believability as it follows the democratic process,'' he said. Romania took its seat with four other nations on the 15-nation Security Council, the most powerful U.N. body. The move came as part of a routine rotation. Romania replaces Yugoslavia, a founding member of the movement professing non-alignment with either superpower. In other new positions on the council, Cuba replaced Brazil, the Ivory Coast replaced Algeria, Democratic Yemen replaced Nepal and Zaire replaced Senegal. The Security Council has five permanent members with veto power: the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union. It has 10 other non-permanent members serving two-year terms on a rotating basis representing various regions. The other members of the council are Canada, Colombia, Ethiopia, Finland and Malaysia. U.S. officials said they expected the balance on the council to be roughly the same as in the past two years. They indicated they expected Cuba and probably Yemen to be strongly anti-U.S., but Romania would be open in its relations with the West. Romanian officials noted that before the Romanian revolution, the government of Nicolae Ceausescu had opposed the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1978. It also had refused to sever links with China in the 1960s. Romania also refused to allow Warsaw Pact troops to be stationed on its soil and had maintained ties with Israel, although relations were severed by the Soviet Union in 1967 during the Middle East War. The Romanian Mission to the United Nations recently tore down all photographs of deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and threw out his books. The country also has removed the Communist emblem from its flag and has changed its name to Romania, from the Socialist Republic of Romania.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Resumes with Fewer Defendants
DOC.TEXT: Trial resumes Wednesday in the case of 20 of 23 men accused of drug smuggling as a result of the same investigation that indicted deposed Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega. U.S. District Judge John Shaw acquitted three defendants during a 2{-week holiday recess. Shaw also dismissed some of the charges against five of the remaining 20 defendants, citing a lack of evidence. The case originally accused 170 people of smuggling more than 250 tons of drugs into the United States. About two dozen defendants are scheduled to go on trial next month in Lafayette, about 60 miles west of Baton Rouge, and several others have pleaded guilty. The judge acquitted Robert Mann, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who set up a banking channel in the Turks and Caicos Islands; John Ferris, a former Teamster official from Detroit, who helped look for a ship used to carry marijuana from Panama; and Ralph Henry Clark, of Pittsburgh, who drove a truckload of marijuana. Each of the three said he was unaware he was dealing with drugs or drug smugglers. Clark had been jailed since September 1988. The judge also acquitted Jorge Martinez of Miami, described by one witness as the man who introduced Kalish to intermediaries of Noriega, of all but one of 16 counts against him. And Shaw threw out about half of the 10 or more charges against four others defendants. The remaining 15, including former Detroit Teamster organizer Larry McHenry, continue to face all counts filed against them. Most of the defendants allegedly were truck drivers or boat captains for the ring, or allegedly supervised crews that unloaded marijuana or cocaine. The defense will open its case when the trial resumes. The 73 prosecution witnesses who testified in the first six weeks of the trial included alleged ringleader Stephen Michael Kalish, the government's star witness who is serving time as a repeat drug offender in Florida. Kalish said he had given Noriega a $300,000 ``present'' for helping arrange a Panamanian banking network to launder drug profits. He said the network he set up with Noriega laundered $50 million to $100 million a month for the Medellin drug cartel. The defendants allegedly were part of a ring that imported 48,000 pounds of marijuana into North Carolina in 1982, nearly 300,000 pounds of marijuana into Louisiana in 1983 and plotted to move nearly 1 million pounds of marijuana into Missouri in 1984. Kalish's 1984 arrest stymied the last plot, prosecutors contend. Trial is scheduled Feb. 12 for about two dozen people accused of more serious involvement, including Harold ``Doc'' McGhee, manager of the rock groups Bon Jovi, Skid Row and the Scorpions. Kalish identified McGhee, who is serving a suspended sentence after pleading guilty to importing marijuana in U.S. District Court in North Carolina, as the link between the smugglers and a Colombian drug supplier.

DOC.HEAD: Flights Divert By Alleged Gunfire
DOC.TEXT: Several flights at San Francisco International Airport were diverted away from a runway near the long-term parking lot Tuesday after a man allegedly fired gunshots in the air, officials said. The man, who may have lived with his family in a motor home on the lot, was taken into custody by airport police, airport spokesman Ron Wilson said. No one was injured and no property was damaged, said Wilson. ``Apparently family members are living in these motor homes, which we just found out about,'' Wilson said. ``The area was surrounded by the airport police. ... At this point they have not found a firearm, but we did have some witnesses who said they saw a rifle or a shotgun type weapon.'' The long-term lot was closed briefly, but operations at the United Airlines terminal nearby were not affected, Wilson said. The few flights that were supposed to use runway 28 near the lot were diverted to runways farther away.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Resume Deliberations After Holiday Break
DOC.TEXT: Jurors deliberating in the longest trial in U.S. history returned from a two-week holiday vacation Tuesday and began working to reach verdicts in the McMartin preschool molestation trial. The panelists are deciding whether Raymond Buckey, 31, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, are guilty or innocent of charges they molested children at their family-owned McMartin Pre-School in Manhattan Beach. They are charged with 65 counts of molestation and conspiracy. Before leaving for the holiday break, jurors turned in sealed verdicts on 26 charges. Superior Court Judge William Pounders, who worried aloud about letting the jurors take the break, said he was relieved all 12 panelists had returned safely. The 2{-year-old trial reached the deliberation stage with no alternate jurors left to fill in for a juror who might fall ill. If even one juror should bow out now, the case would end in a mistrial. The panelists were smiling as they trooped into their deliberation room. Jurors spent a month-and-a-half in deliberations before vacation. Pounders, who initially planned to disclose verdicts piecemeal as they came in, said Tuesday he would wait as long as possible to unseal the verdicts. He said he would open the envelopes early only if there was imminent danger that one juror might drop out or if it appeared that deliberations were getting bogged down. The verdicts are not final until they are read in court with all 12 jurors confirming their votes. The McMartin case dates to 1983 when reports surfaced that children might have been molested at the prestigious nursery school. Seven teachers including Buckey, his mother, grandmother and sister, ultimately were arrested. In 1986, after an 18-month preliminary hearing, District Attorney Ira Reiner dismissed charges against five defendants, saying there was insufficient evidence. Buckey and his mother were left to face drastically reduced charges in a trial that opened with jury selection in April 1987. Testimony began that July. Six alternate jurors originally were chosen, but illnesses and job conflicts caused by the trial's duration exhausted the supply of alternates and left only the minimum 12 jurors required for verdicts.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Vatican Diplomat Assigned to Help Resolve Noriega Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``Berloco, a ...'' to CORRECT age to 48, sted 41.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican has assigned a senior diplomat specializing in Latin America to help resolve the stalemate over Gen. Manuel Noriega's refuge at the Vatican embassy in Panama, officials said Tuesday. Monsignor Giacinto Berloco has been sent to Panama City to ``give a hand'' to the papal nuncio, or Vatican ambassador, in the negotiations over Noriega's fate, said Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro. Navarro declined to give any details of Berloco's role or the status of negotiations involving the Vatican, the United States and the U.S.-installed Panamanian government. Noriega took refuge in the Vatican mission on Dec. 24, four days after U.S. troops invaded Panama to try to capture him and bring him to the United States for trial on drug trafficking charges. The Vatican has said it is trying to convince Noriega to leave the mission on his own but can not turn him over directly to the U.S. troops surrounding the embassy. Berloco, a 48-year-old Italian, is an official in the Vatican's Secretariat of State, the Holy See's highest administrative body. He works in the foreign relations section as a diplomatic adviser on Latin America. Berloco entered Vatican service in 1972 and served in embassies in Costa Rica, The Netherlands and Spain. He was posted to the Secretariat of State in Rome in 1986 with responsibility for Latin American countries including Colombia, Cuba, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala and Nicaragua. ``He was the obvious choice to go down there (to Panama),'' said a Vatican official who knows Berloco. ``He's the one following the region and knows the situation.'' A Rome diplomatic source familiar with Berloco agreed he was a natural choice. ``You need someone with knowledge and skill,'' the source said. ``He has both.'' The Vatican official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Berloco could have an advantage coming from outside. ``He would have clear instructions (from Vatican decision-makers) and he can afford to be much calmer,'' the official said. Berloco will work with the papal nuncio, Jose Sebastian Laboa, who the Vatican says autonomously decided to take in Noriega on grounds that the move would help end the fighting in Panama. With the option of Noriega being given exile in a third country apparently diminishing, negotiations reportedly are focusing on getting him to surrender to the new Panamanian government. The Vatican says that under international law its embassy can only give up Noriega to Panama, not a third country to which the mission is not accredited. The impasse has been complicated by the apparent split among Panamanian leaders over whether he should be prosecuted in Panama or the United States. Attorney General Rogelio Cruz said he was preparing to file murder charges in Panama against Noriega, but President Guillermo Endara said the country does not have the means to try him. The Vatican official suggested the best solution might be for the United States to offer the legal and security support to the Panamanians so they can give him a fair trial at home. ``This problem could have been resolved in any other country because they would have their own government,'' the official said. ``But in Panama there is no government.''

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Raises Food Prices, Communist-Backed Union Critical
With AM-Havel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The non-Communist government raised prices of bread, sugar and other staples Tuesday in the latest moves in a radical program intended to transform Poland's economy to capitalism. But some workers, who average $37 a month in salaries, questioned whether they could endure the program. The Communist-backed trade union denounced the changes. The increases came one day after the government quadrupled electricity rates and doubled the price of gasoline, postal services and bus fares. The price of flour rose 20 percent, sugar about 25 percent and bread more than 50 percent. The price of high quality ham, a favorite cut in Poland, nearly doubled from 90 cents to $1.70 a pound. The food prices are expected to increase from 25 percent to 50 percent each month. In the past, steep food prices have triggered unrest. ``I don't know how I am going to make it. I guess I will have to work harder, but even then the prices still keep going up,'' said a teacher in Warsaw. There were short lines at many gas stations Tuesday as people drove on tanks filled before the price increases or switched to public transportation. ``The cars are just trickling in, but they will be back. People aren't going to stop driving just because prices go up,'' said a gasoline station attendant in central Warsaw. The new economic program calls for strict wage controls in order to check 900 percent inflation and transform the centrally planned economy to capitalism. The Communist-backed OPZZ trade union attacked the program, saying the public had not been consulted and was insufficiently informed about the changes. The OPZZ said it had submitted a list of questions to the government concerning the supply of consumer goods, social services and income target production. The OPZZ, a harsh critic of the Solidarity-led government, was once the only sanctioned trade union in Poland. It lost thousands of members after Solidarity was legalized in April 1989. The exchange rate of the currency, the zloty, was stable with the dollar Tuesday as the official rate corresponded to the black market rate for the first time in memory. The government hopes to achieve complete convertibility of the zloty by having the official and black market rates converge. The National Bank of Poland has set the rate at 9,500 zlotys to the dollar. Grzegorz Wojtkowicz, a vice-president at the National Bank of Poland, told the Zycie Warszawy newspaper Tuesday that the government was determined to defend the new rate, which resulted from a 38 percent devaluation announced last week. Government officials hope Western credits and loans to a special currency stabilization fund as well as Poland's own modest hard currency reserves will be sufficient to support the currency. The economic program, developed by Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, has the support of many Western goverments, the World Bank and officials of the European Economic Community. Balcerowicz has anticipated in coming months but stressed the increases were needed to halt Poland's 900 percent inflation to end its economic decline under more than four decades of Communist rule. In August, Solidarity activist Tadeusz Mazowiecki became prime minister, the first non-Communist head of a government in Eastern Europe. Since then, democratic reforms have swept the East bloc, and non-Communists have been installed as presidents in Czechoslovakia and East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: US Envoys To Meet With Endara, Discuss Aid
With AM-Panama Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The State Department's second-ranking official was sent to Panama on Tuesday for talks with President Guillermo Endara on ways for the United States to help recovery from two years of steep economic decline, officials said. Meanwhile, the White House announced that veteran diplomat Deane Hinton, a leading State Department expert on Central America, will replace Arthur Davis, a political appointee, as U.S. ambassador to Panama. Amid the diplomatic activity, the administration remained silent on the status of talks concerning Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who spent a ninth day at the Vatican Embassy in Panama City. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher was asked repeatedly by reporters at a briefing whether Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger might take part in negotiations concerning Noriega during his visit to Panama City. Boucher declined to answer directly, saying he would rather list the deputy secretary's full schedule of other activities ``and leave that to explain what Mr. Eagleburger is doing.'' At the same time, Roman Catholic officials in Rome said the Vatican was sending a senior diplomat specializing in Latin America, Monsignor Giacinto Berlocoto, to Panama City to ``give a hand'' to the Vatican ambassador in the negotiations over Noriega's fate. Boucher would say only that discussions were continuing and that the administration remained committed to bringing Noriega to the United States to face drug trafficking charges. In another development, the Organization of American States has agreed to accept the credentials of the Endara government's nominee as OAS ambassador, Lawrence Chewning Fabrega. The OAS had refused to seat Chewning when it met shortly after the U.S. military strike last month, but the envoy said Tuesday that the organization had little choice but to recognize that the new government is in effective control of the country. At the State Department, Boucher said the purpose of Eagleburger's visit was to learn first hand from the Panamanian leadership about their plans for economic recovery and to make recommendations to President Bush on ways in which the United States can help. Eagleburger was being accompanied by Deputy Treasury Secretary John Robson and a team of policy experts. The technical members of the team will remain in Panama for a week to continue the economic discussions. Eagleburger and his colleagues will confer on Wednesday with Endara, Panama's two vice presidents and other prominent Panamanians, including leaders of the country's business community. The Panamanian economy has been wracked not only by the heavy fighting that took place after the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion but also by U.S. economic sanctions, dating back almost two years, which were part of the U.S. campaign against Noriega. Of an estimated $370 million in Panamanian assets frozen in the United States, about $70 million has been returned to Panama since the invasion, Boucher said. Among other sanctions, the United States barred imports of Panamanian sugar and prohibited Panamanian participation in programs designed to enhance the country's exports to the United States. Panama also had been dropped from a program to encourage U.S. investment there. U.S. aid to Panama was suspended in 1987 and all aid personnel were withdrawn late that year. The new ambassador-designate, Hinton, 66, is currently ambassador to Costa Rica, having served in the same post in El Salvador from 1981-83. His nomination was interpreted by U.S. officials as evidence of the importance the administration attaches to rebuilding U.S. relations with Panama. Davis, the current ambassador to Panama, previously served as ambassador to Paraguay. He was pulled out of Panama last May after Noriega annulled the returns of the presidential election. He went back immediately after the U.S. military intervention. On Thursday, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., will lead a 30-member house delegation on a two-day trip to Panama City. An aide said the visit is not designed to evaluate or second guess the invasion but will be ``forward looking,'' aimed at what Congress will need to do to help rebuild Panama's economy. Sens. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and John Warner, R-Va., flew to Panama early Tuesday to review U.S. military operations. Nunn and Warner will meet with U.S. military officers, American diplomats, members of the new Panamanian government and officials of the Panama Canal Co., a Nunn spokesman said. Warner is a former secretary of the Navy and the Armed Services Committee's senior Republican member. Earlier, there was a visit by Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee and chairman of the Veterans Affairs Committee, and Rep. John P. Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House defense appropriations subcommittee.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor with AIDS Absent as Proceedings in Lawsuit Begin
DOC.TEXT: Trial proceedings began Tuesday in the lawsuit of a doctor who claims she contracted AIDS when she pricked her finger with a contaminated needle while working at a city hospital. While Dr. Veronica Prego plans to testify despite her illness, she did not attend jury selection, which began Tuesday afternoon. Reporters were barred. ``There was no need to put her through this stress. She will be here when the trial opens,'' said Prego's lawyer, Diane Wilner. Prego was a 25-year-old medical school graduate seven years ago when, she says, she was accidentally stuck by an AIDS-infected needle. Prego has sued the Kings County Hospital and its parent agency, the city Health and Hospital Corp. Also named in the lawsuit are the city and two doctors. According to her $175 million negligence lawsuit, Prego was working under a licensed physician and was cleaning up after an intern when she reached into a tangle of gauze and bed linens in which the intern had left a bloody needle. Two years ago she was diagnosed as having AIDS. The HHC, which operates the city's hospitals, disputes Prego's version of the events, but refused to discuss specifics of the case. The trial judge, State Supreme Court Justice Aaron D. Bernstein said he believed potential jurors might be reluctant to answer sensitive and somewhat personal questions about AIDS if journalists were present.

DOC.HEAD: Five Injured as Police, Moslems Clash in Militant Hotbed
DOC.TEXT: Five Moslem militants were injured in clashes Tuesday with police after trying to take part in an unauthorized anti-government demonstration, a senior security official said. Maj. Gen. Hassan Abeido, security chief of Assiut Province, said the fracas broke out when about 130 Moslem fundamentalists tried to leave a mosque that was surrounded by police and march downtown for the rally. Police, forced to use tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, took 30 people into custody, Abeido said. The 30 face charges of resisting authorities, illegal possesion of arms and unlawful assembly, he said. It was the second incident in Assiut, a hotbed of militant activity, in as many months. Prosecutors charged 78 Moslem militant students with anti-government activity but ordered the release of 82 others arrested during a December riot and shootout with police in Assiut. Unauthorized public gatherings and demonstrations are banned throughout Egypt under an emergency law in effect since Moslem fundamentlists assassinated President Anwar Sadat on Oct. 6, 1981. Assiut, 238 miles south of Cairo, has been a center of militancy since Moslem extremists of a group called Jihad attacked security offices and police stations two days after Sadat's assassination. More than 80 people, mostly policemen, were killed. Since then, militant university students have clashed with police and also attacked colleagues for organizing mixed-sex parties and excursions that they consider contrary to Islamic teachings.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Conservtive Politician Dies
DOC.TEXT: Conservative politician Evanghelos Averof-Tositsas, who was instrumental in forging an agreement that gave Cyprus its independence, died Tuesday of a heart ailment at the age of 80. Averof, who died at Apollonion hospital, was one of Greece's longest-serving lawmakers. He had served in every Parliament since he was first elected on the Liberal Party ticket in 1946. In 1956, he was returned to Parliament as a candidate with the right wing National Radical Union Party newly founded by former premier and president Constantine Caramanlis. The party was disbanded when the military seized power in 1967 and reborn in 1974 as the center-right New Democracy when the military- backed regime collapsed. As foreign minister in 1959, he was instrumental in forging an agreement together with his opposites from Turkey and Britain that gave the Mediterranean island of Cyprus its independence a year later. Averof was last returned to the 300-member Parliament in November's general election and was made honorary president of New Democracy in recognition of his contribution to the party. A graduate of Athens and Lausanne Universities, Averof had written political studies and several plays.

DOC.HEAD: State to Allow Students to Use Calculators on Math Regents Exams
DOC.TEXT: Students will be allowed to use calculators next year for the first time on their math Regents exams, a state Education Department official said Tuesday. ``It's an everyday situation where people have them, they're going to use them and we're just going to acknowledge that,'' said Fred Paul, head of the department's mathematics bureau. Calculators are already allowed to check figuring on science Regents examinations, designed for college-bound high school students. Math students have long been permitted to use slide rules. Paul insisted the calculators won't be that much of an advantage for students, since most of the Regents test questions involve problem-solving. Students will still be required to show their work involved in reaching an answer, he said. Students can use them to check addition, subtraction, multiplication and division, he said. Calculators still won't be allowed for basic math proficiency tests at all grade levels, he said. Those are areas in which students taking Regents exams have already demonstrated their skills, he said. The National Council of Teachers of Mathematics has endorsed the use of calculators for math classes and tests at all school levels, according to a spokeswoman for the Reston, Va.-based organization. Calculators allow students to concentrate on the problem-solving process rather than on the calculations involved, the council said. ``While we don't have an official position, I'm sure our members who are math teachers are supportive of the position. It's never come up as an issue,'' said Robert Rice, spokesman for New York State United Teachers, the state's largest teachers union. School districts will decide whether to provide calculators for students who can't afford their own, Paul said. Only calculators _ available for as little as $5 _ will be allowed in the Regents exam, he said. More complex machines could give some students an unfair advantage, he said. Calculators will first be allowed on the June 1991 math exams, Paul said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Reports 60 Ceausescu Allies Imprisoned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to include Tanjug report about Ceausescu burial; picks up 6th `About 40'
DOC.TEXT: The interim government said Tuesday it had imprisoned about 60 of former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's closest associates and would punish ``all evildoers from the old regime.'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Constanin Girbea said judgment also would follow for ``all members of the Ceausescu family'' and the Defense Ministry would announce further details of punishments. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were convicted of genocide and other ``grave crimes'' against Romania and executed Dec. 25. Whether or where they were buried has not been disclosed, but the official Yugoslav news agency Tanjug quoted Girbea as saying they were ``probably buried on the spot.'' Girbea told a news conference all executive members of the Communist Party Politburo were in prison. ``I estimate there are about 60 ... all close colleagues of Ceausescu,'' he said. ``All evildoers from the old regime will be brought to justice.'' About 40 Ceausescu relatives are thought to have occupied ranking government posts before the popular revolt that ended Ceausescu's 24-year rule. The Ceausescus' youngest son, Nicu, and only daughter, Zoia, were captured in the early days of the violent two-week uprising that claimed thousands of lives. Girbea spoke to reporters hours after the National Salvation Front leadership announced the death of interim Deputy Foreign Minister Corneliu Bogdan. Bogdan, 68, died of a stroke late Monday, said government member Sergiu Nicolaescu, who described Romania's former ambassador to the United States as ``a man of honor and a very close friend.'' Bogdan had been one of several spokesmen for the interim government that took over after Ceausescu fled his presidential palace on Dec. 22. He served as ambassador in the United States from 1969 through 1977, then returned to Bucharest and later was named to a foreign ministry post involving Western Hemisphere relations, said his stepdaughter, Svetlana Hoge, who lives in Washington. She said there was friction between Bogdan and the Ceausescu government, and that Bogdan left the ministry and was placed under what amounted to house arrest. He was allowed to travel to Washington in 1988 on a fellowship and remained in the United States until a month ago, Mrs. Hoge said. In another development, a member of the National Salvation Front and a principal architect of the revolution, Silviu Brucan, announced his organization would probably field its own candidates for elections in April. The front originally had said it would not post candidates for the elections and Brucan did not explain the change of policy in his televised speech late Monday. Bucharest was calm Tuesday. There were no reports of sniper fire or clashes between the army and members of Ceausescu's hated Securitate police, which was officially disbanded Monday. Hundreds of armed secret police agents were still believed at large. The number of people killed in the uprising that toppled Ceausescu was still unclear. A spokesman for the International Red Cross in Geneva, Juerg Bischof, said initial estimates that at one point reached 80,000 were ``far too high.'' But the spokesman offered no total. Western diplomats in Bucharest estimate that 7,000 to 10,000 people have died. According to a videotape of Ceausescu's trial, the prosecution charged him with the death of ``more than 64,000 victims'' during his 24-year rule. In his New Year's address, interim President Ion Iliescu announced his government's first major changes to the most-hated legacies of Ceausescu's rule. The changes announced Monday included abolition of the death penalty, re-establishment of private property and the opening of borders to former exiles. On Tuesday, the Romanian news agency Agerpres was renamed Rompres. It was the latest organization to change its name to distance itself from Ceausescu's despotic reign.

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Tank Explosion Kills Worker
DOC.TEXT: A gasoline tank exploded as a worker was dismantling it with an acetylene torch Tuesday, killing the man, authorities said. ``The explosion could be heard a mile or two away,'' police Detective Michael Culat said. The 2,000-gallon steel tank exploded outside the Antioch Water and Sewer Building, when the man, employed by a plumbing contractor, applied the acetylene torch to it, Culat said. ``The explosion propelled him backwards about 25 feet'' and he hit the building and landed about 25 feet from the wall. Culat said a preliminary investigation indicated that the explosion was caused by the ignition of fumes from in the tank. Only the tank caught fire, Culat said. The explosion sent a piece of the tank crashing into a storage shed on the grounds and causing $1,000 worth of damage. The tank had just been removed from an underground storage area and emptied, Culat said.

DOC.HEAD: Famed American Clothes Designer Dies in Paris
DOC.TEXT: Patrick Kelly, the Mississippi-born designer whose bright, sassy and feminine styles adorned the Princess of Wales, Bette Davis and Madonna, died in a Paris hospital, his company said Tuesday. He was 35. Martine Planterose, managing director of Kelly's business, said he died Monday at Hotel Dieu hospital of bone marrow disease and a brain tumor. Kelly was the first and only American ever to become a member of the powerful Chambre Syndicale of Ready-to-Wear and Couture, the French professional fashion organization. His fitted, feminine styles with signature touches like buttons or bows all over, billiard-ball decor, casual bandanas, attracted attention ever since he came to Paris in the late 1970s. Since 1987, Kelly was backed by Warnaco, the American company that manufactures for names like Geoffrey Beene and Dior. His clothes have sold at Saks, Bergdorf Goodman, Martha's and elswhere in the United States and at the posh ready-to-wear Victoire store in Paris. Newsweek magazine described the laid-back American a ``down-home Christian Lacroix.'' Kelly was born Sept. 24, 1954, in Vicksburg, Miss., where his mother was a schoolteacher. Dressed in outsized overalls, day-glo running shoes, T-shirts and engineers' caps, he hardly looked the part of a typical Parisian courtier. But he always loved women's clothes, ever since he admired the Sunday-best dresses worn by the ladies of the Vicksburg Baptist Church. At a young age, he prevailed on the family seamstress, his aunt Bertha, to teach him how to sew, and soon he was patching up clothes with whatever thread or mismatched buttons were at hand. Craving big-city experience, he headed for Atlanta at age 18 and got a job delivering used clothes. By chance he met top model Pat Cleveland, who encouraged him to move up and out in fashion _ first to New York, then to Paris. By 1979, he was broke, but he accepted a one-way ticket to Paris where he lived with a 6-foot-2 model named Kim and sewed like a demon. Using borrowed sewing machines, he ran up to 100 outfits a day using any fabric he could get his hands on. His first were sold at the Flea Market or right off the fence around the church of St.-Germain-des-Pres _ the only showplaces he could find. The avant-garde bought his slightly funky, fun outfits, and in 1985 the shop Victoire ordered a few models. He began to show on his own during the ready-to-wear collections week, and his shows were a hit _ accompanied by foot-tapping jazz or revival music. Then Warnaco offered its backing in 1987. Kelly was able to renovate an ancient building in the old Marais quarter and move into a colorful shop and atelier there. His clothes caught the eye of the fussy and discriminating Chambre Syndicale, which in 1988 unanimously elected him a member of the ready-to-wear branch. Of its 44 members at the time, Kelly was the only American, and there were only 10 foreigners altogether. Not only the gimmicks sold Kelly's clothes. They were well-fitted, well-made and the collections were versatile, usually offering everything from sexy, sparkly strapless sheaths for disco-dancers to more casual pantsuits, dressy coats and suits, with great attention to fabric and detail. ``You can learn from everybody of all ages,'' he told The Associated Press in an interview last year. ``I saw a lot of old ladies at the flea market in leopard coats, so I thought, `I gotta have spots,' and brought out a line of animal prints in my latest collection.'' His famous clients come in all sizes and shapes _ Madonna, rock singer Grace Jones, the Princess of Wales, Regine the nightclub queen, and opera singer Jessye Norman. One of his favorite clients and friends was Bette Davis, for whom he lovingly turned out a batch of fried chicken during one of her trips to Paris. He said he was proud that his clothes suited women with ``fuller figures, like my own mother. As for sexy clothes, it's all in your mind.'' Beloved by the jet set and others, Kelly was invariably surrounded by friends in his shop or apartment. His laid-back ways, generosity and funny fractured French endeared him even to the French, who can be stuffy about foreigners who massacre their language. Ms. Planterose said the Patrick Kelly Boutique's showroom would probably be kept going, at least for a while, as an exhibition of his art and work. No funeral plans were announced.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Propose Cuts in Home Energy Aid to Poor
With AM-Bush-Congress Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's new budget will propose slashing by one-fourth a program that helps the poor pay their home heating bills, congressional sources said Tuesday. The Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program, which is budgeted for $1.39 billion this year, would receive $1.05 billion in the spending plan Bush will present to Congress later this month, the sources said. That is about what Bush proposed last year. The president's budget proposals cover the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, and could not affect expenditures this winter. The program helps about 6.1 million households in the country, mainly by paying part of their heating bills. Small portions of it are used to help cover air conditioning and insulating expenses and to aid families in danger of losing their heating service. Spokeswoman Barbara Clay of the Office of Management and Budget declined to comment on the proposal. But advocates of initiatives for low-income people said the cuts would damage a program that is already under-financed. ``This program has been cut enough over the last few years,'' said Ed Block, executive director of the National Association of Community Action Programs. Federal energy aid to the poor started shortly after the Arab oil embargo in 1973. The program peaked in 1985, when it reached $2.1 billion and served 6.8 million families and individuals. The program was a favorite target for proposed reductions under former President Reagan's budget proposals. In some years Reagan's budgets called for no appropriations at all on the grounds that refunds to the states, from oil companies who overcharged when petroleum products were under price controls, could provide all the needed money. The program, however, has widespread support in Congress, which geenrally ignored Reagan's proposals. Bush's proposal is likely to be strongly opposed also. Last year, Bush proposed providing $1.1 billion for the program, but lawmakers ended up setting aside $1.39 billion for it. Word of Bush's plan comes after one of the coldest Decembers on record, a month in which heating oil prices shot up dramatically in some parts of the country. In Massachusetts, for example, heating oil costs surged from 88 cents per gallon a year ago to $1.41 per gallon last week. Supporters of the program said there is no way to predict how the proposed cuts, if enacted, would affect people who receive assistance. The federal government funnels the money to the states, which are free to set their own criteria for distribution. In the past, some states have responded to cuts by reducing the number of eligible recipients, while others have shrunk the size of benefits. The average participating household received $204 in heating assistance last year, according to spokeswoman Margot Simmons of the Department of Health and Human Services, which operates the energy assistance program. Program supporters say the benefits typically cover only about 20 percent of a low-income household's annual energy bill.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Will Free About 20,000
DOC.TEXT: The amnesty President Vaclav Havel declared on New Year's Day is the broadest in four decades and will free about 20,000 people, officials said Tuesday. They said about two-thirds of all prisoners and people awaiting trial would be among those released. Havel, who spent a total of more than five years in jail as a political dissident, has criticized prison conditions and said many people were wrongly jailed. Gustav Husak, who resigned as president Dec. 10, freed all political prisoners before stepping down. Justice Ministry officials said Tuesday that 31,000 people were being held in Czechoslovakia. The official news agency CTK quoted Justice Minister Dagmar Buresova as saying about 20,000 would be freed under the amnesty. ``Our system of prisons will have to be generally rebuilt into a system in which humanitarian requirements are met,'' Buresova said, according to CTK. Ministry officials said the cases of an unspecified number of other prisoners would be reviewed. Havel's amnesty applies to all prisoners except those indicted for ``abuse of authority by public officials.'' That charge has been brought against Miroslav Stepan, the former Prague Communist Party boss considered responsible for violent police suppression of a student demonstration Nov. 17, which started a peaceful revolution that drove the Communists from power in less than a month. Stepan and Milos Jakes, the ousted national party chief, were expelled from the party for ``serious political mistakes.'' People convicted of terrorism, murder, rape and sexual abuse cannot be freed under the amnesty, but it reduces their sentences by one year, which could result in the release of those with less than a year left to serve. Sentences for other intentional crimes were reduced by at least two years, and for crimes of negligence by at at least three years. National television called it the broadest amnesty since the Communists took power after World War II. A Justice Ministry official said privately about 15,000 people convicted of minor offenses or awaiting trial would be the first released. He did not give a breakdown of numbers of people imprisoned for the various types of crimes. The amnesty took effect immediately after Havel announced it and all prisoners eligible will be freed by Jan. 21, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Deane Hinton as Ambassador to Panama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs to UPDATE with Mitchell reaction
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has named career diplomat Deane Hinton as ambassador to Panama, the White House announced Tuesday. Hinton, currently ambassador to Costa Rica, replaces Ambassador Arthur H. Davis, who was recalled by Bush in protest of what the administration considered the stealing of the Panamanian elections last May by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Bush sent Davis back to Panama City after the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama by U.S. forces and installation of Guillermo Endara as president. Independent observers mostly concluded Endara had won the elections by a hefty margin. Bush named Hinton as a recess appointment because Congress is not in session. That means Hinton can serve until the end of next year before he must go before the Senate for confirmation. The appointment of the 66-year-old Hinton, with his long expierience on Latin American issues, is seen as a signal of the importance Bush is placing on restoring normal relations with Panama. Those relations steadily deteriorated after the United States indicted Noriega, once a ally particularly of the U.S. intelligence community, on drug trafficking charges in Florida. Hinton has been ambassador to Costa Rica since 1987. Before that he was ambassador to Pakistan from 1983 to 1987, and ambassador to El Salvador from 1981 to 1983. He was assistant secretary of state for economic and business affairs from 1979 to 1981, and before that U.S. representative to the 12-nation European Community, headquartered in Brussels, a State Department adviser on economic affairs, and director and economic counselor of the State Department's Agency for economic Development in Chile and in Guatemala. Davis, a former State Department consultant and former ambassador to Paraguay, was sent to Panama by President Reagan in 1986. Bush wanted to name his own ambassador and the time was appropriate with the installation of a new government in Panama, said one administration official. Officials described Hinton as ``an experienced Latin America hand'' and a good person to have in place with the volatile developments in the South American country. On Capitol Hill, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called Hinton highly qualified for the post because of his ``wide-ranging experience and expertise in Central America.'' However, Mitchell said he hoped Bush would send the appointment to the Senate after Congress convenes Jan. 23 despite the nature of the recess appointment.

DOC.HEAD: Embassy Search: Wrong Address Led to Diplomatic Fracas
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th pvs, `President Bush...' to UPDATE with Nicaragua requesting meeting of OAS, State Department comment. Pick up 12th, `U.S. and...'
DOC.TEXT: A tip about an arms cache, a missing diplomatic ID card and a wrong address led to the U.S. raid on the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence that hurt already tense U.S.-Nicaraguan relations, U.S. officials say. About 80 U.S. troops stormed the residence of Nicaraguan Ambassador Antenor Ferrey on Dec. 29, fired into the air and ordered everyone inside to evacuate. They found weapons, took money and clothes and ransacked the ambassador's office, Ferrey said; U.S. officials deny anything was taken and said the troops ``courteously apologized'' after they discovered they were on diplomatic ground. Even so, Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista government expelled 20 U.S. diplomats from the U.S. Embassy in Managua and ordered the mission's largely Nicaraguan administrative staff be reduced from 320 to 100. ``They acted arrogantly, like Rambos!'' said Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega. President Bush called it a ``screw-up'' and sent his apologies to Managua, but the State Department said the Sandinistas had seized an excuse to reduce U.S. mission personnel in advance of elections scheduled for Feb. 25. On Tuesday, Nicaragua requested that a special meeting of the ruling council of the Organization of American States be held Thursday to consider what it termed the ``violation by the invading army of the United States.'' A State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity said the expulsion of Nicaraguan Embassy personnel from the United States is ``one option under consideration'' as a response to Nicaragua's action. U.S. and Nicaraguan officials have provided contrasting versions of what happened. Here is an account from witnesses and spokesmen for both sides: Since the overthrow Dec. 20 of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, U.S. troops had been searching for weapons. Panamanian citizens were tipping off U.S. troops to arms caches to help crush the pro-Noriega resistance and to win a $5,000 reward for such information. The operation at the Nicaraguan Embassy residence apparently was launched by a U.S. troop commander following up such a tip from an unidentified Panamanian. U.S. officials said the tip gave the United States ``good cause'' to search the residence. Army Lt. Col. James Swank, a spokesman for the U.S. Southern Command, said the order was ``given by the battalion commander on the ground after we received a very good tip, information that the address was the site of an arms cache.'' Swank said the troops demanded to be let in, then fired in the air when the order was ignored. Apparently this was done despite the residence's sign about the size of a manhole cover that identified a Nicaraguan Embassy residence. ``A man drove up in his car, claiming to be the Nicaraguan ambassador and stating that this was his home,'' Swank said. By Ferrey's account, he arrived at his residence Friday evening to find about 80 U.S. troops outside. They stopped him from entering. Ferrey said he told the troops they were surrounding his residence. He demanded to speak to their commander and showed the colonel in charge his identification. However, Southern Command said in a statement that Ferrey did not have the right ID: he produced a ``blue identity card'' instead of his ``red diplomatic identity card.'' Even so, Ferrey said, the colonel radioed from a nearby jeep, seeking confirmation that Ferrey was telling the truth. About 20 minutes later, he came back and told Ferrey his superiors said the address was not registered as an embassy residence. Southern Command said information from the U.S. Embassy indicated the ambassador's residence was in a high-rise building in another neighborhood. Ferrey said he had moved from that residence more than a year ago. Southern Command said it got its list of embassies and diplomatic residences from the U.S. Embassy. The U.S. Embassy refuses to comment publicly, but privately officials admit the list had the wrong address. Ferrey said he pointed to the sign identifying the residence, arguing with the colonel. He said those inside the residence had tried to put a call through to U.S. Ambassador Arthur Davis but couldn't get through. Ferrey said he demanded to be put in contact with Davis, but the soldiers refused to contact the U.S. Embassy. Ferrey said he was finally allowed to enter the residence. He told the colonel the people inside would come out but he would not allow troops in. The troops entered. Ferrey said he struggled with a soldier and they fell off the porch. His sister-in-law, who was inside, was trying to make a phone call. She struggled with a soldier who ripped the phone cord from the wall, he said. The ambassador's brother, the maid, two visiting Nicaraguan officials and a Panamanian labor leader and his wife, who were seeking asylum, were inside. About 30 soldiers entered and searched the house, taking weapons, clothing, money and ransacking Ferrey's office, he said. U.S. officials said the troops found 12 AK-47 assault refiles, four Uzi submachine guns, six rocket-propelled grenades and one light anti-tank weapon, among other weapons. Ferrey told the troops he had a right to have arms inside the residence. Bush and other U.S. officials agreed but questioned why an embassy residence would need such weapons as rocket-propelled grenades. A senior U.S. Embassy official said the search was halted as soon as U.S. officials confirmed the home was Ferrey's and diplomatically immune. The troops had destroyed nothing, returned all the seized weapons and withdrew, said U.S. officials. Ferrey said the troops returned everything except the money, about $1,000. ``The North Americans are going to pay for'' the raid, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Preserves His Government in Political Compromise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 4 grafs after 3rd, `It ended ... to UPDATE with violence in occupied lands. Picks up 4th, `Shamir said ...' with minor editing to trim
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir agreed Tuesday not to fire Ezer Weizman, thus saving the government coalition, but barred the science minister from the inner Cabinet for his alleged secret contacts with the PLO. The compromise came less than two hours before the deadline for Weizman's dismissal and involves a fundamental issue of Israeli policy: refusal to talk with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Israel officially calls a terrorist group. It ended two days of crisis that threatened to bring down the ``national unity'' coalition of Shamir's hardline Likud bloc and the center-left Labor Party, of which Weizman is a senior member. In the occupied lands, Arab hospital officials said Israeli troops shot and wounded 19 Palestinians on Tuesday, including six children under age 14. Arab reporters said 16 were shot in the Gaza Strip. In Nablus on the West Bank, troops accidentally shot a 10-year-old Palestinian boy in the leg with a plastic bullet and wounded two 14-year-old boys, an army spokesman said. Both incidents involved stone-throwing by Palestinians, he said. Shamir said Sunday he would dismiss Weizman on Tuesday for having prolonged contacts with the PLO in which the dovish minister allegedly gave advice on how to obstruct a secret Israeli strategy worked out by the inner Cabinet. He said Tuesday the compromise ``guarantees existence of the coalition government and serves as a severe deterrent to all those who dare to violate our laws and contact our worst enemies.'' In Baghdad, Iraq, PLO chairman Yasser Arafat's political adviser said Tuesday that Shamir sent Arafat a message a few a few months ago about a possible peace settlement in the Middle East. ``I wonder why Shamir is making a lot of noise about Weizman's contacts with the PLO when he and other senior Israeli politicians made similar contacts,'' Abu Sharif told The Associated Press. He said the prime minister's message dealt with efforts to start a dialogue leading to settlement of the 2-year-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. A spokesman for Shamir dismissed Abu Sharif's claim as ``utter nonsense.' The Arafat adviser would not reveal the contents of the message or identify the intermediary. Abu Sharif is known to have been in touch with Israeli officials on behalf of the PLO. On Sunday, Shamir said Weizman acted ``in one mind'' with the PLO. On Tuesday, he summoned the minister to a meeting that lasted five minutes. Weizman said afterward the discussion was ``cordial'' and no evidence of contacts with the PLO was presented. ``This is a typically Middle East Israeli compromise,'' said Weizman, 65, who advocates peace negotiations with the PLO. ``There's no admission of guilt here; admission of guilt can be in court.'' His Labor superiors _ Shimon Peres, party leader and vice premier, and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin _ insisted on a compromise, Weizman said. Although Weizman will remain as science minister in the 26-member Cabinet, he no longer will be admitted to the inner Cabinet, where government strategy is decided. Shamir will consider restoring Weizman to the inner Cabinet in 18 months. Weizman, a former defense minister who defected from Likud, said he would leave as planned on Wednesday for an official visit to Moscow. He denied newspaper reports he would meet with a senior PLO official in the Soviet capital. Cabinet Secretary Eliakim Rubinstein, a top aide to Shamir, said Weizman had promised to act ``according to the government decisions and guidelines ... barring contact with the PLO.'' Right-wing parties criticized the compromise. Geula Cohen, a legislator from the Tehiya Party, said it ``broadcast to all the world that Israel is ready to negotiate with the PLO.'' Leftists said the affair showed there could be no peace without the PLO, and prominent Palestinians said it demonstrated Israel's unwillingness to compromise. Weizman said Peres and Rabin were aware of his contacts with Palestinian leaders abroad through Ahmed Tibi, an Israeli Arab physician. Peres said it was legitimate to meet with Tibi, who was not a PLO member.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega's Co-Defendants: Most Still At Large
With AM-Panama-Miami
DOC.TEXT: The federal indictment against Panamanian strongman Manuel Noriega filed here in February 1988 named 15 other men, including four in custody in Miami awaiting trial. Another eleven are still at large while Noriega has sought refuge at the residence of the papal embassy in Panama City. Negotiations between officials from Panama, the United States and the Vatican have been held for the last week to determine what will happen to the ousted leader. The U.S. attorney's office is still seeking the others. ``Their status is that of fugitives and all have had warrants issued for their arrest,'' said Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen. Cossin said the U.S. Attorney's office did not know if any of the men were holed up at the Vatican embassy with Noriega. Here are the defendants in the Noriega indictment, the charges against them and their current status: _ Manuel Antonio Noriega: Charged with protecting cocaine shipments flown from Medellin, Colombia, through Panama to the United States. He also is charged with arranging transshipment and sale of chemicals used in processing cocaine. Noriega is also accused of providing refuge and a base for continued operations to the members of the cartel after the murder of a Colombian justice minister. If convicted on all counts, he could receive up to 145 years in prison and $1,145,000 in fines. He is currently at the Vatican embassy in Panama City after seeking asylum on Dec. 24. _ Gustavo Dejesus Gaviria-Rivero and Pablo Escobar-Gaviria: Both men are identified in the indictment as members of the Medellin drug cartel. The indictment alleges that they and other cartel members used Panama as a base for their drug operations after the 1984 murder of the Colombian Minister of Justice, Rodrigo Lara-Bonilla. Gaviria faces 135 years in prison and $660,000 in fines and Escobar faces 60 years imprisonment and $100,000 in fines. The two Colombians are still at large. _ Luis Del Cid: Prosecutors have referred to the former captain in the Panama National Guard and Panamanian Defense Forces as Noriega's ``right-hand man.'' He is charged with acting as a liaison, money courier and emissary for Noriega in his transactions with drug traffickers. If convicted on all counts, he faces 70 years in prison and $550,000 in fines. He is in custody in Miami awaiting trial after surrendering to U.S. forces in Panama on Christmas Day. _ Amet Paredes: The Panamanian citizen allegedly smuggled cocaine from Panama to the United States and arranged protection for other drug trafficking activities with Noriega. If convicted on all counts, Paredes faces 95 years in prison and $1,025,000 in fines. Paredes is still at large. _ Ricardo Bilonick: Bilonick is a Panamanian businessman and part-owner of a Panamanian cargo airline, Inair. The indictment said that 1,000 kilograms of cocaine was seized from an Inair plane in Miami in 1984. If convicted, Bilonick faces 50 years in prison and $300,000 in fines. He is still at large. _ Brian Allen Davidow: Davidow is an alleged cocaine ditributor in Miami. He is currently in custody in Miami and was scheduled to go to trial on Jan. 8, but prosecutors expect his case to be delayed. If convicted, he faces 60 years in prison and $750,000 in fines. _ Francisco Chavez-Gil: The indictment said Chavez introduced an associate of Noriega, pilot Floyd Carlton-Chavez, to members of the Medellin cartel in order to arrange for protection of cocaine shipments through Panama. He could be sentenced to 35 years in prison and fined $275,000. Chavez is still at large. _ David Rodrigo Ortiz-Hermida and Roberto Steiner: Both men were allegedly pilots for Colombian cocaine shipments. Ortiz faces 35 years in jail and $275,000 in fines and Steiner faces 15 years in prison and $25,000 in fines. Both are still at large. _ Eduardo Pardo and Daniel Miranda: Both men are accused of flying a plane from Fort Lauderdale to Panama with $800,000 of drug money on board. Both face five years in prison and $10,000 in fines. Miranda was arrested Sunday in Panama and flown to Miami. His first court appearance was Tuesday before a U.S. magistrate. Pardo is still at large. _ Herman Velez, William Saldarriaga, Jaime Gomez and Luis Fernando Escobar-Ochoa: All four men are Colombian cocaine traffickers, according to the indictment. They each face 40 years in prison and $500,000 in fines if convicted. Saldarriaga is in custody in Miami and was scheduled to go to trial Jan. 8, but prosecutors said they expect the trial to be postponed. The other three are still fugitives.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Opens Election-Year Struggle for Congress With GOP Pep Talk
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, girding for his party's 1990 struggle to regain control of Congress, on Tuesday rallied Republican troops still smarting from off-year setbacks at the hands of the Democrats. ``We've got a great big job ahead of us,'' Bush told 200 Republican National Committee workers. ``The party is on the move. I am confident that this will be a great year, a Republican year.'' It was an upbeat appearance before the party rank-and-file who were rocked by GOP losses in several key state races and special congressional elections in 1989. Bush also used the brief political appearance to urge Congress to pass a capital gains tax cut, anti-crime package and clean air bill in the new year. For Bush, it was what he called ``a nostalgic return'' to RNC headquarters, where he toiled as party chairman during 1973-74 when the Republicans were reeling from the Watergate scandal. ``When I went back up to the fourth floor, it was like Yogi Berra said, `deja vu all over again,''' Bush joked. ``Some things never do change, except of course the Muzak,'' said Bush, referring to GOP Chairman Lee Atwater's switch to rhythm and rock for the piped-in music instead of the more traditional instrumental fare. The Democrats won six of eight special House elections during 1989, Atwater's first year as GOP chairman. The Democrats captured an Indiana House seat once held by Dan Quayle and a Mississippi seat that had been in GOP hands for a decade. The Republicans did capture the Miami seat held for years by the late Rep. Claude Pepper, the Democratic dean of Congress. The Democrats also celebrated widely noted election victories in governors' races in Virginia and New Jersey, where they capitalized on their Republican opponents' opposition to abortion. They also held the House seats of former Speaker Jim Wright in Texas and Majority Leader Tony Coelho in California, despite their exits from Congress under ethical clouds. Rep. Beryl F. Anthony, D-Ark., chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said in an interview, ``Ninety looks very positive for us. I think we've outrecruited the Republicans once again.'' ``The real battleground is what happens in state and local elections. The 1992 redistricting is the real battleground for the House of Representatives,'' said Anthony. Bush, who has already begun campaigning for GOP Senate hopefuls in Illinois, Rhode Island and Iowa, is expected to campaign extensively this year, according to Leslie Goodman, the RNC's director of communications. She said 1989 ``was a year we have to look back on and say, `This is what we don't want to do next year.' We're not going to let ourselves get boxed in on an issue like abortion.'' Atwater, 38, an architect of Bush's hard-hitting 1988 victory over Democrat Michael Dukakis, gave the president a belated Christmas present on Tuesday: a framed picture depicting the more than 160 Democrat elected officials who switched parties in the past year, including two congressmen. ``That's marvelous,'' said the president. Bush addressed the GOP workers at the Capitol Hill Club adjacent to RNC headquarters. This year's elections will be the last before House seats are reapportioned based on the decennial census. The GOP is hoping to gain strength from seats certain to be switched from frost belt to sun belt states after the census. Thirty-four Senate seats are up this year, 18 now held by Republicans and 16 by Democrats. Two Republicans _ Bill Armstrong in Colorado and Gordon Humphrey in New Hampshire _ have already announced they are not seeking re-election. The Democrats control the Senate now, 55-45. In the House, the Democrats have an 83-seat margin, 259-176. The Democrats picked up seats even as Bush was keeping the White House in Republican hands in 1988. ``We would anticipate that the president will do what presidents do best, which is raising money,'' said Anita Dunn, spokeswoman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, which expects to be outspent 4-to-1 by its Republican counterpart. It was in 1988, $66 million to $16 million. ``We're anticipating a very hard fought mid-term election,'' she said. ``We've picked up Senate seats in the last three election cycles. We're fighting to hold our own in 1990.''

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Want to Adopt Romanian Orphans
With AM-Romania-Orphans
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of couples have been telephoning charities and adoption agencies in Britain asking how to adopt orphans from Romania, the agencies said Tuesday. Pictures of overflowing Romanian orphanages, the result of the late dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's policies prohibiting abortion, birth control and family planning information for women with fewer than five children, were broadcast by British TV Monday night. The Flanders Scottish Alliance, an Edinburgh-based war charity, reported 2,000 calls since New Year's Eve from couples desperate to adopt. Barbara Mostyn of the support group STORK said the group has been receiving calls all day. The Swansea, Wales-based International Family Support Group said it received calls from 40 to 50 couples. ``I am truly shocked,'' said Kevin Earnshaw, a member of the Flanders Scottish Alliance who returned from a five-day tour of Bucharest orphanages Monday night and spoke about his trip on the radio. ``It's been absolute chaos. The phones have been going non-stop. There are obviously a lot of childless couples in Britain ... but I've had Americans offering me all sorts of money for a baby,'' he said. There are ``countless thousands'' of orphans in homes throughout Romania and at least 4,000 in the capital alone, he said. Earnshaw and Ms. Mostyn of STORK said there were no procedures yet for adopting Romanian orphans. ``We are worried that people might feel they can just rush straight there but, as under Ceausescu none of the orphans were allowed to be adopted abroad, I assume there is no system for adoption, which I find worrying,'' Ms. Mostyn said. Meanwhile, Earnshaw said, ``We are appealing for funds for medicinal and pediatric aid to be airlifted to the orphans.''

DOC.HEAD: Fund to Aid Poland Announced
DOC.TEXT: A $1 billion multilateral stabilization fund to aid Poland in its economic reform program was announced Tuesday by the Treasury Department. ``The stabilization fund will provide Poland with a supplemental line of reserves to support its new foreign exchange regime which is an essential element of Poland's market-oriented economic reform program designed to restore price stability and growth in the Polish economy,'' the Treasury announcement said. The United States contributed about $200 million to the fund. Other major contributors are expected to include Britain, Canada, West Germany, Japan, Italy, France, Switzerland, Austria and Spain. The Treasury announced last week that additional support to Poland is being provided through a short-term multilateral bridge loan of up to $500 million. The U.S. commitment to this loan also is $200 million.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates, Disasters Boost November Construction Spending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `Hurricane Hugo ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT date of earthquake to Oct. 17, sted Oct. 10
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending hit a 10-month high in November, the government reported Tuesday, and an analyst attributed the jump to lower interest rates and to rebuilding after Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco Bay-area earthquake. ``I think a reasonable argument can be made that some of the government spending was disaster related,'' said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Corp. A 7 percent gain in government spending helped push total outlays up 1.5 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $421.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported. It was the highest level since last January's $423 billion. Hurricane Hugo hit the South Carolina coast Sept. 21, while the earthquake struck Northern California on Oct. 17. Berson said the government sector had been growing strongly since July, so not all of the advance should be attributed to the disasters. Government spending totaled $91.4 billion on an annual rate. Residential spending increased 0.6 percent, to $194.4 billion, on an annual rate, helped by a 1.5 percent gain in single-family housing and a 4.7 percent jump in apartment building. ``What we're seeing here is a response by builders to lower mortgage rates and increased sales,'' Berson said. ``We're likely to see that edging up for the next several months but I don't think we're going to see any surges because builders will remain very cautious.'' The Federal Reserve began letting short-term interest rates fall gradually in June as inflation moderated and the economy showed signs of sluggishness. The central bank had propped up the rates initially to stem inflationary pressures. By the end of November, fixed-rate mortgage rates were 9.74 percent, according to a survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. They had peaked at 11.22 percent in March. Despite lower interest rates, construction of non-residential buildings was down 0.7 percent to $100.7 billion on an annual rate. Berson attributed the decline to ``overbuilding, particularly in office buildings,'' in recent years. Industrial construction advanced 1.7 percent, to $18.1 billion, which Berson said was good news for the economy because it increases productive capacity. ``With exports remaining pretty strong, I think we'll see industrial building continue to expand,'' he said. The total construction figure was up 1.5 percent from the level of building a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Rebels Say a Third Town Falls in Push Toward Capital
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopian rebels said Tuesday they seized a third town in central Ethiopia in their drive southward toward Addis Ababa, the capital. The rebels have been fighting since 1974 to oust the Marxist government of President Mengistu Haile Mariam. The Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front said in a secret radio broadcast, monitored in Nairobi, that its fighters captured the town of Jihur after launching a ``fierce offensive'' Sunday. In earlier combat, after fighting stepped up in mid-December, the rebels said they took the garrison town of Debre Tabor in northwestern Gonder province and Mehal Meda and Rabel in Shoa, the province that includes the capital. Mehal Meda, Rabel and Jihur all are within 100 miles of Addis Ababa. Jihur is 70 miles northeast of the capital and 25 miles west of one of two highways that connect Addis Ababa with the port of Assab, home of Ethiopia's sole oil refinery. The broadcast said a brigade and a company of government troops were ``taken apart'' in the weekend fighting, making no mention of rebel casualties. The rebels had claimed that the government lost more than 8,000 dead, wounded or captured in the earlier fighting. It was not possible to verify rebel claims. Western diplomats in Addis Ababa said previous rebel claims appeared to be accurate. The front is a combined force of the Tigre People's Liberation Front and the smaller Ethiopia People's Democratic Movement. Rebels and government have held preliminary peace talks, but the diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the talks ``don't appear to be going far now.'' In Addis Ababa on Tuesday, 21 military and police officers accused of involvement in a May 16 coup attempt against Mengistu were arraigned before a three-member military court. Trial for the eight colonels, six majors, three captains and four lieutenants was adjourned until Jan. 11 to allow them time to get lawyers. Fourteen other officers already are being tried for alleged involvement in the coup attempt. Prosecutors say they will seek penalties ranging from 10 years' imprisonment to death.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Film Flies Out of Obscurity in Specialty Theaters
DOC.TEXT: ``A Hungarian Fairy Tale'' has become a real-life moneymaker at specialty theaters since the film was first shown in the United States in museums a little over a year ago. An allegory about individuals struggling for identity in a bureaucratic world, the 1987 film by Gyula Gazdag was released commercially in this country late in 1988. The movie is back in Boston for an open-ended run, and is getting a marketing boost from the popular revolts in Eastern Europe that have dominated headlines in recent months. With just three copies of the film shown in 26 weeks' worth of screenings, it has taken in more than $110,000 in ticket sales, said Morton Wax of the New York-based distributor, MD Wax@Courier Films. ``It's a great film,'' said Bo Smith, film coordinator at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts. ``It's timely. Anybody looking at it with the headlines in their mind will see how much this artist dealt with what was happening before it happened. ``This is a very subversive film indeed.'' Gazdag's films have been suppressed in the past for up to 12 years at a time. The very making of ``A Hungarian Fairy Tale'' was a measure of the new freedoms in Hungary. Gazdag, who is teaching two semesters of filmmaking at the University of California, Los Angeles, said in a telephone interview Tuesday that the reception gratified and surprised him. ``I didn't expect that American audiences can be sensitive for a small, black-and-white subtitled Hungarian movie. So perhaps there is something else in the film.'' As the 42-year-old director put it: ``It's about looking for an identity, and that's what's going on in Eastern Europe right now.'' In the week that ended Nov. 29, the film ranked No. 39 on Variety's list of 50 top grossing films in terms of average sales per screen. ``A Hungarian Fairy Tale'' made of $9,000 that week on the lone screen surveyed, according to Variety. Although that is small change for a Hollywood blockbuster, it is noteworthy for a foreign fable by a once-suppressed director, said Erica Max, managing director of Coolidge Corner Theater Foundation, which is showing the movie. ``It's a very important indication of how much strength a film has,'' Max said. The film tells the story of an orphan boy's search for a father he has never known. Without a father, the boy can't officially exist as far as a local town clerk is concerned. The movie spins its tale with surrealistic flourishes. When the civil servant who denied the boy an identity ends up burning the contents of his file cabinet, he gets locked up in an insane asylum. Then the ex-civil servant and a nurse who quits the asylum team up with the boy. In the end, they escape the bureaucratic madness by taking flight on a huge, magic bird. The film opened at the Coolidge on Dec. 22. Business has been slow because of the holidays, Max said, but attendance should climb as word gets out. ``By the end of the run it will be doing very well,'' Max predicted. ``It's an extraordinary film that has a great reputation.'' The film was first seen in this country in special showings at a few museums, said Smith, the Boston museum's film coordinator. Smith invited reviewers when the museum showed the film in July 1988. Their enthusiastic reception convinced Morton Wax it could be a box-office success, and he became its distributor.

DOC.HEAD: President to Visit Florida and Ohio
