DOC.TEXT: President Bush will travel to Orlando, Fla., and Cincinnati, Ohio, next week on separate speaking trips, the White House said Tuesday. Bush will fly to Orlando on Monday to address the Americana Farm Bureau convention and tour the Food and Agriculture Pavilion at Epcot Center, part of the Disney World complex. Bush will journey to Ohio on Jan. 12 to attend a briefing on the Cincinnati Youth Collaborative and address a Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Southwest, Dry Weather Prevails
DOC.TEXT: Heavy snow fell Tuesday in several southwestern states and rainshowers were scattered across the lower Mississippi Valley, while the rest of the nation enjoyed dry weather. In contrast to recent weeks, the nation was almost without subzero cold early Tuesday. The low for the Lower 48 states was minus 1 degree at Craig, Colo. A storm system centered over southern Nevada brought heavy snow to parts of California, Nevada, Utah and Arizona. Heavy snow fell in the mountains east and south of Bakersfield, Calif., overnight Monday. As much as 9 inches fell at Greenhorn Mountain and 6 inches at Pine Mountain Club. A winter storm warning was in effect overnight Tuesday for the northwest valleys of Utah and the northern half of Arizona. As much as 2 feet of snow was forecast for some of the higher mountains in Utah. Temperatures were in the 30s and 40s across much of the nation east of the Rockies by Tuesday afternoon. Sunny skies and strong southerly winds prevailed from the southern Plains region to the upper Great Lakes. Temperatures in the southern Plains region were in the 50s by Tuesday afternoon and readings across the Florida peninsula warmed into the 70s.

DOC.HEAD: New Year's Holiday Traffic Accidents Claim 273 Lives
DOC.TEXT: A total of 273 people lost their lives in traffic accidents on the nation's roadways over the long New Year's holiday weekend _ fewer than during the same weekend last year. The toll was toward the low end of the 250-to-350 range for the four-day holiday that the National Safety Council had projected based on data from other years, weather factors and national driving-safety trends. California recorded the most fatalities among the states with 35, followed by Florida with 26 and Texas with 25. Seven states and the District of Columbia reported no fatal traffic accidents. Alaska, Montana, New Hampshire, North Dakota, South Dakota, Vermont and Wyoming were the states that logged no fatalities. During the four-day New Year's holiday last year, 323 people died in traffic accidents. The highest toll on record for the holiday is the 564 recorded during the three-day New Year's weekend in 1965. The counting period this year began at 6 p.m. local time Friday and ended at 11:59 p.m. local time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Portuguese Navy Tracks Atlantic Oil Spill
With AM-Morocco-Spill
DOC.TEXT: Portuguese naval aircraft Tuesday tracked a 7-square-mile oil slick that leaked from a Spanish tanker off the Madeira archipelago. About 25,000 tons of crude spilled into the Atlantic Saturday when the tanker Aragon developed problems in heavy seas about 80 miles northeast of Porto Santo island. According to Cmdr. Raul Semedo of the Madeira Naval Command the slick was drifting slowly southeast and posed no immediate threat to tourist attractions along Madeira's coast. Cmdr. Semedo said the slick was headed toward the Moroccan coast 440 miles east of Porto Santo but already appeared to be breaking up in warm waters. The Aragon spill came at the same time Morocco faced the possibility that a huge oil slick from an Iranian tanker ripped open by an explosion Dec. 19 could wash up on its shores. Spain's Merchant Marine Directorate said the Aragon began leaking oil after incurring damage to the hull in stormy seas. The directorate said the ship was being towed to the Canary Islands by a West German freighter with assistance from a tug and a Spanish vessel equiped with oil dispersal chemicals. The tanker is owned by the Spanish company Transportes Maritimos S.A. and is registered in Spain's north African enclave, Ceuta. It has capacity to carry 230,000 tons of crude oil. The Portuguese islands of Madeira and Porto Santo are about 625 miles southwest of the Lisbon, the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sends Greetings to NAACP
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Tuesday sent New Year's greetings to civil rights leader Benjamin Hooks and deplored the recent spate of racially motivated bomb attacks and threats in the South. ``The recent bombings make it clear we have not totally beaten back the evils of bigotry and racial prejudice. We cannot let up in th fight against racism,'' Bush wrote in the two-paragraph letter that contained best wishes from himself and his wife Barbara to the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``Please assure your members I will see that the federal government does not let up as it works to bring the perpetrators of these hideous crimes to justice.'' ``I send my sincere hope that 1990 will be a great year for your most prestigious organization,'' the president wrote. The series of mail bombs included one that killed a federal judge, Robert Vance, in Alabama, and an NAACP leader, Robert Robinson, in Georgia. A person or group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System claimed responsibility for the two killings in mid-December. A letter to an Atlanta television station subsequently threatened stepped-up violence and claimed the justice system was lenient toward blacks who attack whites. An anchorwoman who received the letter sent to Atlanta station WAGA received police protection. An NAACP official involved in a 21-year-old school desegregation case mentioned in that letter said the FBI warned him he might be a target. The desegregation case involves the DeKalb County schools, and a telephone caller threatened DeKalb police last month also. On Dec. 15, Bush cancelled a trip to New York where he was scheduled to speak to the NAACP conference because he had laryngitis. One close associate of the president said at the time that after a gravelly voiced Bush telephoned his apologies and best wishes to the gathering, he remarked that he wondered if they believed he really was sick.

DOC.HEAD: Crowd Rampages on Soviet-Iranian Frontier
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 9th pvs, `Tass said...' to UPDATE with Azerbaijani denying violent rampage, details. Pick up 10th, `Tass also...'
DOC.TEXT: A drunken, drug-using Soviet mob rampaged for three days on the Iranian frontier, wrecking buildings and communications, threatening to kill border guards and trying to enter Iran illegally, it was reported Tuesday. The ``unprecedented barbarous actions'' in the Azerbaijani enclave of Nakhichevan caused millions of dollars in damage, the Tass news agency said. It was the latest spasm of violence in the Soviet Caucasus, inflamed the past two years by strife among Azerbaijanis, Armenians, Georgians and other ethnic groups. Elsewhere in Azerbaijan, police cadets Tuesday fired on a crowd attacking a convoy with stones and firearms in the predominantly Armenian city of Stepanakert, Tass reported. One person was killed and three wounded. That incident took place in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region, a flashpoint of ethnic hatreds between the neighboring republics of Azerbaijan and Armenia since February 1988. Tass said the spree of destruction in Nakhichevan, 1,200 miles south of Moscow, began Sunday and continued until Tuesday. It blamed ``extremist forces,'' but gave few clues as to their motives. The crowd, ``high on drugs or alcohol,'' rampaged along a distance of more than 85 miles of the Nakhichevan part of the Soviet-Iranian border, destroying or burning buildings, communications lines, poles and border signs, Tass said. ``Threats were also heard to burn down the border stations and kill the border guards personnel and their families,'' Tass said. In its dispatch also read on the evening television news program ``Vremya,'' Tass said ``irresponsible elements'' were trying to aggravate tensions in Azerbaijan and the Caucasus as a whole, but was not more explicit. Tass said some people were trying to cross the border into Iran illegally, indicating the crowd in Nakhichevan was probably Azerbaijani, the only Soviet ethnic group who, like Iranians, are largely Shiite Moslems. Vagiv Samedoglu, editor of the Azerbaijan People's Front newspaper, said by telephone from Baku, Azerbaijan's capital, that for nearly a month Soviet Azerbaijanis had been camped out along the border with Iran in hopes of seeing relatives and friends on the other side. About 4 million ethnic Azerbaijanis live in the adjoining Iranian province of Azerbaijan alone. Their Soviet kin want an open border and the freedom to trade and cross the frontier for personal visits, practices that were suspended by dictator Josef Stalin, Samedoglu said. He said the Tass report of attacks by drunken, narcotics-influenced mobs was a ``lie'' written in Moscow. A rally was held Sunday in Baku to demand a free border with Iran, and on Tuesday pickets renewed the call in front of Azerbaijan's Interior Ministry headquarters and Supreme Soviet legislature, Samedoglu said. Tass also charged the organizers of the melee were trying to ``destabilize'' the border region and provoke a brutal response from authorities, but did not say why. Attempts to secure information from Azerbaijan's official news agency, Azerinform, were not successful. Telephones rang unanswered Tuesday night at its headquarters in Baku. Disruptions caused by the mob's attack continued along the Soviet-Iranian border, Tass said. ``Constant attempts are being made to freely cross the border into Iranian territory,'' it said. ``As a result of such actions, the functioning of border services has become extremely difficult.'' Soviets attempting to exit the country must submit to checks at the frontier by the special Border Troops unit of the KGB before being given permission to leave. Iranian media monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus, had no immediate report on the three-day rampage. But Tass said worried Iranian border commissioners issued a protest saying the ``actions by extremist elements are insulting'' to Iran and requesting the Soviets act to quell the disorders. Violence broke out in the 2,200-square-mile Azerbaijani enclave between Armenia and Iran in November 1988, when Armenian media reported gangs of Azerbaijanis had ransacked Armenian residents' homes in Nakhichevan. Many ethnic Armenians who were among Nakhichevan's more than 235,000 residents then fled to Armenia, joining refugees from Nagorno-Karabakh and Azerbaijan itself who felt threatened because of ethnic attacks sparked by the continuing territorial dispute over Nagorno-Karabakh. Nagorno-Karabakh is a predominantly Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan. Tass said a bus convoy of Azerbajanis being escorted by internal security troops between the cities of Agdam and Shusha was stoned and fired on in Stepanakert on Tuesday. ``Cadets from the police school, for purposes of self-defense, returned the fire,'' Tass said. In the shootout, four Stepanakert residents were wounded, and one of them died, Tass said. Some Azerbaijanis aboard the buses also were injured. When the convoy arrived in the Azerbaijani city of Shusha, 5,000 people formed to ``even the score,'' but reinforced internal security troops prevented further strife, Tass said. In the Azerbaijani town of Dzhali-Abad, the local Communist Party chief was injured in a clash last week between police and demonstrators demanding his ouster, said Savili A. Perets, deputy director of Azerinform, in a telephone interview earlier Tuesday from Baku. Tass said mobs rampaged in the city near the Iranian border and the Caspian Sea coast Friday. Placing women and children in front of them as a shield, they stormed the offices of the party district committee and the police station, Tass said. Roads were blockaded and enterprises shut down. Tass said authorities acted to unblock the roads and dismantle tents set up by demonstrators. Perets said one protester was wounded by gunfire and more than 20 others and 60 policemen injured by other means. Protesters also wounded the top party official in the town, Kherula Aliev, whom they accused of inattention to social and economic problems, Perets said. He said Aliev was taken to Baku for treatment. Tass said Tuesday night the situation there remained tense.

DOC.HEAD: Five Ministers Replaced in Portuguese Government
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva replaced five ministers in his center-right government Tuesday, two weeks after his Social Democratic Party suffered heavy losses in nationwide municipal elections. Those dismissed include Eurico de Melo, defense minister and deputy premier, and Finance Minister Miguel Cadilhe, architect of the economic liberalization program. Cavaco Silva also replaced Health Minister Leonor Beleza, Agriculture Minister Alvaro Barreto and Jose Silveira Godinho, minister for internal administration. All five were leading figures in the government formed after the party won general elections in 1987 with the first parliamentry majority since a 1974 revolution ended 48 years of authoritarian right-wing rule. Tuesday's action was the first major change in the team Cavaco Silva recruited to reduce state control and modernize the country to fit in with the European Community, which Portugal joined in 1986 as the poorest member. News reports said de Melo resigned both his positions when Cavaco Silva decided to replace the other four because of the loss to the opposition Socialist Party in municipal elections Dec. 17. Socialist officials dismissed the Cabinet realignment as ``changing faces but not policies.'' Cavaco Silva presented five new ministers to President Mario Soares, who must approve the appointments. They include Miguel Beleza, brother of the outgoing health minister, who is to replace Cadilhe. Despite strong economic growth since the 1987 election, high inflation and Cadilhe's abrasive style made him the least popular minister in opinion polls. A parliamentry enquiry last year rejected allegations that he had evaded taxes. Miguel Beleza, a director of the Bank of Portugal, supports government plans to sell state-owned companies and reduce controls on the economy. Officials did not reveal Cavaco Silva's choice as deputy prime minister, but government spokesman Fernando Lima said Carlos Brito would replace de Melo as defense minister. Brito lost the race for mayor of Oporto in the December elections, in which the Socialists got 32 percent of the vote nationwide, 1 percent more than the Social Democrats.

DOC.HEAD: Canal Nearly Closed Under Noriega, But Runs Smoothly Now
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Panama Canal was on the verge of closing under Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega but the ``mighty muscle of the U.S. Army'' should guarantee it runs smoothly from now on, the canal's new administrator said Tuesday. ``I saw with great anguish what was happening in Panama,'' said Fernando Manfredo, acting administrator of the 50-mile waterway. ``I was horrified, foreseeing that the deteriorating situation between the United States and Panama would result in the closure of the canal.'' Although Panamanians make up 86 percent of the canal's work force, Manfredo is the first Panamanian to run the shipping route since it began operations 75 years ago. He took over Monday under the terms of the 1977 treaty that gives the canal to Panama in the year 2000. Manfredo and other canal officials said harrassment by the Noriega government was causing morale problems among the canal's 8,000 employees and forcing key canal workers to quit. ``It was getting hard to sustain the standards necessary to keep the canal competitive,'' Manfredo said at a news conference at canal headquarters. He said the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion that toppled Noriega's regime restored faith among canal employees. ``That resolved a series of problems affecting canal workers and which in my opinion was threatening to close the canal at any moment because the morale of workers had hit bottom,'' said Manfredo. He said ``the mighty muscle of the U.S. Army'' is the best guarantee of the canal's future operations and neutrality. ``I think the canal is more protected now than ever,'' he said. Manfredo, deputy administrator for the past 10 years, was named acting administrator because the new government of President Guillermo Endara has not yet nominated a permanent head. He said Endara has not asked him to fill the post permanently and refused comment when asked if he wanted the job. On Monday, Endara said Manfredo could be named to the post. The U.S. Senate and President Bush must approve the choice. An American will be named deputy administrator, a move that does not require presidential or Senate confirmation. Meanwhile, Raymond Laverty and Joseph Wood, two former executives at the canal, are sharing the duty. Laverty said he expects Latin American nations to continue using the canal even though many countries were against the invasion and do not recognize the Endara government. Laverty said few countries have an alternative shipping route and the use of the canal is an economic, rather than a political issue. He cited the example of Ecuador, where the banana industry supports 500,000 people and where two-thirds of its banana crop goes through the canal. Laverty said there were only a handful of instances where shippers canceled plans to use the canal because of the invasion, which closed the waterway for less than two days. He said many shippers delayed shipments until the canal opened, and that the backlog, which reached 150 ships at one point, is about half of that now. Manfredo said Panama and the United States are studying the possibility of investing in increasing canal capacity such as widening the Gaillard, or Culebra, cut, the narrowest part of the waterway. The cost of the project has been estimated at $400 million, but Manfredo said the money could not be recovered through canal tolls by the year 2000. Other possibilities discussed in recent years include adding another set of locks, which raise and lower the ships across the canal, he said. The existing canal is fed by fresh water and rises to about 85 feet above sea level at its highest point, requiring the locks for transit. There has been occasional talk of a new salt water canal built at sea level but costs, engineering problems and environmental considerations are considered enormous.

DOC.HEAD: 1000s Demonstrate Against Decision to Restore Minority Rights
DOC.TEXT: About 10,000 people joined a protest Tuesday of the government decision to cancel such discriminatory policies against ethnic Turks as making them take Bulgarian names, the official news agency BTA reported. The demonstration in Kurdjali, 250 miles southeast of Sofia, lasted more than five hours, the agency reported. Ethnic Turks and other Moslems in the region held their own protest and police moved in to keep the groups apart, the report said. BTA quoted witnesses as saying they feared violence. New policies announced Friday also give ethnic Turks free choice of religion and schools. An estimated 1 million ethnic Turks live in Bulgaria. Last year, the discriminatory laws prompted more than 300,000 to emigrate to Turkey after the Communist authorities granted them passports. Restrictions were placed on ethnic Turks under Todor Zhivkov, the Communist Party chief who ruled Bulgaria for 35 years. Petar Mladenov, who replaced Zhivkov on Nov. 10, has promised reforms and free elections. In Kurdjali, a Committee for the Defense of National Interests was formed last week, including Communists and non-Communists. It demands a referendum on the minorities issue and sent a declaration to Parliament saying the leadership, with the new policies, had ``once again taken categorical and irreversible decisions ... forced its dictates on the popular opinion.'' Representatives of the Communist Party and oppostion should visit the region and learn about the issue ``where it is particularly acute,'' the committee said, according to BTA. The statement, brought to Sofia by a convoy of 200 cars, said the committee would call a general warning strike Friday if it did not receive a satisfactory response.

DOC.HEAD: Small Contingent of Troops Return from Panama
With AM-Panama, Bjt
LaserPhotos MTY1, SA1
DOC.TEXT: The first U.S. troops to pull out of Panama returned home Tuesday, and one soldier said their morale was high because they were ``treated like heroes'' by the Panamanian people. Fifty-six soldiers based at Fort Ord arrived aboard a C-141 transport plane about 6:45 a.m. after a brief stop at Kelly Air Force Base in San Antonio. They were among the 141 that left Panama on Monday, the first to leave since the United States invaded Panama on Dec. 20. ``Now they have a democratic government _ it's what they want. They love Americans,'' said Army Sgt. John Grauer, 29, of Fresno, during the Texas stop. ``They love what we did.'' Spec. 4 Ralph Santos, a 19-year-old soldier from Los Angeles, said the reaction of Panamanians boosted spirits among the troops. ``Overall, the morale of the soldiers was greatly increased. The infantry guys were treated like heroes by the Panamanians,'' said Santos, who speaks Spanish and was called on at times to interpret for military police. ``In some ways I was expecting more of a negative reaction.'' Most of the returning soldiers were from field artillery and air defense batteries that provided protection for infantrymen in Panama City, a Panamanian army base at Rio Hato on the Pacific coast, and in the city of David on the Costa Rican border. Second Lt. John Jaskwhich said the artillery troops were called in to assist infantrymen, but did not have to fire any weapons other than flares to light up the sky for infantrymen. Some troops, however, flew into the Rio Hato area while fighting was still intense and the sound of gunfire made them nervous, the soldiers said. ``The flight crew told us it was pretty hot. The plane was getting shot at when we were coming in,'' said Jaskwhich. ``I'm just glad to be back to celebrate a little Christmas,'' he said in San Antonio. Jim Davis, spokesman at Fort Ord, home base for the troops, described the mood there as ``very up, very up. ``They're glad the guys are coming back,'' he said. ``This post is about 10 feet off the ground.'' President Bush on Monday expressed hope that the remaining U.S. soldiers in Panama could leave ``as soon as possible.'' ``The president is glad to see some of the troops coming home and hopes the rest can leave as soon as possible,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, but he offered no timetable. About 12,000 troops are permanently assigned to Panama. Another 14,000 were sent in as part of the effort to topple Panama's Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Twenty-three U.S. service personnel have been killed in the operation and 322 wounded. Among Panamanians, 297 soldiers and about 300 civilians have been killed, according to the U.S. military.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Envoy Apologizes to Spanish News Agency for Search
With AM-Panama
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to Spain apologized Tuesday to the head of the Spanish national news agency EFE for a search by U.S. troops of the agency's offices in Panama. In a telex to EFE President Alfonso S. Palomares, Joseph Zappala said,``It is regrettable that incidents can occur in these times of conflict which affect those upon whose friendships we count very highly.'' Palomares sent a protest to Zappala and the U.S. Southern Command in Panama Dec. 30, when three U.S. Army soldiers entered the offices to search for a suspected supporter of ousted Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. That same day, U.S. troops searched the Panama City offices of Spain's state-controlled Iberia Airlines and Banco Exterior de Espana. Some Spanish commentators implied the searches were made in retaliation for Spain's vote a day earlier in the U.N. General Assembly to condemn the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion of Panama. Zappala, whose appointment was confirmed by the U.S. Senate in October, expressed his condolences to the leading Spanish daily El Pais on Dec. 23, two days after its photographer, Juan Antonio Rodriguez Moreno, was accidentally shot and killed in a hotel parking lot by U.S. troops in Panama.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Car Bomb Kills Taxi Driver, Injures Daughter
DOC.TEXT: An IRA car bomb exploded Tuesday, killing a taxi driver who was driving his 16-year-old daughter to school in mainly Protestant east Belfast. Harry Dickey, 38, became the year's first victim of Northern Ireland's sectarian and political strife. His daughter Gillian, who was riding in the front seat, was dragged from the wreckage by neighbors and taken to a Belfast hospital where she was listed in fair condition. The Irish Republican Army issued a statement to Belfast media claiming Dickey was a leading member of two outlawed Protestant paramilitary groups, the Ulster Defense Association and the Ulster Freedom Fighters. An Ulster Defense Association spokesman, speaking anonymously, said Dickey ``is not, and never has been, an apologist for violence.'' Dickey, a former oil rig worker, was a member of the Ulster Democratic Party, whose one-time leader John McMichael was killed in a similar IRA attack at Christmas l987. It has close links with the Ulster Defense Association. Dickey and his daughter had just left home when the bomb exploded. Their car crashed into a lamp post, a police spokesman said. The IRA struck only hours after John Hume, leader of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, the province's largest Catholic party, called for ``people power'' to halt the IRA campaign of terror. Northern Ireland Minister Peter Bottomley said of the IRA in a TV interview: ``I wish they would stop trying to imitate the Romanian security forces. It's a tragedy that Northern Ireland is apparently the last place in Europe where people are still using bombs, bullets and sometimes bigotry as well to pursue their causes.'' The IRA is fighting to oust Britain from Northern Ireland and unite the predominantly Protestant province with the Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Seeks Disaster Aid for Freeze Losses
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bill Clements asked President Bush on Tuesday to declare four Rio Grande Valley counties disaster areas because of the devastating freeze that hit the region last month. ``For the second time this decade, the citrus crop in the Valley has been decimated by freezing temperatures. Growers, workers and business people alike have suffered serious economic loss because of this weather disaster,'' said Clements. A damaging freeze also hit the area in 1983. If approved, the disaster declaration would clear the way for agricultural workers in Starr, Cameron, Willacy and Hidalgo counties to receive up to $23 million in federal unemployment benefits, said Rossanna Salazar, the governor's press secretary. In his letter to the president, Clements said preliminary estimates indicate damage from the freeze totals $385 million. Of that, $200 million was in crop losses, $150 million in losses to related businesses and $35 million in lost wages. ``This disaster has left thousands unemployed and businesses in ruin,'' Clements wrote. His request notes that the citrus and vegetable crops were largely destroyed in the four counties.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Drops Appeal of Fernald Lawsuit Settlement
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. appeals court Tuesday granted the government's request to drop its appeal of a $78 million settlement with neighbors of the Fernald uranium processing plant who sued over radioactive emissions. The 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati issued an order Tuesday dismissing the Department of Energy's appeal. The order allows the Energy Department to allocate money for the settlement, which would permit long-term medical monitoring of people living near the plant. The plant, located 18 miles northwest of Cincinnati, is owned by the Energy Department and processes uranium for the government's production elsewhere of nuclear weapons. The department acknowledged in 1985 that tons of radioactive uranium dust had leaked from the plant's exhaust filters into the environment. Marc Johnston, assistant general counsel for the Energy Department in Washington, said Tuesday that the department's lawyers will meet soon with the Fernald-area residents' attorney, Stanley Chesley of Cincinnati, to discuss how the settlement will be paid for. ``We're very pleased,'' Chesley said. ``We're cautiously optimistic because we want to get it funded as soon as possible.'' U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel approved the settlement last fall. The Energy Department then challenged Spiegel's ruling that the settlement not prevent nearby companies from suing the government to recover the cost of cleaning up radioactive material. Department lawyers said last month that they had decided to drop the challenge. The Fernald plant's neighbors filed suit in 1985 against the plant's former operator, National Lead of Ohio Inc., and its parent company. The lawsuit alleged that radioactive contamination had reduced the value of their property and caused them emotional stress. The Energy Department agreed to the settlement because it employed National Lead as a contractor. Westinghouse Materials Co. of Ohio, which took over the plant's operation in January 1986, was not a defendant.

DOC.HEAD: 109 Die of Cold in India, 82 in Bangladesh
DOC.TEXT: At least 109 people, most of them poor and homeless, have died of exposure to cold in northern India the past two weeks, a news agency reported Tuesday. In neighboring impoverished Bangladesh, 82 people have died in the same period, United News of Bangladesh news agency said. Press Trust of India said most deaths in India were reported from the northern state of Bihar, which is also one of the poorest regions in the country. The news agency, quoting meteorolgists, said, ``There was no hope of a let up in the chilly spell (and) the cold is likely to continue throughout the next week.'' Temperatures in northern India dipped to 34 degrees, PTI said. In Bangladesh's capital Dhaka, officials declined comments on the deaths reported by United News of Bangladesh. A district official at Pabna, 75 miles north of Dhaka, said in a telephone interview: ``We have reports of some deaths from cold weather. We don't have specific figures.'' Cold weather is particularly hard on residents in Bangladesh, where the per capita annual income is $160 and even people with shelter are ill-prepared for winter. Most houses in the country of 110 million people have mud floors and walls fashioned from thin mats of straw or split bamboo.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Special, Nonpartisan Judicial Elections
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Tuesday ordered special elections in May for nearly one-third of the state's district judges, saying the power of minority voters in nine counties has been diluted by at-large elections. U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton of Midland said his plan for nonpartisan elections was needed because the governor and Legislature have failed to change the countywide election system since he ruled it discriminatory in two months ago. ``A further delay of implementation of any solution by the Legislature would not be in the interest of justice, would further dilute the rights of minority voters in the counties in question and would be inequitable and work an even greater hardship on the judges and courts involved,'' he said. Gov. Bill Clements called for an immediate appeal of the judge's order. He said he supported elections without party lines, but he claimed that putting Bunton's plan into effect before an appeal is heard would create ``wholesale upheaval'' in the Texas judiciary. ``Not only would this be chaotic, it would result in the loss of qualified and experienced judges who are now on the bench,'' Clements said. Attorney General Jim Mattox said his office was reviewing the judge's order and considering an appeal. He expressed disappointment over the ruling and said both the state House and Senate support partisan elections. ``I still feel strongly that the Legislature is the proper forum to solve the problem, and I wish the judge had heeded the expressed intent and wishes of the Legislature,'' Mattox said. The judge's decision covers only the 115 judgeships out of the 172 in the nine counties up for election this year, officials said. Those positions were to be filled as part of the state's normal election process, with party primaries in March and the general election in November. Overall, the state has 375 district judges. John T. Garcia, Texas director of the League of United Latin American Citizens, which sued to overturn the judicial election process in the nine counties, praised the ruling. ``We now feel minorities ... have the opportunity to be elected to the judiciary,'' Garcia said. ``We believe with the districts cut up into sub-districts we will have better representation in the judiciary, which is something that is long overdue for minorities.'' Under Bunton's order, nonpartisan balloting in the nine counties would be held within existing political subdivisions, such as state House districts, justice of the peace precincts and county commissioner precincts. The special judicial elections would be for four-year terms. Ron Dusek, spokesman for Mattox, said the judge's plan would take effect unless the Legislature acts before May to change at-large voting. State officials, including Clements, had asked for more time. But Bunton said quick action was needed. He said his interim plan is what ``law, equity and justice require.'' Bunton's order covers district court judges in the counties of Bexar (which includes San Antonio), Dallas, Harris (Houston), Travis (Austin), Tarrant (Fort Worth), Jefferson, Lubbock, Ector and Midland counties. The judge ruled in November that countywide voting violated the Voting Rights Act of 1965. At that time, non-Hispanic whites held 155 of the 172 district judge seats in the nine counties. Blacks and Hispanics make up about one-third of the state's population. The judge noted that his discrimination ruling sparked political squabbling and said the case reminds him of the Hank Williams Jr. song, ``I'm for Love.'' ``The lyric goes, `The city is against the county, the county is against the state, the state is against the government, and the highway still ain't paved,'' Bunton wrote. ``In this case, the governor has been against the attorney general, the attorney general against the Legislature, the judges against this court, and the system is still flawed.'' Bunton's order was based in part on a settlement negotiated by Mattox and LULAC. The judge noted that the Legislature is to hold a special session in early March, and he urged Clements and lawmakers to permanently revise the election system. Otherwise, he said, ``this court will put into effect a permanent plan for for the election of state district court judges in the nine target counties.''

DOC.HEAD: About 200 Killed in Tribal Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 200 people were killed in recent clashes between Arab and African tribes in Sudan, a government official said Tuesday. Pio Yukwan, a member of the 15-man military junta that took control of Sudan June 30, said the clashes took place Dec. 28 in the Jabalain area, south of Kosti about 300 miles from this capital. The clashes broke out when workers belonging to the African Shiluk tribe refused to return to work after the Christimas holiday in a farm owned by a member of the Arab Sabaha tribe. In the battles, 182 Shiluk tribesmen and four Arabs were killed. Several others were injured and hospitlized in Kosti, Yukwan said without giving details. It was the first reported dispute between the Shiluk tribe, traditionally known to be calm and reserved, and its central Sudan Arab neighbors. Shiluk is the main African tribe in the Upper Nile region, which is the birthplace of Col. John Garan, leader of the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. Members of the Shiluk tribe and other displaced people from both southern and western Sudan, driven by war and famine, work in irrigated and semi-irrigated farms in central Sudan. Almost seven years of civil war in south Sudan has driven an estimated half-million Shiluk tribesmen to the northern parts of the country. The mostly Christian and animist People's Liberation Army took up arms in 1983 against the Moslem-dominated central government in Khartoum to demand greater autonomy and economic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: 21 Tamil Militants Killed in Factional Fighting
DOC.TEXT: At least 21 militants were killed in fighting between two Tamil groups in the northern Vavuniya district, vacated last week by Indian troops, officials said Tuesday. Military officials in Colombo said at least 18 guerrillas of the pro-India People's Liberation Organization of Tamil Eelam were killed in an attack by the dominant Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. At least three Tamil Tiger militants also were killed in the clash that started Monday and continued early Tuesday, said the officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. They said the fighting erupted after the Tamil Tigers attacked a People's Liberation Organization camp at Chettikulam village, about 135 miles north of Colombo. Earlier Tuesday, President Ranasinghe Premadasa appealed for peace in his troubled nation, where more than 17,000 people have been killed since 1983 in Sri Lanka's twin ethnic wars. Premadasa, who completed one year in office Tuesday, said: ``In this new year and the new era, let us join hands, let us also join hearts, to rededicate ourselves to reunite our motherland, to further the cause of peace, discipline and prosperity.'' Premadasa's one year in office has been marked by daily killings inspired by Tamil militants in north and eastern Sri Lanka, and Sinhalese guerrillas in the south and the center of the country. Fighting between Tamil Tigers and the People's Liberation Organization and its ally, Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front, escalated after India announced in September it was speeding up the withdrawal of its peaceekeeping troops. The Eelam People's Front won control of the Northeastern Provincial Council a year ago in elections boycotted by the Tigers. The Tigers now are trying to dislodge the front and the Liberation Organization and force new elections. The Tigers also have been battling the Indian peacekeeping force sent to Sri Lanka in July 1987 to disarm Tamil guerrillas who have been fighting Sri Lanka's Sinhalese-dominated government for a separate homeland in northeastern Sri Lanka. The Indians, who have lost 1,100 soldiers in the fighting, have withdrawn from six of the eight northeastern districts and pulled out of Vavuniya on Dec. 29. The remaining 25,000 soldiers, deployed mostly in the north, are expected to return home by March 31. The Indian deployment, made under a July 1987 Indo-Sri Lanka accord, angered Sinhalese guerrillas, who started an anti-government campaign of assassinations the same year. More than 6,000 people have been killed in the guerrilla war and the government-sponsored crackdown. Sinhalese, who are mostly Buddhists, are the majority ethnic group here. They comprise 75 percent of the 16 million populace and control the government and the military. Tamils, who are mostly Hindus, make up 18 percent of the population. Tamil militants said they needed a separate homeland to preserve their culture and thwart what they said was discrimination by the Sinhalese majority.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Men Suffer Bone Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to restore time element; INSERTS 1 graf after 5th, ```The major...,' to add that study was published.
DOC.TEXT: Men lose roughly 2 percent of their existing bone mass per year in the same type of loss that can severely affect women after menopause, a study indicates. ``There is a problem with osteoporosis in men that hasn't been appreciated. It's a problem that needs to be recognized and addressed,'' said Dr. Eric Orwoll, who led the study by the Oregon Health Sciences University. Men apparently suffer gradual bone loss throughout their lives, compared with women, who often suffer a marked increase in bone loss after they reach menopause, Orwoll said in an interview Tuesday. Researchers believe bone loss in women is related to the decrease in estrogen levels associated with menopause but no one has studied whether hormonal levels also affect bone loss in men, he said. ``The major point of our study was that, contrary to popular belief, there is significant bone loss in men as they grow older,'' Orwoll said. The study was published in the Jan. 1 issue of the Annals of Internal Medicine. The three-year study, which Orwoll said was the first of its kind nationally, measured the loss of bone from the lumbar vertebrae, or the lower spine, and the forearm. The 77 men studied ranged in age from 30 to 80. The bone loss was detected at all ages and the 2 percent rate did not appear to vary, Orwoll said. ``If you think of that relatively simplistically, you wouldn't have any bone left after 50 years,'' Orwoll said. ``The key is existing bone mass. That means a man may lose half of his vertebral bone mass in a lifetime. ``That's pretty dramatic, and as yet pretty speculative, so I don't want to leave the wrong impression,'' he added. Orwoll said that the skeleton is constantly being broken down and rebuilt, which doctors call ``remodeling.'' Eventually, the entire skeleton is rebuilt several times during a lifetime, he said. ``The problem in bone loss is that not enough new bone is put back when old bone is taken up,'' Orwoll said. He said that calcium and vitamin D supplements given some of the men in his study did not slow the bone loss. However, Orwoll pointed out that all the men in the study were healthy and well-nourished, which could mean that calcium supplements may help men with poor diets. The major effect of bone loss is to increase the brittleness of bones, making them easier to break, he said. ``Fractures definitely increase,'' Orwoll said. ``If you look at the data on broken hips, the incidence goes up dramatically for women from age 50 to 60.'' Women generally suffer twice as many hip fractures as men, he said, but men are increasingly prone to fractures as they reach their 70s and 80s.
Eds: The data for the evening temperature tables was delayed at the source, the National Weather Service. At this time we expect to be able to move the tables in about 30 minutes.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Bomb Explodes in Bureau of Indian Affairs Office
DOC.TEXT: A bomb planted in a federal Bureau of Indian Affairs office blew out windows and doors and ripped out the floor Tuesday, but no one was injured, authorities said. The 5:30 a.m. blast was the second Indian-related bombing in Riverside County in four days, but authorities found no immediate link with a bombing that damaged an office on the Morongo Indian Reservation early Friday. The bureau blast, which also damaged an adjacent office in the building near downtown, was investigated by the FBI and Riverside Police Department. ``We don't know what kind of bomb,'' said FBI spokesman Jim Neilson. He declined to say whether the office had been the target of any threats, but police spokesman Pete Esquivel said that possibility was being investigated. The bureau office is 30 miles from the Morongo Indian reservation, one of several reservations in the area. The two-story building houses several offices, and some of the adjacent ones were damaged by objects hurled through the walls, Esquivel said. ``It was a fairly large explosion, judging by the structural damage to the building,'' he said. A damage estimate was not immediately available. The previous bombing occurred about 2 a.m. Dec. 29 but was not discovered until 7:45 a.m., when workers arrived at a business office of the Morongo Band of Mission Indians near Banning, said sheriff's Capt. Jake Bowser. The explosive was a pipe bomb, but Bowser could not release any other information about the device. It was powerful enough to kill but the bomber may have sought to avoid that by striking at the early hour. ``What you can derive from this is if they wanted to injure someone it would have been timed different,'' he said. There were no known witnesses and both bomber and motive remained unknown, authorities said. There were no threats before the bombing. In the Southeast, a recent string of mail bombings have killed a judge and a civil rights attorney. Federal officials said the bombings may have been carried out by a group with a grudge against the NAACP and the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.

DOC.HEAD: Emigration of Soviet Jews at All-Time High
DOC.TEXT: More than 71,000 Jews left the Soviet Union in 1989, the highest annual figure since the National Conference on Soviet Jewry began keeping track of the emigres in 1968, the organization said Tuesday. Of the 71,196 Jews who left the Soviet Union last year, 12,056 went to Israel, according to the Soviet Jewry Research Bureau of the NCJS. Nearly all the others were bound for the United States. Some 10,000 to 20,000 remain in Italy awaiting permission to come here. Most of the rest have already arrived, and a small percentage went to other Western European countries, Canada or Australia, said Mark Levin, associate executive director of the NCSJ in Washington. Although only 17 percent of the Soviet Jewish emigres overall went to Israel last year, 41 percent of the 8,680 who left the Soviet Union in December went to Israel. ``We see this as a very positive trend in Jewish emigration and welcome it as an integral part of the reawakening of Jewish consciousness now underway in the U.S.S.R.,'' said Shoshana S. Cardin, chairwoman of the NCSJ, in a statement. Most Israel-bound Jews leaving the Soviet Union must travel through Romania, Austria or Hungary. But among those who left in December, 125 did so on the first El Al Israel Airlines charter flight ever to fly out of Moscow, Levin said. ``It's all part of the steps to lead to the resumption of full diplomatic relations between Israel and the Soviet Union,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: American Nun's Choice to Stay in Nicaragua Costs Her Life
With AM-Nicaragua-Ambush
LaserPhoto MGUA2
DOC.TEXT: Sister Maureen Courtney chose to stay with the Nicaraguan people she had served for 15 years rather than take another post last summer because ``she felt that was what she was called to do,'' a friend said Tuesday. Courtney and another Roman Catholic nun, Teresa Rosales of Nicaragua, were killed in an attack on church workers Monday night in eastern Nicaragua. The Nicaraguan government blamed the attack on Contra rebels, but church officials said they could not confirm details. ``She was not at all politically motivated,'' said Sister Jean Steffes, mother superior of Courtney's order, the Sisters of St. Agnes, in Fond du Lac, Wis. ``They simply were there to be with the people.'' Also injured in the attack was Bishop Pablo Schmitz, 46, a native of Fond du Lac and an auxiliary bishop in Bluefields, Nicaragua's main Caribbean port. He was shot in the arm but was in no danger of dying, church officials said. Courtney, 45, a native of Milwaukee, decided a few weeks ago not to come home for Christmas, preferring to wait and celebrate her 25th anniversary as a nun in Wisconsin this summer, Steffes said. ``She loved life and loved to share her life. I think its just a tragic loss of life. I just don't understand this kind of tragedy,'' Steffes said. Courtney taught sewing and catechism to adults at a school in Port DeCasus, Nicaragua, and was helping to establish a medical clinic, the order said. Her parents, Frances and Russel Courtney, have lived in the same suburban Milwaukee home for the last 40 years. Mrs. Courtney said her daughter had been in Nicaragua for 15 years. ``She was supposed to celebrate her 25th jubilee in the order this summer,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``She was just a lovely little girl.'' Mrs. Courtney, 79, said she had been worried about her daughter's safety but did not expect her daughter would be killed. ``Does anybody prepare for death?'' she asked. Church officials said Courtney had visited her mother in Milwaukee last year. A friend said Courtney chose then to return to Nicaragua, although she ``could have gone anywhere she wanted.'' ``She understood what she was in for, but she loved the type of work she was in,'' said Norma Venkler, a classmate of Courtney at Divine Savior Holy Angels High School in the 1960s. `She chose to go back. She felt that was what she was called to do.'' Steffes said she visited Courtney's parents Tuesday. ``It's very difficult for them,'' she said. ``They have lost a child.'' The Courtneys supported their daughter's decision to stay in Nicaragua and understood why she had no plans to return to the United States permanently, Steffes said. ``The people are wonderful,'' she said. ``The people are warm and they want peace.'' She said the Courtneys ``found it difficult but they know that's what Maureen wanted.'' Ms. Venkler said Courtney decided to become a nun immediately after high school. Before going to Nicaragua, Courtney taught elementary school in Beloit, Wis., and in Harlem in New York City, Steffes said. Bishop Schmitz went to Nicaragua as a missionary in 1972 and was ordained auxiliary bishop in 1984, according to Brother Larry La Cross, a spokesman for the Capuchin Order provincial headquarters in Detroit. ``It's an awful shock,'' said Schmitz's mother, Lavina Schmitz of Fond du Lac, adding only that she was relieved her son was alive. About 35 Capuchin missionaries work in Nicaragua. La Cross said they hadn't expressed any concerns about their safety in the days before the attack. Milwaukee Archbishop Rembert Weakland, an acquaintance of Schmitz, said he was a ``very devoted and pastoral bishop who has been very careful in avoiding any political involvement as he preaches the Gospel and ministers to his people.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Newspaper Denies Frenchman's Body Was Booby-Trapped
DOC.TEXT: An official newspaper claimed Tuesday that a French aid worker's body was burned in an airport traffic accident as it was being driven to a plane for a flight to France. The report in the Al-Kuwat Al-Musalaha was the first reaction from Sudan's military government to the incident last week. A French Embassy spokesman insisted the body was booby-trapped and exploded. The Paris-based aid organization for which the man worked has also made that claim. The corpse was among those of three Frenchmen who died with a Sudanese colleague when their light plane was shot down Dec. 21 in southern Sudan. The government blamed southern rebels, but rebel spokesmen denied involvement. On Dec. 29, the French aid organization Medecins Sans Frontieres said in Paris that the Frenchman's body exploded at Khartoum airport. Agency spokesmen said medical personnel at the scene did not believe the explosion was caused by a buildup of natural gases, and feared the body had been booby-trapped. On Tuesday, the government daily, Al-Kuwat Al-Musalaha, denied there was an explosion and said the Frenchman's body was burned in a traffic accident on the tarmac. The newspaper said a French Embassy pickup truck carrying two of the bodies collided with ``rails'' on the tarmac, a term it did not explain. After the accident, it said, friction of the truck's body against chemical and plastic materials meant to prevent decomposition of the bodies caused the fire. The newspaper added that French Embassy officials participated in the investigation and concurred with the findings. But a spokesman for the French Embassy denied that, saying instead that a dry explosive was ``placed inside the coffin or was attached to it,'' causing the explosion. He said an Ethiopian working as the embassy's driver also was severely burned and that a Sudanese and an Eritrean also were injured. Southern Sudanese rebels have been waging a civil war against the government in the north since 1983.

DOC.HEAD: Two Nuns, Including American, Killed in Nicaragua; Bishop Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to RECAST and move higher Nicaraguan government blaming Contra rebels. Picks up 6th, `Northeastern Nicaragua...' Russel is cq
DOC.TEXT: Two nuns, including one from Milwaukee, were killed and an American bishop and a third nun were wounded in an attack on their car in northeastern Nicaragua, church officials and radio reports said Tuesday. Church authorities said gunmen ambushed the car Monday night, but one suggested later that a land mine explosion may have been responsible. The Nicaraguan government blamed Contra rebels for the incident, which the Rev. Marcelino Estrada said took place on a highway near Puerto Cabezas in the remote Caribbean coastal region, about 200 miles northeast of this capital. The church said it had no information as to responsibility. Church officials and family identified the slain nuns as Maureen Courtney, 45, of Milwaukee, and Teresa Rosales, a Nicaraguan. Bishop Pablo Schmitz, 46, of Fond du Lac, Wis., auxiliary bishop of Bluefields, was wounded in the arm. ``He has lost a lot of blood,'' said Estrada, a Roman Catholic priest in Bluefields. ``He is out of danger.'' Northeastern Nicaragua is an isolated area with few roads. A stronghold of the Miskito Indians, it formed an autonomous part of the Contra resistance. Bluefields, Nicaragua's main Caribbean port, is about 100 miles south of Puerto Cabezas. Sister Jean Steffes, mother superior for the Sisters of St. Agnes in Fond du Lac, said reports she received from Nicaragua indicated the church workers were traveling between cities and may have driven over a mine. ``We're assuming it was a mine. But we just don't know,'' she said. She told reporters in Wisconsin it marked the first time members of her order were killed doing missionary work. She identified the wounded nun as Sister Francisca Maria Colomer, 24, a Nicaraguan. The nun suffered head and face wounds, but would survive, she said. The mother superior said the two Nicaraguans became nuns on Jan. 21, 1989. Frances Courtney, mother of Maureen, told journalists in the Milwaukee suburb of Wauwatosa, ``I just found out, the convent came and told me. They know nothing either. She is dead.'' Mrs. Courtney, who lives with her husband Russel, said her daughter had been in Nicaragua 15 years. ``She was supposed to celebrate her 25th jubilee in the order this December,'' the mother said. ``She was just a lovely little girl.'' Schmitz went to Nicaragua as a missionary in 1972 and was ordained auxiliary bishop in 1984, according to Brother Larry La Cross, a spokesman for the Capuchin Order provincial headquarters in Detroit. Schmitz was identified as part of the Capuchin order of the Order of the Franciscans. Thomas Quigley, adviser on Latin American affairs at the Washington-based U.S. Catholic Conference, said he spoke to the provincial superior of the Capuchins in Managua, who gave him this account: Two carloads of church people started out, including Bishop Salvador Schlaeffer of Bluefields, and Schmitz, his auxiliary bishop. ``They were going to a meeting scheduled for Puerto Cabezas, to meet with leaders of the Miskito community. They drove from Managua, and left yesterday (Monday) morning. They drove to Siuna en route to Puerto Cabeza.'' Schlaeffer and the people in that car decided not to continue driving that night because it was late. ``Schmitz and the three ... sisters of Saint Agnes continued on. At about 7 o'clock last night, they were ambushed, and the result is two people killed, two people wounded.'' Norma Venkler, a classmate of Maureen Courtney in the 1960s at Divine Savior Holy Angels High School in Milwaukee, said her friend was setting up an education system for the Miskito Indians. About 35 Capuchin missionaries work in Nicaragua. La Cross said his headquarters is in frequent contact with them and no concerns were expressed about their safety in the days before the attack. Radio Catolica reported the attack, as did the government-run Voz de Nicaragua. Voz de Nicaragua said the attackers were ``Contra forces encouraged by the invasion of U.S. troops in Panama.'' The government did not say why it believes Contras were responsible. The Contras began fighting the Nicaraguan government in 1981, saying the leftist Sandinistas had betrayed the popular revolution that toppled Anastasio Somoza in 1979. A fragile cease-fire ended on Nov. 1, 1988, and fighting has been sporadic since then. Asked about the government claim that the Contras were responsible for the ambush, Estrada replied, ``We have no indication. ... It doesn't matter who has done it, we condemn the fact.''

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militants Blow Up Bus
DOC.TEXT: Suspected Moslem militants hijacked a bus Tuesday, ordered the passengers and driver out and blew it up, police said. Deputy Police Inspector General Shoeb Ali said four men carrying Soviet-made AK-47 assault rifles held up the private bus when it was about to enter Srinagar, the summer capital of northern Jammu-Kashmir state. Ali, contacted in Srinagar by telephone, said the men ordered the 50 passengers to get down on the highway and told the driver, Ghulam Mohammad, to divert the bus to an isolated spot on a side road where they blew it up. There were no injuries, he said. The gunmen escaped in the darkness, and no one claimed responsibility for the attack. The bus was on a regular run between Gulab Bagh and Srinagar, a distance of nine miles. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Moslem majority state in officially secular, predominantly Hindu India. Moslems make up 64 percent of the state but nationwide they comprise only 11 percent of the population of 880 million people. Hindus make up 82 percent. Kashmir is claimed both by India and Pakistan, and the two countries have fought three wars over the territory since they gained independence from Britain in 1947.

DOC.HEAD: Unidentified Man Leaves Vatican Embassy; U.S. Hustles Him Away
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with church sources saying man was Cuban, government closes TV, radio stations. Picks up 14th, `President Bush...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAN10
DOC.TEXT: A man emerged Tuesday from the Vatican Embassy, where Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega took refuge more than a week ago, and U.S. soldiers hustled him away. A priest inside said he was ``a little fish,'' not Noriega. At least two of the deposed general's top aides are known to have sought shelter in the embassy, and a Panamanian officer said many former Noriega henchmen were believed to be hiding in the Vatican or other embassies. ``I can assure you none of the big ones left,'' said the Rev. Javier Villanueva, reached by telephone in the embassy. He said he did not know the name of the man taken out. Reporters and photographers with telephoto lenses posted on the roof of a nearby hotel agreed the man did not appear to be Noriega. He came out of the embassy with two others, including Villanueva, and was turned over to the American soldiers who surround the compound. They marched the man to a helicopter, which took him away. Church sources said the man was a Cuban trying to get a visa to the United States at the time of the U.S. invasion and fled to the embassy fearing for his life. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he was flown to Fort Clayton, headquarters of U.S. Army South near Panama City, to be investigated. U.S. Embassy spokesmen said they had no explanation. Seventeen people besides Noriega are believed to have sought asylum inside the Vatican Embassy, among them Lt. Col. Nivaldo Madrinan, director of the secret police, and Capt. Eliezer Gaytan, chief of Noriega's personal security force. Col. Roberto Armijo, head of the Security Forces created since the U.S. invasion Dec. 20, said Tuesday many former Noriega aides were believed to have eluded capture by hiding in embassies. The Vatican announced that one of its top experts on Latin America had arrived in Panama to help in the negotiations about Noriega's fate. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said Monsignor Giacinto Berloco would ``give a hand'' to the papal nuncio, Sebastian Laboa, who is the equivalent of an ambassador. Navarro would not give details and said the Vatican would have no comment. The Vatican has said it was trying to convince Noriega to leave the building, but also has said it would not hand him over to the United States without his consent. Foreign Minister Julio Linares said Tuesday he is confident the Vatican will turn Noriega over soon but urged patience. ``The Vatican wants to come up with a solution that will not cause trauma to anyone,'' he said. ``The Vatican will turn him over. It has to do it. ... No one would ever consider Noriega a political refugee.'' The government, meanwhile, closed two television and 10 radio stations believed linked to Noriega and declared them ``under state custody.'' Government spokesman Edwin Cabrera said the stations' finances would be investigated and their assets expropiated if irregularities were found. If not, he said they would be returned to their owners. ``We don't intend to turn these mediums into propaganda machines while they are under investigation,'' he said. President Bush named career diplomat Deane Hinton as ambassador to Panama, the White House announced Tuesday. Hinton, now ambassador to Costa Rica, replaces Ambassador Arthur H. Davis, who was recalled months ago. Officials in Washington said Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger would fly to Panama for talks with President Guillermo Endara on U.S. aid to Panama and other issues. Panamanian officials said Eagleburger would meet with Endara and Vice Presidents Ricardo Arias Calderon and Guillermo Ford Wednesday morning. Sen. Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee, was in Panama on Tuesday to review military operations. Outside the white-stucco compound where Noriega sought shelter on Christmas Eve, Panamanians wait and an effigy of Noriega with a pineapple for a face hangs by a rope. Many critics called the general ``pineapple face'' because of his acne scars. ``We are waiting for the nuncio to turn Noriega in to the gringos so he can pay for everything he's done to us,'' a woman said. ``The heat doesn't matter. Here we stay.'' Throughout the day, trucks with loudspeakers circulated through the capital, urging citizens to join an anti-Noriega rally. At a roadblock, about 200 showed up, shouting: ``Noriega, you're trash! Get out of the nunciature!'' Armijo, head of the new Security Forces, said an interview Noriega should be handed over to the United States because he is a ``latent threat'' to the country while sheltered in the Vatican Embassy. He said many of Noriega's most notorious officers were believed to have sought refuge in foreign embassies. ``They are not fighting,'' he said. ``There is no combat. The last surrender was two days ago.'' Among the top officers, he said, were Gonzalo ``Chalo'' Gonzalez, a former commander of Noriega's headquarters, and Col. Luis ``Papo'' Cordoba. Both were identified as torturers by prisoners released from the headquarters after the invasion. U.S. troops have surrounded the Nicaraguan, Libyan and Cuban embassies since the invasion in case some of Noriega's associates sought refuge there. Armijo said a lieutenant and 30 others who ``had taken to the hills'' surrendered to U.S. soldiers Sunday in Chiriqui province near the Costa Rican border, 200 miles west of Panama City. Twenty-three U.S. servicemen and three civilians were killed in the invasion and more than 300 American soldiers were wounded. President Bush sent about 14,000 U.S. soldiers to augment the 12,000 already stationed at bases in Panama. The first U.S. troops _ 141 of them _ left Panama and returned early Tuesday to Fort Ord, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Report Vandalism, Neo-Fascism Spreading in East Germany
DOC.TEXT: Vandals and New Year's Eve revelers extensively damaged Berlin's Brandenburg Gate and neo-fascist slogans were smeared on monuments in East German cities, authorities reported Tuesday. Officials said one man died and about 300 people were hurt in holiday celebrations along the Berlin Wall, the official ADN news agency reported. They said many were treated for cuts from shattered champagne bottles and for broken bones. More than 500,000 Germans gathered along the Berlin Wall to cheer the arrival of 1990. Hundreds scaled the towering Brandenburg Gate and nearby structures. The bronze chariot and horses atop the monument were damaged and some sections will have to be replaced, said Horst Weiss of the national office for protection of memorials. A laurel wreath affixed to a statue of the Greek goddess Nike was stolen, and someone tried to break off an arm, Weiss told ADN. East Berlin police spokesman Michael Braemer told The Associated Press the death of a 24-year-old West Berlin man found in East Berlin was under investigation. Authorities first thought he died when scaffolding holding up an outdoor projection screen collapsed under the weight of revelers shortly after 1 a.m. on New Year's. But Braemer said he may have fallen from a tree along Unter den Linden. ADN said neo-Nazi groups smeared slogans on memorials in other cities and some physical attacks were reported. In Pirna and Goerlitz near Dresden, ``Hitler Lives,'' and ``We are here _ REP,'' the abbreviation for West Germany's ultraright Republican Party, were scrawled on walls and windows, ADN said. In Goerlitz ``Foreigners Out'' and ``Jews Out'' were painted on structures and a memorial to those persecuted under the Nazis was daubed with swastikas, the agency said. Anti-communist demonstrators in Halle spraypainted ``SED _ No Thank You'' on memorials, referring to the East German Communist Party. ``Skinheads'' and neo-Nazi youths carrying homemade weapons threatened passers-by in Erfurt and two people were hurt confronting them, ADN said. The report said some of those arrested said they supported the Republicans. ADN said Communist Party groups planned to protest in East Berlin this week the recent spate of neo-Nazi activity in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Fatalities Up 40 Percent in 1989 Over Year Before
DOC.TEXT: Deaths from illegal drug use rose nearly 40 percent in West Germany in 1989, with 980 reported last year, officials said Tuesday. Frankfurt, with a population of about 600,000, topped the list of West German cities with the highest per capita drug death toll. Officials said drugs killed 80 people in Frankfurt in 1989, compared with 94 deaths in West Berlin, which has a population of more than 2 million. In 1988 Frankfurt had 62 confirmed drug deaths, with 80 in West Berlin the same year. Hans-Georg Fuchs of the Federal Criminal Police office in Wiesbaden attributed the rise to the smuggling of more and higher-quality drugs into West Germany, including increases in cocaine and amphetamines. The most dramatic increases were in the states of Lower Saxony, with 114 drug-related deaths in 1989, compared to 60 the previous year; Baden-Wuerttemberg with 123 deaths compared to 71 in 1988; and the country's most populated state, North Rhine-Westphalia, with 234 compared to 179 the previous year. The figures were provided to news media by state interior ministries in year-end reports.

DOC.HEAD: Vail Skier Killed in Avalanche
DOC.TEXT: A skier was killed and his two companions were injured Tuesday in an avalanche just outside the Vail ski area, authorities said. Scott Walton, 25, of Ridgefield, Conn., was pronounced dead after his body was found by search and rescue teams using probes in the deep snow, said Jeff Beavers, a spokesman for the Eagle County Sheriff's Department. Daniel Gurnett, 24, of Avon, Colo., a Vail Associates employee, and Peter Leitton, 24, of Ridgefield, were injured in the slide shortly before 11 a.m. They were treated and released from Vail Valley Medical Center. Leitton and Gurnett managed to ski out of the avalanche and Leitton hiked back up to the Vail ski area to telephone for help, Beavers said. Beavers said the 100-foot-wide slide occurred outside the China Bowl area, where numerous avalanche warnings were posted. Vail Associates spokeswoman Pat Peeples said the resort did not restrict skiers' access to the area.

DOC.HEAD: County Prosecutor Says He's Victim of Drug-Related Assassination Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 14th graf, `The prosecutor ...' with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that attackers drove off, UPDATE with Asbell saying his guns were registered.
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor known for his tough stance on drugs said Tuesday two gunmen opened fire on him New Year's Day in an assassination attempt, and he shot one of his assailants in the head. ``Thank God I'm alive,'' Camden County Prosecutor Samuel Asbell said Tuesday. ``I guess it just wasn't my day or my time.'' Asbell said the assailants pursued him in a green Toyota station wagon as he left his downtown Camden office about 5 p.m. Monday. When the gunmen opened fire, Asbell fired one round from a 12-gauge sawed-off shotgun, striking the passenger, and then got off seven rounds from his semi-automatic handgun, he said. ``I had my shotgun on my lap and I just let go,'' the prosecutor told reporters at a news conference. ``I saw his head explode.'' State police and the Attorney General's Office are investigating. ``The state is approaching this as a very serious incident,'' said Chuck Davis, spokesman for the Attorney General's Office. ``They're looking at whether it was just a bump-and-rob type, and they're looking at whether it was some sort of narcotics terrorism.'' Asbell said the gunmen shot out the windows of his unmarked county-issued Lincoln Towncar with a MAC-10 automatic weapon. The prosecutor was cut on his hands from the shattered glass, but did not require medical treatment. ``The car that I was driving looks like a piece of swiss cheese,'' Asbell said. ``All I know is my back windows blew into my head. ... I was combing glass out of my head all night.'' Asbell and his family have been placed under 24-hour state police protection. The prosecutor said he was unable to identify the men or get the license number of the car they were driving. A high-profile prosecutor, Asbell often accompanies undercover narcotics detectives on drug raids in the city. Last year, drug arrests increased by four times, according to Asbell, who was appointed county prosecutor in 1984 by Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Asbell, a former practicing attorney, was shot in the chest in 1970 while representing a client whose property was put up for sheriff's sale. The bullet is still lodged in his chest. ``I'm a hands-on prosecutor,'' said Asbell. ``The public knows me. If they know me, the drug dealers know me.'' Asbell said he went into his office Monday to catch up on paperwork after a week-long vacation. He said the gunmen began following him as he drove off, and then opened fire. The prosecutor said he fled, leading his assailants on a 3- to 4-mile chase traveling between 80 and 100 mph through downtown and a deserted industrial park. Asbell said that after the Toyota passed him, he stopped his car and fired the shotgun and the handgun at the vehicle before it drove off. Police were still looking for the car and the assailants. Asbell said both of his weapons were registered. State police spokesman Daniel Cosgrove said the department's crime scene unit has taken custody of the prosecutor's car and planned to photograph it and extract bullets from it. He would not provide details of the investigation. Asbell said he usually travels alone but alters his route several times a week. He said he receives numerous telephone and mail threats weekly and always carries a weapon. Asbell said he may have used poor judgment in going into the deserted office on the holiday. ``It was stupid,'' he acknowledged. ``It was New Year's Day and I didn't think there'd be any problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Maynard Jackson Goes to Work _ Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Among those...,' to CORRECT that Brown and Hooks did not attend.
DOC.TEXT: Declaring ``I'm back,'' Maynard Jackson was inaugurated as Atlanta's mayor for a third term Tuesday after an eight-year hiatus. Elsewhere, Pittsburgh's first elected woman mayor, Sophie Masloff, promised to lower taxes and develop the city's riverfront at her inauguration, while in Houston Kathy Whitmire took the oath of office for a record-tying fifth term as mayor. Among those who attended Jackson's inaugural at the Atlanta Civic Center were the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Rep. John Lewis, D-Ga. Democratic National Committee Chairman Ron Brown and NAACP executive director Benjamin Hooks had been expected but did not attend. ``I'm back, and I want you to know I'm fired up, turned on and I'm ready to roll, starting tomorrow morning,'' Jackson said during a 30-minute inaugural address in which he promised to fight homelessness, crime and drugs and to invest in downtown Atlanta. ``As the Lord as my witness and my guide, we're going to move Atlanta on up to higher ground, and we're going to do it together,'' said Jackson, who was Atlanta's first black mayor. His previous terms ran from 1974 to 1982. Security at Jackson's inauguration was tightened in light of death threats associated with the recent string of mail bombings which federal officials said may have been carried out by a group with a grudge against the NAACP and the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Mrs. Masloff, flanked by her family and colleagues, said her administration would cooperate with other governments and the private sector in competing for new business and conventions. ``In everything we do, we will be concerning ourselves with families: saving and creating jobs, owning a home and getting a mortgage, protecting people from crime and drugs, caring for our older citizens, guiding and loving our children,'' she told several hundred onlookers packing the lobby of the City-County Building. Mrs. Masloff said she would meet with Gov. Robert P. Casey to work on a plan to provide property tax relief for the elderly and trim the city's 10 percent amusement tax, which covers sports events, concerts and other entertainment. She also promised to form a riverfront development commission to create housing, jobs and green space along the Allegheny, Monongahela and Ohio rivers. The former head of the City Council, Mrs. Masloff automatically became mayor following the death of Richard Caliguiri on May 6, 1988. She ran unopposed in the November general election after defeating four challengers in the Democratic primary in May. In Houston, Mrs. Whitmire was joined by 13 other City Council members in induction ceremonies at the Brown Theater. She gave no hint whether she would accept a 24 percent raise that would boost her salary to $130,875. ``I don't think she's had time to think about it,'' spokesman Paul Mabry said. Mrs. Whitmire usually accepts a lower amount for her job, Mabry said. Since she first took office in 1982, she has turned down a total of about $125,000 in pay, he said. Her raise, along with a nearly 14 percent hike for city council members, goes up automatically under a 1977 state law that sets salaries of elected city officials at a percentage of the pay of a Harris County district judge, which is $87,250 this year. Jackson, who enjoyed strong campaign support from neighborhood activists, has said he will try to kill two controversial road projects: the Presidential Parkway, from downtown to the Druid Hills neighborhood; and the Georgia 400 extension, from Interstate 285 north of the city through the affluent Buckhead neighborhood to Interstate 85. His most immediate problem may be money. Finance officers, under the outgoing administration of Andrew Young, have called for a property tax increase; Jackson says he doesn't want one. Jackson, 51, served the maximum two consecutive terms allowed under the city charter and was succeeded by Young in 1982. Young, having served two terms, is running for governor this year. During his eight years out of office, Jackson practiced law, but remained a popular political figure. His chief challenger in the October mayor's race, Fulton County Commission Chairman Michael L. Lomax, dropped out of the race last summer after polls showed him far behind.

DOC.HEAD: Shipping Experts Warn of Dangers from Aging Supertankers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 19 grafs to UPDATE with spill threatening coast, details; CLARIFIES that ship off Morocco not large enough to be a supertanker. Picks up 16th, `Shell is ...
DOC.TEXT: Shipping experts expressed concern Tuesday about the safety of aging supertankers following a tanker explosion and massive oil spill that threatened Morocco's coastline. ``It's certainly true that the world tanker fleet is aging,'' said Geoff Garfield, shipping editor of Lloyd's List, the daily newspaper for international shipping. ``Most companies own ships built in the 1970s and a lot of them are now reaching 15 years.'' Garfield said the accepted life span of a tanker is 15 to 20 years before extensive renovation or replacement is needed. ``There were predictions that supertankers would last 15-20 years but structurally nobody particularly knows,'' said Ian White of the International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation. ``It's like old jumbo jets, we didn't know how long they would last.'' The union representing ship masters and officers is concerned. ``When ships get long in the tooth it gets us worried,'' said Derek Bond, the assistant general secretary of the 20,000-member National Union of Marine, Aviation and Ship Transport Officers said. ``It's a bit like a car, we normally prefer it taken out of service at 20 years, but there is a difference between the way that ships are maintained by first class operators who spend money on maintenance and others who overwork their ships that should be withdrawn from service,'' Bond said. Mike Squires, a spokesman at the International Chamber of Shipping, dismissed concerns about supertanker age limits and said the debate is stoked by commercial interests wanting to sell new vessels. ``A ship is not something that has a best by date on it,'' Squires said, referring to the dates stamped on many supermarket items. Some supertankers can remain in service much longer than others depending on maintenance levels, experts agreed. The Khark 5, built in 1975 and acquired by the National Iranian Tanker Co. in 1986, spilled about 19 million gallons of light crude after an explosion tore through its hull on Dec. 19 in the Atlantic Ocean about 100 miles off Morocco. Oil spill expert Richard Golob said the Khark 5's history, which includes damage in attacks during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, may have contributed to its problems. The vessel was the target of Iraqi fighter jets on at least three occasions between 1986-88, said Golob, who is based in Cambridge, Mass. On Feb. 7, 1988, Golob said an Iraqi jet ``dropped a ... (1,100-pound) bomb on the vessel, setting it on fire and severely damaging its center tanks.'' At least two people were injured, he said. ``These incidents may have contributed to the Khark 5's current problems,'' said Golob, publisher of Golob's Oil Pollution Bulletin.
