DOC.TEXT: Even after exit permits are issued and paperwork is completed, Soviet emigres to Israel often have to wait for transportation six to eight months. And, with a new law in the works, the situation may get worse.

When Efem Starovinsky finally wrested an exit permit from Soviet officials after a 10-year struggle, he thought his emigration problems were over. Then he tried to buy an airline ticket. Starovinsky is one of the thousands of Soviet Jews discovering that while President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has chipped away at political barriers to emigration, bureaucratic and logistical hassles remain. In fact, those problems are getting worse as more people flood an underdeveloped transportation and currency exchange system designed for only a trickle of travelers. According to Israeli sources, more than 51,000 Jews were allowed to emigrate in the first 10 months of 1989, matching the height of the previous tide of emigration in 1979. Starovinsky, a 40-year-old father of two from Lithuania, has been waiting daily in the cold and snow outside the Moscow offices of the Hungarian airline Malev along with dozens of other Jews to get tickets to fly to Budapest, and from there to Israel. ``We waited for many years for the hour when we could arrive in Israel,'' Starovinsky and his group said in an appeal to the Israeli government and emigre activist Natan Sharansky, who heads an Israeli emigre aid organization. ``And now, when we have passed through a large part of the journey, we have wound up in a desperate situation.'' He says airline officials say no spaces are available and only accept two or three names daily on a waiting list. Malev officials could not be reached for comment. Soviet officials refused for 10 years to give Starovinsky an exit permit because his parents wouldn't give their consent. He finally received the permit in September and has been trying since to get a ticket out, in the interim becoming a man without a country. Would-be emigres have given up their apartments, jobs and Soviet citizenship before descending on Moscow from throughout the country to try to obtain airline tickets to Budapest or Bucharest, Romania, the only two transit points from which Israel will accept them. Soviet Jews heading for the United States and other destinations _ about 87 percent of the total, according to Israeli sources _ face similar logistical troubles. Some of those who want to go to the United States are stuck in a limbo caused by tighter U.S. limits imposed on emigration. The new rules give priority to Soviets with relatives already in the United States, and officials have indicated 200,000 people might be turned down in the current year. Israeli officials are hoping to lure 300,000 Soviet immigrants over the next three years with a program providing housing, jobs and air fare to Israel from Budapest or Bucharest. But they feel powerless to help with the Soviet transportation problem. Aryeh Levin, the head of an Israeli consular delegation in Moscow, said the transportation problem is the biggest his diplomats face in trying to get Jews out. Even after exit permits are issued and Israeli paperwork is completed, the wait for transportation averages six to eight months, he said. The Israelis are hoping to cut the wait with direct air flights between Moscow and Tel Aviv, but officials of Israel's El Al Airlines say negotiations with the state-run Soviet airline Aeroflot have stalled over flight prices. No start-up date has been announced. Space on Soviet and foreign airplanes is at a premium because the number of Soviets traveling or emigrating, as well as the number of foreign tourists and businessmen traveling to the Soviet Union, has skyrocketed. For Soviet Jews traveling to Israel, planes are the only option because Israeli officials, fearful they might suddenly choose another country, will not accept them if they leave by train. ``It's practically impossible to buy a plane or train ticket,'' the weekly newspaper Literaturnaya Gazeta complained in a recent article that reported widespread corruption among sales clerks, who it said are accepting bribes of at least 200 rubles ($324) for tickets. The problem is likely to get worse if the Soviet legislature adopts a law lifting most emigration and travel restrictions. Under current law, emigration is granted only for family reunification and travel is by invitation only. Both of these restrictions are to be lifted under a law the legislature preliminarily approved Nov. 13. If the bill is given final approval, Soviet officials predict the number of citizens traveling abroad will jump from 2 million in 1989 to as much as 7 million in 1990. The number of emigres is projected to jump from 200,000 to 600,000. But the logistical problems, like the shortage of spaces on planes, the heavy workload of visa officials, immigration restrictions imposed by other countries and limits on the amount of money Soviets can convert into foreign currency could hinder the flow. Literaturnaya Gazeta said the Soviet Union could be accused of not keeping its promise to open its doors unless transportation and currency exchange problems are solved. ``Without corresponding practical provisions, it (the new law) could turn into just a declaration, not adding anything to real human rights,'' the newspaper said. With the wait as long as it is now, Efem Starovinsky says he ``can't imagine what it will be like'' when the law produces a real exodus.

DOC.TEXT: He once played trombone for Duke Ellington, traveling with the band from Chicago to London, Birdland to Broadway. But he exchanged the bandstand for the pulpit of an inner-city parish in Connecticut.

You can't really blame the organist at St. Mary's for chasing after Monsignor John Sanders to get up there in the choir loft with his valve trombone. If the monsignor could lift the congregation the way those cats were lifted out of their chairs and into the aisles, stomping and screaming, at 2 a.m. in that unforgettable climax to the 1956 Newport Jazz Festival, there would be no need for a sermon and hardly anybody would be ducking out before the second collection. A couple of decades ago, when the Big Band era was in its final full cry, John Sanders held down the middle chair in Duke Ellington's trombone section. Birdland. The Blue Note in Chicago. Boston's Storyville and Ritz Carlton Roof. Carnegie Hall. The Savoy Ballroom and the Apollo Theater up in Harlem. The Paramount and Loew's State on Broadway. London's Royal Festival Hall. John Sanders was up there on the bandstand in white tie and tails sending out sensuous solos and melding joy and sighs into melodic arrangements of ``Mood Indigo,'' ``I Got It Bad and That Ain't Good,'' ``Take the A Train,'' ``I'm Beginning to See The Light,'' ``Don't Mean a Thing If You Ain't Got That Swing,'' ``I Let a Song Go Out of My Heart'' and other Ellington classics. But coming out of Salt Lake City one night, the reading light came on over the right front row seat in the band bus. That meant Duke had an inspiration and was composing again. Then the reading light came on over the seat just behind. John Sanders, who served as Ellington's copyist on the road, was beginning to see the light, a different light. He was absorbed in pamphlets about delayed vocations to the Roman Catholic priesthood. ``I was past 30 and really thought it was too late, but the idea was always on my mind,'' says this son of a New York Harlem postal clerk. ``So I dropped in for a chat with a priest in Salt Lake City. He urged me to look into what I was going to do with the rest of my life.'' Sanders also received encouragement from the Rev. Norman O'Connor, a Paulist priest who had a radio jazz show in Boston and was master of ceremonies at that Newport Jazz Festival when the Ellington band made the police nervous by igniting the crowd to a dancing frenzy with a scorching rendition of ``Diminuendo in Blue.'' It seems like only yesterday the world was John Sanders' bandstand: Hollywood, London, Paris, Rome, Vienna. But now, he does his solo turns from the pulpit and confessional of an inner-city parish in Norwalk, a decaying factory town trying to make a comeback as a historic seaport. Soul has a deeper meaning for this dedicated man with a horn who at the Christmas midnight Mass retreated into the past from his usual pastoral duties to lift his trombone toward the altar for a triumphant rendition of ``Once in Royal David's City.'' ``Do I miss the old days?'' He ponders the question he sometimes asks himself on his knees in his nightly examination of conscience. ``Yes, I really do. But not in the sense of longing to go back. I treasure those memories. Duke made dreams come true of everything I wanted to do or be as a musician.'' Those memories began with a sixth-grader at St. Mark's parochial school in Harlem investing 25 cents of the dollar he got for his 11th birthday in a balcony seat at the Apollo Theater on New York's 125th Street. ``I was always an Ellington fan, before, during and after,'' confesses the monsignor who still rummages through record stores and garage sales for additions to his collection of Duke albums. Sanders took the A-train to the High School of Commerce, where Lincoln Center now stands. He played trombone in the school band, which won him assignment to ``those fine Navy bands at Great Lakes and San Diego'' at the close of World War II. He studied composition and arranging under the GI Bill at New York's Juilliard School and began ``doing gigs'' with Lucky Thompson's orchestra at the Savoy ballroom and some club dates with Mercer Ellington, Duke's son, who had his own group. ``One night Duke needed a substitute trombonist and Mercer recommended me. It was like a dream come true,'' Sanders recalls in his tiny rectory office, his eyes flickering like high altar candles. ``I always thought he was beyond my reach and never met him until I went backstage at the Apollo. He loaned me a jacket, handed me some music and told me I'd be OK. ``They were closing that night with Pearl Bailey. I played the second show. Duke suggested I come out on the road with them for a few nights. He didn't say where we were going or for how long. We went to the South and out through Texas. Four months went by. We wound up in San Diego and I didn't get home until April.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
NORWALK: until April.''
DOC.TEXT: Memories warmed that rectory cubicle more than the afternoon sun faintly filtering through the lace curtains: Going to Hollywood to record Duke's sound track for ``Anatomy of a Murder,'' playing Lyndon Johnson's White House and Carnegie Hall with Ella Fitzgerald, crossing the Atlantic on the Ile de France to do a command performance for the queen and that other duke, the Duke of Edinburgh. Jazz then was America's most popular export, and Ellington's recordings led all Continental charts. ``The Europeans took our music very seriously. They knew everyone in the band,'' he says. ``I'll never forget the Royal Festival Hall. As each of us came on stage they applauded us, like players coming on the field at the Super Bowl.'' Duke and his valve trombonist came home on the Queen Mary. A few weeks later Sanders had a confession to make. He told Ellington he was leaving the band to find himself. An incident during rehearsals at the Blue Note in Chicago eased some of the pain. ``Duke called me over to the piano and played something serene and meditative. I told him it was beautiful. It was an accompaniment to the `Our Father' he was writing for a sacred concert with Mahalia Jackson. ``I never talked religion with Duke and wasn't conscious he belonged to any particular denomination. But his whole way of doing things and how he dealt with us musicians showed a respect and warmth for the individual that I think is very spiritual. ``God was treated reverently on the bandstand, too. Duke was very generous with requests but there was one he would always bypass. If someone requested, as they usually did, `When the Saints Go Marchin' In,' he wouldn't touch it. He felt that with all the other music available, why risk making fun of what his mother taught him as a hymn.'' Ellington hated to lose a fine trombonist and, even rarer, an expert copyist. ``He was very fatherly about my decision,'' says Sanders, his voice still throbbing with the ache of their parting. ``He kept saying: `Do what you got to do and make it work for you.' '' He was ordained on Feb. 10, 1973, by Bishop Walter Curtis of Bridgeport. Duke couldn't get to the ordination; he was off doing one-nighters. But the next day, when the new priest celebrated his first Mass at St. Pius V church in the Jamaica section of New York City, where his family had moved, ``lo and behold, there was Duke sitting in the front pew and, my, it was wonderful to see him.'' A year later, Duke was dead and Sanders was among the mourners at New York's St. John the Divine Cathedral listening to Ella Fitzgerald sing his haunting ``Solitude.'' Sanders doesn't think the motivation for his priestly duties of celebrating Mass, performing baptisms and marriages, hearing confessions, burying the dead, visiting hospitals and homes, counseling youth and senior citizens is all that far removed from the music world. ``Band experience helped a lot with the discipline needed in a priestly life. As a musician I had to practice and be on my toes every night. No matter how well you did the night before, this is a new theater, a new ballroom. Every audience has its own chemistry. ``In the priesthood, no matter how many times you preached and said Mass before, you hope you're not just repeating words. There's a challenge to bring a message of hope through Scriptures, not just something routine. Like at a concert, you begin at the beginning and imagine you're doing it and the congregation is hearing it for the first time.'' When his priestly day is done, the monsignor likes to ``put something on the record player'' and relax in the past. Most often, an Ellington classic. ``I don't use earphones, but I keep it down real quiet, so as not to wake up the whole house. Other priests live here. And in this business, you get up real early: about the time we used to be going to bed.''

DOC.TEXT: Statistics are the ammunition Gus Miller uses in his war against smoking. And while the fight is far from over, he feels he's won a few battles already.

He doesn't sport anti-smoking badges or constantly spout smoke-and-croak warnings like his more militant comrades. Nonetheless, Gus Miller is relentless in his campaign to snuff out what he considers America's No. 1 drug _ cigarettes. His is a solitary, relatively quiet war. His ammunition is statistics. ``I'm a scientist. I'm also a pragmatist. And to me, the best way to do it is to just chip away,'' Miller says. The 65-year-old statistician has been poking into America's penchant to puff since 1972, when he launched Studies on Smoking, a non-profit research group, from his Edinboro home in northwestern Pennsylvania. Last summer, Miller quit his job as a math and computer science professor at Edinboro University to devote all his time to seek out the perils of tobacco. ``Why is this so important to me? Because cigarettes are responsible for 400,000 premature deaths a year,'' he says. ``I've seen so many of my family or my friends die needlessly because they smoked.'' He manages, he says, to push personal feelings aside. ``Yeah, it's an emotional issue,'' says Miller, an ardent non-smoker who despises cigarette smoke. ``But I teach stop-smoking clinics, so you have to use psychology. You can't get emotional about it.'' More than 50 million Americans smoke cigarettes, according to a 1989 report by then Surgeon General C. Everett Koop. An additional 40 million would be smoking if not for changes in an increasingly health conscious environment, the report contends. Miller's efforts to publicize his message have been thwarted at times, he says, because of who he is, or rather who he isn't. ``If you're not a member of `the club' and you're not an M.D. and you want to get into medical journals, you've got problems,'' says Miller, who has a doctorate in educational psychology. ``The club,'' he explains, ``is the people who get all the grant money and publish. That's the club.'' Donald Shopland, public health adviser for the National Cancer Institute's smoking, tobacco and cancer program, acknowledges most published data on smoking is financed through federal grants. Except for occasional, small donations from industry, Miller finances his own research. He figures he's spent $60,000 to $70,000 over the years. ``They are a fairly rare bunch who are doing their own individual research with their own individual funds,'' Shopland says. Despite such obstacles, Miller has had several dozen articles published in professional periodicals. He signs his work as G.H. Miller. Miller also has presented his findings at scientific conferences around the world, including a symposium on cancer prevention in France last April. There, he reported an eight-to-nine times greater risk of cancer among non-smoking women who live with smokers than those in smoke-free homes. He based his conclusion on a study of 906 non-smoking women from surrounding Erie County who died from 1975 to 1980. In late October and early November, Miller attended the fifth General Chautauqua Conference on U.S.-Soviet Relations at the University of Pittsburgh. He spent the week urging Soviet medical officials to adopt more stringent no-smoking measures. Dr. Yuri Lopukhin, director of the Research Institute for Physiochemical Medicine in Moscow and an expert on addiction, was impressed with Miller's work and would like him to visit the Soviet Union to share his views. Although anti-tobacco education has been offered in Soviet schools the past five to 10 years and stop-smoking programs are available for adults, the efforts have not made much of a dent in the country's large smoking population, Lopukhin said. ``I think he (Miller) is, yes, helpful. He is very active,'' Lopukhin says. ``But he maybe does not succeed so much in this very heavy problem in your country and our country, too.''

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
EDINBORO: country, too.''
DOC.TEXT: The Tobacco Institute, a trade association representing U.S. cigarette manufacturers, has criticized Miller for being non-scientific in his collection and analysis of data. ``And of course you get that from your fellow scientists who say, `No, your data is invalid' because it varies from what they have found,'' Miller says. ``You see, my problem is I'm always on the forefront.'' Lawrence Garfinkel, vice president of epidemiology and statistics for the American Cancer Society, is among those researchers skeptical of Miller's work on secondhand smoke. ``Some people don't agree with the methods he uses,'' Garfinkel says. ``He may have done some of the early work (on passive smoking). I can tell you when they cite the studies that have been done, they don't include his very often.'' The surgeon general's 1989 report concludes that secondhand smoke can cause lung cancer in healthy non-smokers. In addition, children of parents who smoke have an increased frequency of respiratory infections. More than one of every six deaths in the United States is due to cigarette smoking, according to the surgeon general. Smoking is responsible for an estimated 30 percent of all cancer deaths, including 87 percent of lung cancer deaths; 21 percent of deaths from heart disease; and 18 percent of stroke deaths. ``Cigarettes are much more deadly, much, much more deadly'' than narcotics, Miller says. ``They're much more addictive. ``That's why we try to push for getting laws strengthened and churn out research articles showing how bad active smoking is and how bad passive smoking is.'' Like many Americans, Miller was unaware of all the risks when he decided in 1972 to take on smoking. He was prompted into action after talking to a nurse about the varying lifespans of men and women. ``I mentioned to her that to me it was pretty obvious smoking has something to do with the male-female longevity difference and the reason I knew that is my father was a heavy smoker. He got emphysema. He tried to quit several times and he got wiped out,'' he says. ``She said, `Well, where's your data?' So I figured, well, let me go chase around and look for data.'' Miller began sorting through Erie County death notices in 1972 in his spare time, noting those people who were at least 30 when they died. By the following year, he was interviewing survivors to see whether the dead had smoked. He found after analyzing the lifestyles of about 500 people that men and women lived to about the same age if they did not smoke. There was a difference of 16 years, though, between smoking and non-smoking women and a 12-year gap between smoking and non-smoking men. The Journal of Breathing published his findings in 1975. ``I knew there was more there,'' he says. ``I started going full-blast.'' In 1976, after compiling data on 3,500 more subjects with the help of volunteers, Miller issued a second report showing similar longevity results. Miller ventured into the controversial area of secondhand smoke in the late 1970s and since has devoted most of his time to it. In a particularly controversial study published in 1984, he reported a significantly higher risk of cancer among unemployed women whose husbands smoked compared to those whose husbands did not. He based his conclusions on 842 Erie County residents who died in 1975 and 1976. The Tobacco Institute still is fuming over that report. ``We assume anything he attempts to publish, anything he presents to a conference, will follow along the same lines of his previous research,'' says Walker Merryman, the institute's vice president. Undaunted, Miller now is trying to determine whether there is a link between secondhand smoke and breast cancer. He also is in the midst of expanding the study he presented in France. When Miller is not collecting data, he's busy trying to get smokers to quit. About 150 people have paid up to $200 to attend his SOS Stop-Smoking Clinic, part of his Studies on Smoking. Nearly half are cigarette-free after one year, according to Miller. Miller, whose only brush with cigarettes was as a youth, says the clinics have made him more tolerant of smokers than some might suspect. ``I don't go out with my sword in hand and lop off heads of people who smoke,'' he says. ``I feel sorry for them because I know it's a very bad habit and I know they probably want to quit and they can't.''

DOC.TEXT: Richard Chamberlain's Hawaii-based medical series is undergoing cosmetic surgery to make it more attractive to the audience. In the near future, his character of Dr. Daniel Kulani in ``Island Son'' will spend more time away from the hospital and become more involved with people. The CBS show also has new opening credits and new music. That went into effect when ``Island Son'' moved from Tuesday to Thursday in mid-December. ``When we go back into production after the first of the year we'll open up the show and spend more time out of the hospital,'' says Chamberlain. ``You'll see those changes around February.'' Chamberlain says this will take ``Island Son'' closer to its original concept of a man who was educated in modern medicine yet still honors the Hawaii traditions and folk medicine of his upbringing. ``These are things we've been asking for for a long time,'' he says. ``The drop in the ratings seems to support me. Now everyone has the same idea. The interesting thing to me as an actor is the human side, not the medical drama. I think people have seen enough faulty gall bladders and hematomas. ``Even doctors have a life outside the hospital, which may come as a surprise to some people. I'll be involved in closer relationships with the residents, and some surprising things will happen in my life. My ex-wife is going to come back and cause me some severe emotional difficulties.'' Besides family and human relations, the show will have fast cars and martial arts. Chamberlain is no stranger to hospitals, of course. His first and only other series, ``Dr. Kildare,'' was one of television's earliest and most successful medical dramas. Since that series in 1961-66, Chamberlain made a name for himself as a classical actor in England, starred on Broadway, made a number of feature films and became the king of television miniseries. He was interviewed during a visit to the mainland while ``Island Son'' was temporarily out of production. Even before starting the series he had moved to Hawaii. ``I've always wanted a house by the sea. Everything I looked at in Malibu was impossible; you can't get into Malibu for less than $3 million. I found this place in Hawaii. It's beautiful and off the beaten track. After doing a miniseries it was a place for me to go and recuperate. It's very healing and soothing.'' The actor says he's been traveling consistently for 25 years and ``wouldn't have missed a second of it.'' But he adds: ``I wanted to put down some roots. I wanted to stop living out of a suitcase. Besides staying put, another reason I wanted to do a series was that I wanted to be involved on the production side. I'm co-executive producer of `Island Son.' That makes the job even more interesting for me.'' The miniseries Chamberlain has done have taken him all over the world. ``Centennial'' landed him in Colorado, ``Shogun'' in Japan, ``Wallenberg: A Hero's Story'' and ``The Bourne Identity'' in Europe and ``Dream West'' in the American West. ``The Thorn Birds,'' an Australian story, was the only one Chamberlain made in California. Two films, ``King Solomon's Mines'' and ``Quartermain and the Lost City of Gold,'' took him to Africa for many months. Recently he went back to Spain, where he had done ``The Three Musketeers'' and ``The Four Musketeers,'' for ``Return of the Musketeers.'' He plays Aramis. Chamberlain's Hawaii-based show had been in development for a long time. There were extensive delays in finding a suitable writer. Nigel and Carol Evan McKeand, who had done ``Family,'' were signed as executive producers only five weeks before production began. Chamberlain would like it much better if the writing and production staff would move to Hawaii but he knows that will never happen. ``It's difficult to grasp the feeling of the islands if you've never lived there,'' he says. ``Our original idea was somewhat different from what's been seen so far. We were going to have more of Hawaii itself in it and more of its healing arts. Kulani is a man who was adopted by a traditional Hawaiian family and raised in this culture. ``I think the first script stressed that too much and Lorimar Television and CBS got anxious. So we're bringing that back. We didn't intend to be so confined to the hospital. We're opening that up.''

DOC.TEXT: Glynis Johns is a perfectionist about acting _ precise, analytical and opinionated about a profession she has worked at all her life. That quest for perfection can be seen in the current Broadway revival of ``The Circle,'' W. Somerset Maugham's nearly 70-year-old romantic comedy about love, marriage and fidelity, which also stars Rex Harrison and Stewart Granger. Johns plays Lady Kitty, a fading beauty who years ago left her husband (Granger) and young son and ran off with Lord Porteous (Harrison). Now the wayward couple has returned, and Lady Kitty watches as her daughter-in-law, Elizabeth, prepares to leave with another man. History is about to repeat itself. In the play's most touching scene, the seemingly frivolous Lady Kitty counsels the young woman about sacrificing her life for a love that may not last. ``The tragedy of love is not separation or death,'' she says. ``The tragedy of love is indifference.'' Their encounter is the high spot of the play, a touching moment in what until then has been a light 1920s drawing room comedy. ``Lady Kitty is one of the most difficult, challenging parts I've had to play _ if you want to play it many-faceted,'' says Johns. Which, of course, she does. Anything else would be giving less than her all. ``As far as I'm concerned, I'm not interested in playing the role on only one level,'' she says. ``The whole point of first-class acting is to make a reality of it. To be real. And I have to make sense of it in my own mind in order to be real. ``I've never seen anyone play this part in the way I'm playing it. And I didn't realize at the beginning which way I was going to go, but it grew and it grew and it's evolved.'' The challenge, she says, was to come in and out of what she calls the character's ``flaky, Billie Burke, surface kind of comedy'' and a moment later show Kitty's real depth. ``In real life, we act according to the cue. We can appear irritable and slightly unpleasant or we can appear terribly good-natured and flaky and frothy and rather lacking in depth. ``Or we can, when it is demanded of us, go into a depth of wisdom and compassion. That is an all-rounded person. I expect that there are people who don't have all those sides but there are many people who do, and I think that Kitty is one who does.'' Johns always has been part of the theater. She's the fourth generation of an English theatrical family. Her father, Mervyn Johns, had a long career as a character actor. Her mother was a pianist. And now the actress' son is also in the profession. Johns was a dancer at 12, an actress at 14 in London's West End. There were countless stage appearances and scores of movies in England and Hollywood ranging from ``Mary Poppins'' to ``The Chapman Report'' to ``The Sundowners.'' Johns is the only member of ``The Circle'' company to have worked before with Maugham. She did a film called ``Encore,'' based on one of his short stories. The actress met the famous writer in the south of France at Vichy, where he always took the waters for a liver problem. ``The place was like a morgue,'' she recalls. ``Some of the people were quite gloomy and odd-looking. I was quite young and bright at the time. I said to him, `This must be very depressing for you coming here every year.' And he answered: `Oh that's nothing compared to the old ladies who come down in their wheelchairs with their Pekingese dogs. They force the jaws of the dogs open and pour the Vichy water into them. They don't take it themselves.' ``The thought of that made him laugh,'' she said. ``The Circle'' is Johns' first Broadway appearance since 1973. The last time she graced a New York stage was as the world-weary Desiree Armfeldt in Stephen Sondheim's ``A Little Night Music.'' The musical had gone into rehearsal with some of the book and score unfinished, including a solo song for Johns. The actress had specific thoughts about how her character should be portrayed. Director Hal Prince suggested she and co-star Len Cariou improvise a scene or two to give book writer Hugh Wheeler some ideas. ``Hal said `Why don't you just say what you feel,''' she recalls. ``When Len and I did that, Hal got on the phone to Steve Sondheim and said, `I think you'd better get in a cab and get round here and watch what they're doing because you are going to get the idea for Glynis' solo.''' In one night, Sondheim wrote ``Send in the Clowns,'' possibly the best-known Sondheim song of all time. It also was a perfect marriage of performer and material. ``I've had other songs written for me, but nothing like that,'' Johns says. ``It's the greatest gift I've ever been given in the theater.'' Until ``The Circle,'' the actress had never worked with Harrison although they had met years ago and had a lot of mutual friends. He was the reason she did the play. ``Rex is wonderfully, innately talented, and it's a gift that God gives you,'' she says. ``You don't learn what he's got.'' Is she fussy now about the roles she chooses? ``It depends on how well-stocked my bank balance is,'' she says. ``I've retired many times. My personal life has come before my work. The theater is just part of my life. It probably uses my highest sense of intelligence, so therefore I have to come back to it, to realize that I've got the talent. I'm not as good doing anything else.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Video View: Home Video News and Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``Pink Cadillac'' (Warner Home Video. VHS-Beta, $89.95. Rated PG-13)
The usually stoney-faced Clint Eastwood, who gives one-note performances with snarling grace, is a master of disguises and voices in Buddy Van Horn's ``Pink Cadillac.'' And he's as funny as Dirty Harry is mean. That's the good news. The bad news is that ``Pink Cadillac'' treads on old ground and never really takes off. Written by John Eskow, whose only other film credits are two shorts for TV's ``Saturday Night Live,'' the adventure-comedy-romance follows the antics of Tommy Nowak (Eastwood), an easy-going but resourceful guy who hunts down bail-jumpers and brings 'em back alive. ``I find you, fetch you and Federal Express you,'' he tells his latest target, Lou Ann McGuinn (Bernadette Peters). Bringing back Lou Ann, who's charged with possessing conterfeit money, has a few problems. First of all, the money belongs to her ex-con husband, Roy (Timothy Carhart), and his mangey white supremacist friends who belong to a violent armed and angry group known as The Birthright. Second, the group has laundered the phoney stuff for real greenbacks and stuffed about $250,000 worth of bills in the back of Roy's pink Cadillac convertible, in which Lou Ann has absconded. Things are further complicated when The Birthright snatches Lou Ann's baby, and offers to swap the tiny tyke for the loot. Alex (Michael Des Barres), the leader of the group, which wants to keep America pure for white, Protestant Americans, also plans to kill ``the female'' who has given them so much trouble. In the meantime, Tommy violates his own ethics and the ethics of the ``skip-tracing'' trade by falling in love with Lou Ann. Despite injections of violence and some tired car chases, the mood is mellow and understated, and there is infinite comic relief from Eastwood and Peters. Eastwood's something for nothing hustles are a riot. Watch for the casino scene in which he dons a gold lame tux, greases his hair until it gleams like patent leather and appends a mustache. But the direction of Van Horn, who also did ``The Dead Pool'' and ``Any Which Way You Can,'' is often labored, and the pacing is slowed to a crawl. Eskow's dialogue is trite and uninspired. ``Pink Cadillac'' had a tepid showing theatrically. On the home screen, though, it's just as interesting as any other TV fare. However, if the theme of hunter forging a close relationship with huntee and ultimately switching the game intrigues you, go to your video store and pick up ``Midnight Run,'' starring Robert De Niro and Charles Grodin, or the black and white classic ``It Happened One Night,'' starring Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
In the Groove: Record Reviews
DOC.TEXT:
``11'' (Capitol) _ The Smithereens
Paul McCartney's sagging record sales, despite a sell-out tour, has led some critics to conclude that the Beatles' influence on popular music has petered out after more than two decades. Yet albums such as ``11'' by the Smithereens show there are still practitioners of the melodic, three minute pop-rock song. And they don't have to sound like anachronisms. ``11'' stands with Tom Petty's ``Full Moon Fever'' as the best ``pure pop'' rock album of 1989. In contrast to Petty's laconic wit and sprightly songs, the Smithereens' music is denser and darker. In fact, if the word ``blue'' were suddenly banned, Smithereens' writer and singer Pat DiNizio would be strapped. But although ``Blues Before and After'' and ``Blue Period'' are two of the first three songs on ``11,'' DiNizio shifts moods more effectively than in the past. ``A Girl Like You'' is radio-friendly, with Jim Babjak's metallic guitar reassuring those who worry the Smithereens' may not be tough enough. The exceptionally pretty ``Blue Period'' features Gary Sutyak's cello and backing vocals by Belinda Carlisle. ``When you think that you have won, then your heartbreak's just begun,'' DiNizio sings, in two lines that neatly encapsulate his romantic philosophy. ``Baby Be Good,'' which musically quotes ``I Only Want to Be With You,'' and ``William Wilson'' are the only two weak cuts of 10 on this album. And with ``Maria Elena'' and ``Kiss Your Tears Away,'' the ending is strong and unusually upbeat. The former is a musical tribute to Buddy Holly and a lyrical tribute to the love that endures with his widow. The latter is an exotic lullaby with a sitar-like guitar sound. With ``11,'' the Smithereens have rebounded forcefully from a mediocre followup to their promising full-length debut, ``Especially for You.'' _ By David Bauder, Associated Press Writer.

Concierto de Aranjuez, Fantasia para un Gentilhombre, by Joaquin Rodrigo; Granada, Asturias, Sevilla, Majorca, Cordoba, by Isaac Albeniz (CBS) _ John Williams, guitar; Philharmonia Orchestra, Louis Fremaux, conductor
This disc of guitar music is unevenly interpreted but unified by superb sound. Williams' guitar is immediate and clear, and the orchestra rich in tone. What is disappointing is their presentation of the Concierto de Aranjuez, perhaps the quintessential Spanish guitar piece. The orchestra sounds stodgy and Fremaux's accompaniment is run-of-the-mill. Williams' playing, though technically excellent, sometimes sounds routine. Maybe it's because he has recorded this piece at least four times. His performance lacks rhythmic snap and the necessary jauntiness of a dandy strolling down a Spanish boulevard. Nor does Fremaux really dig into the romantic passages of the second movement. This is heart-on-the-sleeve music played with hands in the pockets. Things are better in the more intimate but less guitaristic Fantasia. One hears more of Williams' individual notes, and each seems to have a life existing within. Williams is such a fine musician that at times the listener loses the sense of a ``guitar line'' and just hears a melody. What makes this disc worth acquiring, however, are the Albeniz pieces, free solos evoking different Spanish cities. Each one is a gem. Williams plays completely unself-consciously. He zeroes right in on the mood of each piece and maintains it. These are personal performances that speak directly to the listener. _ By Daniel Wakin, Associated Press Writer.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Star Watch: Diverse Pair Hailed as Certain Oscar Nominees
DOC.TEXT: Amid the flurry of Academy Award hopefuls this year, two actors have been hailed as certain nominees: Jessica Tandy and Morgan Freeman. They are a diverse pair, both in their ``Driving Miss Daisy'' roles and in their own lives. Tandy, 80, is a product of the London stage, a three-time Tony winner who created the role of Blanche DuBois in ``A Streetcar Named Desire.'' Freeman, 52, born in the South and raised in Chicago, is a late-blooming actor who first attracted wide notice with his Oscar-nominated pimp in ``Street Smart.'' In ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Tandy is a cantankerous Jewish lady who is trying to cope with her advancing years and the myriad changes in the South following World War II. Freeman plays Hoke, a crafty survivor of a lifetime of subservience who learns over the years to deal with Miss Daisy's temper. In her 90s, she tells Hoke, ``You're the best friend I've had.'' Both performers were recently in Los Angeles to help publicize the film, and their reactions to the Oscar talk was expectable. ``Wouldn't that be nice?'' remarked Tandy. ``It would be wonderful. But I think it's too early to count those chickens. ``(The Oscars are) a great honor, a great honor. But I wish they ended with the nominations, instead of making us adversaries. When they pick the nominations, it means they've picked the best of the crop. It's a pity they have to single them out as one winner and four losers.'' ``For a film, the Oscar is a financial shot in the arm, no doubt about it,'' commented Freeman. ``For an actor, it's a tremendous career advancement. Or, it could very well be an albatross. One never knows.'' His nomination two years ago was a welcome ``pat on the back, but I can't say it was the reason I got such-and-such a part. I might have gotten that part because they saw me perform and said, `Hey, this guy is good.' I rather think that is what happened.'' Freeman originated the role of Hoke off-Broadway and won an Obie for it. Tandy saw the play twice but never thought about playing Miss Daisy in the film _ ``I didn't even know if it would be a film.'' But she was delighted when the producers, Richard and Lili Fini Zanuck, asked her to join the cast. She appears on the screen throughout. ``I like big roles, I like to be there all the time,'' she laughed. ``I wanted to be as good as I possibly could. But I didn't think it was out of my range.'' In terms of energy and appearance, Tandy seems a few decades less than her real age. She was asked how she managed to play an old lady. ``I AM an old lady,'' she insisted. ``I'm not as old as that lady, but I can imagine what it's going to be as I get stiffer and weaker. I've observed it in other people.'' Freeman, who spent his early years in Greenwood, Miss., had no problem understanding Hoke. ``This character was totally realized on paper,'' he said. ``(Playwright and screen writer) Alfred Uhry had dotted all the i's and crossed all the t's. There was little for me to do but slip into it and do it. ``Having grown up in the South, I knew this man. He was a real, finely drawn composite of a lot of people. ... I don't think of him in terms of being `subservient.' You live in a certain society, and that society has rules, and you abide by them. You can always do that with a certain amount of dignity.'' Jessica Tandy was born in London and made her stage debut in 1927 with ``The Manderson Girls.'' She first appeared in New York in 1930 and for 10 years she shuttled between Broadway and London's West End. A 20th Century-Fox contract brought her to Hollywood, and in 1942 she married an MGM actor, Canadian-born Hume Cronyn. In 1946, she had the role of a lifetime, as Tennessee Williams' doomed heroine in ``A Streetcar Named Desire.'' She won the Tony, but she was missing from the cast of the movie. ``I didn't expect it, and I understood perfectly,'' she remarked. ``I would have loved to do the movie, but Elia Kazan was able to keep his whole cast together with the exception of me. It was Warner Bros. that wanted to have a movie star (Vivien Leigh). So you pick yourself up and go on to the next thing.'' She went on to a busy career, co-starring with Cronyn in plays (``The Fourposter,'' ``The Gin Game''), films (``Cocoon,'' ``batteries not included'') and television (``Foxfire''). Morgan Freeman was slower to establish himself as an actor, but seems to be making up for it in later life. After Air Force service, he studied drama and dance, played everything from ``Hello, Dolly'' to ``Coriolanus'' in New York. His career flowered with ``Street Smart.'' This year he has appeared in a staggering four films: ``Lean on Me,'' ``Johnny Dangerously,'' ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' ``Glory.'' Does he wish that success had come sooner? ``There is a tendency to wish things had happened earlier. But there's always the danger that happening earlier would not be in your best interests,'' he said. ``It's safe to assume that the world is unfolding as it should.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Masked Women Fight Discrimination in Art World
DOC.TEXT: The two women are dressed in black. They speak with passion and gravity. They argue about art and sexism. They wear gorilla masks. They are the Guerrilla Girls, self-proclaimed ``conscience of the art world.'' And in their crusade to end discrimination against female and minority artists, these artists will quote statistics and cite examples, but they won't reveal their identities. Instead, they wage ``Guerrilla Girl'' warfare. They have surreptitiously plastered walls with black-and-white broadsides since 1985. ``Bus companies are more enlightened than NYC art galleries,'' reads one poster, which compares the percentage of women who are bus drivers (49.2 percent) and managers (43 percent) to the number of women represented at the city's 33 major art galleries (16 percent). ``How many women had one-person exhibitions at NYC museums last year?'' asked another poster in 1986. Answer: one at the Museum of Modern Art and none at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art or the Whitney Museum of American Art. A similar group, Mothers of Medusa (they wear Medusa masks), has postered Los Angeles, crashed the opening of the Museum of Contemporary Art and distributed plastic snakes with messages attached about the lack of visibility of women artists. There also have been guerrilla actions in Chicago and Texas. But the Guerrilla Girls stress they're not an organization as much as a state of mind. There's no national structure, or even a local organizational structure. What galleries show no more than 10 percent women artists? What male artists allow their work to be shown in those galleries? What art critics write about women artists less than 20 percent of the time? The Guerrilla Girls name names. They may wear masks. They may go to outrageous lengths to maintain their anonymity, arranging that an interview take place in a large basement painted entirely in black, at a converted warehouse in lower Manhattan. But the Guerrilla Girls are very serious. ``The art world, which is supposed to be such an enlightened, liberated situation is in fact worse than corporate America,'' said Girl No. 1, dressed in a black turtleneck, khaki shorts and a fierce-looking mask with fangs. ``We don't want this generation that's right now to be lost, so that 100 years from now, feminists have to be digging up who was doing art now,'' said Girl No. 2, clad entirely in black with a somewhat tamer mask. The group was born in 1985 after the Museum of Modern Art mounted a grand-scale survey of international art, and less than 10 percent of the artists included were women. They worked under cover of darkness, concealed by a cloak of anonymity, to avoid retribution from galleries and museums and to allow the message to stand alone, unclouded by personalities. Gallery owners don't agree with them and don't like them. The Museum of Modern Art would not comment on them, and the Met did not return calls made by The Associated Press. Most of the Guerrilla Girls are visual artists, although they say some sympathetic women in positions of power in museums and other institutions also belong. The two women interviewed _ both artists themselves _ won't say how large the group is. They put out about a half-dozen posters a year, and have sponsored exhibitions, panel discussions and lectures at which sexist audience members are likely to be pelted with bananas from the stage. They are distinctly low budget. Most of their money comes from small donations, although they received grants for two art shows. Their campaign shows signs of success. More women are getting into galleries and major museums have held a few shows of female and minority artists, including the Guggenheim, which now is showing the works of Jenny Holzer. The standard college text, H.W. Janson's ``The History of Art,'' has been revised to include women. But detractors such as gallery owner Mary Boone say the Girls are climbing up the wrong tree. Three of the eight Americans she represents are women. ``The whole art world is highly competitive and discriminatory,'' she said. ``But it's discriminatory based on talent, not on gender. ... The issue is not men versus women, the issue is really success versus failure.'' Yet even critics concede that women historically were discouraged from expressing themselves as artists, just as they were kept out of most pursuits except housework and parenting. Art critics and historians were generally men, and the women who did manage to produce art were often ignored. The lead character of the Pulitzer Prize-winning play ``The Heidi Chronicles'' is a feminist art historian who tries to rectify those centuries of neglect. Author Wendy Wasserstein applied some guerrilla tactics herself, incorporating into the play slides and lectures about women artists through the ages, such as Clara Peeters and Lily Martin Spencer. Now wherever the play is staged, Wasserstein said, ``they're going to have to show slides (of works by women) forever.'' But major hurdles remain, the most significant being money. Art is a field in which success increasingly is judged in terms of dollars. ``The disparity in terms of the economics is unbelievable,'' said Girl No. 1. According to the U.S. Census, women artists earn a third of what their male counterparts make. The highest price for any painting by a living man was $17.05 million, the winning bid last year for Jasper Johns' ``False Start.'' That is more than 81 times the record price for a contemporary painting by a woman _ $209,000 for ``Three Trees'' by Susan Rothenberg _ and nearly four times the record price for any painting by a woman, $4.51 million for Mary Cassatt's ``The Conversation.'' Art dealers say prices for art are not based on gender, but rather on a hierarchy that places artists such as Picasso and Van Gogh on one level, Johns and Andy Warhol at another and so on. The price is based on supply and demand, the accessibility and the desirability of the work and the artist's audience, Boone said. Very few command multimillion-dollar prices. Susan Dunne, a contemporary art specialist at Christie's auction house, said the prices fetched by female artists such as Joan Mitchell and Holzer are rising. The Girls hope to accelerate that trend through cagey manipulation of the auction system. ``It doesn't happen accidentally that particular male artists have hit particular auction prices,'' said Girl No. 2. The high prices usually follow museum shows or other publicity-generating events that heighten interest in the artist. ``So what we're saying is, OK, it's not only the white guys who can play this game,'' she said. ``We can set things up, push for certain women who might be able to break certain auction prices, or certain black artists who we think can break auction barriers.'' The Girls will continue putting out the posters and plan a billboard for lower Manhattan. They also are considering a sex-discrimination lawsuit against one or more of the big New York museums. All get some federal funds, they note. ``The bottom line is women artists are there, and artists of color are there,'' said Girl No. 2.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: Warren Zevon's Excitable Boys
DOC.TEXT: In rock 'n' roll, there's the Beatles expert _ the kind of guy who plays ``Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band'' backwards looking for hidden messages. There's also the Dylanologist, who will pick through garbage if necessary to find the ``meaning'' of the master's music. And don't forget the Springsteen fanatic, proudly singing along throughout the Boss' four-hour concerts. But what about Warren Zevon fans _ call them Excitable Boys _ who must still be scratching their heads over ``Werewolves of London'' and ``Roland the Headless Thompson Gunner.'' Just what did he mean by ``I saw Lon Chaney walking with the Queen,'' or ``Accidentally like a Martyr.'' Zevon doesn't know himself. Search through his garbage, and you'll find egg shells, milk cartons and a shopping bag from the local video store. Play his records backward and you'll wind up with nice, big scratches. Sing ``Lawyers, Guns and Money'' in public and you'll likely be dragged away. ``I'm always saying the lyrics I'm the happiest with are the ones I can explain least,'' said Zevon, whose new album is called ``Transverse City. '' ``When I hear a lot of meanings read into them I don't object because there must have been a lot of stuff bubbling subconsciously to come out so quick and seem magical. I don't think it's an important enough job in the world where God is sending me lightning bolts and I'm just his vessel. It's a little lofty.'' So don't think that Zevon's gone political just because he sings about perestroika and Afghanistan on ``Turbulence''; he lets his friend, Jackson Browne, take care of issues. Zevon's view of the world is as even as his deadpan style of speaking. He sees himself as just another song and dance man who doesn't get upset by the evening news. ``I'm not a big `sides taker.' I wonder why the bad guy did it, it's hard for me to see good and bad guys. I think when you do it, it enables you to be passionate, and that's fun. It's also productive. ``I'm interested in the lyrics themselves, which is, frankly, something I've been called to task for in Europe where everything is so political, so border-oriented. When I explain it's about how the words go very well together, it doesn't go over very well.'' He was once idealistic, even ``Napoleonic,'' dreaming of the unification of rock songs and modern classical music. Blame it on '60s superstars such as the Beatles and the Rolling Stones. Those groups made it seem simple to Zevon: Make great music and people will buy your records. Blame Bob Dylan, too. ``Certainly Dylan is the biggest, the all-time influence for me,'' said Zevon, born in Canada in 1947 and raised in Arizona and California. ``I heard him and thought, `That's the job.' He invented it. he writes them and he sings them. ``He was the undisputed, impossible to comprehend, master of that form. He was like an astonishing folk guy. It was awesome, seeing a guy with a guitar and a harmonica was really, really amazing.'' So Zevon left his symphony unfinished and played rock 'n' roll. With some help from Browne, who got him a deal with Asylum Records, Zevon released his self-titled debut album in 1976, a time when Browne, the Eagles, Linda Ronstadt and others had struck gold in California. But Zevon was different, his comedy a little too dark for those sunny skies, his rock 'n' roll too tough. Critics admired him, Ronstadt covered ``Poor, Poor Pitiful Me'' and others, and Eagles Don Henley, Glenn Frey and Joe Walsh appeared on his albums. But only a handful of listeners could be bothered with gleeful songs of murder, floods and hairy-headed gents. ``I always like to have violent lryics and violent music. The knowledge of death and fear of death informs my existence. It's a safe, kind of cheerful way of dealing with that issue,'' he said. After his 1982 album, ``The Envoy,'' Zevon didn't release another record for five years. ``The shop closed down for a while'' is how he remembers that period of his life. Now signed with Virgin Records, Zevon finds that fame is still something to be written about, not experienced. So ``Splendid Isolation,'' with its attacks on ``putting tinfoil up on the windows,'' is no poke at himself. When Zevon cites recluses such as Michael Jackson and Georgia O'Keeffe, he does it from a distance, like a street kid tossing pebbles against someone's window. ``I can certainly go to the market. I can certainly go get cheeseburgers. Occasionally, I meet somebody who says, `Aren't you ...?' `I saw you at ...,' `What are you doing here?' I tell them I'm buying a cheeseburger. It's nothing that keeps me from going to get one. ``I remember periods of my life when we didn't have TV like this; we relied on other people,'' he said. ``That's what you did, you saw other people _ from the time you woke up and went to bed. Now, everybody has a Walkman plugged into their ears.''

Books and Authors: The `Anti-Minimalist' Margaret Drabble
DOC.TEXT: One of Margaret Drabble's trademarks is her narrator who makes asides to the reader. This technique can be considered either astonishingly quaint or strictly postmodern. Alix Bowen ``drives north to Harley Bridge ...,'' the narrator tells us in Drabble's 11th novel, ``A Natural Curiosity'' (Viking, $19.95). ``As it is a rural route, avoiding the great industrial conurbations that straddle the middle of upper England, she is not here provoked into much political thought about the nature of the north and How Britain Votes, and you may be spared her occasional reflections on these themes, for this is not a political novel, and anyway her reflections are repetitive and do not seem to be getting her anywhere very fast.'' Drabble said the technique was both a modern device and a Victorian throwback. ``It's a self-aware narrator, a self-reflexive narrator. The address to the reader is, in my view, the product of the rise of English studies in the universities _ that there are readers at least as trained as the writer,'' the author said in a recent telephone conversation from her home in Hampstead, a London suburb. ``But I do think that in both the Victorian period and now, it's the completely natural thing to do. I think that I am addressing not `Dear Reader' like Charlotte Bronte; I'm partly addressing `Dear Postgraduate Student,''' she said. And like the Victorian novels Drabble loves, ``A Natural Curiosity'' is crowded with characters. ``I know that some people have found this book overcrowded. I don't mind that; I quite like overcrowded books myself,'' she said. She is asked how she keeps so many characters straight when she is writing. For example, does she have to stop and think if Shirley Harper knows Susan Enderby, to name two minor characters in the book? ``Yes, I do; I do. I get quite lost in it. But I think she does herself,'' Drabble said. ``I'm sure we all have cousins that we're not quite sure of their relationship, and we think, `Oh, that must have been Uncle Michael's second wife's daughter.' I think that's the texture of life, really. You get muddled up. ``I would say I'm anti-minimalist. I don't like very empty books. Some people's books have been getting emptier; I quite like them to be full, and that indeed is a Victorian thing.'' ``A Natural Curiosity'' brings back Alix Bowen, Liz Headleand and other characters introduced in Drabble's last novel, ``The Radiant Way.'' The year is 1987 and the tale divides its time between shabby Northam, an economically depressed city in the North, and London, prosperous symbol of privatized England under Margaret Thatcher. As the title indicates, curiosity is much at issue here. Alix has taken to visiting a mass murderer in prison out of a curiosity she can't explain. Liz, a psychotherapist who specializes in the problems of adopted children, is more curious about other people's pasts than her own. The rest of the characters _ husbands and ex-husbands, children and step-children, siblings and half-siblings, lawyers, lovers and losers _ also suffer from curiosity variously labled ``natural,'' ``morbid'' and ``fatal.'' ``I think curiosity is good for you,'' Drabble said. ``I suppose the title is also asking, is curiosity natural or can it be morbid? ... I don't know the answer; and the book is partly about that.'' Drabble is considered one of England's foremost contemporary novelists, although she was relatively unknown on this side of the Atlantic until her sixth novel, ``The Needle's Eye.'' Despite literary acclaim she cannot entirely escape the ``women's writer'' label assigned to her more than a quarter-century ago. ``I don't write for women only, but I recognize the fact that a majority of my readers are women. But then I think the majority of readers of serious fiction ... are female. I wouldn't like it to be thought that I wrote only about women's topics. But I think I probably do write from a woman's point of view,'' she said. Drabble was born in Yorkshire, in northern England, in 1939. She graduated from Cambridge with honors and married the actor Clive Swift. When he joined the Royal Shakespeare Company at Stratford on Avon, she went with him, appearing in minor roles before abandoning acting for writing. They divorced after 15 years and three children, and in 1982 Drabble wed writer Michael Holroyd, the esteemed biographer of George Bernard Shaw and others. In addition to her novels, Drabble edited the fifth edition of the Oxford Companion to English Literature, and has written a number of short stories, plays and critical pieces. ``A Natural Curiosity'' is very much a chronicle of the times. Characters discuss kidnappings in the Middle East, worry about AIDS after sexual escapades, buy raspberry vinegar and operate fax machines. Asked if she fears her book will seem dated in the future, the author responded: ``I don't worry about the future. I think if it does become dated it will become dated as a sort of pickled curiosity of what time was like then. I'm just interested in catching all these things before they vanish. ``I think we live in a world of immensely quick social change. One of the techniques of the book, in narrative terms _ I mean it jumps about a lot, with a lot of cross-cutting, quick sequences _ one of the things I'm trying to catch is the speed with which we are fed information.'' Drabble is now working on a third novel in the series started by ``The Radiant Way'' and ``A Natural Curiosity.'' It will focus on the adventures of Stephen Cox, a character off in Cambodia who is referred to but never seen in the latest novel.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Tennessee Ernie Ford Still Draws a Crowd
DOC.TEXT: Tennessee Ernie Ford occasionally refers to himself these days as a ``gray haired, broken-down bass singer.'' The 70-year-old Ford, best known for his TV variety shows in the 1950s and '60s and his million-selling record, ``Sixteen Tons,'' sure draws a crowd for someone ``broken down.'' Some of the top names in show business recently gathered in Burbank, Calif., for a TV special commemorating his 50 years in show business. They included Dinah Shore, George Gobel, Della Reese, the Everly Brothers, George Lindsey and Minnie Pearl. Andy Griffith and Roy Clark taped messages for the 60-minute program, which will be aired in February on cable TV's Nashville Network. ``I had no idea who would be there,'' Ford said. ``It was a marvelous surprise and one great, big beautiful party. This ol' boy was really surprised.'' Ford, known affectionately as ``the ol' peapicker'' and ``ol' Ern,'' was host of a nighttime TV variety show on NBC from 1956 to 1961. He had another program from 1962 to 1965, this one on ABC-TV in the daytime. He believes he came across to TV audiences as a loving member of the family. ``They felt like when the time came for my show, they didn't have to change clothes or put sterling on the table,'' he said in a telephone interview from his home near San Francisco. ``They felt comfortable with me. I met families at state fairs and they seemed comfortable around me and gave me a warm feeling. They'd say, `I feel like I know you.' It was the greatest compliment you could get.'' At last count, he said, ``Sixteen Tons'' has sold 20 million copies worldwide after becoming a sensation in 1955. It was a tribute to blue collar workers, especially coal miners, with such lines as ``I owe my soul to the company store.'' ``Every artist dreams of a song like this,'' Ford said a few days before heading for southern Mississippi and a quail hunting trip. ``It's an everlasting hit. You cover the gamut of the audience with it or with something like `White Christmas' or `Stardust.' ``It's still a must on my act even though it was done in 1955. It seems that young marrieds and even high school kids know it. It caught on to every working man in the world, I guess.'' He did a concert tour of the Soviet Union in 1974 and recalled that Soviets were aware of the song. ``They didn't know me but they knew the song and recognized my voice when I did it on stage,'' Ford said. He is especially known for his religious repertoire and it became traditional for him to end each show with a spiritual number. He has sold more than 24 million gospel music albums, with some still advertised on TV today. ``It's great music,'' he said. ``It fits so well if done right. It's happy music and people enjoy it. You do it because it's good music and good writing and it lends itself to solos, choral work and great orchestration.'' Ford, a crewman on heavy bombers during World War II, said it was exciting breaking into television in the mid-1950s when most of the country was getting acquainted with the relatively new household fixture. ``I was so enthralled getting to go into people's homes. I was comfortable in their homes and they were with me. I felt warm getting into the medium when it was live and black and white. Watching it progress has been a great thrill. It was like flying those big old planes in World War II and then coming into the jet age.'' These days Ford does a handful of concerts a year, sings at a few state fairs, does a little recording and some television specials. His wife of almost 50 years died recently and he has remarried. He said he watches television a lot, especially dramas and John Wayne movies, and he wishes there were more variety shows like his a generation ago. ``TV puts out some good things, but not as much as it used to. The budget rears its ugly head,'' he said. ``We don't have too many people directing and producing who know a lot about it.'' Ford, born Ernest Jennings Ford in Bristol, Tenn., said he wouldn't mind having ``a fat part in a TV movie or a picture, just to see what happens. This gray haired, broken-down bass singer wouldn't turn down something like that.''

DOC.HEAD: Trading Briefly Suspended On Italian Markets After Brokers Protest
DOC.TEXT: Italian stockbrokers on Tuesday suspended trading of shares for 20 minutes to protest the nation's slow pace in modernizing the securities business. The protest delayed stock exchange operations on Italy's largest market in Milan and in minor markets in Rome and Turin. It did not prevent regular listing of closing prices. Italian stockbrokers, who have a monopoly on executing transactions, want Parliament to move faster on a number of bills regarding public tender offers, insider trading and anti-trust regulations. Trading volume of Italian markets is one of the lowest in Europe and stockbrokers claim this is the result of insufficient numbers of listed companies and antiquated operations, which they say actually hurts competition and fails to attract foreign investors.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders of UAL Flight Attendants Step Down after Turbulent Five Years
DOC.TEXT: Two top officials of the United Airlines flight attendants' union have turned over the reins of control to new leaders after five years of bitter struggle with UAL management. ``We've been under siege since 1985,'' said Carol Holmes, the local's outgoing vice president. When she and local President Pat Friend left their posts Monday, the Association of Flight Attendants remained deadlocked in contract talks with United and facing a possible strike. Ms. Friend blamed differences within the union's executive council for the inability to reach an agreement. ``It's like walking away from unfinished business,'' she said in a recent interview. She and Ms. Holmes announced in December their decisions to leave their posts, six months before their terms expire. ``I'm not sure I could ever deliver a contract,'' Ms. Friend said. ``The situation calls for new leadership and a fresh perspective. Some catalyst needs to come in and alter the situation.'' United is pressing the union for concessions its leaders say are not warranted or needed by a company as strong and profitable as parent UAL Corp. And the UAL buyout plan _ originally proposed by United Airlines' members of the Air Line Pilots Association as a takeover defense and later embraced by UAL management _ is viewed by the flight attendants as a management ploy to extract givebacks so far withheld by the unions. The original $6.75 billion, $300-a-share pilot-management bid collapsed in October for lack of financing, and has been supplanted with a $240-a-share, $5.43 billion offer. New York investment group Coniston Partners has proposed to back a recapitalization of UAL if there is no deal by Jan. 8. Ms. Friend wants all three United unions _ the 13,000-member AFA, the 7,000-member ALPA and the 25,000-member International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers _ to collaborate on a revised proposal, rather than allow management to dictate terms that require employee concessions for financing. ``There are common interests among the unions and it's time to find out what they are,'' she said. Ms. Friend said a lull in the buyout furor should give her successor, Diane Robertson, a chance to get settled. Ms. Robertson, a 30-year United veteran and past union president, was unanimously elected by the union's master executive council. Ms. Holmes' successor is to be chosen this month. Both Ms. Holmes and Ms.Friend plan to take some time off and then rejoin their colleagues ``flying the line.''

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Minister Says Malev Airline to Be Privatized
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's reform-minded government plans to privatize the Malev state airline, the deputy transport minister said Tuesday. In an interview with the Magyar Hirlap daily, Sandor Kalnoki Kiss said the government had already received many offers for Malev but planned to hire a professional company to handle the sell-off. ``We have not agreed with anyone but we give everyone a hearing and urge them to take part in the competition,'' Kalnoki Kiss said. He said that, while it would be difficult for the government to retain a controlling stake in the airline, his ministry would seek a guarantee to have a say in future company decisions, the news agency reported. Kalnoki Kiss gave no further details. Malev's 22-plane fleet flies to 40 countries in Europe, the Middle East and North America.

Prices moved lower in early trading on Wall Street today as the financial markets anxiously awaited the first economic indicator of the new year. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was off 10.88 to 2,742.32 as of 10 a.m. EST. Declining issues were ahead of advancers by a margin of about 4 to 3, with 441 stocks rising, 595 falling and 437 unchanged on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Big Board came to 17.9 million shares after the first half-hour of trading. Analysts said the stock market was following the lead of bond traders, who were selling as they waited for the National Association of Purchasing Management to release its monthly survey on the economy today. On Friday, Chicago purchasing managers reported strength in the manufacturing economy in their area, and traders were concerned that if the national survey also reported an improvement in the economy, the Federal Reserve would be less likely to nudge interest rates lower. Philip Morris led the NYSE's most active list, trading down [ to 41{. Among the gainers was IBM, which rose 1\ to 95]. Several other big name stocks were among the losers: AT&T was off \ at 45\, Mobil was down [ to 62{, and Exxon was off \ to 49}. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was down 0.61 at 194.43. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 0.41 to 377.59. On Friday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.90 to 2,753.20, extending its gain for the week to 41.81 points. In 1989 the average climbed 584.63 points, or 26.96 percent, capping off a rise for the decade of 1,914.46 points, or 228.25 percent. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 2 to 1 in the daily tally on the NYSE, with 1,072 up, 464 down and 439 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 145.94 million shares, against 128.03 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Union Pacific to Sell Realty Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Union Pacific Corp. plans to sell most of the remaining assets of its realty subsidiary for $532 million to an affiliate of The Koll Co. of Newport Beach, Calif. The deal, which is expected to be closed in February, includes 30 buildings and about 15,000 acres, mostly in western states, Union Pacific said in a statement Saturday from corporate headquarters in Bethlehem. Financing is being arranged by UBS Securities Inc., a Swiss banking firm. Koll Co. is a real estate investment concern. Since Union Pacific's board of directors authorized disposal of Union Pacific Realty's assets last April, it has sold more than $125 million of property. It will continue to market about 1,000 remaining acres, including properties in and near New Orleans, Las Vegas, Denver and Long Beach, Calif. Drew Lewis, Union Pacific's chairman and chief executive officer has said the company intended to focus more on its remaining subsidiaries, including Union Pacific Railroad, the nation's second-largest railroad. Its other businesses include Overnite Transportation, a trucking company, Union Pacific Resources, an oil and natural gas concern, and USPCI, a hazardous waste management firm. Union Pacific had revenue of $6.1 billion in its last fiscal year and net income of $644 million.
