DOC.HEAD: Computer Company Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
DOC.TEXT: MiniScribe Corp. said Tuesday it has filed for protection from creditors under federal bankruptcy laws because it was ``the only practical step'' in light of a series of investor lawsuits the company faces. The Longmont, Colo.-based maker of computer disk drives said it filed for Chapter 11 reorganization Monday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Denver. The move had been expected in the financial and business community because of the pending lawsuits. ``Attracting the new infusion of equity capital that the company needs to take advantage of its new 7000 Series family of one-inch high, 3{-inch disk drives is impossible in the face of 13 class action and individual lawsuits brought by stockholders and debenture holders, which together hold the potential of enormous liability for the company,'' said MiniScribe President Richard P. Rifenburgh. ``We believe that this is the only practical step the company can take to solve its many legal problems,'' he said. The bankruptcy filing follows an internal report in September concluding that former senior managers of MiniScribe had ``perpetrated a massive fraud'' on the company over the past three years. The report painted a picture of a company run amok under the direction of then Chief Executive Officer Q.T. Wiles, once known as the Dr. Fix It of the high-tech industry. Wiles resigned from the company last February. MiniScribe undertook the in-house investigation under pressure from investor lawsuits which allege, among other things, that MiniScribe officials made ``false and misleading statements'' to artificially inflate the company's stock. The company previously announced it was phasing out its U.S. manufactured products and by the end of the first quarter of 1990 would have only a pilot production line, sales and marketing, research and development at its headquarters in Longmont. Most of the company's production already had been taking place through its Far East subsidiaries. Worldwide, MiniScribe employs 5,927 workers, including 849 in the United States. There were 110 positions cut last year with the company's announcement it was ending its manufacturing lines here. In conjunction with the bankruptcy filing, the company's lending bank, Standard Chartered of Hong Kong, agreed in principal to permit the company to use the bank's cash collateral and to provide debtor-in-possession financing of up to $20 million, MiniScribe said, but the bankruptcy court now will have to approve those plans. The company also earlier retained Merrill Lynch to formulate a Chapter 11 recapitalization and reorganization plan to allow the company's continuing operations to emerge as soon as possible from bankruptcy. MiniScribe said because of the complexity of the multiple claims against the company, and its ``substantial negative net worth,'' the reorganization may involve a purchase of assets by new investors to set up a new company, with claims then being handled from the proceeds of the sale. The company also filed its long-delayed Form 10-K with the Securities and Exchange Commission, showing totals assets of $200 million and total liabilities of $351 million excluding any liabilities that could be established by the pending lawsuits. ``The years of neglect of the company's financial accounting function have compounded the difficulty in arriving at these numbers,'' Rifenburgh said. ``We have had to restate three years of financial statements, frequently having to reconstruct records, and utilizing a staff that has been seriously overburdened.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Slip On Weather, Crop Program
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting wet weather in South America, snowy forecasts at home and an anticipated increase in U.S. soybean acreage. Expectations for new grain sales to the Soviet Union and Romania limited the early losses. Weekend rainfall in South America helped the soybean crops there, analysts said. Snow is expected this week in the Great Plains and Midwest, where any precipitation is welcome after two dry summers. Additional selling in the soybean complex stemmed from new Agriculture Department policies that are expected to increase soybean acreage this year. A crop program rule announced Friday will permit participating farmers to plant up to 25 percent of their base acreage with certain crops, including soybeans. ``The USDA expects a gain of about a million acres of soybeans,'' said William Biedermann, director of research with Allendale Inc., a futures brokerage in Crystal Lake, Ill. In early trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.08} a bushel; corn futures were } cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower wiith March at $1.53 a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 3 cents lower with January at $5.66{ a bushel. Cattle futures were slightly higher while pork futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .07 cent to .20 cent higher with February at 77.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .25 cent higher with January at 85.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .17 cent lower to .18 cent higher with February at 48.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .20 cent to .35 cent higher with February at 50.22 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mixed on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Will Submit Budget One Week Late
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with Darman letter
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said today it will miss a Jan. 22 deadline for submitting a fiscal 1991 budget by one week. In a letter to House and Senate leaders, Budget Director Richard G. Darman apologized for the delay, but said there was no way the administration could make the deadline for its first full-year budget. ``Budgets have, of course, been late many times before,'' Darman said in a letter to Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. ``But I hope you may appreciate that I would have preferred to have been exactly on time, rather than seven days late.'' Darman also said in a letter to House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., that the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., had balked at the prospect of a week's delay. ``Unfortunately, however, we simply cannot deliver the budget by the 22nd of January, and will have to delay its submission until Jan. 29th,'' Darman said. The letters to Mitchell and Foley were both dated Dec. 29. Administration and congressional sources also disclosed another timing flap with Congress _ over the date of President Bush's State of the Union address. Officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said congressional leaders balked at a White House proposal that the message be delivered on Thursday, Jan. 25, not wanting to return right before a weekend. After a period of negotiations, the date for the State of the Union address is now set for Tuesday, Jan. 30, a day after the budget submission, sources said. Darman said a principal reason for the budget-submission delay was because appropriations bills and a budget-cutting measure ``were late this year.'' A so-called reconciliation bill chopping $14.7 billion from the current year's fiscal deficit was one of the final measures enacted by Congress before it began its Christmas and New Years' holiday. ``For reasons that I do not fully understand, the Congress did not actually deliver the reconciliation bill to the White House until Dec. 13th. The president signed it on Dec. 19th. For many years, OMB has been given at lest 45 days _ and ordinarily about 60 days _ from enactment of the last major spending or reconciliation bill to prepare the next year's budget. ``If the customary minimum time were allowed this year, the budget would not have to be presented until early Feburary,'' Darman said in his letter to Mitchell. The measure will call for $1.23 trillion in spending, sources said. By law, it must call for reducing the federal deficit to $64 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Dips by 19
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs dropped for the second straight week, plummeting by 19 rigs to total 1,042, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. The latest rig count remains well above the 908 rigs posted a year ago, the company reported Tuesday. Last week, the number of rigs dropped by 18 after increasing by 21 the previous week. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among the major oil producing states, Oklahoma showed the worst loss, down 12 rigs, while Wyoming lost seven. Other states recording losses for the week included Texas, which dropped two, while Kansas and Colorado each lost one. Of those showing gains, Louisiana showed the largest increase with two, while New Mexico increased by one rig. Most states remained unchanged, including California, Michigan, North Dakota, Ohio and Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 15.5 million tons during the week ending Dec. 23, down 19 percent from the 19 million tons produced in the previous week, the Department of Energy reported Tuesday. The U.S. coal industry produced 19.1 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. West Virginia ranked first among the 27 coal-producing states with 2.5 million tons produced. Kentucky was second at 2.4 million tons and Wyoming was third at 2.3 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production through Dec. 23 was 953.2 million tons, 4.8 percent ahead of production for the comparable period of 1988. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: Toys `R' Us Reports 22.7 Percent Increase in Christmas Sales
DOC.TEXT: Toys `R' Us Inc. on Monday reported its holiday sales rose 22.7 percent from a year earlier. Sales for the 8-week Christmas selling season between Oct. 30 and Dec. 24 rose to $2.02 billion compared to $1.65 in 1988, the company said. Sales for the 11 months ended Dec. 24 totalled $4.48 billion, up 19.2 percent from the $3.76 billion for the same period last year. The company will issue its report on fourth quarter and 1989 earnings after its fiscal year ends. Charles Lazarus, chairman and chief executive, said last year was ``another excellent'' one for Toys `R' Us in terms of sales, earnings and market share expansion. ``During a year of retailing uncertainty filled with promotional gimmickry, our stores throughout the United States experienced outstanding Christmas business by staying with our concept'' that features low prices and deep stock levels, he said in a year-end letter to stockholders. He said the retailer's stores overseas and its clothing shops also had strong results during the holidays. Sales at the retailer's U.S. toy stores open at least a year, called comparable- or same-store sales, rose 10 percent during the eight-week holiday season and 6.2 percent for the first 11 months of the fiscal year. Retailers and analysts consider same-store sales a better reflection of a company's performance than results that include newly opened stores. Toys `R' Us, based in Paramus, N.J., is the world's largest toy specialty retailing chain, with 404 toy stores in the United States, 74 international toy stores and 137 children's clothing stores.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Of Boston Announces $300 Million In Loan Writeoffs
DOC.TEXT: Bank of Boston Corp. said today that its earnings for the final quarter of 1989 will be reduced by about $300 million largely because of problem real estate loans and the uncertainty of the New England economy. The large regional banking company also said it added $280 million to its loan-loss reserves to cover future losses. However, Bank of Boston said it expects to break even for the three months ended Dec. 31, and earn a profit for the full year. It said it would realize a $145 million pre-tax gain from the previously announced sale of its $590 million credit-card operation to Chase Manhattan Corp. of New York, and a $50 million gain from the funding of a portion of its penison obligations with annuity contracts. Net income for the first nine months of 1989 totaled $62 million. About half of Bank of Boston's $300 million in net charge-offs, or $140 million, were for loans related to real estate, said Wayne J. Taylor, a company spokesman. About $40 million was due to problem loans to Third World countries, he said. ``Given the uncertainty of the economic environment generally and in New England, we thought taking this kind of action would be prudent,'' Taylor said of the charge-offs and reserves. The bank's move comes as other institutions in New England also have responded to a contracting economy. Last week, the Bank of New England said it expected to report a ``substantial'' loss for the year because it had to boost reserves to cover bad real estate loans. Bank of Boston said credit-loss reserves totaled $925 million, or about 85 percent of an estimated $1.1 billion in non-accrual loans and leases, in the fourth quarter. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, the bank reported non-accrual loans and leases of $1.5 billion and a credit-loss reserve of $942 million, or 62 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Barrier Built To Protect Coast, Leaking Ship Towed To Sea For Repair
DOC.TEXT: A salvage firm today said it repaired an Iranian supertanker that spewed millions of gallons of crude oil into the Atlantic Ocean off the Moroccan coast, but a French official disputed the claim. Three tugs towed the supertanker farther out to sea today, and cleanup crews prepared for a 100-square-mile oil slick to hit the coast. The roughly 19 million gallons of crude that escaped the stricken vessel threatened oyster beds, fishing stocks, a pink flamingo breeding ground and resort beaches on Monday. Officials said 100,000 jobs depend on fishing and tourism in the affected area. The spill was nearly double the 11 million gallons of crude oil dumped into Alaska's Prince William Sound by the Exxon Valdez last year, but a British shipping official said much of the oil has been broken up by high waves and dissolved in the warm water. The dispersed oil is falling to the ocean bed, unlike the oil in Prince William Sound, said Joe Nichols, technical manager of the International Tanker Owners Pollution Federation in Britain. The Dutch salvage company Smit Tak said workers plugged a 60- by 90-foot hole in Khark 5's port side. ``We have done some repairs to the ship and we managed to stop the leak,'' spokesman Daan Kaakebeen said from the company's headquarters in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. He said three tugs were towing the 1,837-ton ship out to sea. Iran's environmental protection agency also said the spill had been contained and an agency spokesman said ``the imperialist media'' had exaggerated its seriousness. However, France's environment minister, helping to coordinate cleanup operations for its former colony, said the Khark 5 was still leaking and a second tanker eventually would try to take aboard some of the remaining oil. The huge oil slick moved to within 12 miles of the coast on Monday, and high winds could push some of the oil ashore by Thursday, said the French official, Brice Lalond. An explosion, its cause unknown, tore through the tanker's hull Dec. 19 when it was about 400 miles north of the Canary Islands. A fire forced the crew to abandon ship and the vessel began drifting toward northwest Africa. The ship, originally loaded with 72 million gallons of oil bound for refineries in Europe, came within 50 miles of Safi, south of Rabat, before salvors towed it 120 miles off the coast, the official Moroccan news agency Maghreb Arab Press said. It said Moroccan technicians were struggling to repair a gash in the hull that continued streaming light crude oil. Experts placed a barrier at the leading edge of the slick to prevent it from reaching a 106-mile stretch of coastline. Spanish oil-spill technicians on the scene and experts from Marseille, France, say high winds and 8-foot waves have slowed efforts to control the spill. Robert Luigi, an oil-spill expert for the Marseille Port Authority, said Moroccan authorities were coping well with the spill and the risk to coastal areas was slight. Luigi, who returned to France on Sunday after aiding local authorities for a week, said much of the oil had evaporated or disintegrated into small particles due to the warm seas. The slick threatened an area from Mehdiya north of Rabat, the capital, to Mohammedia in the south, the French TV station La Cinq reported. The slick could affect oyster beds at Oualidyia and a migratory bird reserve at Moulay Bousselham, also a key breeding ground of pink flamingoes, authorities said. It could blacken beaches around Agadir, one of the most popular resorts in Morocco. Potential damage to fishing stocks, tourism and other coastal industries could cost 100,000 jobs, according to the Interior Ministry. The government has formed an emergency council to deal with the crisis. In an interview on the French radio station Europe 1, marine scientist Jacques Cousteau complained of slow reaction to the spill and criticized safety precautions in the oil transport industry.

DOC.HEAD: Soft Landing Accomplished, But Still More Worries
DOC.TEXT: We are now experiencing the muted impact of an economic soft landing, the very thing the Federal Reserve sought and seers thought impossible, but still the economic worries persist. The great fear throughout last year was that the Fed's restraint of the money supply might stall the engine of economic growth, in a manner similar to that of a commercial aircraft with a pinched fuel line. Such a situation could, of course, lead to a crash landing, with widespread joblessness, personal and commercial bankruptcies, repossessed homes, shattered confidence and an economy incapable of rising again for years. There was no crash, just the mushy sound of a great craft settling into the marsh. Corporate profits ceased to grow, joblessness rose fractions of a point, available factory capacity retreated from near-record highs, inflation and interest rates fell, savings rose, the trade and budget balances declined. Forced to compete for market share in a slow-growth economy, manufacturers and retailers improved their efficiency and cut their prices, which was painful to them, but the consumer and the country got a better deal in the process. While huge problems remain _ lenders must be bailed out, business failures seem destined to rise, houses are often beyond the reach of median-income families, health-care costs continue to rise _ the landing has been ``soft.'' Worries, however, are among the factors that seem not to have abated. The big new worry is that the economy now might sink slowly into the sludge and fail to take off when the time comes for re-expansion. Some examples: _While home mortgage rates have declined from their highs of a year ago, home prices in many areas have not, in part because of a slower pace of home-building. That latter was a direct consequence of Federal Reserve restraints. If the situation is to be remedied, incomes must rise or more housing must be made available. But in a near-recession economy, how do you spur either of those activities? _Thanks to the slowdown, carmakers are ready to make deals. But, because of the sluggish economy, consumers are in perhaps their worst buying mood in a decade. Job insecurity has risen a bit also, undermining buyer determination. The sale-inducing ability of rebates and below-market interest rates, therefore, have lost a good deal of their power. The Fed could try to push borrowing rates even lower, but that could cause problems of another sort. To guide a craft as large as the U.S. economy is a tricky and uncertain assignment, and there is no assurance the Fed has full command of the controls. Precision is called for but economic gauges are inexact. Response is slow. It took a year of monetary restraints by the Fed _ from the early spring of 1988 to that of 1989 _ to slow an economy that seemed headed for inflationary trouble. Restraint began, that is, nearly two years ago. The Fed then began easing up on the controls last spring, but nobody can say for certain when the impact of that easing will be felt. Later this year? Sometime in 1991? It leaves lots of time for the economy to settle into the mire, and for those who worry about such things it raises the possibility that a subsequent takeoff might be more difficult than foreseen.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with closing figures. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished higher Tuesday on London's Stock Exchange, as the market welcomed the resumption of trading in a new year. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index gained 11.4 points, or 0.5 percent, to close at 2,434.1. The session high was 2,443.3. The Financial Times 30-share index rose 17.5 points to 1,934.1. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 8.55 points to close at 1,319.17. Volume came to 329.5 million shares, compared with last Friday's 365.0 million shares in an abbreviated session before the New Year's weekend. The market shot higher at the outset. Analysts said some of the gains came from institutions anxious to own shares that had been widely touted over the weekend in speculative stories about what stocks would be the winners in the new decade. Other investors were afraid they might miss out on another January rally. However, the market backed off its peaks reached early in the session as some investors decided to sell and profit from the recent runup in prices.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Of Boston Announces $300 Million In Loan Write-offs
DOC.TEXT: Bank of Boston Corp., echoing moves by New England banks in response to the region's slumping real estate market, said Tuesday it would write off about $300 million in loans for the final quarter of 1989 and set aside around $280 million for other possible losses. However, the company predicted it would break even in the quarter and earn a profit for the whole year, partly due to its decision to sell its $590 million credit-card business. Bank of Boston said it expected a gain of $145 million from the sale to Chase Manhattan Corp. of New York, and a $50 million gain from the funding of a portion of its pension obligations with annuity contracts. The acquisition of the credit-card unit was the fifth for Chase in 1989. About half of Bank of Boston's $300 million in net write-offs, or $140 million, was for loans related to real estate, said Wayne J. Taylor, a company spokesman. About $40 million was due to problem loans to Third World countries, he said. ``Given the uncertainty of the economic environment generally and in New England we thought taking this kind of action would be prudent,'' Taylor said. Bank analysts said they expected the move, which followed similar actions by other New England banks. The Bank of New England said last week that it expected to report a ``substantial'' loss for the year because it had to boost reserves to cover bad real estate loans. On Tuesday, it announced the sale of its vehicle fleet leasing unit to GE Capital Corp. for an undisclosed price. ``Every time there is a problem with real estate, we start to see a problem with loans. There is a certain level of fulfilled prophecy every time,'' said Mas Kakutani, a director of bank analysts for Moody's Investors Service Inc. Analysts said it was difficult to forsee the market's downturn from the boom years of the early 1980s. ``In 20-20 hindsight it's always easy to say they (Bank of Boston management) made a mistake,'' Kakutani said. ``It's a little irresponsible for us to say that, although they should have controlled their growth a little bit,'' Bank of Boston said its non-performing assets totaled $1.7 billion at year end, including $600 million in real estate holdings. That was down from $1.8 billion in non-performing assets reported in the third-quarter, a decline due mainly to the fourth-quarter charge-offs, Taylor said. ``It's still discouraging to see non-performing assets at such a magnitude _ that will be a drag on them in the '90s,'' said James Moynihan, senior vice president of Advest Inc. in Boston. The bank said it expected total credit-loss reserves of $925 million, or about 85 percent of an estimated $1.1 billion in non-accrual loans and leases, in the fourth quarter. For the period ended Sept. 30, the bank reported non-accrual loans and leases of $1.5 billion and a credit-loss reserve of $942 million, or 62 percent. Net income for the first nine months of 1989 totaled $62 million.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Drop On South American Rain
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely in reaction to reports of rain in the South American soybean belt. Most grain futures also closed lower. The South American soybean region, encompassing the southern third of Brazil and the northeastern section of Argentina, has received generous amounts of precipitation in recent weeks after a dry beginning to the growing season. ``In fact, Brazil may be getting too much of a good thing,'' said Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. She said the northern reaches of Parana, a major Brazilian soybean-growing state, ``may be getting a little on the wet side.'' William Biedermann, research director for the futures brokerage Allendale Inc., linked additional selling in the soybean market to a change in the U.S. government crop program allowing participating farmers to plant soybeans on some of their idled acres. At the close, soybean futures were 5{ cents to 8{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in January at $5.61{ a bushel; wheat was } cent lower to 1\ cents higher with March at $4.08{ a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 3} cents lower with March at $2.37{ a bushel; and oats were } cent to 2\ cents lower with March at $1.51\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: DuPont Sells Blood Screening Business
DOC.TEXT: The DuPont Co. has sold its blood screening business and will concentrate efforts on its core diagnostics business, the chemical giant said Tuesday. Ortho Diagnostics Systems Inc., a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, and Chiron Corp., based in Eneryville, Calif., have purchased the blood screening business for an undisclosed price. Du Pont became involved in the virology blood screening market in 1984 in partnership with Biotech Research Laboratories Inc., based in Rockville, Md. The companies supplied tests to screen for and confirm the presence of AIDS and other diseases in donated blood. Ortho will now market Biotech's blood screening products in the United States and other parts of the world, but DuPont will continue to market them in some European countries. DuPont will also continue to market Biotech's research products worldwide. ``We entered the market when there was a national priority to stop the rapid spread of AIDS through blood transfusions, and we have had a major role in seeing that objective was achieved. However, continued participation in this area is not consistent with our strategic business objectives,'' said John Landon, the director of diagnostics at DuPont. The sale is DuPont's first step toward increasing spending in its core diagnostics business and divesting non-strategic diagnostic product lines developed or acquired recently, the company said. The company will spend five times as much on research and development in 1990 for its clinical chemistry business, which manufactures and markets instruments and prepackaged chemical reagents for hospitals and reference laboratories, DuPont said. The money will be used for development of advanced models of DuPont's ``aca'' and ``Dimension'' instruments. DuPont will continue to develop and sell virology products to AIDS and viral disease researchers, Landon said. DuPont has annual healthcare sales of approximately $1.3 billion. Biotech is a producer of human viral diagnostic products.

DOC.HEAD: Company Selling Interest in Titanium Unit to Baroid
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny International Inc. said Tuesday it has reached an agreement to sell its interest in Titanium Metals Corp. of America to Baroid Corp. of Houston. Allegheny International said Baroid agreed to pay $50 million for about 30 percent of Titanium Metal's outstanding stock and a related $3.25 million note payable by the metal corporation. The deal will give Baroid, a worldwide supplier of services and equipment for oil and gas well drilling, complete ownership of Titanium Metal. Allegheny International, meanwhile, said it has amended its plan of reorganization with federal bankruptcy court. The manufacturer of consumer products expects its amended plan to be implemented at the end of March. Bankruptcy court hearings resume Jan. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Sector Still in Decline But at Lower Rate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with Dow Jones industrial average closing at a record high, SUBS 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Weakness persisted in the manufacturing sector during December but the pace of economic decline eased, the nation's purchasing managers reported Tuesday. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which tracks economic trends by polling its members each month, said its index rose to 48 percent in December from 46.6 percent in November. Despite the unexpectedly big improvement in the widely followed index _ which raised it to the highest level since June 1989 _ the reading suggested the economy still was in a slump. December marked the eighth straight month in which the index has come in below the dividing line between economic growth and decline. A reading below 50 generally means that the manufacturing economy is deteriorating while a reading above 50 indicates it is expanding. Financial markets keep tabs on the purchasing managers' monthly report on business for clues about economic health. Wall Street welcomed the December report and the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks surged 56.95 points to a record close of 2,810.15, surpassing its previous peak of 2,791.41, reached last Oct. 9. But the report was subject to varying interpretations. It was regarded by some observers as additional evidence that the feeble economy needs to be livened up with a dose of lower interest rates. It tended to support the notion that the Federal Reserve Board should nudge rates lower to stimulate economic activity. On the other hand, the report was taken as a sign that the economic downturn may have bottomed out late last year. Some stock market analysts were cheered because they thought the purchasing managers had handed them a reason for optimism about the fortunes of industrial companies, which have been held back by the sluggish economic conditions of the past year. In a separate piece of encouraging news, the Commerce Department reported construction spending jumped 1.5 percent in November, rebounding from a 0.1 percent dip in October and reaching a 10-month high. A 7 percent surge in goverment spending, which accounts for roughly 20 percent of total construction outlays, combined with a 0.6 percent gain in residential spending to produce November's overall growth. The purchasing managers' report, based on replies to questions asked of purchasers at more than 300 industrials companies, said both production and new orders posted slight increases, helped by favorable seasonal adjustment factors. Inventories decreased, marking a full year of monthly declines, but at a lesser rate than in the past five months. Among the other components in the overall index, manufacturing employment dropped for the eleventh straight month and vendor deliveries were faster for the eighth month in a row, reflecting greater availability of goods against a backdrop of sluggish demand. Inflation continued to moderate. Prices declined for the seventh straight month, but at a slightly higher rate than in November. A total of 27 items were reported lower in price, compared with only 14 reported to be higher. Robert Bretz, chairman of the organization's business survey committee and director of materials management at Pitney Bowes Inc., said despite the modest improvement in the December index the readings in the vendor deliveries and price components confirm ``a continued weakness in the underlying economy ...'' The purchasing managers' index averaged 49 percent for all of last year, a level that is consistent with an increase of about 1.6 percent in the gross national product, the broadest measure of economic activity. The index would have to slip below 44 percent for it to point to a contraction in inflation-adjusted GNP. The December level, which was higher than the figure expected by financial market economists, compared with 57.3 percent in December 1988 and was the highest since 48.8 percent in June 1989. Economists had forecast the index would register around 47 percent in December. The purchasing management group, based in Tempe, Ariz., is an education and research organization with more than 30,000 members. Its report on business has been issued each month since 1931, except for during World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Nissan Raises Prices
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Corp. on Tuesday announced that prices for three of its 1990 model sedans will rise by about 1 percent because of increased costs. The price of a Nissan Sentra will be boosted by $100 to $7,399 and prices for the Nissan Stanza and Maxima will go up $200 apiece, to $11,650 and $17,899, respectively. Nissan spokesman Shane Smith said he didn't know what caused the higher costs. Prices for other Nissan cars and light trucks remain the same.

DOC.HEAD: Highest Closes in Dow Jones Industrials Average
With AM-Wall Street
Dollar Up, Gold Mostly Lower
Precedes LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended the first trading day of 1990 Tuesday with a strong advance against most major currencies despite reported efforts by the Federal Reserve to drive it down, particularly against the Japanese yen. Gold prices declined following a mixed performance overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $399.60 a troy ounce, down $2.90 from late Friday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $399.75 an ounce, off $3.25 from Friday. The financial markets were closed on Monday for New Year's Day. Although domestic and most European markets reopened Tuesday, trading was described as thin as Tokyo extended the holiday and many offices here and abroad remained partially staffed. Therefore, currency dealers said it remained to be seen whether the dollar was on its way up again after an extended decline in the last weeks of 1989. Most dealers attributed Tuesday's dollar rally to internal market influences that were being exaggerated by the thinness of the market on the first trading day of the new year. However, they said the dollar would have closed even higher had it not been for at least four separate episodes of dollar selling by the Fed for yen. The yen remained under pressure because of Japan's relatively low interest rates and amid market concern about the future of that country's ruling Liberal Democratic Party. The dollar was selling at 146.15 yen in London late Tuesday, up from 143.40 in Tokyo last Friday. In New York, the dollar soared to 146.40 yen from 143.85 yen. In London, one British pound cost $1.6115 late Tuesday, unchanged from Friday. Sterling fetched $1.6085 in New York, less than Friday's $1.6105. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Friday's late quotes, included: 1.7128 West German marks, up from 1.6897; 1.5815 Swiss francs, up from 1.5420; 5.8510 French francs, up from 5.7805; 1,284.00 Italian lire, up from 1,267.00; and 1.16005 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15875. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Friday's late rates included: 1.7090 West German marks, up from 1.6923; 1.5715 Swiss francs, up from 1.5430; 5.8335 French francs, up from 5.7860; 1.9130 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9100; 1,280.00 Italian lire, up from 1,270.00; and 1.1604 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1587. In London, gold was bid at $400.75 a troy ounce, down from $401 Friday. Gold rose to $401.50 an ounce from $401 in Zurich. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $403.25 an ounce, up from $400.55. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery closed at $5.183 a troy ounce, down from $5.208. Silver rose in London to $5.25 an ounce from $5.18.

DOC.HEAD: AGENCIES AND RADIO OUT
From AP Newsfeatures. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.NOTE: (APN SUNDAY ILLUSTRATIONS: Mailed print subscribers get 4 b&w photos, 1 graphic. ColorFoto subscribers get 3 35mm slides.)
DOC.TEXT: Once considered a miracle fiber, asbestos is now recognized as a serious health threat and will be taken off the U.S. market in a series of bans beginning this year. But for utility workers like Kevin Quinn, who says he was exposed to asbestos on the job, the damage may already have been done.

Kevin Quinn's father began working for Consolidated Edison in the 1940s, when asbestos was still considered a miracle fiber and no regulations governed its use. William Quinn died in 1980 of cancer linked to asbestos. His son was hired by the same utility in 1979. In the years since his father first came in contact with asbestos, numerous laws had been passed to protect workers from what was now acknowledged as a prime health risk. But in 1987, Quinn says, he was working at a plant when asbestos-covered doors were removed from boilers and dropped to the floor. The doors remained for weeks while workers went about their duties without protective gear amid clouds of asbestos dust, he says. ``I used to walk past that area every day,'' he says. ``They told us it was safe. And it turns out it wasn't.'' Now, Quinn has joined 180 co-workers and the Environmental Protection Agency in suing Con Ed, charging that he was exposed to the same material that killed his father. Eighteen years after passage of the first federal law regulating asbestos, thousands of workers _ at utilities like Con Ed, and in other industries where asbestos was used as an insulator _ still face its effects. ``We are talking to people who are extremely surprised that asbestos is still a problem,'' said Heather Maurer, executive director of Asbestos Victims of America. ``But the incidence of asbestos disease is on the increase instead of the decrease, despite restrictions that have been applied to make the use of asbestos safer.'' A recent union-sponsored screening of 538 Con Edison workers found that 20 percent had either scarred lungs or mesothelioma, an asbestos-caused cancer of the lining of the abdomen or the lungs. Since 1987, Con Ed has been cited by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration for more than a half-dozen alleged violations _ mostly failure to monitor the level of asbestos fibers in the air _ at the Indian Point nuclear plant in Buchanan, a plant in Astoria, Queens, and at Quinn's 74th Street plant in Manhattan. Some allegations are still under investigation, some have been contested and dropped by OSHA, and Con Ed settled others by paying a fine. ``Prior to 1973, we didn't know what the asbestos risks were,'' said Con Ed spokeswoman Rosalie Zuckerman. ``We're not denying that prior to that time, there was exposure. But now that we're aware of it, whenever we do any asbestos work, we follow all the regulations.'' She added that since 1973, the company has had two medical vans visiting Con Ed plants, carrying X-ray machines to test for asbestos scarring. She would not comment on Kevin Quinn's suit. But Quinn says the company was negligent in 1987, when he was exposed. The workers, he says, were kept in the dark. ``We didn't realize we were working around asbestos 'til a shop steward took an air sample to the White Lung Association,'' he said. Because asbestos cancers can take 20 to 35 years to develop, workers like Quinn who believe they have been exposed recently may not become sick until the year 2020. And people who were exposed to asbestos in the 1950s, '60s and '70s are just now getting sick. A study by Dr. Irving Selikoff, perhaps the world's most noted asbestos researcher, and his colleagues at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine projects that asbestos cancer rates won't peak until 1992 and won't drop off significantly until after the year 2000. Smoking exacerbates the risk of asbestos-related lung cancer, which is incurable in 70 to 95 percent of cases, said Dr. Stephen Levin, who works with Selikoff. Mesothelioma is always fatal. Asbestos exposure also increases the risk of colon cancer, which has an 80 percent cure rate if caught early. The study predicts that 9,739 deaths from asbestos exposure will be recorded in 1992 in just 11 industries, including utilities, construction, car and railroad engine repair, shipbuilding, and asbestos manufacturing. Many Con Ed workers fear they might surface among those statistics: _Gene Duffy, 46, has worked for Con Edison for 25 years. His chest X-rays show lung scarring; he often has trouble breathing. Duffy said he can't even cut his lawn without taking a rest halfway through to catch his breath. _Artie Sagevick, 58, a 31-year veteran. He gave up smoking 25 years ago, but he has ``coughing fits 15 minutes at a time a couple of times a day.'' _Says Steven Amato, a 21-year employee: ``If you had to do a strenuous job, go up and down stairs, I could not do it. In the wintertime, I throw the phlegm all day long. ... I'm 51 years old and I feel like an old man.'' All three want compensation from Con Ed, more help from their union, and along with many of their co-workers, they are suing asbestos manufacturers. Lawyer Chris Placitella is handling similar suits by 130 Con Ed workers. His firm represents 3,300 additional workers from other utility companies who are involved in similar suits, and the number of plaintiffs rises daily. Con Edison has other asbestos-related worries. City officials have raised concerns about public exposure to asbestos from Con Ed accidents. In several recent incidents, asbestos insulation wrapped around underground Con Ed steam pipes has blown off when the pipes or nearby water mains burst. One explosion killed three people and contaminated Manhattan's entire Gramercy Park neighborhood with asbestos, forcing hundreds of people to relocate. Con Ed was faulted for failing to report the presence of asbestos for several days, which delayed the cleanup and increased health risks. Other accidents contaminated streets and subways. The city Department of Environmental Protection has called on federal officials to come up with new techniques to deal with these outdoor and underground emergencies, since the usual procedures have not always applied. Most asbestos products will be taken off the U.S. market under a three-stage EPA ban that begins in 1990 and ends in 1997. Advocates for asbestos victims applaud the ban but wish more were being done. Asbestos manufacturers have filed a lawsuit challenging the ban, claiming today's products are safe because the fiber is encased in hard materials like cement and won't deteriorate. Whether or not the manufacturers are successful, AFL-CIO occupational safety expert Peg Seminario predicts, ``It's going to be some time before our asbestos problems are over.''

DOC.HEAD: Petroleum Futures Spurt on Supply Worries, Strong Demand
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices rallied in brisk trading Tuesday amid buying on speculation about tight supplies. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for February delivery surged nearly 4 cents a gallon while crude and home heating oil prices also were bid sharply higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The March gas and heating oil contracts closed with gains of the maximums allowed for a single day. Buying enthusiasm in European markets spilled over into U.S. energy futures pits and represented a continuation of the strength displayed Friday in an abbreviated session, market analysts said. Markets were closed Monday for New Year's Day and energy trading ended at 1 p.m. EST on Friday in advance of the holiday. Much of the buying reflected traders scrambling to cover short positions on the hunch that prices would continue to move ahead. Short covering involves buying back something that has previously been sold. A senior energy specialist at Merrill Lynch Energy Futures, who asked that his name not be used, said the strength in the petroleum markets reflects fundamental supply and demand factors. Problems over the weekend at several refineries on the Gulf Coast intensified concerns about possible shortages. The potential tightness in supplies would come at the peak usage time for heating oil, which has been rising recently due to unsually cold weather around the country. Scattered shortages of heating oil already have been reported, particularly in northeastern states, and have contributed to a steep runup in prices. Heating oil for delivery in February jumped 2.14 cents to finish at 77.39 cents a gallon. The January contract had jumped 5.47 cents to finish at $1.0187 on Friday, the last trading day for that contract. Heating oil contracts for later delivery posted gains of between 2 cents a gallon to 1.52 cents. The March contract closed up 2 cents a gallon _ the daily limit. Meanwhile, wholesale unleaded gasoline futures also soared. The February contract rose 3.94 cents to 65.69 cents a gallon. On Friday, the expiring January unleaded gasoline contract rose 3.11 cents to end at 63.22 cents a gallon. The March unleaded gas contract closed up the daily limit of 3 cents a gallon and later contract months also posted strong but smaller increases. West Texas Intermediate, the main U.S. grade of crude oil, rose $1.07 to $22.89 per 42-gallon barrel for the February contract, adding to Friday's gain of 32 cents. Later contracts rose by 81 cents to 92 cents.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Prices Sweep Dow to New Closing High
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS advance-decline margin in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices advanced sharply and the Dow Jones industrial average reached a new closing high Tuesday as optimism about interest rates swept Wall Street in the first session of the new year. The Dow Jones average of 30 blue chip stocks soared 56.95 to close at 2,810.15, surpassing its previous closing high of 2,791.41, reached last Oct. 9. The closely-watched index surged more than 29 points during the last half-hour of trading alone, boosted by computerized buying programs. Advancing issues outdistanced decliners by a margin of 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,257 stocks rising, 412 falling and 333 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 162.07 million shares, up from 145.94 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 193.27 million shares. Analysts said economic and technical factors were behind Tuesday's rally. Stocks fell in early trading as investors nervously awaited the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly survey of its members. But after the association reported there was continuing weakness in the manufacturing economy last month, prices moved broadly higher. The Purchasing Managers Index gained in December, rising to 48 percent from November's 46.6 percent. But it was the eighth straight month that the purchasing managers have reported weakness in the industrial sector _ a reading below 50 percent generally indicates a slowing of the economy _ and it was this fact that motivated investors. Traders believed the continuing weakness would make the Federal Reserve more likely to nudge interest rates lower. Analysts said gains in the dollar also supported the rally on Wall Street. A stronger dollar gives the Fed more leeway with interest rates, and it also makes U.S. stocks more attractive to foreign investors. Analysts said there was program trading through much of the session, especially in the final 30 minutes. However, said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co., ``There are real buyers out there in the marketplace.'' The stock market benefited from what traders call the ``January effect'' _ buying by institutional investors who are flush with cash after liquidating their portfolios at the end of 1989. Blue chip issues were at the top of many shopping lists. IBM jumped 3~ to 98, General Electric rose 2\ to 66}, General Motors rose 2\ to 44{, and Philip Morris, the most actively-traded issue on the NYSE, picked up 1[ to 42}. Technology stocks, including IBM, were also big gainers. Digital Equipment rose 2[ to 84[ and Hewlett Packard was up 2[ to 49]. Dennis Jarrett, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Co., said that if the market can continue its gains for a third session _ the Dow Jones average rose nearly 21 points on Friday _ it will augur well for Wall Street in the first quarter. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $49.4 billion, or 0.83 percent, in value Tuesday. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 2.96 to 198.00. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 7.71 to 411.20, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 6.29 to 359.69. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 4.51 to 459.33. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 381.53, up 3.53.

DOC.HEAD: OJ Futures Climb Higher On Cash Price Hike
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices rose sharply Tuesday after Florida and Brazilian juice processors announced cash price increases of more than 20 percent in reaction to frost damage to the Florida orange crop. On other commodity markets, energy futures prices climbed; precious metals dipped; grains and soybean were lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. In trading on the New York Cotton Exchange, futures prices for frozen concentrated orange juice soared the expanded daily limit of 8 cents a pound for all contracts except the spot January contract, which rose 4.6 cents to $1.70\ per pound. The increase brought the contract's gain since Dec. 15 to nearly 35 percent. The buying followed announcements late Friday and early Tuesday that most Florida orange juice processors had raised their effective cash discount price for bulk juice to about $1.68{ from $1.33\ per pound. Brazilian processors followed suit, increasing their rate to about $1.63{ from $1.34\ a pound. A cash price increase was expected in the wake of a Christmas weekend freeze in the Florida citrus belt that some analysts believe destroyed as much as 30 percent of the state's orange crop. Florida officials have not estimated the damage. The damage is expected to lead to an increase in U.S. imports of Brazilian juice, which accounted for about 21 percent of U.S. consumption in the year ended Dec. 2, 1989. Ernie Thomas, an orange juice specialist in Winter Haven, Fla., with Merrill Lynch Consumer Markets, said he was surprised by the magnitude of the price increases. But he said the futures market overreacted. ``There are a lot of shorts in there, desperately trying to get out at any price,'' he said. The term shorts refers to traders who sold borrowed contracts earlier, hoping the price would decline before they would have to buy contracts to complete their deals. Energy futures prices rose sharply in brisk trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid buying on speculation about tight supplies. The gasoline market took the lead and heating oil followed, reflecting forecasts for warmer weather in the Northeast and concerns about problems at several oil refineries in Pennsylvania and along the Gulf Coast. ``These are no big deals in and of themselves but when you get a lot of news floating around, that tends to spark a little buying,'' said Jim Ritterbusch, vice president of trading and research with Carson Petroleum Co., a Chicago-area oil distributor. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled .58 cent to 1.07 cents higher with February at $22.89 a barrel; heating oil was 1.42 cents to 2.14 cents higher with February at 77.39 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.05 cents to 3.94 cents higher with February at 65.69 cents a gallon. Precious metals futures slid lower, led by platinum, in reaction to weaker foreign currency values. But gold for February delivery halted its slide at $400.20 an ounce, just above $400 level that some analysts consider an indicator of the market's strength. Gold futures settled $3.10 to $3.90 lower with February at $402.10 a troy ounce; silver was 2 cents to 2.5 cents lower with March at $5.253 a troy ounce. Soybean futures prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade, largely in reaction to reports of rain in the South American soybean belt. Most grain futures also closed lower. Soybean futures settled 4{ cents to 8\ cents lower with January at $5.61\ a bushel; wheat was { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with March at $4.08} a bushel; corn was 1} cents to 3} cents lower with March at $2.37} a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2\ cents lower with March at $1.51\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures finished narrowly mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in lackluster trading ahead of Wednesday's quarterly Agriculture Department hogs and pigs inventory, which is expected to show little change from a year ago. Live cattle futures settled .05 cent lower to .25 cent higher with February at 77.45 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .20 cent lower with January at 84.70 cents a pound; live hog futures settled .27 cent lower to .35 cent higher with February at 48.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to .70 cent higher with February at 49.95 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
DOC.TEXT: MiniScribe Corp., the computer disk maker hurt by allegations of mismanagement and fraud, has filed for bankruptcy protection and called the step the only practical strategy to solve its legal problems. The company said it sought protection in a Chapter 11 filing Monday with the U.S. bankruptcy court in Denver. It listed liabilities that exceed assets by $151 million, but those figures don't include a potentially unlimited liability from lawsuits filed by angry shareholders and debtholders. The Chapter 11 filing, which gives the company a reprieve from creditors while reorganizing, had been expected because of the lawsuits, which allege MiniScribe grossly misrepresented past financial results. An internal investigation prompted by the lawsuits concluded former managers ``perpetrated a massive fraud'' by fabricating financial statements and sometimes shipping bricks and scrap parts disguised as disk drives to confuse auditors. ``This fraud was all the more alarming in that it required the active participation of many company personnel, and was apparently common knowledge among a great many other employees,'' said the internal report, given to the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission. In a prepared statement Tuesday, MiniScribe President Richard P. Rifenburgh said, ``Attracting the new infusion of equity capital that the company needs to take advantage of its new 7000 Series family of one-inch high, 3{-inch disk drives is impossible in the face of 13 class action and individual lawsuits brought by stockholders and debenture holders, which together hold the potential of enormous liability for the company. ``We believe that this is the only practical step the company can take to solve its many legal problems,'' he said. The company previously announced it was phasing out U.S.-built products and by the end of the first quarter of 1990 will have only a pilot production line, sales and marketing, research and development at its headquarters in Longmont. Most of the company's production already is done through Far East subsidiaries. Worldwide MiniScribe employs 5,927, including 849 in the United States. Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. analyst Doug van Dorsten, who follows MiniScribe, said the Chapter 11 filing could force owners of its stock and debt securities to unite and perhaps try to negotiate with the company. ``I think more than anything else MiniScribe would like to get those different parties together and move toward a settlement,'' he said. ``MiniScribe needs to settle that if the company is to move forward.'' MiniScribe's new 7000 series of disk drives has received high reviews in the computer industry and its 1989 sales were strong, but the company's future has been clouded by the legal problems. The company said it had retained Merrill Lynch & Co. to formulate a Chapter 11 recapitalization and reorganization plan. The company also filed a long-delayed Form 10-K financial statement with the SEC, showing totals assets of $200 million and total liabilities of $351 million, excluding liabilities that could be established by the lawsuits.

DOC.HEAD: AmeriFirst Announces Agreement to Settle Class Action Suits
DOC.TEXT: AmeriFirst Bank and its stockholders have signed an agreement to settle all claims against the bank in four class-action lawsuits filed over losses in its real estate and commercial loan portfolios, AmeriFirst said Tuesday. The agreement, reached after several weeks of bargaining, requires AmeriFirst to pay the stockholders $2 million by Feb. 1 and an additional $2.5 million within 30 months. ``The settlement is a major accomplishment for AmeriFirst,'' said Alfred L. Teti, the bank's president and chief executive officer. ``If judicial approval is obtained, this settlement will greatly enhance our ability to propose and implement a capital plan to restore the bank's capital to federally-required levels.'' The class action suits were filed by stockholders against the bank, its former management and its former auditors. The settlement also requires the bank to cooperate with plaintiffs in pursuing claims against the remaining defendants and others to recover losses recognized by the bank in its fiscal year ended Sept. 30. ``It permits the bank to pursue claims against those who we believe are responsible for the losses in our real estate and commercial loan portfolios,'' Teti said. The agreement is subject to contingencies including judicial approval and regulatory review, the bank said in a Tuesday release. Final judicial approval will occur only after formal notification of the terms of the settlement is sent to the plaintiffs and stockholders and after a fairness hearing before the court, the release said.

DOC.HEAD: Key Government Witness in S&L Collapse Says He Won't Testify
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with expected appearance of Keating, inserting new grafs 7-10, beginning James Murphy, deleting last 3 grafs pvs; CORRECTS this year to last year in 12th graf, Kevin O'Connell ... and adds 2 grafs background on separate suit. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A prospective key witness in the government's defense of its seizing of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association is refusing to testify, attorneys said Tuesday. Arizona real estate developer E.C. Garcia has told the government through attorneys he will invoke his Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination if called as a witness in a suit challenging the federal takeover of the Irvine, Calif., thrift, said Paul Guterman, an attorney for the government. Government attorneys had told U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin in December that they expected Garcia to be their top witness, testifying about what they say was the siphoning by Lincoln's owner, Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr., of millions of dollars in federally insured deposits from the now-collapsed institution. Garcia was the principal participant in two transactions _ one involving a stock-junk bond deal and the other a sale of 1,000 acres of land outside Phoenix _ which the government contends resulted in the taking of more than $16 million from Lincoln. Despite Guterman's comments, Sporkin said he still wanted Garcia to take the stand in the case. Attorneys for Lincoln and its parent company, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, said they intend to subpoena Garcia as a witness if the government drops its demand that he appear. James Murphy, another attorney for the government in the case, said he expected to call Keating and his son, Charles H. Keating III, as witnesses on Thursday or Friday. Murphy said he will call one of Keating's son-in-laws, Robert M. Wurzelbacher Jr., as a witness Wednesday. Wurzelbacher, as a senior vice president for American Continental, was the key participant in one land transaction that the government is citing as an example of phony land sales by Lincoln. The government contends that through a series of bogus land transactions, Lincoln recorded unwarranted profits in order to funnel depositors' savings to American Continental. The elder Keating, who is now the target of a federal grand jury investigation in Los Angeles, invoked his constitutional protection against self-incrimination in refusing two months ago to answer questions in a subpoenaed appearance before the House Banking Committee. Meanwhile, the government's chief regulator in the case acknowledged in testimony Tuesday that the savings and loan had told federal regulators in early 1986 about a tax arrangement the government now says was used to siphon $94 million in federally insured deposits out of the thrift. Kevin O'Connell, the regulator who recommended the government's seizure of Lincoln last April at a cost of up to $2 billion _ potentially the heaviest loss to taxpayers among some 600 thrift failures _ admitted officials began questioning the tax-sharing arrangement only last year. O'Connell, deputy director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, had testified last month that the arrangement between Lincoln and American Continental Corp. was ``illegal on its face.'' Under cross-examination today by attorneys for Keating, O'Connell acknowledged that Lincoln had provided details of the accord to his agency all along and that the agreement had been approved by regulators in California. The arrangement _ under which American Continental collected taxes allegedly owed by Lincoln but never paid to the Internal Revenue Service _ is a centerpiece of the government's claim that Lincoln was being operated in an ``unsafe and unsound'' manner in violation of the law. ``Washington took no action on the tax-sharing agreement that you say was illegal on its face?'' Robert Huffman, an attorney for Lincoln, asked O'Connell. ``That's correct,'' O'Connell answered. The testimony came in the third day of hearings into a suit by Keating seeking to regain control of Lincoln. Keating has charged in the suit that the government's decision to seize control of the thrift was capricious and arbitrary. Earlier Tuesday, a Tucson real estate agent testified that he was a ``straw man'' for Garcia's purchase of a 1,000-acre parcel near Phoenix from Lincoln in March 1987 for $14 million. Fernando R. Acosta said he never put up one penny of his own cash in the transaction and that he allowed the property to be put on his company's books as a favor to Garcia. It wasn't until a year later when Lincoln tried to collect the first payment on a $10.5 million loan for the parcel's purchase that he learned that Lincoln also was the seller of the land, Acosta said. After Acosta answered more than a dozen questions with ``I don't know,'' the judge said he was reminded of a television advertisement for Nike athletic shoes featuring rhythm and blues singer Bo Diddley. Sporkin said of Acosta, ``He gets into a cab, goes to a strange place and leaves owning $14 million in property. It's like that Diddley commercial. He doesn't know Diddley.'' In addition to being the subject of the federal grand jury probe in Los Angeles, Keating is the target of a $1.1 billion federal fraud and racketeering suit. Until last week, the 11 defendants in that suit also included Keating's brother, William J. Keating, a former two-term Republican congressman who is chief executive officer of the Detroit Newspaper Agency and chairman of the board of directors of The Associated Press. On Friday, federal attorneys dismissed charges against William Keating, who had been accused of negligence and breach of fiduciary duty.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Express, Others Get Defense Department Contract
DOC.TEXT: Federal Express Corp. is among five companies sharing a U.S. Defense Department contract valued at more than $700 million, the company announced Tuesday. Federal Express, which has its headquarters in Memphis, estimated its potential share of the $724 million contract at about 68 percent, spokesman Armand Schneider said. The contract extends through September 1992 and calls for Federal Express, Pan American World Airways, Northwest Airlines, United Parcel Service and Tower Air to provide airlift services for the U.S. Air Force, Schneider said. Congress has approved funding for the first nine months of the contract. Funding for the balance must be approved in subsequent appropriations, Schneider said.

DOC.HEAD: Group of Campbell Investors Announce Support for Independence
DOC.TEXT: Several members of the family that founded Campbell Soup Co. announced Tuesday they will maintain control of their 2.5 percent stake in the company and will support efforts to keep the food-products company independent. The group is headed by George Strawbridge Jr., a member of the company's board of directors and a grandson of John T. Dorrance Sr., the chemist who invented condensed soup. The Strawbridge group controls about 3 million of Campbell's 129.6 million outstanding common shares. ``I believe that shareholders will realize the greatest value for their stock by the Campbell Soup Co. remaining independent at this time,'' Strawbridge said in a statement. ``My shares are not for sale.'' The announcement by Strawbridge comes in the wake of growing dissent among other members of Campbell's founding family, who in total control about 59 percent of the company's outstanding common shares. Three family members announced last week they would sell their 17 percent stake and urge a sale of the entire company.

DOC.HEAD: Transportation Company's Earnings Climb 2{ Percent
DOC.TEXT: CSX Corp. said Tuesday that cuts in railroad expenses helped boost its fourth-quarter earnings by 2{ percent. Earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31 were $125 million, or $1.25 a share, up from $122 million, or $1.01 a share, for the same quarter last year. Revenue totaled $2.034 billion, down slightly from $2.048 billion in 1988's fourth quarter. Earnings for all of 1989 more tripled, from $147 million, or 93 cents a share, in 1988 to $452 million, or $4.34 a share. However, a work force reduction program in 1988 resulted in a pre-tax special charge that reduced earnings that year by $492 million. Revenue for 1989 totaled $7.75 billion, down from $7.59 billion in 1988. John W. Snow, president of the Richmond-based transportation company, said the fourth-quarter results show that ``efforts to reduce operating expenses on the railroad are clearly taking effect and helped overcome challenges presented by service suspensions due to severe December weather, lower traffic volumes and substantially higher fuel costs.'' Fourth-quarter rail revenue declined by $56 million, or 4 percent, largely because of a 22 percent drop in new automobile shipments, the company reported. CSX blamed the harsh weather for a decrease in coal traffic from 46.4 million tons a year ago to 43.9 million tons for the fourth quarter of 1989. Coal traffic for the year was 175.3 million tons, an increase of 1 million tons over 1988. ``Given the low stockpiles, the apparent resolution of the Pittston strike and heavy demands on utilities due to severe winter weather, we expect strong coal loadings in the first quarter of 1990,'' Snow said. The CSX report was issued a day after federal mediators and officials of the United Mine Workers union and the Pittston Co. announced a tentative settlement of a 9-month-old strike that had idled 1,700 miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky.

DOC.HEAD: Leaking Barge Spills 10,000 Gallons of Fuel into River
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 8th graf, `A water ...' to UPDATE with trace of spill detected in Ohio. ADDS 3 grafs with heating oil spill in New Jersey. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Officials predicted little environmental damage after 10,000 gallons of gasoline leaked into the Monongahela River from a runaway barge, and a second loose barge was recovered Tuesday with its cargo intact. The two vessels were among at least 55 barges that were ripped from their moorings along a 58-mile stretch of river on New Year's Day by chunks of ice rushing through the rain- and snow-swollen waters. Thirty sank, some of which were empty and the others loaded with coal. ``We were very fortunate'' more barges weren't loaded with fuel, said Senior Chief Ronald Bogdan of the Coast Guard's marine safety office in Pittsburgh. ``We believe there will be minimal environmental damage,'' said Chuck Duritsa, regional director of the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources. Unlike two years ago when 750,000 gallons of diesel oil gushed from a ruptured Ashland Oil Inc. tank into the Monongahela, the gasoline that leaked Monday was lighter and more volatile, and thus able to evaporate more easily, Duritsa said. The Jan. 2, 1988, spill fouled drinking water for residents in three states and killed about 11,000 fish and 2,000 waterfowl. Monday's spill did not affect drinking water, said Betsy Mallison, a spokeswoman for the environmental resources agency. A water plant at East Liverpool, Ohio, about 50 miles down the Ohio River from Pittsburgh, detected a trace of the gasoline Tuesday, but it did not represent a health threat and could be removed by the plant's carbon filtering system, said Jeanne Ison, spokeswoman for the Ohio River Valley Water Sanitation Commission. The Coast Guard and state agencies prepared to round up the loose barges, including seven jammed against the Maxwell Dam, 61 miles upstream from Pittsburgh. A 20-mile stretch of the river remained closed to traffic because of the sunken barges. The Army Corps of Engineers planned to begin searching for those barges with sonar later this week. ``Our biggest concern was getting these petroleum barges out, which was taken care of,'' Bogdan said. The two oil product barges and an empty barge were knocked from their moorings early Monday at Speers, about 30 miles south of Pittsburgh. One barge containing 420,000 gallons of gasoline and diesel fuel was pried Tuesday from a lock and dam at Charleroi, about two miles downstream, and pulled to shore for inspection. The other two barges went over the lock and dam at Charleroi. The loaded barge, which was carrying 336,000 gallons of unleaded gasoline, hit a bridge before coming to rest at New Eagle, about 14 miles further downstream. The barge likely ruptured when it went over the dam, but it was not known when the gasoline started leaking, Bogdan said. Police and fire officials in river communities were notified of the spill. ``We don't want anybody throwing matches in there and lighting the thing up. That's all we needed was a 20-mile flame,'' Bogdan said. The leaking barge was contained Monday morning. Cleanup crews pumped the remaining 326,000 gallons of gasoline into an Ashland Oil barge late Monday and early Tuesday. The salvaged fuel was taken to Ashland's Floreffe terminal, 27 miles upstream from Pittsburgh, the site of the 1988 spill. Thirty-seven barges broke loose Monday from moorings in Brownsville, near the Maxwell Dam. Another 15 barges owned by LTV Steel Co. broke loose on the Monongahela three miles upstream from Pittsburgh early Monday and floated as far as six miles down the Ohio River. Three became stuck beneath the Smithfield Street Bridge in downtown Pittsburgh, forcing officials to close the span temporarily. Those barges were removed Tuesday. In New Jersey, a ruptured underwater pipeline spilled 5,000 gallons of heating oil into the Arthur Kill, causing an 11-mile slick on the heavily traveled channel separating New Jersey and the New York City borough of Staten Island. Cleanup of the spill, ranked as small by the Coast Guard, was expected to take about one week, said Petty Officer Jeff Crawley at the Guard station at Governor's Island, N.Y. Much of the fuel is expected to evaporate. The 12-inch pipe connects Exxon's Bayway Refinery and Chemical Plant in Linden and its refinery in Bayonne. The joint facility is Exxon's largest refinery on the East Coast.
